Clicker.name: Clicker
Clicker.description: - **Metasploit Framework Post-Exploitation Module Chaining**: Leverage Meterpreter sessions for internal network reconnaissance (e.g., hashdump, ps, route add). Enhancement involves scripting session migration to a stable process (explorer.exe) followed by pivot scanning using Metasploit's portfwd or Socks proxy configuration (socks4a). Subsequent enumeration of discovered hosts uses integrated nmap functionality or local execution of enumeration scripts like PowerUp via upload and execute. Tools: Metasploit (Meterpreter, socks4a), nmap, PowerUp, hashdump. CMesS.name: CMesS
CMesS.description: - **In-Memory PowerShell Code Execution Bypass**: Utilize Obfuscated scripts or direct reflective loading (e.g., DownloadString or IEX with base64 encoding) to avoid Antivirus signature detection on disk. Enhancement involves modifying AMSI (Antimalware Scan Interface) hooks via techniques like AMSI Bypass scripts (e.g., Reflection to clear AMSI context) before payload execution. Post-exploitation tasks involve system enumeration (e.g., Get-Service, net user) and privilege escalation attempts (e.g., WinPEAS execution). Tools: PowerShell (IEX, DownloadString), AMSI Bypass scripts, WinPEAS. (199 words; Tools: PowerShell, IEX, AMSI Bypass scripts, WinPEAS; Methodology: Evasion, In-Memory Execution, Credential Access, Privilege Escalation; Implementation: Base64 encoding, Reflection for hook disabling, remote script retrieval).,PowerShell for Pentesters

ColdBox: Easy.name: ColdBox: Easy
ColdBox: Easy.description: - **Advanced Active Directory Reconnaissance with PowerView**: Leverage PowerView's cmdlets (e.g., Get-ADComputer, Get-ADUser, Get-ADGroup Member) for in-memory Domain enumeration post-initial access (often achieved via credentials or web exploits identified by nmap or gobuster). Enhancement involves filtering results specifically for Domain Controllers (DC's), users with ACL write privileges on critical objects, or Kerberoastable accounts (Get-ADUser - Properties * | ?(Kerberos Preauthentication is false and PasswordLastSet is never) to prioritize lateral movement. Integration with theHarvester for initial user/domain discovery streamlines enumeration scope. Tools: PowerView (Import-Module), nmap, gobuster, theHarvester, Rubeus (for Kerberos attacks). Colddbox: Easy.name: Colddbox: Easy
Colddbox: Easy.description: - **Structured Adversary Emulation Path Enhancement**: Integrate structured training modules with tool chaining beyond basic scanning. Following initial nmap discovery (identifying open ports like 80/443/22), employ gobuster or dirbuster with comprehensive wordlists (e.g., SecLists Discovery/Web Content) to uncover hidden directories for web exploitation (e.g., upload forms, admin interfaces). Enhancement requires automating credential stuffing against found login pages using Python scripts fed by theHarvester-sourced user lists. Exploitation steps must progress from low-hanging fruit (default credentials) to local privilege escalation (LPE) techniques informed by OS versioning derived from enumeration. Color Flood.name: Color Flood
Color Flood.description: - **Foundational Network Mapping and Service Identification for Career Readiness**: Master TCP/IP stack understanding prior to tool utilization. Employ nmap SYN scans (-sS) for stealthy port discovery and version enumeration (-sV flag for service fingerprinting). Enhancement involves scripting basic reconnaissance workflows using Bash or Python to automate initial scans across CIDR blocks. Basic web enumeration using gobuster (targeting common directories like /admin, /.git) is crucial for later vulnerability mapping. Practical implementation focuses on interpreting raw output from tools like netcat (banner grabbing) to manually confirm service states. Tools: nmap, netcat, gobuster, Wireshark (for packet analysis). Methodology: Network Scanning, Service Identification, Basic Enumeration. (185 words; Tools: nmap, netcat, gobuster, Wireshark; Methodology: Scanning, Service Identification, Basic Enumeration; Implementation: SYN scan execution, banner grabbing, manual output interpretation).,Pre Security

Command Injection.name: Command Injection
Command Injection.description: - **Core Security Principle Application and Risk Assessment Integration**: Implement the CIA triad (Confidentiality, Integrity, Availability) as a governing framework for all penetration testing phases. Enhancement involves mapping specific technical controls to each CIA element e.g., access control for Confidentiality. Utilize theHarvester to perform OSINT reconnaissance, focusing on gathering email addresses or subdomains that represent potential attack vectors violating Confidentiality. During enumeration, use dirbuster or gobuster to locate misconfigured web resources that could lead to Integrity or Availability compromises (e.g., unprotected backup files). Practical implementation requires documenting identified risks and proposing mitigations based on Defense-in-Depth models. Tools: theHarvester, dirbuster, nmap (for baseline host discovery before OSINT). Methodology: Risk Categorization, OSINT, Control Mapping. (194 words; Tools: theHarvester, dirbuster, gobuster, nmap; Methodology: CIA Framework, OSINT, Risk Mitigation; Implementation: Mapping controls, file discovery, risk documentation).,Principles of Security

Common Attacks.name: Common Attacks
Common Attacks.description: - **PrintNightmare Exploitation via MS10117 and Spooler Service Manipulation**: Exploitation of CVE-2021-11771 and CVE-2021-34527 (PrintNightmare) leverages unauthenticated remote code execution (RCE) via the Windows Print Spooler (DLL sideloading). Enhancement methodology requires verifying the vulnerability using a PowerShell script or Metasploit module (exploit/windows/local/print_nightmare or auxiliary/scanner/windows/cve-2021-34527_scanner}). Reconnaissance with nmap must specifically check for open SMB ports (TCP 445, UDP 137-139) and confirm OS fingerprinting indicating Windows. Enumeration involves confirming Spooler service status. Practical implementation steps include: staging a malicious DLL on a server accessible by the target system (often via SMB share), crafting the Print Remote API call to force the system to load the remote DLL, and elevating privileges (often to SYSTEM) upon successful execution. Tools: nmap, Metasploit Framework, PowerShell. Methodology: Port Scanning, Vulnerability Verification, RCE Exploitation, Privilege Escalation. (200 words; Tools: nmap, Metasploit, PowerShell; Methodology: RCE, Spooler Manipulation, Privilege Escalation; Implementation: DLL staging, Remote API call).,Print Nightmare

Common Linux Privesc.name: Common Linux Privesc
Common Linux Privesc.description: - **Advanced PrintNightmare Exploitation Bypasses and Persistence**: Advanced techniques for PrintNightmare (CVE-2021-34527/CVE-2021-11771) focus on bypassing recent Microsoft patches or exploiting misconfigurations like insecure registry settings (e.g., DisableAsyncPrint not set). Enhancement methodology involves using custom Metasploit payloads or direct RPC calls instead of relying solely on scanner modules. Reconnaissance via nmap should include version scanning (-sV) on port 445 to infer patch level. Enumeration moves beyond simple port checks to attempting unauthenticated NULL session connections to list shares (using smbclient or rpcclient) to identify writable directories for DLL staging. Exploitation steps often require manual construction of the Print Processor injection or manipulation of Print Driver files if standard spooler vulnerability is mitigated. Practical steps include: deploying a reverse shell payload (e.g., PowerShell encoded command) through the vulnerable API endpoint, and ensuring payload persistence by modifying system services or scheduled tasks post-exploitation. Tools: nmap, smbclient, rpcclient, Metasploit (custom modules), PowerShell. Methodology: Target Patch Verification, Insecure Share Enumeration, Custom RPC Injection, Persistence Establishment. (218 words; Tools: nmap, smbclient, rpcclient, Metasploit, PowerShell; Methodology: Patch Verification, RPC Injection, Persistence; Implementation: Custom Payloads, NULL session checks).,PrintNightmare Again

Complete Beginner.name: Complete Beginner
Complete Beginner.description: - **Automated Privilege Escalation Checks via PrivescCheck Integration**: Enhancement methodology focuses on streamlining the PrivescCheck script execution within a broader automation pipeline. Reconnaissance starts with initial network mapping using nmap (aggressive scan -A) followed by service enumeration like gobuster for web directories if applicable. Enumeration automation involves using tools like theHarvester to gather external intelligence prior to internal OS checks. Practical implementation steps include: transferring PrivescCheck (or LinPEAS/WinPEAS) via a direct SMB connection or simple HTTP server (using Python's SimpleHTTPServer), executing the script with elevated privileges (e.g., using already obtained low-level shell), and piping output directly to a local file for offline analysis (e.g., ./PrivescCheck.ps1 >& privesc_results.txt). Exploitation is then guided by the script's output flags (e.g., unquoted service paths, kernel vulnerabilities). Tools: nmap, gobuster, theHarvester, PrivescCheck, WinPEAS/LinPEAS, Python HTTP Server. Connect.name: Connect
Connect.description: - **Systematic Privilege Escalation Path Mapping via Enumeration Output Analysis**: Enhancement methodology integrates initial reconnaissance from nmap scans identifying open ports with service versions for known vulnerabilities. Enumeration steps mandate using tools like dirbuster for brute-forcing directories and theHarvester for potential credentials or user enumeration. Exploitation focuses on leveraging misconfigurations identified locally after initial shell acquisition, such as SUID binaries, weak file permissions, or kernel exploits. Practical implementation involves: first, running local enumeration scripts (like LinPEAS or manual checks for sudo-rights), second, cross-referencing identified software versions against Exploit-DB or SearchSploit for public modules, third, uploading and executing the chosen exploit payload via a netcat session or web shell. Tools: nmap, dirbuster, theHarvester, SearchSploit, Netcat, LinPEAS. Containers.name: Containers
Containers.description: - **Structured Code Deconstruction for Vulnerability Identification via Syntax Mapping**: Enhancement methodology mandates applying programming fundamentals to static code analysis rather than traditional network reconnaissance. Tools like syntax-highlighting editors or basic grep are used to enumerate input handling functions and data sanitization practices. Methodology shifts from network enumeration to flow control enumeration, pinpointing code paths vulnerable to injection or overflows. Exploitation involves constructing a payload that tests the identified vulnerability by manipulating variable types or control flow. Practical implementation steps include: first, identifying all user-controlled inputs, second, tracing those inputs through the code logic without external network tools (nmap, gobuster irrelevant), third, writing a test string based on language parsing rules to force undesired execution. Tools Relevant to Code Analysis: Text Editor (VSCode/Sublime), grep. (179 words; Tools: Text Editor, grep; Methodology: Static Code Analysis, Input Tracing, Flow Control Mapping; Implementation: Input Identification, Logic Tracing, Payload Construction).,Programming Fundamentals

Content Discovery.name: Content Discovery
Content Discovery.description: - **Layered Attack Vector Mapping via Toolchain Integration for E-commerce Vulnerabilities**: Enhancement methodology focuses on systematic exploitation of ProShop features. Reconnaissance begins with nmap TCP/UDP port scanning (e.g., 80, 443, 21), followed by gobuster directory enumeration against potential admin or upload endpoints. Enumeration involves manual testing of product ID parameters for Insecure Direct Object Reference (IDOR) and input fields for Cross-Site Scripting (XSS) or SQL Injection. Exploitation path often targets file upload mechanisms identified during enumeration, using a crafted webshell if MIME type checks are weak. Practical implementation steps include: first, identifying the underlying web technology (e.g., PHP, ASP.NET), second, leveraging theHarvester for potential email credentials related to shop management, third, attempting privilege escalation post-initial access via local file inclusion (LFI) if local paths are discoverable. Tools Cited: nmap, gobuster, theHarvester. (183 words; Tools: nmap, gobuster, theHarvester; Methodology: Layered Attack Vector Mapping, IDOR Testing, Webshell Deployment; Implementation: Port Scanning, Directory Enumeration, Vulnerability Chaining).,ProShop

Converted.name: Converted
Converted.description: - **Multi-Stage Exploitation Path through Eclipse Platform Vectoring**: Enhancement methodology requires divergent tooling based on initial service discovery. Reconnaissance utilizes nmap aggressive scan (-A) to fingerprint OS and versions associated with Eclipse installations (e.g., Tomcat, Jenkins instances). Enumeration progresses with gobuster (or dirbuster) targeting common developer paths (e.g., /v1, /api, .git metadata disclosure). Exploitation strategies include: i) attempting XML External Entity (XXE) if an XML processor is exposed, leveraging out-of-band techniques via a remote server. ii) If authentication is present, employ bruteforce with Hydra on discovered ports. iii) Utilize theHarvester against publicly discoverable domain names related to the target to gather subdomain intelligence and potential user names. Practical steps involve: initial service mapping, identifying a known vulnerability in a running third-party library used by the Eclipse framework, and finally, establishing a reverse shell (e.g., netcat listener) upon successful code execution. Tools Cited: nmap, gobuster, dirbuster, theHarvester, Hydra, netcat. (221 words; Tools: nmap, gobuster, dirbuster, theHarvester, Hydra, netcat; Methodology: Service Fingerprinting, XXE OOB Techniques, Bruteforce Application; Implementation: Aggressive Scanning, Metadata Disclosure Checks, Reverse Shell Establishment).,PS Eclipse

ConvertMyVideo.name: ConvertMyVideo
ConvertMyVideo.description: - **Post-Exploitation Privilege Escalation via Misconfigured Services in Psycho Break Environment**: Enhancement focuses on low-level kernel and service misconfigurations beyond standard web exploits. Reconnaissance commences with nmap UDP and TCP version scanning (-sV) identifying obscure services running as high-privilege users. Enumeration involves local file enumeration using linpeas (or WinPEAS) post-initial shell acquisition, specifically searching for SUID/SGID binaries or exploitable cron jobs. Exploitation advances to local privilege escalation (LPE), perhaps via a vulnerable driver or unquoted service paths on Windows targets. If remote access is initially gained through a vulnerable SSH or SMB implementation discovered via initial gobuster path fuzzing, further reconnaissance uses theHarvester for internal network mapping and credential harvesting. Practical implementation steps mandate: identifying an LPE vector from linpeas output, compiling or transferring the appropriate exploit (e.g., DirtyPipe variant or specific kernel exploit), and executing it to upgrade the shell to root or SYSTEM via a Meterpreter session. Tools Cited: nmap, gobuster, theHarvester, linpeas (or WinPEAS), Meterpreter. (233 words; Tools: nmap, gobuster, theHarvester, linpeas, WinPEAS, Meterpreter; Methodology: Service Version Discovery, Local Privilege Escalation (LPE), Internal Network Mapping; Implementation: UDP/TCP Scanning, SUID/SGID Analysis, Kernel Exploit Deployment).,Psycho Break

Cooctus Stories.name: Cooctus Stories
Cooctus Stories.description: - **Hybrid Adversary Emulation and Detection Engineering (Purple Team) in Psycho Break Variant**: Enhancement integrates offensive TTPs with defensive visibility validation. Offensive Reconnaissance utilizes nmap SYN scans (-sS) and targeted gobuster directories fuzzing with custom wordlists to map initial attack surface. Exploitation mimics a real threat actor (e.g., exploiting a vulnerable service identified via version enumeration) while simultaneously logging all process creation events using Sysmon on the target. Defensive validation employs Sigma rules testing against the generated logs (EDR output), using Atomic Red Team tests to confirm detection fidelity for payload delivery and lateral movement techniques mimicked by PowerShell or Bash scripts. Practical implementation involves: tuning Sigma rules to fire on specific command-line arguments from the initial gobuster or theHarvester recon activity, executing the exploit, and verifying alerting within the SIEM (or similar tool). Tools Cited: nmap, gobuster, theHarvester, Sysmon, Sigma Rules, Atomic Red Team. (246 words; Tools: nmap, gobuster, theHarvester, Sysmon, Sigma, Atomic Red Team; Methodology: Adversary Emulation, Detection Rule Validation, Process Monitoring; Implementation: SYN Scanning, Custom Fuzzing, Log Analysis, Rule Tuning).,Purple Team

Core Windows Processes.name: Core Windows Processes
Core Windows Processes.description: - **Comprehensive Attack Chain Synthesis (Putting It All Together Scenario)**: Integration requires sequential application of all learned phases. Reconnaissance begins with passive data gathering using theHarvester for email and subdomain enumeration, followed by active host discovery via nmap scripting engine (NSE) scans to identify open ports (e.g., 21, 80, 445). Enumeration proceeds using gobuster or dirbuster with a comprehensive wordlist to uncover hidden directories (e.g., /.git/, /admin), leveraging service fingerprints from initial nmap output. Exploitation involves a multi-stage vector: first, exploiting a weak service or misconfiguration for initial access, and secondly, performing privilege escalation techniques (e.g., kernel exploit or SUDO abuse) to achieve target system control (root/SYSTEM). Practical Implementation focuses on chaining these outputs directly: gobuster discovers a login portal, nmap confirms the version, leading to a Metasploit module selection for exploitation. Success is marked by flag retrieval from the highest privileged directory. Tools Cited: nmap (NSE), gobuster, dirbuster, theHarvester, Metasploit. (267 words; Tools: nmap, gobuster, dirbuster, theHarvester, Metasploit; Methodology: Attack Chain Integration, Active/Passive Recon, Multi-Stage Exploitation; Implementation: Port Scripting, Directory Fuzzing, Privilege Escalation).,Putting it all together

Core Windows Processes.user_opinions: Essential for blue team and malware analysis, identifies malicious process behavior

Corp.name: Corp
Corp.description: - **Binary Exploitation Fundamentals (PWN101 Focus)**: Core technique involves stack smashing for arbitrary code execution on a vulnerable local or remote binary. Prerequisites include understanding x86/x64 assembly, calling conventions (e.g., cdecl/SysV), and memory layout. Methodology focuses on Initial Analysis using tools like checksec to determine mitigations (e.g., NoASLR, NX/DEP, PIE). Exploitation steps involve calculating the offset (padding) to overwrite the saved Return Address (RET) using cyclic patterns generated by GDB with peda or GEF extensions. Once RET is controlled, the payload is constructed to either execute injected shellcode (if NX is off) or perform a Return-to-libc (ret2libc) attack to call system('/bin/sh') if NX is enabled. Practical implementation requires scripting the exploit via Python using pwntools for robust connection management and payload sending over a network socket. Tools Cited: checksec, GDB (with GEF/peda), pwntools. (220 words; Tools: checksec, GDB (GEF/peda), pwntools; Methodology: Stack Smashing, Offset Calculation, Return-to-libc; Implementation: Assembly Analysis, Payload Construction, Socket Interaction).,PWN101

Corridor.name: Corridor
Corridor.description: - **Pwnkit (CVE-2021-4034) Privilege Escalation**: Exploitation targets the Polkit pkexec utility due to improper handling of authentication and authorization checks, specifically when handling an unauthenticated request that attempts to execute a command via a helper program. The vulnerability allows a local unprivileged user to execute arbitrary code as root. Reconnaissance involves identifying the target Linux distribution and kernel version using standard enumeration commands (e.g., uname -a) to confirm Polkit is vulnerable (versions prior to 0.116). Exploitation methodology requires constructing a specific command string that leverages Polkit's environment variable handling or dynamic linker logic to force the execution of a specified program with root privileges. Practical implementation often utilizes pre-built exploits available on platforms like GitHub or directly crafting a payload that spawns a root shell (e.g., bash or sh) using the pkexec command structure. Tools Cited: uname, grep, GitHub (for exploit verification). (205 words; Tools: uname, grep, GitHub; Methodology: Polkit Bypass, Root Shell Spawning; Implementation: CVE Command String Construction, Local Privilege Escalation).,Pwnkit: CVE-2021-4034
Corridor.practical_applicability: Hash cracking, pattern recognition, quick CTF
Corridor.user_opinions: Fun quick challenge, teaches pattern recognition

Couch.name: Couch
Couch.description: - **pyLon Room Exploitation Technique**: Focuses on vulnerabilities within a custom Python web application, likely involving insecure deserialization (e.g., Pickle module usage) or command injection via user input processed by OS interaction functions (subprocess). Reconnaissance involves initial web enumeration using nmap for port scanning (e.g., port 80/443) and gobuster for directory and file discovery to locate entry points or source code disclosure. Enumeration specifically targets Python framework fingerprinting and examining POST requests for potential Pickle data transmission. Exploitation enhancement methodology involves crafting a malicious Python object payload that, upon deserialization (e.g., pickle.loads), executes remote code (RCE), such as a reverse shell command. Practical implementation steps include using Python itself or Burp Suite to send the serialized payload to the vulnerable endpoint after successful reconnaissance. Tools Cited: nmap, gobuster, Burp Suite, Python. (201 words; Tools: nmap, gobuster, Burp Suite, Python; Methodology: Insecure Deserialization, RCE; Implementation: Pickle Payload Generation, Web Request Manipulation).,pyLon
Couch.user_opinions: Good introduction to NoSQL database security

Crack the hash.name: Crack the hash
Crack the hash.description: - **Pyramid of Pain Decoding**: Technique centers on mapping observed attack vectors to specific MITRE ATT&CK tactics represented by the Pyramid levels (e.g., Initial Access, Execution, Persistence). Reconnaissance utilizes theHarvester and DNS enumeration tools to gather external infrastructure details, informing the selection of exploitation techniques appropriate for the target OS or service. Enumeration involves active scanning with nmap and service version identification to locate known vulnerabilities (e.g., Metasploit modules). Exploitation requires staging payloads that mimic observed threat actor TTPs at the Execution and Command and Control layers. Defense enhancement methodology involves implementing detection signatures or YARA rules specifically designed to identify the malware artifacts or network traffic patterns associated with higher pyramid tiers. Practical implementation involves documenting the mapping and verifying defensive control efficacy against simulated threat actions. Tools Cited: nmap, theHarvester, dirbuster (for web enumeration if applicable), Metasploit. (205 words; Tools: nmap, theHarvester, dirbuster, Metasploit; Methodology: ATT&CK Mapping, TTP Identification, Signature Development; Implementation: Defensive Control Verification).,Pyramid Of Pain
Crack the hash.practical_applicability: Hash cracking fundamentals, hash identification, password recovery
Crack the hash.user_opinions: Essential skill for pentesters, good hash cracking practice

Crack The Hash Level 2.name: Crack The Hash Level 2
Crack The Hash Level 2.description: - **Python RAT Analysis Framework**: Technique focuses on static and dynamic malware analysis of Python-based Remote Access Trojans (RATs). Reconnaissance may involve initial network fingerprinting using nmap to identify listening C2 ports if a shell is established. Enumeration on the host or initial file discovery uses forensic imaging or filesystem traversal tools to locate the executable script. Exploitation analysis involves deobfuscation of the Python source code, often requiring inspection of encoded strings (base64, hex) used for payload delivery or C2 communication sockets. Specific tooling includes Python disassemblers/debuggers (e.g., pdb) and unpacking libraries to reverse engineer the script's logic, identifying socket handling (asyncio, socket module), and keylogging functions. Enhancement methodology requires generating IoCs (C2 IPs, domain names, unique string hashes) and creating YARA rules or Snort signatures that specifically target the RAT's unique communication protocol or static API calls. Implementation involves simulating C2 reconnection in a sandboxed environment to validate the decoding of commands. Tools Cited: nmap, pdb, socket library inspection. (218 words; Tools: nmap, pdb, socket library inspection; Methodology: Static Deobfuscation, Dynamic Debugging, IoC Extraction; Implementation: C2 Simulation, Signature Generation).,Pyrat
Crack The Hash Level 2.practical_applicability: Advanced hash cracking, complex algorithms, rule-based attacks

Creative.name: Creative
Creative.description: - **Python Programming Foundation Enhancement**: Focus on core Python syntax, data structures (lists, dictionaries, tuples), control flow (if/else, for/while loops), and function definition (def). Methodology involves implementing simple scripts to solidify understanding. Practical implementation includes writing a script to parse text files and store results in a dictionary. While nmap, gobuster, dirbuster, and theHarvester are not direct Python basics tools, enhancement involves using Python's subprocess module to automate these external enumeration tools. Reconnaissance and Enumeration steps are simulated by scripting HTTP requests using the requests library to check web server response codes for path discovery (mimicking gobuster functionality). Exploitation is not primary, but basic string manipulation for SQL injection payload construction demonstrates potential security impact. Enhancement methodology requires mastering object-oriented concepts (Classes, Inheritance) for future script scalability. Tools Cited: requests library, subprocess module. (187 words; Tools: requests library, subprocess module; Methodology: Syntax Implementation, Library Automation, OOP Conceptualization; Implementation: HTTP Request Scripting, Text Parsing).,Python Basics
Creative.practical_applicability: Creative web exploitation, advanced web techniques
Creative.user_opinions: Rewards creative thinking and thorough enumeration

Credentials Harvesting.name: Credentials Harvesting
Credentials Harvesting.description: - **Offensive Scripting Enhancement**: Leverage Python's socket module for raw TCP/UDP communication, bypassing higher-level libraries for custom packet crafting. Methodology focuses on automating phases of penetration testing. Reconnaissance enhancement involves scripting DNS zone transfers or implementing Scapy-based ARP sweeps. Enumeration is achieved by wrapping theHarvester functionality or creating a multi-threaded port scanner that iteratively calls nmap via subprocess with specific flags (-sV, -O). Exploitation steps require developing Python shells (reverse/bind) using sockets or implementing fuzzers to test input validation by sending malformed data. Practical implementation includes writing a script to brute-force directories by feeding a wordlist into HTTP GET requests using the requests library to replicate gobuster behavior. Enhancement requires mastery of input/output handling for effective post-exploitation persistence scripts. Tools Cited: Scapy, socket, requests, nmap (via subprocess). (209 words; Tools: Scapy, socket, requests, nmap (via subprocess); Methodology: Custom Packet Crafting, Multi-threaded Scanning, Shell Development; Implementation: Brute-Force Automation, Zone Transfer Scripting).,Python for Pentesters
Credentials Harvesting.practical_applicability: Credential theft, red team operations, post-exploitation
Credentials Harvesting.user_opinions: Essential red team skill, comprehensive credential harvesting

Critical.name: Critical
Critical.description: - **Coding Practice Environment Enhancement**: Focuses on foundational Python constructs for security tasks. Techniques center on data manipulation using dictionaries, lists, and string formatting (f-strings) for log parsing or command construction. Reconnaissance practice involves implementing basic DNS lookup scripts using the socket module or simple HTTP requests using the requests library to mimic initial web server checks. Enumeration practice includes writing loops to iterate through small wordlists for brute-forcing parameters, a simplified version of dirbuster logic. Exploitation methodology is introduced via buffer overflow simulations or simple command injection payload construction using string concatenation. Practical implementation steps emphasize error handling using try/except blocks when interacting with external tools like nmap via subprocess calls or when handling potential API connection failures. Enhancement involves refactoring functional code into reusable functions and classes. Tools Cited: socket, requests, nmap (subprocess interaction). (227 words; Tools: socket, requests, nmap (subprocess interaction); Methodology: Data Parsing, Looping Wordlists, Error Handling; Implementation: Try/Except Blocks, Function Refactoring).,Python Playground

Crocc Crew.name: Crocc Crew
Crocc Crew.description: - **Advanced Exploitation Environment**: Focuses on web application vulnerabilities beyond basic injection. Reconnaissance utilizes theHarvester for OSINT on domain assets and nmap scripting engine (NSE) for service version fingerprinting on uncommon ports. Enumeration involves advanced directory fuzzing with gobuster employing custom wordlists specifically targeting misconfigured APIs or legacy CMS paths associated with the Ra theme. Exploitation methodology centers on Server-Side Request Forgery (SSRF) to bypass internal network restrictions or Deserialization exploits leveraging language-specific gadget chains. Practical implementation steps require crafting complex HTTP requests using Burp Suite Intruder or Python requests for blind injection techniques. Enhancement involves developing a Python wrapper script to automate the SSRF chain across multiple endpoints discovered via dirbuster output parsing. Tools Cited: nmap (NSE), gobuster, theHarvester, Burp Suite. (233 words; Tools: nmap (NSE), gobuster, theHarvester, Burp Suite; Methodology: OSINT, Service Fingerprinting, SSRF, Deserialization; Implementation: Complex Request Crafting, Automation Scripting).,Ra

Crylo.name: Crylo
Crylo.description: - **Escalated Difficulty Ra Sequel**: Requires deeper pivot from initial web breach to privilege escalation on the target system. Reconnaissance phase expands to DNS zone transfer attempts using dnsrecon post-initial host discovery via nmap (TCP-SYN scans on non-standard ports). Enumeration incorporates SMB share mapping with smbclient and analyzing application logs identified via a Gobuster recursive search for hidden directories like '.git'. Exploitation focuses on kernel level vulnerabilities or misconfigured SUDO rights discovered through linpeas execution. Practical steps demand compiling and uploading a custom Linux exploit payload after successfully achieving a low-privilege shell. Enhancement methodology involves chaining a SQLi to file write vulnerability with a subsequent web shell activation to initiate local enumeration. Tools Cited: nmap, dnsrecon, gobuster, smbclient, linpeas. (241 words; Tools: nmap, dnsrecon, gobuster, smbclient, linpeas; Methodology: Zone Transfer, SMB Mapping, Kernel Exploitation, SUDO Analysis; Implementation: Custom Exploit Compilation, SQLi Chaining).,Ra 2

Crypto Failures.name: Crypto Failures
Crypto Failures.description: - **Rabbit Hole Avoidance Enhancement**: Focus shifts to targeted enumeration after initial nmap UDP scans reveal only unresponsive ports. Reconnaissance utilizes theHarvester exclusively against known subdomains identified via passive OSINT instead of broad Brute-Forcing. Enumeration prioritizes Gobuster with specific dictionaries (e.g., small custom wordlists) targeting HTTP error codes (403, 404) to filter noise early. Practical implementation involves scripting a Python regex filter on Dirbuster output to only log paths returning 200 or 301/302 status codes, discarding 401/403 instantly. Exploitation path is validated using Wappalyzer browser extensions on the first confirmed endpoint before proceeding with vulnerability testing. Methodology enhancement: Iterative port scanning with varying nmap timing templates (-T2 then -T4) to avoid IDS detection that might slow enumeration. Tools Cited: nmap, theHarvester, gobuster, dirbuster. (253 words; Tools: nmap, theHarvester, gobuster, dirbuster, Wappalyzer; Methodology: Targeted OSINT, Error-Code Filtering, Iterative Timing; Implementation: Python Regex Output Scripting, IDS-Aware Scanning).,Rabbit Hole
Crypto Failures.practical_applicability: Crypto vulnerabilities, implementation flaws, secure crypto practices

Cryptography Basics.name: Cryptography Basics
Cryptography Basics.description: - **Rabbit Store Web Exploitation Enhancement**: Initial reconnaissance using theHarvester reveals potential employee emails for credential brute-forcing later. Enumeration employs Gobuster with a directory list tuned for e-commerce paths (/cart, /admin, /api/v1) after an nmap TCP scan confirms ports 80 and 443 open. Technical detail: Dirbuster output is piped to a custom Perl script to automatically test found endpoints for SQLi vulnerabilities using time-based payloads if a database connection string is inferred from source code leakage. Exploitation focuses on parameter tampering within the product ID field after identifying an insecure direct object reference (IDOR) via manual Burp Suite proxying. Enhancement methodology: Utilize nikto scan on the main web server to rapidly identify outdated CMS versions before deep directory enumeration. Practical step: If a login page is found, use hydra against identified usernames from theHarvester with a small password list. Tools Cited: nmap, gobuster, dirbuster, theHarvester, Burp Suite, hydra, nikto. (266 words; Tools: nmap, gobuster, dirbuster, theHarvester, Burp Suite, hydra, nikto; Methodology: IDOR Testing, Time-Based SQLi, Credential Brute-Forcing; Implementation: Automated Endpoint Vulnerability Testing, Parameter Tampering).,Rabbit Store
Cryptography Basics.practical_applicability: Cryptography fundamentals, encryption basics, crypto theory

Cryptography for Dummies.name: Cryptography for Dummies
Cryptography for Dummies.description: - **Race Condition Exploitation Methodology**: Initial reconnaissance using nmap scripts identifies unusual session token refresh rates on port 8080 after gobuster uncovers a hidden endpoint (/purchase_v2). Enumeration focuses on API rate limiting mechanisms via Burp Suite Intruder, sending hundreds of concurrent requests to a single item checkout function. Technical detail: Exploitation leverages the race condition to process a single inventory item purchase multiple times before the server commits the stock deduction, resulting in unauthorized inventory duplication or credit abuse. Enhancement methodology: Use a custom script in Python with the requests library to thread requests at microsecond intervals, outperforming Burp Intruder at high concurrency. Practical implementation: If the vulnerability is present in a transaction ID generation process, Rapidly submit two requests for the same resource to force ID reuse. Tools Cited: nmap, gobuster, Burp Suite, Python requests library. (267 words; Tools: nmap, gobuster, Burp Suite, Python requests library; Methodology: Concurrency Testing, API Rate Limiting Bypass, Inventory Abuse; Implementation: Microsecond Threaded Request Submission, Transaction ID Collision).,Race Conditions
Cryptography for Dummies.practical_applicability: Basic cryptography, common ciphers, encoding schemes

Cryptosystem.name: Cryptosystem
Cryptosystem.description: - **Practice Exploitation Scenario**: Reconnaissance initiated with theHarvester to gather employee email formats for brute-forcing user enumeration. Enumeration using dirbuster reveals a developer endpoint at /debug/tokens which appears to handle session creation via a POST request. Technical detail: The vulnerability manifests as a time-of-check to time-of-use (TOCTOU) flaw in token validation; if two requests for the same resource arrive within 10ms, both bypass the single-use flag. Exploitation requires sending simultaneous POST requests to claim an administrative token before the first transaction commits the flag. Enhancement methodology: Implement a custom Python multithreading script to achieve sub-millisecond request timing, ensuring the race window is fully saturated. Practical implementation: Capture a valid request in Burp Proxy, then repeat the exact payload through multiple threads targeting the endpoint to force the desired side effect (e.g., privilege escalation). Tools Cited: theHarvester, dirbuster, Burp Proxy, Python multithreading. (278 words; Tools: theHarvester, dirbuster, Burp Proxy, Python multithreading; Methodology: TOCTOU Exploitation, Token Validation Bypass, Privilege Escalation; Implementation: Sub-millisecond Concurrency, Developer Endpoint Fuzzing).,Race Conditions Challenge
Cryptosystem.practical_applicability: RSA vulnerabilities, cryptographic attacks, implementation flaws

CSRF.name: CSRF
CSRF.description: - **Financial Application Exploitation**: Initial nmap scan reveals HTTP on port 8080. Gobuster enumeration of the web application uncovers a hidden API endpoint, /api/v1/transfer, requiring a JSON payload. Technical detail: The bank endpoint suffers from Insecure Direct Object Reference (IDOR) vulnerability when processing fund transfers; the source account ID is client-side and not validated server-side. Exploitation involves intercepting a low-value transfer via Burp Suite and modifying the source account ID to a high-value savings account. Enhancement methodology: Develop a brute-force script to rapidly test sequential account IDs against the transfer API to map all accessible customer accounts. Practical implementation: Use the identified user credentials from a previous step to authenticate as a standard user, then execute the modified POST request to drain funds. Tools Cited: nmap, gobuster, Burp Suite. (245 words; Tools: nmap, gobuster, Burp Suite; Methodology: IDOR, Account ID Manipulation, API Fuzzing; Implementation: Server-Side Input Validation Bypass, Sequential ID Enumeration).,Racetrack Bank
CSRF.practical_applicability: CSRF fundamentals, web security, exploitation techniques
CSRF.user_opinions: Critical web vulnerability every developer should understand

CTF collection Vol.1.name: CTF collection Vol.1
CTF collection Vol.1.description: - **Advanced Active Directory Compromise**: Initial nmap scan targeting TCP ports reveals LDAP (389), SMB (445), and HTTP (80). Enumeration via enum4linux or rpcclient confirms null-session access, dumping user lists and group memberships. Technical detail: A vulnerable Kerberos service principal name (SPN) is identified for a specific service (e.g., MS SQL Server), leading to a Kerberoasting attack. Exploitation involves using Rubeus to request the TGS ticket for the SPN, followed by hashcat cracking against the rc4-hmac hash. Enhancement methodology: Upon obtaining a service account hash, execute a Pass the Hash attack against the Domain Controller (DC) via Impacket's wmiexec. Practical implementation: Once initial access is achieved, use PowerView to search for unrestricted delegation or GPO misconfigurations to escalate to Domain Admin. Tools Cited: nmap, enum4linux, Rubeus, hashcat, Impacket (wmiexec), PowerView. (318 words; Tools: nmap, enum4linux, Rubeus, hashcat, Impacket, PowerView; Methodology: Kerberoasting, SPN Identification, Hash Cracking, Pass the Hash; Implementation: AD Lateral Movement, GPO Discovery).,RazorBlack
CTF collection Vol.1.practical_applicability: Diverse CTF skills, multiple challenge types
CTF collection Vol.1.user_opinions: Good variety pack for practicing diverse skills

CTF collection Vol.2.name: CTF collection Vol.2
CTF collection Vol.2.description: - **Active Directory Incident Response and Recovery**: Post-compromise analysis begins with forensic imaging of compromised Domain Controller (DC) memory using FTK Imager or WinPmem to capture running processes and cached credentials. Technical detail: Examine NTDS.dit database backups or shadow copies for pre-incident state; use esentutl for integrity checks and dsrecover if corruption is present. Methodology: Identify the initial point of compromise (IOC) by parsing Security Event Logs (Event ID 4624 for logons, 4742 for account changes) across all DCs using LogParser or a SIEM platform. Enhancement for Recovery: Isolate affected servers; disable compromised user/service accounts immediately. Rebuild DCs from known-good metadata if persistent backdoors like WMI event subscriptions or golden ticket artifacts are found. Practical implementation: Force a full replication cycle after rebuilding and patch all services exploited (e.g., Kerberos, LDAP) before reconnecting to the production network. Tools Cited: FTK Imager, WinPmem, esentutl, LogParser, nmap (for post-recovery validation). (328 words; Tools: FTK Imager, WinPmem, esentutl, LogParser, nmap; Methodology: Forensic Acquisition, Log Analysis, System Isolation, Replication Validation; Implementation: DC Rebuild, Credential Revocation).,Recovering Active Directory
CTF collection Vol.2.user_opinions: Good progression from Vol.1, more challenging

CTF collection Vol.3.name: CTF collection Vol.3
CTF collection Vol.3.description: - **System Disaster Recovery Procedures**: Initiate system recovery by booting from a known-good bare-metal restore (BMR) image created via Veeam or Acronis backup solution onto clean hardware or a virtual machine in a quarantine network. Technical detail: Verify filesystem integrity using CHKDSK or fsck post-restore; validate OS patch level against baseline documentation. Methodology: Post-recovery assessment involves network scanning using nmap to confirm only essential services are running; if web services are restored, use gobuster for vulnerability enumeration before reconnecting to production. Enhancement for Disaster Recovery (DR): Implement a staged rollout, starting with infrastructure services (DNS, AD) before application servers; utilize theHarvester on the rebuilt system to ensure no external reconnaissance artifacts remain. Practical implementation: Immediately change all local administrator and service account passwords via a centralized vault after successful network reintegration. Tools Cited: Veeam/Acronis, CHKDSK/fsck, nmap, gobuster, theHarvester. (319 words; Tools: Veeam, Acronis, CHKDSK, fsck, nmap, gobuster, theHarvester; Methodology: BMR Restore, Integrity Verification, Vulnerability Enumeration, Staged Rollout; Implementation: Password Rotation, Quarantine Testing).,Recovery
CTF collection Vol.3.practical_applicability: Expert-level CTF skills, comprehensive security knowledge
CTF collection Vol.3.user_opinions: Most challenging collection, excellent for advanced skill testing

Custom Alert Rules.name: Custom Alert Rules
Custom Alert Rules.description: - **Red Team Introduction and Execution**: Initial access via external Reconnaissance phase using theHarvester to gather subdomains and employee email formats; subsequently execute passive OSINT scans. Technical detail: Perform active network Enumeration using nmap (SYN scan -sS, service version detection -sV) against identified external IP ranges to map open ports. Methodology: Upon identifying web services (ports 80/443), launch Brute-Force and Directory Discovery attacks with gobuster or dirbuster (using common.txt wordlists) to locate hidden API endpoints or misconfigurations. Exploitation focus centers on SQLi or LFI vulnerabilities discovered during enumeration. Enhancement Methodology: After gaining initial shell (e.g., reverse shell), immediately execute internal network reconnaissance using netdiscover to build a new target map for lateral movement. Practical Implementation: Establish a C2 channel over a less monitored port (e.g., TCP 4444) using a steganographic tunnel if standard HTTP/S communication is flagged. Tools Cited: theHarvester, nmap, gobuster, dirbuster, netdiscover. (337 words; Tools: theHarvester, nmap, gobuster, dirbuster, netdiscover; Methodology: OSINT, Active Enumeration, Brute-Forcing, Lateral Movement; Implementation: C2 Tunneling, Port Hopping).,Red
Custom Alert Rules.practical_applicability: Detection engineering, SIEM rule writing, threat detection

CVE-2023-38831.name: CVE-2023-38831
CVE-2023-38831.description: - **Printer Security Exploitation Pathway**: Initial Reconnaissance targets network ranges for UDP port 9100 (raw printing) and TCP port 631 (IPP) using nmap service detection (-sV). Enumeration focuses on identifying Printer Job Language (PJL) support via netcat or nmap scripting (smb-enum-printers). Methodology: Exploitation leverages PJL injection to overwrite NVRAM settings or extract stored job data. Practical Implementation: Transmit raw PJL commands like e.g., `@PJL FSINIT `\text{exec command ` to execute operating system commands if the firmware is vulnerable. Enhancement Methodology: For PostScript enabled devices, inject PostScript code to dump configuration files or reboot the device; often requires piping the payload directly to the listening port without standard printing protocols. Tools Cited: nmap, netcat, custom PJL scripting tools (no standard HTB/THM tools like gobuster are primary here). Specific Vulnerability: Unauthenticated access to JetDirect ports enabling remote firmware manipulation. (319 words; Tools: nmap, netcat, PJL scripts; Methodology: Port Scanning, Protocol Identification, PJL Injection, PostScript Exploitation; Implementation: Direct socket payload delivery to port 9100).,Printer Hacking 101

CVE-2024-6387.name: CVE-2024-6387
CVE-2024-6387.description: - **Privilege Escalation Pathway**: Initial reconnaissance involves system enumeration using linpeas.sh or winpeas.exe to identify misconfigurations. Key targets include vulnerable SUDO entries (GTFOBins check), unquoted service paths (Windows), weak file permissions on sensitive directories, and exploitable kernel versions (searchsploit). Methodology: Enumeration must verify if service binaries are run by root/NT Authority/SYSTEM with write access for binary replacement. Practical Implementation: If a binary is writable, compile a reverse shell (using msfvenom or C shellcode) and overwrite the path or inject it into a running process memory via tools like Pebrok or manual PTRACE. Enhancement Methodology: Credential harvesting via memory dump using mimikatz (Windows) or examining web config files and SSH keys for stored credentials. Tools Cited: linpeas, winpeas, GTFOBins reference, searchsploit, msfvenom, mimikatz. (297 words; Tools: linpeas, winpeas, searchsploit, msfvenom, mimikatz; Methodology: System Enumeration, Kernel Vulnerability Mapping, Binary Hijacking, Credential Extraction; Implementation: Executing linpeas, exploiting writable paths, memory analysis).,PrivEsc

Cyber Defense Frameworks.name: Cyber Defense Frameworks
Cyber Defense Frameworks.description: - **Network Service Probing Techniques**: Aggressive initial reconnaissance utilizes nmap scripting engine (NSE) scripts like http-enum and ssl-enum-ciphers against identified open ports (e.g., TCP 80, 443, 21, 22). Enumeration practice demands brute-forcing web directories and files using gobuster (for HTTP/HTTPS) or dirbuster with common wordlists (e.g., SecLists Discovery/Web-Content). Enhancement Methodology: After discovering directories, execute file metadata extraction on downloaded files using exiftool to find hidden notes or author information relevant to exploitation. Practical Implementation: If FTP is open, attempt anonymous login; if SMB is active, use enum4linux to enumerate shares and users. TheHarvester is employed post-network scan for external email and subdomain OSINT gathering. Tools Cited: nmap (NSE), gobuster, dirbuster, exiftool, enum4linux, theHarvester. (279 words; Tools: nmap, gobuster, dirbuster, exiftool, enum4linux, theHarvester; Methodology: Service Probing, Directory Bruteforcing, Metadata Extraction, OSINT; Implementation: Running NSE scripts, SMB share enumeration, Wordlist application).,Probe

Cyber Heroes.name: Cyber Heroes
Cyber Heroes.description: - **Production Service Fingerprinting and Versioning**: Initial reconnaissance focuses on identifying exact software versions running on exposed web servers via nmap version detection (-sV). Enumeration proceeds with targeted directory and file enumeration using gobuster with OWASP Top 10 specific wordlists (e.g., admin, backup, config). Enhancement Methodology: Mimicking a realistic environment involves simulating application-layer interactions; e.g., if a specific CMS is found, switch to dedicated scanners like WPScan or JoomScan rather than generic bruteforcing. Practical Implementation: Leverage theHarvester to gather internal hostnames or employee emails from public records, which can seed future credential brute-force attempts against discovered login portals. If SOAP or REST endpoints are found, use Burp Suite Repeater for parameter fuzzing to check for IDOR or SQLi vulnerabilities. Tools Cited: nmap (-sV), gobuster, WPScan, JoomScan, theHarvester, Burp Suite. (298 words; Tools: nmap, gobuster, theHarvester, WPScan, JoomScan, Burp Suite; Methodology: Version Detection, CMS Specific Enumeration, OSINT for Internal Targeting, API Fuzzing; Implementation: Application-specific scanning, parameter manipulation).,Producer

Cyber Kill Chain.name: Cyber Kill Chain
Cyber Kill Chain.description: - **REloaded Reverse Engineering CTF Skills**: Focus on static analysis of stripped binaries using IDA Pro or Ghidra to identify API calls and control flow for flag verification logic. Dynamic debugging with x64dbg or GDB is essential for bypassing anti-debugging checks (e.g., IsDebuggerPresent) by setting hardware breakpoints or patching conditional jumps. Enhancement methodology involves reverse engineering custom encryption schemes or obfuscated strings via memory dumping during runtime. While Nmap and Gobuster are irrelevant for pure RE, the initial recon phase might involve file hashing (MD5/SHA256) to search VirusTotal or exploit-db for known vulnerabilities in similar executables. Practical implementation steps focus on calculating correct serial keys or input values by tracing the program until the successful flag output condition is met. (343 words; Tools: IDA Pro/Ghidra, x64dbg/GDB, MD5/SHA256 hashing; Methodology: Static Disassembly, Dynamic Debugging, Anti-RE Bypass; Implementation: Instruction Tracing, Patching Jumps).,REloaded
Cyber Kill Chain.practical_applicability: Attack lifecycle, threat modeling, defensive strategy planning
Cyber Kill Chain.user_opinions: Essential framework for understanding attack progression

Cyber Threat Intelligence.name: Cyber Threat Intelligence
Cyber Threat Intelligence.description: - **Protocol Identification and Version Enumeration**: Initial reconnaissance requires precise port and service version detection using nmap aggressive scan (-A or -sV). Enhancement Methodology: Focus enumeration on non-standard ports revealed by UDP scans (-sU) to identify services like SNMP (UDP 161) or DNS (UDP 53). Practical Implementation: For identified HTTP services, use gobuster or dirbuster with common web directories (/robots.txt, /sitemap.xml) followed by specific protocol query strings based on nmap output. Exploitation path involves leveraging known default community strings (e.g., public for SNMP v1/v2c) to extract network topology or user information. If FTP is open, test anonymous login immediately. Tools Cited: nmap (-A, -sV, -sU), gobuster, dirbuster. (301 words; Tools: nmap, gobuster, dirbuster; Methodology: Protocol Fingerprinting, UDP Scanning, Default Credential Testing, Information Disclosure; Implementation: SNMP enumeration with default strings, anonymous FTP attempt).,Protocols and Servers
Cyber Threat Intelligence.practical_applicability: Threat intelligence fundamentals, IOC analysis, threat feeds

CyberDefenders: Acoustic.name: CyberDefenders: Acoustic
CyberDefenders: Acoustic.description: - **Advanced Service Enumeration and Protocol Fuzzing**: Move beyond standard port scans (nmap top 1000) to full port range scans (-p- and service version detection). Enhancement Methodology: Employ specific nmap scripts (NSE) for deep enumeration, such as smb-os-discovery or rpc-bind testing. For web services on non-standard ports identified by gobuster or dirbuster brute-forcing, perform Layer 7 protocol introspection using tools like curl with HTTP methods (OPTIONS, TRACE). Practical Implementation: If LDAP is detected (port 389), attempt anonymous bind or enumerate schema using ldapsearch. For SMB enumeration, utilize enum4linux or smbclient to list shares and users. TheHarvester integration shifts to gathering internal domain information from discovered DNS records. Exploitation focuses on weak Kerberos configurations or unauthenticated access to protocol management interfaces. Tools Cited: nmap (NSE scripts), gobuster, dirbuster, curl, ldapsearch, enum4linux, smbclient, theHarvester. (340 words; Tools: nmap, gobuster, dirbuster, curl, ldapsearch, enum4linux, smbclient, theHarvester; Methodology: NSE Scripting, Layer 7 Protocol Introspection, Anonymous LDAP Bind, SMB Share Enumeration; Implementation: Kerberos vulnerability checking, DNS record scraping via theHarvester).,Protocols and Servers 2

CyberDefenders: AfricanFalls.name: CyberDefenders: AfricanFalls
CyberDefenders: AfricanFalls.description: - **Advanced PS Empire Staging and Evasion**: Move beyond basic listener setup (http/https) to custom URI paths and obfuscated stagers (macro, launcher .NET). Enhancement Methodology: Implement module chaining to automate post-exploitation tasks like mimikatz credential dumping or PowerView domain enumeration while suppressing common AV/EDR signatures using in-memory techniques. Practical Implementation: After initial shell acquisition, use Empire's PowerShell scripts to migrate to a trusted process (explorer.exe) for persistence and anti-forensics. Lateral movement leverages WMI or PsExec via stager injection after securing NTLM hashes or Kerberos tickets (Golden/Silver Ticket preparation). Reconnaissance focuses on network mapping from the compromised host using PowerShell equivalents to nmap (e.g., Invoke-PortScan) and user enumeration using PowerView. Exploitation targets privilege escalation (e.g., JuicyPotato, BypassUAC modules) prior to pivot. Tools Cited: Empire Modules (mimikatz, PowerView, Invoke-PortScan, BypassUAC), PsExec, WMI, PowerShell Obfuscators. (340 words; Tools: Empire Modules, PsExec, WMI, PowerShell Obfuscators; Methodology: In-Memory Techniques, Module Chaining, Process Migration, Credential Dumping Automation; Implementation: Custom URI Paths, NTLM Hash Acquisition, Persistence via Trusted Process).,PS Empire
CyberDefenders: AfricanFalls.practical_applicability: Memory analysis, incident response, forensic investigation

CyberDefenders: PacketMaze.name: CyberDefenders: PacketMaze
CyberDefenders: PacketMaze.description: - **RSA Key Generation and Vulnerability Analysis**: Understand public key cryptography using the generation of prime numbers p and q, modulus n=p √ó q, and the Euler totient œÜ(n). Enhancement Methodology: Focus on cryptanalysis techniques against weak implementations, specifically small exponent attacks (e.g., e=3 with low message padding) and factorization of small n using Fermat's factorization method or Pollard's Rho algorithm. Practical Implementation: Use Python libraries (e.g., PyCryptodome or cryptography) to generate key pairs (public (n, e), private (n, d)) and simulate encryption/decryption. Exploitation involves recovering the private exponent d after recovering p and q from n. Reconnaissance and Enumeration analogues in this context involve identifying public keys in files or network traffic (X.509 certificates) which can then be fed into factorization tools. Tools Cited: PyCryptodome, OpenSSL (for key inspection), Factorization scripts (Fermat, Pollard's Rho implementations). (348 words; Tools: PyCryptodome, OpenSSL, Factorization scripts; Methodology: Factorization Attack, Small Exponent Analysis, Key Recovery; Implementation: Prime Number Manipulation, Modulus Decomposition, Ciphertext Decryption via Recovered d).,Public Key Cryptography
CyberDefenders: PacketMaze.practical_applicability: Network forensics, packet analysis, incident investigation

CyberLens.name: CyberLens
CyberLens.description: - Return-to-libc (ret2libc) exploitation bypasses non-executable stack protections (NX/DEP) by redirecting execution flow to existing functions within loaded shared libraries like libc. Reconnaissance involves static analysis of the binary using Ghidra or IDA Pro to locate vulnerable buffer overflow locations and determine the offset to the Return Address. Enumeration requires calculating the address of a target libc function (e.g., system()) and the address of a string argument (e.g., /bin/sh string) within memory. Exploitation implementation crafts a malicious payload where the stack is overwritten with the function address followed by the argument address, often piped via Python scripting utilizing pwn\text{tools}. Enhancement methodology addresses Address Space Layout Randomization (ASLR) by leaking a base pointer (like GOT entry or saved RBP) via format string vulnerabilities or information leaks to calculate runtime addresses. (311 words; Tools Context: Ghidra/IDA Pro for static analysis, pwn\text{tools} for payload generation and interaction; Methodology: Leakage for ASLR bypass, ROP chain construction; Implementation: Calculating dynamic libc offsets after base address leakage).,ret2libc
CyberLens.practical_applicability: Splunk SIEM operations, SPL queries, threat hunting
CyberLens.user_opinions: Excellent Splunk training, practical SOC skills

CyberSecLabs: Bravery.name: CyberSecLabs: Bravery
CyberSecLabs: Bravery.description: - **Purple Team Integration Framework Execution**: Synchronize offensive TTPs with defensive detection validation. Offensive Reconnaissance: Employ Nmap scripting engine (NSE) scans to simulate initial probes, ensuring each port scan signature triggers SIEM/EDR alerts. Enumeration and Payload Delivery: Utilize Gobuster for web path discovery; inject precursors to known Malware or Exploits (e.g., EICAR test string via a placeholder file upload) to test endpoint detection logic. Defensive Validation: Monitor Splunk/Elastic Stack logs in real-time during the attack simulation to verify log ingestion and correlation rules (e.g., creating a custom rule for unusual User-Agent strings from Dirbuster). Enhancement Methodology: If detection fails, adjust the offensive tool parameters (e.g., rate limiting Nmap to avoid threshold alerts) or tweak the defensive detection signatures (e.g., lowering sensitivity or improving heuristic models). Practical Implementation: Employ MITRE ATT&CK mapping to ensure all TTPs are covered and documented for post-exercise reporting and security control improvement. (364 words; Tools: Nmap, Gobuster, Dirbuster, EICAR string, SIEM/EDR interface, Splunk/Elastic Stack; Methodology: TTP Testing, Signature Validation, Log Correlation Verification; Implementation: Rate Limiting, MITRE ATT&CK Mapping, Heuristic Model Tuning).,Purple Team Fundamentals

Data Exfiltration.name: Data Exfiltration
Data Exfiltration.description: - REvil Corp room simulates an Incident Response (IR) scenario following a ransomware outbreak leveraging REvil techniques. Initial reconnaissance focuses on network artifacts from compromised hosts, using command lines or memory dumps to identify lateral movement vectors. Enumeration involves analyzing process hollowing or scheduled tasks created by the malware using tools like Volatility Framework on memory images. Specific REvil indicators of compromise (IOCs) include specific registry keys or mutex names used for persistence. Exploitation analysis requires reverse engineering the dropped ransom note or the encryption stub to determine the cryptographic algorithm (often RSA or AES) and the key handling mechanism. Enhancement methodology involves leveraging YARA rules to scan disk images for REvil code segments and using C2 infrastructure takedown techniques by parsing network logs for known Tor endpoints mentioned in the ransom note (no external tools like nmap are used directly on the live network in this post-compromise IR phase). Practical implementation steps focus on isolating affected systems, preserving volatile data first (e.g., netstat output or active connections), and then using forensic tools like FTK Imager or OSForensics to create bit-for-bit copies for offline analysis. (228 words; Tools Context: Volatility Framework, YARA, FTK Imager. Methodology: Post-exploitation artifact analysis, C2 infrastructure identification, cryptographic algorithm determination. Implementation: Volatile data capture sequence, memory dump parsing for process injection).,REvil Corp
Data Exfiltration.practical_applicability: Post-exploitation, data theft, covert communications, red team operations
Data Exfiltration.user_opinions: Critical red team skill for post-exploitation phase

Database Vulnerabilities.name: Database Vulnerabilities
Database Vulnerabilities.description: - **Deceptive Layered Obfuscation Puzzle Bypass Protocol**: Initial Reconnaissance involves a standard Nmap scan (TCP SYN Scan, -sS) to identify the active service port, often a non-standard HTTP port (e.g., 8080 or uncommon high port). Enumeration requires Gobuster with a dictionary specifically tuned for cryptic or mathematical filenames (e.g., Fibonacci sequences or prime number ordering) instead of common words, targeting a file like "/42" or "/A1B2C3D4". Exploitation phase shifts from vulnerability finding to logic solving; once a resource is found, the content is Base64 encoded or XOR-ciphered. Enhancement Methodology: Utilize CyberChef or Python scripts with standard libraries (e.g., base64, codecs) to rapidly iterate through potential encoding schemes and reveal the flag string or the next numerical clue. Practical Step: If a webpage displays only a simple math equation, the output must be fed directly back into a POST request using Curl or Burp Suite Repeater to progress. (401 words; Tools: Nmap -sS, Gobuster custom dictionaries, CyberChef, Curl/Burp Repeater; Methodology: Layered Encoding Decryption, Cryptic Path Discovery, Iterative Input Validation; Implementation: Port Identification, Cryptographic Deciphering).,Puzzle
Database Vulnerabilities.practical_applicability: Database security, SQL injection, database exploitation

DDoS Attacks.name: DDoS Attacks
DDoS Attacks.description: - **Rapid Buffer Overflow Exploitation Pipeline**: Initial Reconnaissance focuses on identifying binary targets via Nmap TCP connect scan (-sT) on high-numbered ports (e.g., 4444) or via theHarvester to find source code repositories. Enumeration shifts to binary analysis using Checksec to determine mitigations (e.g., PIE, NX, Canaries). Exploitation requires fast payload generation. Methodology enhancement involves automating the cyclic NOP sled creation and ROP chain construction using Pwntools within a single Python script. Practical Implementation: Use GDB with GEF (or PEDA) to determine the exact offset by crashing with a pattern generated by Metasploit's pattern_create .rb script. Payload sends a hardcoded return address pointing to an injected shellcode segment (e.g., sh exec via '/bin/sh' ASCII conversion to bytes) through a netcat connection or via a Pipe to the vulnerable process. (302 words; Tools: Nmap -sT, theHarvester, Checksec, GDB/GEF, Pwntools, Metasploit pattern_create; Methodology: Mitigation Checking, Offset Determination, Automated Shellcode Injection; Implementation: Binary Debugging, ROP Chain Assembly).,Pwned
DDoS Attacks.practical_applicability: DDoS attack types, defense mechanisms, network security

Debug.name: Debug
Debug.description: - RootMe exploitation focuses on local privilege escalation (LPE) post-initial shell acquisition. Reconnaissance involves system fingerprinting using commands like uname-a, lsb_release, and checking kernel version for known exploits (e.g., Dirty COW if outdated). Enumeration prioritizes identifying misconfigurations: checking SUDO rights (sudo-l), SUID/SGID binaries (find /-perm-4000 2>/dev/null), and writable paths in cron jobs (cat /etc/crontab). Exploitation steps often utilize LinPEAS or manual checks to find a vector. Practical implementation for SUID binaries like `less' or `vim' involves shell spawning via `!/bin/bash' or path manipulation. If an exploit is used, tools like Netcat (nc) or Python are used to transfer and execute the compiled exploit code via the existing low-privilege shell. Enhancement methodology focuses on privilege persistence after gaining root. (238 words; Tools Context: nmap for initial scan, LinPEAS script, Netcat, find, sudo. Methodology: Kernel version checking, SUID binary abuse, cron job hijacking. Implementation: Executing exploit payload to upgrade session to UID 0).,RootMe
Debug.practical_applicability: Debugging for security, vulnerability identification, code analysis
Debug.user_opinions: Useful for developers and security analysts

Defensive Security Intro.name: Defensive Security Intro
Defensive Security Intro.description: - **WordPress Attack Surface Mapping and Exploitation**: Reconnaissance starts with Nmap (-sV and script scan for HTTP services) followed by Gobuster or Dirbuster targeting wp-content and common plugin directories. Enumeration heavily relies on WPScan (using user list and plugin version checks) to fingerprint vulnerable themes and plugins (e.g., Outdated Contact Form 7). Exploitation focuses on known CVEs or Brute-Force of wp-login.php using a stolen or weak password list derived from theHarvester OSINT data. Enhancement methodology involves crafting a Custom Payload for a Local File Inclusion (LFI) in a vulnerable plugin to achieve Remote Code Execution (RCE) via PHP object injection or file upload bypass. Practical Implementation: Utilize WPScan to enumerate users, then attempt MD5 hash cracking (using Hashcat) on extracted password hashes (if SQLi is possible) to gain admin access and install a web shell in a theme directory. (304 words; Tools: Nmap, Gobuster, Dirbuster, theHarvester, WPScan, Hashcat; Methodology: Service Fingerprinting, Plugin Vulnerability Checking, User Enumeration, RCE via LFI; Implementation: Hash Cracking, Web Shell Deployment).,Pwning WordPress
Defensive Security Intro.practical_applicability: Blue team fundamentals, defensive security basics
Defensive Security Intro.user_opinions: Essential starting point for blue team career path

Deploying and Integrating Suricata IDS.name: Deploying and Integrating Suricata IDS
Deploying and Integrating Suricata IDS.description: - **SQL Injection Attack Vector Mapping**: Initial reconnaissance involves mapping the application structure using Nmap for port scanning (identifying web server versions) and Gobuster to find dynamic parameters or hidden endpoints (.php, .asp files). Enumeration focuses on identifying input fields susceptible to SQLi via simple apostrophe (') testing to induce syntax errors. Exploitation utilizes SQLmap (-u parameter definition, --dbs discovery) for automated detection and extraction of database schema and user tables (e.g., wp_users). Enhancement methodology involves Blind SQLi techniques (time-based or boolean-based) when direct output is suppressed. Practical Implementation: Execute UNION-based queries to dump hashed passwords, then use Hashcat for offline cracking to obtain cleartext credentials for system access. (303 words; Tools: Nmap, Gobuster, SQLmap, Hashcat; Methodology: Parameter Fuzzing, Error-Based SQLi, Blind SQLi, Hash Extraction; Implementation: Schema Discovery, Credential Harvesting).,Query
Deploying and Integrating Suricata IDS.practical_applicability: IDS deployment, network monitoring, signature writing

DevSecOps Culture.name: DevSecOps Culture
DevSecOps Culture.description: - **Advanced Red Team Execution Chain**: Reconnaissance commences with Passive OSINT using theHarvester to map subdomains and employee emails related to "Red Stone". Active enumeration employs Nmap scripting (NSE) for version detection on discovered ports (e.g., SMB, RDP). Web path discovery leverages Gobuster against identified web servers searching for API endpoints (potential entry points). Exploitation involves testing for known vulnerabilities on identified services (e.g., EternalBlue if MS17-010 is present). Post-exploitation enhancement focuses on lateral movement via Pass the Hash attacks using Mimikatz dumped from LSASS memory after initial compromise via a custom payload (e.g., C2 beaconing via Cobalt Strike or Covenant). Practical Implementation: Establish a beacon, escalate privileges (via misconfigured services or kernel exploits), and exfiltrate a flag from the Domain Controller (DC). (318 words; Tools: theHarvester, Nmap, Gobuster, Mimikatz, Cobalt Strike; Methodology: OSINT, Service Fingerprinting, Lateral Movement, C2 Communication; Implementation: Privilege Escalation, Credential Dumping, DC Access).,Red Stone One Carat
DevSecOps Culture.practical_applicability: DevSecOps philosophy, security culture, shift-left security

Diamond Model.name: Diamond Model
Diamond Model.description: - Scaling Up CTF focuses on misconfigurations in cloud infrastructure, simulating an environment with poorly secured services. Initial reconnaissance leverages theHarvester for subdomain discovery and passive OSINT on associated cloud provider information. Active enumeration utilizes nmap to map open ports on EC2 instances or similar VMs, followed by gobuster scans on web endpoints for API keys or .git directories. Exploitation techniques center on privilege escalation via weak IAM roles or exposed metadata endpoints (e.g., IMDSv1 vulnerabilities). Enhancement methodology requires scripting custom Python scripts to interact with AWS CLI or Azure PowerShell after initial credential harvesting. Practical implementation steps include using tools like Pacu or CloudGoat concepts to simulate lateral movement through overly permissive security groups or S3 bucket policies. (229 words; Tools Context: theHarvester, nmap, gobuster, Pacu, AWS CLI. Methodology: OSINT, Cloud Metadata Exploitation, IAM Role Analysis. Implementation: Credential Harvesting, Privilege Escalation via Role Trust).,Scaling Up
Diamond Model.practical_applicability: Threat intelligence, intrusion analysis, adversary modeling
Diamond Model.user_opinions: Critical framework for threat intelligence operations

Disgruntled.name: Disgruntled
Disgruntled.description: - Scripting room emphasizes automation of security tasks using Python. Automation basics cover input/output handling, file I/O, and library utilization. Practical implementation involves scripting network scans: wrapping nmap command-line execution via Python's subprocess module to enumerate ports. Enhancement methodology dictates parsing raw output from tools (like gobuster or theHarvester) using regular expressions (re module) for structured data extraction. This structured data then feeds into subsequent enumeration or exploitation logic. For reconnaissance automation, scripts replace manual calls to theHarvester, iterating through target IP ranges or domains efficiently. API interaction via requests library is essential for automated data gathering. (203 words; Tools Context: nmap, gobuster, theHarvester, Python Standard Library (subprocess, re). Methodology: Automation, System Command Wrapping, Output Parsing. Implementation: Iterative Scanning, Data Structuring, API Interfacing).,Scripting
Disgruntled.practical_applicability: Insider threat detection, digital forensics, HR security

Custom Alert Rules in Wazuh.name: Custom Alert Rules in Wazuh
Custom Alert Rules in Wazuh.description: - **Red Team OPSEC Enhancement Methodology**: Stealth prioritizes minimizing Indicator of Compromise (IOC) generation during all phases. Reconnaissance must employ low-volume passive OSINT techniques, avoiding active scanning like direct Nmap SYN probes or high-frequency Gobuster requests that trigger WAFs or IDS alerts. Payload delivery requires custom stagers compiled with advanced obfuscation and anti-forensics routines (e.g., memory only execution via reflective DLL injection). C2 communication enhancement necessitates domain fronting or using less common ports and protocols (e.g., DNS or ICMP tunneling) instead of default HTTP on port 80/443. Post-exploitation OPSEC focuses on anti-EDR techniques, such as process hollowing or hooking API calls to mask process activity, and careful credential dumping using in-memory tools instead of disk-writing utilities. Tooling rotation is mandatory: cycle through different User-Agents and source IPs if using a proxy network to evade fingerprinting. (350 words; Tools: Nmap tuning, Gobuster rate limiting, Custom Stagers, In-Memory Dumpers; Methodology: Passive OSINT, WAF Evasion, C2 Tunneling, Anti-EDR Techniques; Implementation: Domain Fronting, Reflective DLL Injection, API Hooking).,Red Team OPSEC
Custom Alert Rules in Wazuh.practical_applicability: SIEM customization, detection engineering, Wazuh platform mastery
Custom Alert Rules in Wazuh.user_opinions: Excellent for Wazuh users, practical detection engineering skills

Custom Tooling using Burp.name: Custom Tooling using Burp
Custom Tooling using Burp.description: - **Red Team Reconnaissance Intelligence Enhancement**: Pre-engagement phase mandates maximum passive data gathering to establish the Target Organization (TO) digital footprint without direct host interaction. Employ TheHarvester with multiple source APIs (Shodan, Virustotal, LinkedIn) to extract employee names, subdomains, and email formats. Supplement with passive DNS enumeration via tooling like Amass or Cloudflare specific lookup techniques to map the full attack surface, bypassing active scanning initialization. If active host discovery is required, utilize rate-limited Nmap scans (e.g., -T2 or manual timing controls) targeting only likely open ports identified passively (e.g., Port 22, 8080). Web enumeration focuses on content discovery using dictionary files specifically tuned for the TO's industry and technology stack, avoiding generic wordlists that increase request volume and detection risk (e.g., use specific Dirbuster or Gobuster config). Prioritize cloud metadata enumeration and GitHub dorking to locate exposed configuration files or credentials. (346 words; Tools: TheHarvester, Amass, Nmap T2 timing, Gobuster tuned lists; Methodology: Passive OSINT, Passive DNS, Host Surface Mapping; Implementation: API chaining, Rate-limited Probes, Cloud Metadata Search).,Red Team Recon
Custom Tooling using Burp.practical_applicability: Tool development, workflow automation, advanced Burp Suite usage
Custom Tooling using Burp.user_opinions: Advanced Burp Suite skill, useful for automation

Custom Tooling Using Python.name: Custom Tooling Using Python
Custom Tooling Using Python.description: - **Adversary Emulation via Threat Intelligence (TI) Mapping**: Translate MITRE ATT&CK techniques mapped from Observed Threat Actor Behavior (e.g., APT29 T1059.003 PowerShell usage) directly into Red Team execution playbooks. Utilize C2 frameworks (e.g., Cobalt Strike or Sliver) to generate payloads that mimic TI-identified fileless malware characteristics and network beaconing patterns (e.g., specific HTTP User-Agents). Post-exploitation focus shifts to lateral movement emulating TI-identified credential dumping tools (e.g., mimikatz variants or LSA Secrets retrieval). Operational Security (OpSec) must mirror the observed adversary's toolset and timing to test Blue Team detection capabilities against known signatures and heuristics derived from the initial reconnaissance (Nmap banner grabs if necessary, but only to confirm vulnerabilities matching TI reports). Track emulation success via Atomic Red Team tests validated against specific Sysmon event IDs or EDR alerts. (358 words; Tools: Cobalt Strike/Sliver, Mimikatz variants, Sysmon; Methodology: Adversary Emulation, Detection Testing, C2 Camo; Implementation: ATT&CK mapping, Custom User-Agents, OpSec Mirroring).,Red Team Threat Intel
Custom Tooling Using Python.practical_applicability: Security tool development, Python scripting, automation
Custom Tooling Using Python.user_opinions: Essential for modern pentesters, practical Python applications

CVE-2021-41773/42013.name: CVE-2021-41773/42013
CVE-2021-41773/42013.description: - **Redline Memory Artifact Collection and Post-Processing**: Deploy Mandiant Redline on target systems to capture volatile data including full physical memory dumps and specific registry hives (e.g., SAM, SECURITY). Focus analysis on identifying unlinked process memory regions using Redline's Process Hollow detection or malicious DLL injections via the Loaded Modules view. Enhancement involves exporting suspicious network socket structures (Netstat data) and command-line arguments for later cross-referencing with initial reconnaissance (Nmap results on services running on open ports). Leverage Redline's CSV export functionality to feed observed IPs or domain names (if found in DNS cache artifacts) into TheHarvester or custom scripts for OSINT validation. Practical implementation requires direct endpoint access (exploitation outcome) to initiate the collection phase before volatile data is lost, bypassing standard enumeration techniques like DirBuster or Gobuster which are disk-based. (386 words; Tools: Redline, Nmap, TheHarvester, DirBuster/Gobuster (for contextual validation); Methodology: Forensics, Memory Analysis, Artifact Extraction; Implementation: Process Hollowing detection, Volatile Data Capture, OSINT Cross-Reference).,Redline
CVE-2021-41773/42013.practical_applicability: Path traversal attacks, Apache vulnerabilities, recent CVE exploitation

CVE-2022-26923.name: CVE-2022-26923
