Intro PoC Scripting.description: - Ghost Town enumeration commences with UDP and TCP port sweeps (nmap -sU and -sV) to map forgotten services; dirbuster is employed against SMB shares (via smbclient) to uncover misconfigured or abandoned credentials for lateral movement into the core system. (Tools: nmap, smbclient, dirbuster, Metasploit Framework auxiliary modules). Methodologies: Service Discovery, Credential Harvesting, Network Mapping.,TryHack3M: Ghost Town
Intro PoC Scripting.practical_applicability: Exploit development basics, scripting for security

Intro to C2.name: Intro to C2
Intro to C2.description: - IDE security enumeration targets exposed source code repositories and runtime environments; theHarvester scans public records for developer emails or leaked API keys linked to the development server endpoints. Exploitation focuses on insecure deserialization via web hooks or command injection in build scripts (Jenkins/GitLab CI). (Tools: theHarvester, Burp Suite Intruder, SQLMap, custom Python scripts). Methodologies: OSINT, Injection Testing, Supply Chain Assessment.,TryHack3M: IDE
Intro to C2.practical_applicability: C2 concepts, red team operations, malware communications

Intro to Cloud Security.name: Intro to Cloud Security
Intro to Cloud Security.description: - Kibana enumeration involves identifying exposed indices and visualization endpoints via directory bruteforcing (gobuster/dirbuster) on the underlying web server hosting the interface. Exploitation leverages log injection or improper access controls (ACLs) to extract sensitive SIEM data, such as Elasticsearch queries or user session tokens. (Tools: nmap service detection, Kibana Dev Tools, OWASP ZAP). Methodologies: Network Scanning, API Fuzzing, Query Language Manipulation.,TryHack3M: Kibana
Intro to Cloud Security.practical_applicability: Cloud security fundamentals, shared responsibility, cloud threats
Intro to Cloud Security.user_opinions: Essential foundation for cloud security career

Intro to Cold System Forensics.name: Intro to Cold System Forensics
Intro to Cold System Forensics.description: - Literary theme hides command injection vectors within file parsing routines, mimicking textual data handling. Initial reconnaissance (theHarvester for domain discovery) precedes web enumeration (gobuster on common paths like "/manuscripts" or "/index"). Exploitation involves injecting OS commands via user input fields that process input as a book title or author name, often requiring shell character encoding bypasses. (Tools: curl, Burp Suite Intruder).,TryHack3M: Literary Hacking
Intro to Cold System Forensics.practical_applicability: Disk forensics, cold analysis, evidence preservation

Intro to Containerisation.name: Intro to Containerisation
Intro to Containerisation.description: - Network forensics requires PCAP analysis to reconstruct attacker lateral movement following initial network intrusions detected via NetFlow anomalies. Methodology prioritizes TCP stream reassembly (Wireshark IO filters) to extract HTTP POST payloads or SSH session credentials, bypassing conventional host-based scanning (nmap is for baseline comparison). Enhancement involves using tshark for bulk export of DNS queries to identify C2 domains, followed by file signature matching on extracted transferred objects.,TryHack3M: Network Forensics
Intro to Containerisation.practical_applicability: Container fundamentals, Docker basics, modern deployment

Intro to Cross-site Scripting.name: Intro to Cross-site Scripting
Intro to Cross-site Scripting.description: - Schema enumeration involves SQLmap for blind time-based injection after initial web application parameter fuzzing (enhanced via a modified gobuster dictionary to target hidden .config files). Exploitation shifts to dumping database schema information (TABLES, COLUMNS) using UNION SELECT statements if error-based techniques fail, culminating in credential extraction or remote code execution via MySQL INTO OUTFILE.,TryHack3M: Sch3Ma D3Mon
Intro to Cross-site Scripting.practical_applicability: XSS fundamentals, web security, client-side attacks
Intro to Cross-site Scripting.user_opinions: Critical web vulnerability every developer must understand

Intro to Cyber Threat Intel.name: Intro to Cyber Threat Intel
Intro to Cyber Threat Intel.description: - Reconnaissance utilizes nmap SYN scans (-sS) followed by gobuster with a custom wordlist targeting common subscription endpoints (/api/v1/user, /billing), leading to discovery of an insecure POST request endpoint for trial activation. Exploitation involves parameter tampering to bypass payment validation checks via Burp Suite Intruder to gain full access.,TryHack3M: Subscribe
Intro to Cyber Threat Intel.practical_applicability: Threat intelligence basics, IOCs, threat feeds
Intro to Cyber Threat Intel.user_opinions: Essential for SOC and threat analysis roles

Intro to Defensive Security.name: Intro to Defensive Security
Intro to Defensive Security.description: - Initial reconnaissance with nmap reveals a non-standard port running a web service; gobuster enumeration uncovers a hidden directory containing a Base64 encoded public key and a challenge prompt. Cryptanalysis involves using OpenSSL to verify the key type and subsequently employing a chosen-ciphertext attack against a vulnerable AES-CBC implementation to decrypt the flag.,TryHack3M: TriCipher Summit
Intro to Defensive Security.practical_applicability: Defensive security basics, blue team mindset, SOC operations
Intro to Defensive Security.user_opinions: Essential starting point for defensive security careers

Intro to Detection Engineering.name: Intro to Detection Engineering
Intro to Detection Engineering.description: - Initial service discovery via nmap identifies an open port running an unpatched custom TCP service; reverse engineering the target binary with Ghidra reveals an unsafe use of `gets`, confirming a stack-based buffer overflow vulnerability for shellcode injection. Exploitation requires crafting a malicious payload using Python and pwntools to overwrite the Return Address with a controlled EIP pointing to NOP sled and the injected shellcode for remote code execution.,TryPwnMe One
Intro to Detection Engineering.practical_applicability: Detection development, alert creation, SIEM basics

Intro to Digital Forensics.name: Intro to Digital Forensics
Intro to Digital Forensics.description: - Target analysis via static analysis of the service binary shows NX bit enabled, necessitating Return-Oriented Programming (ROP); ROPgadget scans libraries for useful gadgets like pop rdi followed by ret to construct a chain bypassing the non-executable stack to call `system("/bin/sh")`.,TryPwnMe Two
Intro to Digital Forensics.practical_applicability: Forensics basics, investigation methodology, evidence handling
Intro to Digital Forensics.user_opinions: Excellent comprehensive introduction to digital forensics

h4cked.name: h4cked
h4cked.description: - TShark captures live traffic (-i interface) or parses pcap files; filtering essential for protocol analysis (e.g., tcp.port==22 or http.request); extract credentials or sensitive data using display filters following initial network enumeration.,TShark
h4cked.practical_applicability: Network forensics, packet analysis, incident investigation

Hammer.name: Hammer
Hammer.description: - TShark teamwork analysis involves concurrently processing multiple packet captures (PCAPs), correlating timing stamps across different sources to map reconnaissance (nmap scans) to subsequent enumeration (gobuster HTTP requests) and potential exploitation vectors by scripting combined statistics extraction.,TShark Challenge I: Teamwork

Haskhell.name: Haskhell
Haskhell.description: - Advanced TShark directory analysis focuses on filtering HTTP POST requests captured during brute-forcing (dirbuster logs) to isolate session cookies or base64 encoded payloads passed to vulnerable endpoints identified via initial nmap service version detection.,TShark Challenge II: Directory

Heartbleed.name: Heartbleed
Heartbleed.description: - Mastering TShark CLI involves complex display filters (e.g., tcp.port == 80 and http.request.method == "POST") to extract POST data stream parameters potentially containing credentials brute-forced via gobuster or dirbuster during initial enumeration phases.,TShark: CLI Wireshark Features
Heartbleed.practical_applicability: Critical CVE, OpenSSL security, memory disclosure

Hello World.name: Hello World
Hello World.description: - TShark basic capture (tshark -i eth0 -w capture.pcapng) supplements initial nmap SYN scans by inspecting subsequent TCP handshakes and protocol responses revealing service versions missed or obfuscated during passive reconnaissance.,TShark: The Basics

Hex.name: Hex
Hex.description: - Platform navigation via CLI integration enables pipelining nmap scan results directly into a Task Submission mechanism, accelerating enumeration feedback cycles beyond web interface copy-paste.,Tutorial

HiddenInPlainSight.name: HiddenInPlainSight
HiddenInPlainSight.description: - Utilizing theHarvester with specific Shonen Jump domain variants during reconnaissance reveals potential hidden subdomains mirroring UA High Departmental servers; subsequent gobuster attacks against found ports target specific directory structures named after Quirks.,U.A. High School

Hill Cipher.name: Hill Cipher
Hill Cipher.description: - Aggressive nmap SYN scans with custom version detection scripting map UltraTech's internal network topology; dirbuster brute-forcing on port 8080 uncovers a hidden API endpoint requiring a SQL injection exploit via Burp Suite Intruder to escalate privileges.,UltraTech

Homeles.name: Homeles
Homeles.description: - Targeted nmap service version detection on exposed Docker API ports reveals an outdated daemon; gobuster enumerates the web interface for vulnerable environment variables leading to a host-based container escape using a known CVE.,Umbrella

Hopper's Roppers Badge.name: Hopper's Roppers Badge
Hopper's Roppers Badge.description: - Initial nmap scan identifies unsecured SMB shares on the Unattended Windows installation endpoint; theHarvester gathers domain user enumeration details, followed by local security policy dump via PowerShell to extract cached credentials for privilege escalation.,Unattended

How to Use TryHackMe.name: How to Use TryHackMe
How to Use TryHackMe.description: - Gobuster directory bruteforcing on the Python web application reveals an unpatched Jinja2 template engine vulnerability; exploit using Server-Side Template Injection (SSTI) payloads to execute OS commands via template context manipulation.,Unbaked Pie

How Web Applications Work.name: How Web Applications Work
How Web Applications Work.description: - Advanced Reconnaissance utilizes theHarvester for email and subdomain enumeration, feeding results into nmap scripting engine (NSE) scans targeting identified ports to map Attack Delivery vectors against the target network infrastructure aligned with the initial phases of the Cyber Kill Chain.,Unified Kill Chain

HTTP2 Explained.name: HTTP2 Explained
HTTP2 Explained.description: - Evil Twin exploitation requires precise WLAN Reconnaissance using Aircrack-ng suite (airodump-ng) to identify target BSSID and channel; then, setup rogue AP via hostapd while deauthenticating legitimate clients with aireplay-ng to force connection for subsequent credential capture.,Unstable Twin

Identity and Access Management.name: Identity and Access Management
Identity and Access Management.description: - Techsupp0rt enumeration commences with nmap scanning for open ports, followed by gobuster or dirbuster brute-forcing common directories like `/admin` or `/login`; exploitation often targets weak credentials or unpatched CMS vulnerabilities revealed via theHarvester for potential remote code execution.,Techsupp0rt: 1

Imbalanced Data.name: Imbalanced Data
Imbalanced Data.description: - Thompson room reconnaissance targets SMB shares via nmap scripts for misconfigured credentials; enumeration employs gobuster against common web application paths; exploitation focuses on vulnerable file upload functionality to establish a reverse shell using netcat.,Thompson

Immunity Tutorial.name: Immunity Tutorial
Immunity Tutorial.description: - Threat Hunting initial foothold requires rapid port scanning with nmap identifying open services; enumeration utilizes gobuster for directory brute-forcing discovering unlinked endpoints; exploitation involves leveraging identified vulnerabilities for initial system access and persistence setup.,Threat Hunting: Foothold

Impact.name: Impact
Impact.description: - Threat Hunting lateral movement post-foothold demands internal network reconnaissance using advanced nmap scans to map new subnets; enumeration proceeds via local service checks and credential reuse attempts to achieve pivoting through compromised hosts.,Threat Hunting: Pivoting

Incident Response Foundations.name: Incident Response Foundations
Incident Response Foundations.description: - Threat hunting for ransomware involves endpoint detection monitoring file system write patterns and process injection; initial reconnaissance may reveal network shares via SMB enumeration or use of theHarvester for domain discovery preceding encryption payload execution.,Threat Hunting: Ransomware

Incident Response Prep.name: Incident Response Prep
Incident Response Prep.description: - Vim productivity enhancement leverages macros (q for recording) to automate repetitive text manipulation, akin to scripting tasks seen in exploitation phases; though not directly related to reconnaissance tools like nmap or gobuster, Vim's global substitution (:g/pattern/s/old/new/g) mimics mass data modification commands.,Toolbox: Vim

Introduction to Django.name: Introduction to Django
Introduction to Django.description: - Uranium CTF advancement requires omitting standard nmap SYN scans due to anti-tamper measures, shifting reconnaissance to passive OSINT via theHarvester for subdomain enumeration; exploitation then targets custom binary vulnerabilities using Ghidra for reverse engineering, followed by ROP chaining to bypass stack canaries.,Uranium CTF
Introduction to Django.practical_applicability: Django security, web development, Python frameworks
Introduction to Django.user_opinions: Good for web developers learning security

Introduction to Flask.name: Introduction to Flask
Introduction to Flask.description: - Valley landscape CTF exploitation commences with aggressive port scanning using nmap aggressive scripts (-sC -A), followed by gobuster directory brute-forcing on web servers using common wordlists like rockyou.txt, targeting misconfigured file shares for LFI injection or unauthenticated RCE.,Valley
Introduction to Flask.practical_applicability: Flask security, web development, Python frameworks

Introduction to Linux.name: Introduction to Linux
Introduction to Linux.description: - Velociraptor DFIR automation leverages custom KQL queries pushed via the central server to deploy memory acquisition and process listing artifacts across compromised endpoints, bypassing initial nmap recon if agents are already active, focusing on persistence mechanisms like registry Run keys or scheduled tasks for forensic containment.,Velociraptor
Introduction to Linux.practical_applicability: Linux basics, command line, file system
Introduction to Linux.user_opinions: Essential starting point for technical careers

Intro to Docker.name: Intro to Docker
Intro to Docker.description: - Container escape enumeration utilizes CVEs against outdated Docker or Kubernetes runtimes, employing specific payloads after initial network recon with nmap to identify exposed management APIs or misconfigured service accounts, followed by privilege escalation exploitation within the host OS.,Virtualization and Containers
Intro to Docker.user_opinions: Essential modern technology, well-explained for beginners

Intro to Endpoint Security.name: Intro to Endpoint Security
Intro to Endpoint Security.description: - Remote Code Execution exploitation in Void Execution focuses on unvalidated input leading to OS command injection via web parameters, validated after reconnaissance using theHarvester for endpoints, and enumeration with gobuster to discover vulnerable scripts, culminating in shell retrieval using netcat or reverse shell payloads.,Void Execution

Intro to GraphQL Hacking.name: Intro to GraphQL Hacking
Intro to GraphQL Hacking.description: - Volatility framework mastery for memory forensics involves dumping RAM images followed by profiling with the --profile flag, utilizing plugins like pslist, netscan, and dlllist to reconstruct process activity, network connections, and loaded modules, enhancing analysis by extracting command history via consoles and identifying malicious artifacts absent from disk.,Volatility

Intro to IaC.name: Intro to IaC
Intro to IaC.description: - Essential Volatility techniques focus on initial image assessment using imageinfo for profile selection, followed by process tree reconstruction via pstree, and malware signature detection using yarascan; this methodology lays the foundation for enumeration of user activity before proceeding to exploitation via memory artifacts, unlike external reconnaissance tools like nmap.,Volatility Essentials

Intro to IoT Pentesting.name: Intro to IoT Pentesting
Intro to IoT Pentesting.description: - Volt Typhoon analysis requires mapping observed TTPs to MITRE ATT&CK techniques like Masquerading and Defense Evasion, leveraging threat intelligence feeds to identify known C2 infrastructure often found via OSINT reconnaissance (theHarvester for domains) before network enumeration (nmap) reveals exposed services targeted for exploitation.,Volt Typhoon

Intro to IR and IM.name: Intro to IR and IM
Intro to IR and IM.description: - Vulnerabilities 101 focuses on foundational security mechanisms like input validation and access control testing commencing with port scanning (nmap) for service discovery, followed by directory enumeration (gobuster or dirbuster) to uncover unlinked endpoints susceptible to common exploitation vectors.,Vulnerabilities 101

Intro to Kubernetes.name: Intro to Kubernetes
Intro to Kubernetes.description: - Vulnerability Capstone demands comprehensive end-to-end testing utilizing automated reconnaissance (theHarvester for OSINT) and intrusive enumeration (nmap aggressive scans and web path bruteforcing via gobuster), culminating in manual exploitation of identified flaws like SQLi or LFI to achieve target system privilege escalation or shell access.,Vulnerability Capstone

Intro to LAN.name: Intro to LAN
Intro to LAN.description: - Enterprise Vulnerability Management requires continuous scanning (Nessus/OpenVAS integration) post-initial enumeration (nmap service versioning for baseline) followed by risk-based patch triage and remediation validation testing using exploit frameworks (Metasploit) to verify mitigation efficacy against zero-day or known CVEs.,Vulnerability Management

Intro to Log Analysis.name: Intro to Log Analysis
Intro to Log Analysis.description: - Automated vulnerability scanning enhancement involves initial network mapping (nmap -sV -A) feeding data to authenticated scanners (Nessus/Qualys) to detect misconfigurations and missing patches, followed by manual web enumeration (gobuster for directories) to validate application layer flaws not captured by network scans.,Vulnerability Scanner Overview

Intro to Logs.name: Intro to Logs
Intro to Logs.description: - VulnNet tackling requires systematic reconnaissance using nmap for port identification and service versioning, then targeted enumeration via gobuster on web ports (e.g. port 80/443) for hidden directories, leading to protocol-specific exploitation paths based on identified vulnerabilities.,VulnNet

Intro to Malware Analysis.name: Intro to Malware Analysis
Intro to Malware Analysis.description: - Active Directory exploitation within VulnNet Active involves initial nmap scans for SMB/Kerberos ports, followed by theHarvester for user enumeration, then utilizing tools like Impacket suite for Kerberoasting or AS-REP roasting to obtain credentials for lateral movement.,VulnNet: Active

Intro to Offensive Security.name: Intro to Offensive Security
Intro to Offensive Security.description: - VulnNet dotjar focuses on Java application security vulnerabilities; reconnaissance includes nmap for web ports, followed by gobuster or dirbuster for discovering exposed endpoints or deployment files like .war or .jar, leading to exploitation via deserialization or remote code execution paths within the JVM.,VulnNet: dotjar
Intro to Offensive Security.user_opinions: Perfect entry point for offensive security

Intro to Pipeline Automation.name: Intro to Pipeline Automation
Intro to Pipeline Automation.description: - VulnNet dotpy targets Python web frameworks; initial reconnaissance utilizes nmap for service identification, then gobuster scans for common Flask or Django directories, exploitation often involves exploiting insecure template rendering or command injection via user input processing functions.,VulnNet: dotpy

Intro To Pwntools.name: Intro To Pwntools
Intro To Pwntools.description: - Endgame requires multi-stage compromise starting with comprehensive network mapping using nmap aggressive scans; enumeration focuses on identifying legacy SMB shares and unpatched Kerberos services, exploitation path often involves initial user credential harvesting via theHarvester and subsequent privilege escalation using a known Windows exploit to achieve Domain Admin.,VulnNet: Endgame

Intro to SSRF.name: Intro to SSRF
Intro to SSRF.description: - Internal network penetration involves post-exploitation lateral movement after initial pivot; enumeration prioritizes internal DNS records via host-level nmap scans and web service discovery using gobuster on discovered IPs; exploitation techniques center on Pass-the-Hash attacks or exploiting unsecured intranet applications revealed by dirbuster.,VulnNet: Internal

Intro to Threat Emulation.name: Intro to Threat Emulation
Intro to Threat Emulation.description: - Node.js application enumeration targets source code disclosure via gobuster directory bruteforcing, searching for .env files or unprotected API endpoints; exploitation focuses on Prototype Pollution or insecure deserialization of JSON objects to achieve Remote Code Execution (RCE), leveraging discovered npm package vulnerabilities.,VulnNet: Node

Introduction to Antivirus.name: Introduction to Antivirus
Introduction to Antivirus.description: - Active Directory reconnaissance via theHarvester and nmap identifies domain controllers and Kerberos ports (TCP/UDP 88); enumeration involves using Impacket's GetUserSPNs.py to discover AS-REP roastable accounts, followed by a brute-force attack on KRB5CCache hashes using Hashcat with a password list derived from enumeration or dirbuster scans on web servers for credential leaks.,VulnNet: Roasted
Introduction to Antivirus.user_opinions: Good foundation for understanding endpoint protection

Introduction to Cryptography.name: Introduction to Cryptography
Introduction to Cryptography.description: - Nmap scans reveal running web services (Apache/Nginx); gobuster brute-forces directories and files to locate the file upload endpoint, testing for extension whitelisting bypass via double extensions (e.g., .php.jpg) or content-type manipulation in the HTTP request to upload a web shell (e.g., cmd.php) for remote code execution.,VulnUniversity

Introduction to CryptOps.name: Introduction to CryptOps
Introduction to CryptOps.description: - TheHarvester gathers external information (emails, subdomains); subsequent nmap ping sweeps and gobuster enumeration identify exposed ports (21, 22, 80), leading to FTP anonymous login attempts or SSH bruteforcing and web directory traversal exploitation on identified endpoints to exfiltrate credentials.,VulnVault

Introduction to DevSecOps.name: Introduction to DevSecOps
Introduction to DevSecOps.description: - Initial reconnaissance using theHarvester uncovers user data; nmap scans reveal an unusual port running a custom service; gobuster identifies a hidden API endpoint vulnerable to SQL injection for privilege escalation and shell acquisition.,W1seGuy

Introductory Networking.name: Introductory Networking
Introductory Networking.description: - Target application enum via gobuster dirbuster reveals insecure file upload interface; manual testing with Burp Suite confirms path traversal leading to sensitive configuration file disclosure and subsequent command injection.,Walking an Application
Introductory Networking.user_opinions: Essential networking foundation, excellent for beginners

Introductory Researching.name: Introductory Researching
Introductory Researching.description: - Initial reconnaissance using theHarvester on target domain yields an internal IP; nmap port scan detects unsecured SSH and a non-standard logging service on port 2222, requiring Wireshark packet capture analysis to identify clear-text credentials for privilege escalation.,Watcher

Intrusion Detection.name: Intrusion Detection
Intrusion Detection.description: - Wazuh agent deployment on compromised host begins real-time log monitoring; custom rules are configured to alert on failed enumeration attempts (e.g., gobuster directory scans) and subsequent SSH bruteforce activity, correlating with nmap discovery findings for incident response playbook validation.,Wazuh

Investigating with ELK 101.name: Investigating with ELK 101
Investigating with ELK 101.description: - Initial reconnaissance using theHarvester uncovered subdomains and email formats; subsequent nmap TCP SYN scans revealed port 80 open, leading to gobuster directory enumeration yielding a hidden API endpoint requiring complex parameter injection for flag retrieval.,We Are Groot

Investigating Windows.name: Investigating Windows
Investigating Windows.description: - Comprehensive reconnaissance with nmap identified ports 80 and 443; gobuster brute-force discovered a vulnerable admin panel path; subsequent SQLmap exploitation on a login form achieved database dump containing user credentials for lateral movement.,Web App Security

Investigating Windows 2.0.name: Investigating Windows 2.0
Investigating Windows 2.0.description: - Initial nmap scan revealed Cloudflare WAF shielding port 80; theHarvester identified an exposed origin IP via historical DNS records; direct requests to origin enabled XSS payload injection by encoding payload using URL and HTML entities to evade WAF signature detection.,Web Application Firewall

Investigating Windows 3.x.name: Investigating Windows 3.x
Investigating Windows 3.x.description: - Target reconnaissance commenced with theHarvester for email and subdomain discovery; subsequently, gobuster utilized the common Wordlist X against directory paths on port 80, uncovering a hidden admin interface requiring brute-force via Hydra.,Web Enumeration

Investigating with Splunk.name: Investigating with Splunk
Investigating with Splunk.description: - Initial service discovery via nmap scanning revealed HTTP on port 80; web foundation enumeration involved dirbuster for deep path discovery, identifying an unrestricted robots.txt file guiding subsequent enumeration efforts.,Web Fundamentals

IR Timeline Analysis.name: IR Timeline Analysis
IR Timeline Analysis.description: - Target domain reconnaissance utilized theHarvester against public sources and search engines to gather email addresses and subdomains; subsequent enumeration involved gobuster on identified subdomains to locate hidden directories and potential API endpoints for further exploitation.,Web OSINT
IR Timeline Analysis.user_opinions: Critical IR skill for reconstructing incidents

IronCorp.name: IronCorp
IronCorp.description: - Initial reconnaissance mapped open ports using nmap with aggressive scripting (`-sC -sV`) on target web servers; subsequent enumeration employed dirbuster in brute-force mode against common directories to identify unlinked assets and potential file inclusion vectors for exploitation.,Web Scanning

IRSE.name: IRSE
IRSE.description: - Targeted web application enumeration commenced post-reconnaissance via gobuster with a comprehensive directory list to uncover hidden endpoints, followed by Burp Suite for manual parameter fuzzing to test for SQLi and XSS vulnerabilities during the exploitation phase.,WebApp Security

Island Orchestration.name: Island Orchestration
Island Orchestration.description: - Wekor room exploitation initiated with nmap service version detection on identified ports, proceeding to gobuster directory bruteforcing to locate the vulnerable upload mechanism for shell staging.,Wekor

Jack.name: Jack
Jack.description: - Wgel CTF commences with theHarvester OSINT on target domain, followed by nmap script execution to uncover specific service vulnerabilities, then dirbuster brute-forcing uncovers a misconfigured admin panel leading to initial shell access.,Wgel CTF

Jack of All Trades.name: Jack of All Trades
Jack of All Trades.description: - What the Shell requires initial nmap port scan revealing an HTTP service, gobuster directory enumeration identifies a vulnerable script endpoint, exploitation via command injection achieves a reverse shell, followed by linpeas for privilege escalation using SUDO misconfigurations.,What the Shell

James Bond: Room 1.name: James Bond: Room 1
James Bond: Room 1.description: - Windows Fundamentals 1 focuses on initial reconnaissance using nmap targeting SMB ports (445/139) and RDP (3389), enumeration involves NetBIOS name queries and checking shares with smbclient, practical steps include identifying user accounts and password policy via built-in CMD commands like net user.,Windows Fundamentals 1

Jason.name: Jason

Java Deserialization.name: Java Deserialization
Java Deserialization.description: - Windows Fundamentals 3 focuses on advanced lateral movement and privilege escalation techniques beyond initial access, employing tools like Mimikatz post-exploitation for credential dumping, coupled with system enumeration using PowerUp or WinPEAS to discover misconfigurations for kernel or service exploitation.,Windows Fundamentals 3

Java SSTI.name: Java SSTI

JIS CTF: VulnUpload.name: JIS CTF: VulnUpload

John Hammond Junior.name: John Hammond Junior
John Hammond Junior.description: - Windows Privilege Escalation targets unquoted Service Paths, weak Service Permissions (e.g., Service owner or binary path writable by current user), kernel exploits (post-enumeration via WinPEAS or manual version check against nmap scan results), and AlwaysInstallElevated registry keys for MSI abuse, exploited via command line tools like icacls or specific exploit binaries.,Windows PrivEsc

JokerCTF.name: JokerCTF

JSONWEBTOKEN.name: JSONWEBTOKEN
JSONWEBTOKEN.description: - Mastery involves post-exploitation persistence via registry run keys or WMI event subscriptions after initial network mapping (nmap SYN scans), followed by local enumeration (PowerSploit modules) to find unquoted service paths or weak file permissions for Binary Planting exploitation.,Windows Privilege Escalation

Juicy Details.name: Juicy Details
Juicy Details.description: - Wireless reconnaissance utilizes airodump-ng to capture 802.11 frames, identifying SSIDs and BSSIDs; exploitation involves deauthentication attacks followed by handshake capture (WPA2-PSK), then offline dictionary cracking using Hashcat or Aircrack-ng suite to derive the pre-shared key.,Wireless Hacking 101

Juice Shop.name: Juice Shop

K-9.name: K-9
K-9.description: - Advanced Wireshark operations require expert use of I/O graphs to visualize throughput and latency deviations following enumeration scans like aggressive Nmap timing templates (-T4 or -T5), subsequent analysis focuses on reconstructing TCP sessions to extract cleartext credentials or data exfiltrated during simulated exploitation.,Wireshark: Packet Operations

Katana.name: Katana
Katana.description: - Wireshark fundamentals entail applying capture filters (e.g., host 10.10.10.5 and port 80) to isolate traffic generated during reconnaissance scans like initial host discovery using ping or low-and-slow Gobuster requests, then using display filters (e.g., http.request) to verify successful enumeration responses.,Wireshark: The Basics

Kerberos.name: Kerberos
Kerberos.description: - Mastering traffic analysis involves deep packet inspection of captured session data following enumeration tools like Nmap SYN scans or DirBuster brute-force attempts, specifically examining TCP three-way handshakes, TLS/SSL negotiations, and identifying potential exploitation payloads within unencrypted application layer data.,Wireshark: Traffic Analysis

Kessel Run.name: Kessel Run

Keybored.name: Keybored

Keyring.name: Keyring

Kitchen.name: Kitchen
Kitchen.description: - XDR platforms ingest telemetry across endpoints, network, cloud, and identity layers, leveraging AI/ML for cross-domain correlation beyond traditional SIEM alert fatigue; enhancement requires tuning behavioral baselines to reduce false positives from simulated reconnaissance activities like nmap scans or gobuster web enumeration.,XDR: Introduction

Koth Hackers.name: Koth Hackers
Koth Hackers.description: - Reflected and stored XSS exploitation techniques involve injecting malicious JavaScript payloads via user-controllable input fields identified during enumeration (\text{gobuster/dirbuster for paths or nmap for service discovery preceding web testing)}; enhancement involves strict input validation and context-aware output encoding to prevent session hijacking or credential theft via document.cookie.,XSS

Kubernetes for Everyone.name: Kubernetes for Everyone

KyleBot.name: KyleBot

Linux Wireshark Traffic Analysis.name: Linux Wireshark Traffic Analysis
Linux Wireshark Traffic Analysis.description:
- Web basics enumeration utilizes HTTP/HTTPS protocol understanding, examining source code for hidden credentials or JavaScript endpoints.
- Directory bruteforcing with gobuster or dirbuster targets common paths (/admin, /backup) identified during initial reconnaissance via nmap service version detection.
- HTTP request manipulation using Burp Suite or OWASP ZAP identifies potential vulnerabilities like IDOR or parameter tampering.
- DNS enumeration via theHarvester or nslookup maps subdomains critical for expanded attack surface mapping.
- File inclusion testing (LFI/RFI) involves injecting path traversal sequences (e.g., ../etc/passwd) into URL parameters.
- Cookie and session management analysis reveals weak token generation or insecure storage practices.
- Web server fingerprinting from nmap output (e.g., Apache 2.4.41) guides the selection of exploit modules.
- Form field fuzzing targets input validation for potential SQL Injection (SQLi) or Cross-Site Scripting (XSS) vectors.
- Robots.txt analysis uncovers directories intentionally hidden from search engines but accessible via direct navigation.
- Identifying web technology stacks (Wappalyzer or manual check) informs vulnerability lookup on CVE databases.,World Wide Web

LNX.name: LNX
LNX.description:
- Worm propagation initialization often relies on network service enumeration using nmap to scan for vulnerable ports like SMB (445) or RDP (3389).
- Payload delivery during exploitation stage requires crafting malformed packets or leveraging known buffer overflows specific to the identified service version.
- Reconnaissance involves internal network mapping, potentially using tools like arp-scan or custom scripts after initial host compromise.
- Malware behavioral analysis necessitates dynamic analysis in a sandboxed environment using tools like Cuckoo Sandbox to monitor API calls.
- Persistence mechanisms are identified by examining registry keys (Run keys), startup folders, or scheduled tasks post-exploitation.
- Command and Control (C2) communication detection involves traffic sniffing with Wireshark to spot exfiltration patterns or beaconing activity.
- Directory enumeration techniques, while less direct for network worms, can be adapted to find configuration files that dictate worm spreading logic.
- Memory forensics using Volatility framework extracts injected code segments or active process lists for worm artifact retrieval.
- System call tracing with strace (Linux) or Procmon (Windows) maps the exact sequence of file writes and network connections made by the malware.,Worm Propagation

Local File Inclusion.name: Local File Inclusion
Local File Inclusion.description:
- Structured writeup creation mandates sequencing from initial nmap port scans to final privilege escalation documentation.
- Reconnaissance sections must detail gobuster or dirbuster wordlist selections and resulting directory paths discovered.
- Exploitation documentation requires exact paste of Metasploit module names or custom exploit code used during the vulnerability phase.
- TheHarvester output screenshots or direct text should be embedded to substantiate OSINT claims in the initial setup.
- Enumeration steps should specifically list response codes (e.g., HTTP 200, 403) observed after web enumeration attempts.
- Technical enhancement involves annotating tool flags and parameters (e.g., nmap -sV -A) rather than simple command execution.
- Privilege escalation methods (e.g., SUID binaries, kernel exploits) must link directly to the specific proof-of-concept file utilized.
- Markdown formatting (# headers, \`\`code blocks) is crucial for readability when presenting complex command chains.
- Post-exploitation activity, such as data staging or lateral movement, requires detailed use of Netcat or similar utilities.,Writeups

Local File Inclusion - Advanced.name: Local File Inclusion - Advanced
Local File Inclusion - Advanced.description:
- Initial reconnaissance focused on discovering the hidden web interface, utilizing gobuster with a custom wordlist targeting Chinese Zodiac-themed paths.
- Nmap scanning revealed non-standard ports, requiring specific version detection (-sV) to identify the vulnerable service running.
- Enumeration of the vulnerable service involved manual parameter fuzzing instead of automated dirbuster scans due to rate-limiting.
- Exploitation centered on an insecure input validation flaw, likely requiring base64 encoding of payloads for bypass.
- OSINT component involved theHarvester to gather associated emails or subdomains related to the Zodiac theme for potential credential leaks.
- Post-exploitation required locating a specific configuration file misplaced on the system, often found via recursive find commands after initial shell access.
- Privilege escalation involved identifying a weakly configured cron job or SUDO entry related to a system utility.
- Technical writeup enhancement demands documenting the exact sequence of character escapes necessary to trigger the vulnerability path.,Year of the Dog 2

Nmap.name: Nmap
Nmap.description: - **Meterpreter Post-Exploitation Payload Lifecycle & Evasion**: After initial **msfvenom** shell staging, Meterpreter employs complex inter-process migration (`migrate` command) to evade termination, leveraging kernel-level API calls fundamentally operating around OSI Layers 3/4 interaction for C2 maintenance via encrypted channels; post-exploitation enumeration progresses from local system enumeration (`sysinfo`, `getuid`) to privilege escalation (`getsystem`), followed by lateral movement using Mimikatz (`load kiwi` for credential dumping); practical steps mandate backgrounding the session (`background`), re-establishing persistence mechanisms (e.g., modifying `Run` keys via registry manipulation tools, conceptually Layer 7), and finally, utilizing pivoting techniques (e.g., setting up SOCKS proxy tunnels using **autoroute** and **socks4a**) to execute internal network scans using **nmap** against non-directly accessible subnets, bypassing initial perimeter defenses established during the reconnaissance phase where tools like **theHarvester** identified the target landscape. (171 words; Tools: msfvenom, Meterpreter (built-in commands: migrate, getsystem, kiwi, autoroute, socks4a), nmap, theHarvester; Methodology: Persistence Establishment, Credential Harvesting, Internal Pivoting/Network Expansion; Implementation: Secure C2 channel, escalate privileges, deploy internal enumeration tools via established tunnel.)

Nmap Advanced Port Scans.name: Nmap Advanced Port Scans
Nmap Advanced Port Scans.description: - **Mindgames Puzzle Decryption & Enumeration Strategy**: Mindgames room challenges demand non-standard execution paths, bypassing typical **nmap** service enumeration or **gobuster** directory brute-forcing; techniques often involve reverse-engineering base64/ROT variations, analyzing provided file metadata discrepancies, and exploiting logic flaws within challenge scripts, treating input/output validation as the primary vulnerability vector; practical enhancement involves systematic base conversion checks (Hex rightarrow ASCII rightarrow Decimal), iterative application of substitution ciphers until flag syntax is recognized, and utilizing command-line text processing tools like **grep** or **awk** to rapidly filter voluminous, obfuscated text outputs until a key variable or shell command execution sequence is isolated for final flag submission. (104 words; Tools: nmap, gobuster (limited applicability), grep, awk, manual cipher tools; Methodology: Cryptographic Analysis, Logic Flaw Exploitation, Data Filtering; Implementation: Iterative substitution, metadata examination, pattern recognition in high-entropy data streams.)

Nmap Basic Port Scans.name: Nmap Basic Port Scans
Nmap Basic Port Scans.description: - **Misguided Ghosts Enumeration & Lateral Movement**: Initial **nmap** scan reveals non-standard SMB/RPC ports open; **theHarvester** reconnaissance targets internal subnet lookups, potentially exposing user credentials or forgotten shares; **gobuster** targeting common WordPress/vBulletin paths fails, forcing pivot to PowerShell abuse via suspicious scheduled tasks identified via low-privilege file access; exploitation focuses on weak service credentials found in configuration files (e.g., hashdump format, often LM:NTLM pairs), requiring **hashcat** on a GPU rig for offline cracking using rockyou.txt baseline wordlist before attempting **WMI** or **psexec** lateral movement to the "Ghost" target host. (108 words; Tools: nmap, theHarvester, gobuster, hashcat, powershell, psexec, wmic; Methodology: Credential Harvesting, Service Enumeration, Offline Cracking, Lateral Movement; Implementation: Port scanning (syn scan), credential file extraction, cracking, remote command execution via privileged protocols.)

Nmap Live Host Discovery.name: Nmap Live Host Discovery
Nmap Live Host Discovery.description: - **Mission Impossible Deep Dive Exploitation**: Initial **nmap** full scan (-sC -sV -p-) identifies obscure TCP/14147 service; **theHarvester** fails due to hardened DNS records, necessitating internal DNS zone transfer attempts; **gobuster** (using ffuf-tuned wordlist) reveals a hidden XML-RPC endpoint; exploitation proceeds via fuzzing the XML-RPC structure to trigger a deserialization vulnerability (XXE or Java native deserialization); post-exploitation involves securing a stable reverse shell via obfuscated nc/bash one-liners, followed by exploiting kernel unpatched LPE vulnerability (Dirty Pipe variant) targeting the final root flag. (115 words; Tools: nmap, ffuf, gobuster, nc, bash, kernel exploit PoC; Methodology: Zero-day hunting simulation, advanced fuzzing, deserialization exploitation, privilege escalation; Implementation: Comprehensive port scan, blind path enumeration, payload injection, kernel patch bypass.)

Nmap Post Port Scans.name: Nmap Post Port Scans
Nmap Post Port Scans.description: - **Monitor Room Security Practice**: Preliminary **nmap** targeted scan (-sU for UDP enumeration) reveals open SNMP (UDP/161) community strings; successful SNMPwalk yields network device configuration details, pointing to misconfigured Syslog server; **Wireshark** utilized for passive packet capture during simulated alert traffic; **ELK stack** (Elasticsearch, Logstash, Kibana) analysis focuses on Kibana dashboard tuning for IDS/IPS signature correlation; exploitation hinges on leveraging discovered SNMP write access (read-write) to inject malicious Syslog message redirecting internal traffic for MITM capture; enhancement involves creating custom Logstash filters for unstructured Syslog normalization prior to alerting threshold configuration. (119 words; Tools: nmap, Wireshark, SNMPwalk, ELK Stack (Elasticsearch, Logstash, Kibana); Methodology: Protocol enumeration (SNMP/Syslog), passive monitoring, log parsing, threat correlation; Implementation: Custom MIB traversal, filter development, threshold baselining, packet analysis.)

Master.name: Master
Master.description: - **Moria CTF Theme Implementation**: Initial **theHarvester** reconnaissance gathering subdomains pointing to an archival web server; **gobuster** -w /usr/share/wordlists/rockyou.txt -x .html,.php against HTTP port 80 uncovers a hidden directory, `/mines/records/`, leading to an outdated Apache version vulnerability; **nmap** -sV confirms vulnerable services; exploitation involves crafting an LFI payload targeting configuration files potentially containing API keys necessary for flag decryption; enhancement methodology dictates SQLmap execution post-directory traversal success, targeting inferred backend database connection strings (SQLite) to extract the final flag encrypted with Base64 encoding requiring symmetric key brute-force. (118 words; Tools: theHarvester, gobuster, nmap, sqlmap; Methodology: OSINT, directory brute-forcing, version scanning, LFI exploitation, database exfiltration; Implementation: Wordlist selection, payload construction, key derivation via brute-force.)

Meterpreter.name: Meterpreter
Meterpreter.description: - **MotherSecret Investigation Framework**: Comprehensive **nmap** -sC -sV -p- -oA initial_scan mapping all open ports; **gobuster** -u http://<target_ip>/ -w /usr/share/wordlists/dirb/common.txt -x .txt,.bak reveals an unindexed backup.txt file containing obfuscated credentials for an FTP service; **enumeration** focuses on FTP login, subsequent file system traversal yields SSH keys; **exploitation** necessitates leveraging ssh2john to convert the private key format for **john** or **hashcat** cracking (rockyou.txt list); enhancement methodology involves using **Wireshark** to capture and analyze SMB traffic observed during enumeration, potentially exposing NetNTLM hashes for relay attacks if Kerberos constraints permit. (126 words; Tools: nmap, gobuster, john/hashcat, ssh2john, Wireshark; Methodology: Port scanning, directory enumeration, service credential harvesting, key cracking, lateral movement preparation; Implementation: Port range scanning, credential extraction, hash cracking pipeline, packet analysis.)

Mindgames.name: Mindgames
Mindgames.description: - **Mr. Phisher Phishing Analysis Pipeline**: Initial **theHarvester** sweeps targeting example.com for MX records and associated email addresses; DNS enumeration using **dig** identifies SPF and DKIM records indicating weak email security posture; **nmap** identifies open SMTP ports (25, 587), facilitating VRFY/EXPN testing for valid user harvesting; **exploitation** involves crafting a HTML malicious email template impersonating HR to harvest credentials via a spoofed login portal hosted on a C2 server spun up via Netcat listening on 4444; enhancement targets DMARC bypass by analyzing mail headers for From address mismatches, focusing on subdomain takeover potential post-recon. (132 words; Tools: theHarvester, dig, nmap, Netcat; Methodology: Domain reconnaissance, DNS record analysis, SMTP enumeration, HTML phishing lure deployment, header analysis; Implementation: OSINT gathering, SMTP service testing, C2 setup, email construction validation.)

Misguided Ghosts.name: Misguided Ghosts
Misguided Ghosts.description: - **Multimedia File Forensics & Exfiltration**: **ExifTool** parsing of JPEG metadata reveals hidden steganographic data embedded within the XMP structure; binwalk analysis of MP4 container identifies layered file system structures, requiring foremost extraction of constituent audio/video streams; brute-force directory enumeration via **gobuster** on web services hosting media assets targets hidden upload endpoints for reverse shell establishment; exploitation involves manipulating ID3 tags in an MP3 file to embed a base64 encoded command payload, subsequently triggered by a custom media player exploit targeting buffer overflow vulnerabilities observed during static PE/ELF analysis of proprietary codec libraries. (135 words; Tools: ExifTool, binwalk, foremost, gobuster; Methodology: Metadata analysis, file carving, directory brute-forcing, steganography extraction, vulnerability exploitation; Implementation: Metadata fingerprinting, layered file recovery, web enumeration, payload encoding/injection.)

Mission Impossible.name: Mission Impossible
Mission Impossible.description: - **Mnemonic Memory Dump Analysis**: Volatility framework utilized on a captured WinPMEM memory image; pslist and pstree plugins establish process lineage mapping to identify anomalous parent-child relationships indicative of injection; malfind scans target unbacked memory regions for shellcode artifacts; dlldump extracts suspicious loaded modules for static analysis, specifically targeting kernel-mode drivers or injected DLLs associated with process hollowing or direct system call manipulation; **theHarvester** reconnaissance output (if network artifacts are present) correlates IP/hostname data with active socket connections identified via netscan to map lateral movement; hivelist and printkey assist in registry hive traversal to recover cached credentials from LSA secrets utilizing mimikatz functionality within Volatility extensions for offline credential extraction. (146 words; Tools: Volatility, pslist, malfind, dlldump, theHarvester, netscan, hivelist, mimikatz extension; Methodology: Process analysis, memory carving, injection detection, credential dumping, network correlation; Implementation: Memory image loading, process mapping, shellcode signature identification, registry key enumeration, credential extraction from LSA.)

Monitor.name: Monitor
Monitor.description: - **Miskatonic Digital Archives Breach**: Initial nmap aggressive scan (-sA or -sC) mapping open ports, focusing on SMB (139/445) and HTTP/S (80/443) services; gobuster or dirbuster employed with a custom Lovecraftian dictionary (Cthulhu.txt) targeting web directories for hidden API endpoints or sensitive document repositories (/admin, /research/forbidden); theHarvester sourcing emails and subdomains linked to the miskatonic.edu domain to establish an external attack surface; suspected weak authentication vector on a Tomcat or JBoss service identified via version enumeration (nmap --script=http-enum), leading to brute-force credential stuffing using Hydra against the identified service banner; successful exploitation reveals an outdated internal wiki utilizing CVE-2019-XXXX resulting in remote code execution (RCE) via a crafted PHP shell payload deployed through the web root. (154 words; Tools: nmap, gobuster, dirbuster, theHarvester, Hydra; Methodology: Port scanning, aggressive directory busting, external intelligence gathering, service version enumeration, brute-forcing, RCE exploitation; Implementation: Port mapping, dictionary-based enumeration, metadata scraping, credential testing, vulnerability confirmation, reverse shell establishment.)

Moria.name: Moria
Moria.description: - **Perimeter Defense Bypass**: nmap SYN stealth scan (-sS) to fingerprint OS and service versions across the defined IP range; smbclient and enum4linux run against discovered SMB shares (port 445) searching for null session access or misconfigured ACLs yielding credential dumps or sensitive configuration files; Nikto or Wapiti scanning web interfaces for common OWASP Top 10 vulnerabilities, specifically targeting SQL injection vectors (SQLi) on login forms; manual crafting of Netcat (nc) listeners on non-standard ports (e.g., 4444) anticipating successful pivot points or reverse shell connections following identified buffer overflows (boofuzz utilized for payload fuzzing against vulnerable services); successful internal enumeration reveals an older Linux kernel version (uname -a output from shell), triggering the deployment of a specific Metasploit module (exploit/multi/handler) targeting known privilege escalation vulnerabilities (Dirty Cow analogue). (178 words; Tools: nmap, smbclient, enum4linux, Nikto, Wapiti, nc, boofuzz, Metasploit; Methodology: Stealth scanning, service enumeration/credential harvesting, web application vulnerability scanning, listener setup, payload fuzzing, kernel exploit for privilege escalation; Implementation: Port discovery, credential testing, injection payload testing, shell establishment, kernel version analysis, exploit module execution.)

MotherSecret.name: MotherSecret
MotherSecret.description: - **Distributed Attack Simulation**: theHarvester executing LinkedIn and Shodan searches (-d targetdomain) to map organizational structure and exposed infrastructure; gobuster (-w wordlist, -x php,bak) aggressively probing for forgotten administrative interfaces or exposed Git repositories (.git/config access attempts); successful DNS zone transfer identification forces immediate nslookup mass querying across the subnet to identify Active Directory domain controllers; tcpdump deployed to capture ARP traffic, identifying host MAC addresses for subsequent MITM pivot using ettercap (selective poisoning via -P arp); subsequent stage involves deploying custom Python scripts leveraging Scapy to craft malformed ICMP Echo requests targeting firewall state tables, inducing potential denial-of-service conditions on key gateway devices. (174 words; Tools: theHarvester, gobuster, nslookup, tcpdump, ettercap, Python, Scapy; Methodology: External reconnaissance/OSINT, directory brute-forcing, service discovery, traffic interception/spoofing, low-level packet manipulation for network disruption; Implementation: OSINT gathering, forced directory enumeration, DNS enumeration, traffic sniffing, ARP cache poisoning, custom packet generation/injection.)

Mr Phisher.name: Mr Phisher
Mr Phisher.description: - **Layered Security Evasion Protocol**: Nmap -sS SYN scan against target range, followed by -p- -T5 aggressive port sweep (1-65535) to map all open services; identified web service running IIS (445 open) triggers immediate SMB enumeration via enum4linux (-U users, -S shares); gobuster -u http://target/ -w common.txt -x aspx successfully identifies .aspx administrative backend vulnerable to SQL injection, leveraged using sqlmap (--dbs extraction); privilege escalation initiated by exploiting known vulnerability in unpatched Windows kernel service (msfvenom generated payload delivery via established SMB channel); post-exploitation involves PowerShell reverse shell deployment (iex (new-object net.webclient).downloadstring), bypassing Windows Defender restrictions via AMSI bypass script injection. (187 words; Tools: Nmap, enum4linux, gobuster, sqlmap, msfvenom, PowerShell; Methodology: Aggressive port scanning, SMB enumeration, Web application injection, Kernel exploitation, Defense evasion/Malware execution; Implementation: Stealth scanning, credential harvesting, database dumping, shellcode generation, in-memory execution.)

Multimedia.name: Multimedia
Multimedia.description: - **Protocol-Specific Vulnerability Exploitation Chain**: Nmap -sV -O version detection on UDP/TCP ports 161 (SNMP) and 139/445 (NetBIOS/SMB); theHarvester executed against known domain metadata (-d example.local -b all) to source potential internal usernames; SNMP enumeration using snmp-check reveals read-write community strings, allowing for configuration dumping; SMB enumeration proceeds with smbclient (-L //target) to map accessible shares, attempting Null session connection; Gobuster utilized specifically against discovered HTTP services (-x html,php) searching for configuration files or .git repository leaks; Metasploit Framework leveraged (use exploit/multi/samba/usermap_script) upon confirmation of SMB vulnerability; successful exploitation yields a low-privilege shell, immediately followed by privilege escalation attempt targeting vulnerable Linux kernel modules (DirtyPipe or similar check via uname -a). (234 words; Tools: Nmap, theHarvester, snmp-check, smbclient, gobuster, Metasploit Framework; Methodology: Service fingerprinting, metadata harvesting, protocol-specific enumeration, exploit chaining, privilege escalation; Implementation: Version scanning, credential discovery, configuration access, remote code execution via vulnerable service module, kernel patch gap assessment.)

Mnemonic.name: Mnemonic
Mnemonic.description: - **SMB/NFS Share Mapping and Data Exfiltration**: Nmap service detection (-sV) targeting ports 139, 445, 2049 confirms SMB and NFS presence; smbclient -L //target executes SMB share listing; enum4linux -a target performs comprehensive SMB enumeration for users/groups/shares; mount -t nfs target:/path /mnt/nfs_share attempts NFS mount if access confirmed; Gobuster dir module directed against associated web interfaces (if present) to locate configuration files referencing credentials; Null session exploitation (if allowed) using smbclient to brute-force NULL or default credentials against writable shares (w flag confirmation); successful mount/access allows rsync or wget deployment within the share context for file transfer validation/exfiltration (scp post-initial access); Kerberos auditing (rpcclient) investigates potential pre-authentication vulnerabilities if Active Directory environment detected. (231 words; Tools: Nmap, smbclient, enum4linux, mount, gobuster, rsync, wget, scp, rpcclient; Methodology: Port scanning, service enumeration, null session testing, protocol-specific mounting, credential harvesting, data staging/exfiltration, Kerberos auditing; Implementation: Service versioning, share enumeration, anonymous access testing, file system mounting, brute-force credential attempts, secure file transfer simulation.)

Miskatonic University.name: Miskatonic University
Miskatonic University.description: - **Web Service Enumeration and Directory Traversal Exploitation**: Initial nmap -sC -sV target scans reveal running HTTP/HTTPS services (ports 80, 443). Gobuster/Dirbuster (Mode: dir or ffuf) employed with common wordlists (SecLists/Discovery/Web-Content/Common.txt) maps hidden directories and backup files (e.g., /.git, /backup.zip). TheHarvester targets external OSINT reconnaissance for subdomains and potential email addresses linked to the domain. Upon discovering an accessible web.config or configuration file, search for hardcoded database strings or API keys. If a vulnerable endpoint is identified (e.g., a file retrieval parameter), LFI/RFI (Local/Remote File Inclusion) payload construction using ../ sequences (e.g., ?file=../../etc/passwd) confirms traversal capability; successful traversal permits reading system files for privilege escalation vectors or credentials; Burp Suite Repeater facilitates precise payload testing and response verification. (207 words; Tools: nmap, gobuster, dirbuster, ffuf, theHarvester, Burp Suite Repeater; Methodology: Port scanning, service fingerprinting, aggressive directory brute-forcing, OSINT gathering, configuration file inspection, LFI/RFI exploitation, path traversal testing; Implementation: Baseline scanning, brute-force execution, file path chaining, payload injection via request parameters, response inspection.)

Net Sec Challenge.name: Net Sec Challenge
Net Sec Challenge.description: - **Automated Web Vulnerability Scanning and Configuration Auditing**: Nmap (script: http-enum) precedes Nikto execution (nikto -h target_ip -ssl -dbpath /path/to/custom/db) to identify running services and initial technology stack. Gobuster or ffuf performs concurrent directory/file enumeration to identify non-standard endpoints missed by Nikto's default scans. Nikto focuses on identifying known CGI vulnerabilities, insecure file permissions, outdated server versions, default configurations, and .bak files by leveraging its extensive vulnerability database (-plugins option enhances coverage). If Nikto flags a specific software version (e.g., Apache 2.4.xx), subsequent targeted exploitation enumeration (searchsploit) is initiated; enhancement involves scripting the output parsing of Nikto reports to automatically generate specific exploit payloads for identified weaknesses. (151 words; Tools: nmap, nikto, gobuster, ffuf, searchsploit; Methodology: Pre-scan service identification, automated vulnerability assessment, concurrent discovery, targeted plugin activation, exploit identification based on versioning; Implementation: Baseline network scan, comprehensive Nikto run, parallel directory discovery, output correlation, exploit module preparation.)

Netwars.name: Netwars
Netwars.description: - **NoNameCTF General Practice Workflow**: Initial reconnaissance utilizes theHarvester against specified targets to map external assets and associated email addresses. Nmap (SYN scan -sS -A) performs deep service version detection; subsequent directory enumeration employs gobuster (gobuster dir -u http://target -w wordlist.txt -x php,bak,zip) to map hidden web structure, prioritizing extensions likely to harbor sensitive data or application logic flaws. Dirbuster might substitute gobuster for testing complex, non-standard file extensions found during initial enumeration. Exploitation phase involves crafting payloads (SQLi, LFI) based on identified web tech/versions, often requiring iterative testing using Burp Suite Interceptor/Repeater to bypass rudimentary input validation mechanisms flagged during Nikto or manual review. (155 words; Tools: theHarvester, nmap, gobuster, dirbuster, burp suite; Methodology: External asset mapping, deep service fingerprinting, brute-force directory discovery, iterative payload crafting, input validation circumvention; Implementation: Reconnaissance execution, service enumeration, concurrent brute-forcing, vulnerability verification via proxy manipulation.)

Netsec Playground.name: Netsec Playground
Netsec Playground.description: - **Basic Practice Workflow Simulation**: Standard reconnaissance employs nmap -sV -p- target for comprehensive port scanning and service identification; gobuster iterates through common web directories (common.txt) testing for configuration files or login portals. Enumeration extends to checking identified services (e.g., SMB, FTP) for default credentials or anonymous access policies. Exploitation focuses on low-hanging fruit: executing known exploit chains against outdated services identified by nmap versioning, or attempting basic directory traversal (../../etc/passwd) on identified web endpoints. Privilege escalation likely involves analyzing local binaries for SUID/SGID bits using find / -perm -u=s -type f 2>/dev/null post-initial shell acquisition. (119 words; Tools: nmap, gobuster, find; Methodology: Comprehensive port scanning, version identification, brute-force directory scanning, known exploit chaining, local privilege escalation via SUID analysis; Implementation: Full port scan, concurrent web enumeration, service-specific credential testing, shell establishment, kernel/binary privilege assessment.)

Network Exploitation.name: Network Exploitation
Network Exploitation.description: - **NoSQL Injection Exploitation Chain**: Initial reconnaissance (nmap) maps open ports, typically web services. Enumeration targets input vectors vulnerable to NoSQL syntax manipulation, particularly in JSON-based query parameters. Exploitation leverages the absence of strict input sanitization in MongoDB/CouchDB style queries, utilizing operators like \ne (not equal) or \where for boolean bypasses or command execution via JavaScript evaluation. Post-exploitation involves crafting payloads like {"where":"function(){return db.users.findOne({username:'admin').password=='[HASH]'}"}} to extract sensitive hashes or utilizing time-delay functions for blind injection confirmation. Enhancement focuses on identifying the underlying database technology before payload development. (113 words; Tools: nmap (for initial port discovery, though less critical than custom payloads); Methodology: Input vector identification, syntax manipulation leveraging native operators (\ne, \where), hash extraction/credential dumping, blind time-delay confirmation; Implementation: Scanning for web entry points, systematic payload insertion into parameter fields, iterative testing of database-specific injection syntax.)

Network File Shares.name: Network File Shares
Network File Shares.description: - **OSINT Reconnaissance and Data Aggregation**: Initial reconnaissance (theHarvester) targets domain names, employee emails, and subdomains using public sources like Google, Bing, and Shodan. Enumeration proceeds via specialized passive tools to map digital footprint: Maltego visualizes relationships between extracted entities (IPs, domains, PII). Exploitation in this context is information gain; scraping GitHub repositories for code snippets, analyzing publicly accessible DNS records (dig), and using Shodan queries to identify exposed services not found by active scanning (nmap is typically avoided in pure OSINT). Enhancement involves chaining low-level data points into actionable intelligence graphs. (107 words; Tools: theHarvester, Maltego, Shodan, dig; Methodology: Passive data collection, relationship visualization, metadata analysis, public record scraping; Implementation: Systematic querying of search engines/APIs for initial targets, visualizing connections via graph databases, filtering noise from high-volume data streams.)

Nice Try!.name: Nice Try!
Nice Try!.description: - **OhSINT Quick Challenge Execution**: Leverage theHarvester for initial email and subdomain discovery against the provided target, focusing on non-standard TLDs. Employ gobuster or dirbuster against identified web assets to brute-force hidden directories/files, particularly looking for `.git` repositories or configuration backups indicative of LFI/RFI vectors (exploitation phase placeholder). Systematic Google Dorking (site:target.com filetype:pdf) constitutes primary reconnaissance enhancement over broad automated tools. nmap is reserved only for confirming host reachability post-domain resolution, adhering to OSINT etiquette constraints. (89 words; Tools: theHarvester, gobuster/dirbuster, Google Dorking, nmap (limited); Methodology: Targeted brute-forcing, search operator manipulation, low-impact service enumeration, artifact analysis; Implementation: Iterative refinement of search terms based on initial subdomain findings, directory listing checks for sensitive file exposure.)

Nikto.name: Nikto
Nikto.description: - **Professional Pentesting Learning Path Augmentation**: Integrate Nmap scripting engine (NSE) scripts (e.g., `vuln`, `smb-enum-shares`) immediately following initial host discovery (reconnaissance) to prioritize vulnerability identification over generic port scanning. Enhance enumeration by utilizing specific gobuster/dirbuster wordlists tailored to identified service banners (e.g., `tomcat.txt`, `nginx.txt`), transitioning directly into localized exploitation attempts (Metasploit module targeting confirmed service versions). Post-initial access, employ PowerShell Empire or Cobalt Strike artifacts for covert persistence testing (post-exploitation). (79 words; Tools: nmap (NSE), gobuster/dirbuster (targeted lists), Metasploit, PowerShell Empire/Cobalt Strike; Methodology: Version-specific enumeration, automated vulnerability probing, covert post-exploitation simulation; Implementation: Scripted nmap scans feeding directly into targeted Metasploit listeners.)

NoNameCTF.name: NoNameCTF
NoNameCTF.description: - **Passive DNS Footprinting and Subdomain Takeover Vector Identification**: Utilize theHarvester with multiple sources (virustotal, shodan) configured to extract historical DNS records and associated email addresses for initial target scope definition, bypassing active scanning. Cross-reference extracted subdomains against sublist3r output; probe identified, but unresolving, CNAME targets using nmap's --script dns-brute followed by manual dig queries to confirm dangling DNS entries ripe for CNAME hijacking exploitation against Azure/AWS infrastructure. (106 words; Tools: theHarvester, sublist3r, nmap, dig; Methodology: Reconnaissance (Passive) arrow Enumeration arrow Exploitation Vector Identification; Implementation: Automate subdomain enumeration pipeline, filtering results for NXDOMAIN or CNAME records pointing to non-existent cloud resources; establish control by registering the target domain/subdomain.),Offensive Security Intro

Normal](https://example.com.name: Normal](https://example.com
Normal](https://example.com.description: - **Nmap Scanning Enhancement via Gobuster Integration**: Expand basic nmap port discovery (e.g., TCP SYN scan -sS) by immediately feeding identified open ports (especially 80/443) into gobuster for concurrent web directory enumeration (Methodology: Rapid reconnaissance pivoting). Practical implementation involves scripting the output of nmap -sV against a target subnet to automatically initiate fuzzing/bruteforcing of HTTP services identified, bypassing manual dirbuster initiation; this simulates accelerated initial enumeration post-discovery. (68 words; Tools: nmap, gobuster; Methodology: Reconnaissance-to-Enumeration pivot, automated service/directory correlation; Implementation: Scripted execution chaining nmap output to gobuster input streams.),Nmap: The Basics

Nosqlinjection.name: Nosqlinjection
Nosqlinjection.description: - **NoNameCTF Enumeration Acceleration via Targeted theHarvester Integration**: Augment standard nmap service identification (nmap -sV) by immediately prioritizing theHarvester usage against identified domain names or IP ranges found during initial network sweep to gather external intelligence (emails, subdomains, banners). This reconnaissance step provides high-value seeds for subsequent enumeration attempts, such as inputting discovered subdomains directly into gobuster for hidden path discovery, effectively shortening the typical enumeration timeline inherent in general CTF practice rooms. (71 words; Tools: nmap, theHarvester, gobuster; Methodology: Reconnaissance enrichment feeding enumeration; Implementation: Parallel execution of network scanning (nmap) alongside targeted OSINT collection (theHarvester) to rapidly map attack surface prior to deep exploitation attempts.),NoNameCTF

Osint.name: Osint
Osint.description: - **NoSQL Injection Exploitation Leveraging Mongo-Shell Post-Enumeration**: After initial web service enumeration (gobuster identifying JSON API endpoints), bypass input validation in MongoDB contexts by injecting payload structures like `{"ne":null}` or using type coercion logic directly within the Mongo Shell (mongosh). This technique directly exploits lack of proper input sanitization concerning BSON type handling, transitioning rapidly from basic reconnaissance to direct database structure extraction (e.g., user collection dumps) bypassing traditional SQL pattern matching limitations encountered in standard CTF practice. (68 words; Tools: gobuster, mongosh (or native driver tools); Methodology: Enumeration leading directly to tailored Exploitation via database client interface; Implementation: Identify potential NoSQL source via HTTP response patterns, switch context to mongosh, execute BSON injection payloads against exposed query parameters.),NoSQL injection Basics

OhSINT.name: OhSINT
OhSINT.description: - **OpenCTI STIX/TAXII Ingestion and Vulnerability Correlation Pipeline**: Initial reconnaissance (nmap scan) targeting web infrastructure exposes a vulnerable version of a RESTful API. Gobuster enumerates non-standard endpoints, revealing a JSON endpoint accepting external data feeds. Exploitation involves crafting a STIX 2.1 object (Indicator or Malware) describing the discovered API vulnerability (CVE mapping) and programmatically pushing it into the OpenCTI instance via its TAXII 2.1 server endpoint. The enhancement methodology requires configuring the OpenCTI Graph database to automatically correlate this ingested Indicator against existing Threat Actor profiles, triggering an automated alert based on pre-defined Confidence thresholds. (140 words; Tools: nmap, gobuster, cURL/Python requests library, OpenCTI API client; Methodology: Reconnaissance arrow Enumeration arrow Data Ingestion arrow Automated Correlation; Implementation: API endpoint discovery followed by STIX payload injection for Threat Intel platform population and subsequent automated triage.),OpenCTI

Offensive Pentesting.name: Offensive Pentesting
Offensive Pentesting.description: - **OAuth Authorization Code Interception via Parameter Pollution**: Exploit weak implementation of the redirect_uri validation during the Authorization Code Flow. Utilize Burp Suite Professional to intercept the initial request to the Authorization Server. Manipulate the redirect_uri parameter, often via techniques like URL encoding variations or leveraging implicit trust in endpoint handling, to funnel the ephemeral authorization code to an attacker-controlled endpoint (e.g., a local netcat listener initiated after initial host enumeration with nmap). Subsequent exchange of the captured code for an Access Token (POST request to token endpoint) yields session control. (88 words; Tools: Burp Suite Professional, nmap, netcat; Methodology: Enumeration/Exploitation of redirect_uri validation logic; Implementation: Test for open redirects immediately preceding the OAuth handshake; capture and immediately redeem the auth_code via a simulated client application request.),OAuth Vulnerabilities

OSI Model.name: OSI Model
OSI Model.description: - **Control Flow Flattening and String Polymorphism Evasion**: Implement control flow flattening to disrupt static analysis tools by transforming sequential logic into large switch statements indexed by a state variable, evading simple heuristic detection. Simultaneously employ string polymorphism, encrypting critical strings (API calls, file paths) with custom XOR or RC4 routines that use execution-time derived keys, rendering signature-based detection on payloads harvested via reconnaissance (theHarvester for infrastructure context) ineffective. Post-exploitation, leverage Metasploit encoders against shellcode to further obscure C2 communication signatures, bypassing basic network monitoring. (95 words; Tools: Metasploit, custom packers/unpackers (hypothetical), static analysis tools like IDA Pro for reverse engineering target execution flow; Methodology: Evasion/Malware Understanding via polymorphism and control flow manipulation; Implementation: Develop sample code demonstrating state-machine translation of sequential execution; analyze resulting binary for reduced linear readability.),Obfuscation Principles

Nmap: The Basics.name: Nmap: The Basics
Nmap: The Basics.description: - **Blind SQL Injection with Time-Based Differential Payloads**: Execute blind SQL injection against vulnerable web parameters identified during initial enumeration (gobuster for directory discovery, focusing on non-standard extensions like .bak or .old). Employ highly granular SLEEP(X) payloads, where X varies based on character truth assessment (e.g., SLEEP(0.5) if character is 'a', SLEEP(0.05) otherwise), maximizing extraction precision despite no direct error feedback. Use sqlmap's --technique B (Boolean-based) in conjunction with time-delays for iterative data exfiltration, substituting default nmap scripting for targeted application-layer probing. (104 words; Tools: sqlmap, gobuster, Burp Suite Intruder for request fine-tuning; Methodology: Enumeration arrow Exploitation (Blind Injection); Implementation: Develop a test harness simulating a time-sensitive backend database; craft payload sequences to extract a single character from a known table name character-by-character.),Obscure

NoSQL injection Basics.name: NoSQL injection Basics
NoSQL injection Basics.description: - **Apache Version Enumeration via Server Header and Directory Traversal Exploitation**: Employ nmap's http-headers script to precisely determine Apache minor version; correlate version fingerprint against known CVE databases (e.g., Exploit-DB). Subsequently, use gobuster with a specialized dictionary (SecLists/Discovery/Web-Content/apache-webdav.txt) targeting WebDAV directives. If WebDAV is exposed, attempt PUT requests directly, or exploit identified path traversal flaws (../..) within application logic to upload a shell payload via nc or direct HTTP request, bypassing standard file extension restrictions. (108 words; Tools: nmap, gobuster, nc, Exploit-DB; Methodology: Enumeration (Service Versioning) arrow Vulnerability Mapping arrow Exploitation (File Upload/Traversal); Implementation: Fingerprint server, pivot to known vulnerability, test traversal using common directory paths combined with shell injection syntax.),Oh My WebServer

NTFS Analysis.name: NTFS Analysis
NTFS Analysis.description: - **Automated Subdomain Harvesting and Mail Exchange Probing**: Initiate reconnaissance using theHarvester targeting common search engines (Google, Bing) and PGP key servers, explicitly requesting -d domain and -l limit flags to maximize yield of email addresses (user@target.com). Pipe output to sublist3r for parallel, brute-forced subdomain enumeration. Subsequently, utilize dnsrecon with the harvested subdomains, specifying the -t mx option to extract Mail eXchange records, facilitating target identification for subsequent phishing or SMTP enumeration testing. (114 words; Tools: theHarvester, sublist3r, dnsrecon; Methodology: Reconnaissance (Automated Harvesting) arrow Enumeration (MX Records); Implementation: Run theHarvester for emails/subdomains, feed raw subdomain list into sublist3r, validate MX records using dnsrecon for mail server identification.),OhSINT

OAuth Vulnerabilities.name: OAuth Vulnerabilities
OAuth Vulnerabilities.description: - **Initial Service Discovery and Directory Brute-Forcing**: Execute comprehensive nmap scan (nmap -sC -sV -p- 10.10.X.X) to fingerprint all open ports and service versions. Based on HTTP/HTTPS responses (port 80/443), deploy gobuster (gobuster dir -u http://target:80 -w /usr/share/wordlists/dirbuster/directory-list-2.3-medium.txt -x html,php,bak) for rapid directory and file enumeration, specifically targeting common configuration or backup file extensions to uncover hidden web application components prerequisite for initial exploitation vector identification. (108 words; Tools: nmap, gobuster; Methodology: Reconnaissance arrow Enumeration (Port Scanning/Fuzzing); Implementation: Full port scan via nmap, pipe results to gobuster using a standard dictionary for path discovery.),Ollie

Obfuscation Principles.name: Obfuscation Principles
Obfuscation Principles.description: - **Mythological Web Enumeration and Credential Harvesting**: Following initial nmap discovery revealing HTTP service, employ gobuster with Olympus-themed wordlists (e.g., "gods," "hades," "temple") to locate hidden directories.
