If credentials are suspected (e.g., 'admin' login), utilize theHarvester (theHarvester -d olympus.thm -b all) targeting SRV and PE records, searching for leaked email addresses (user@olympus.thm) to craft brute-force payloads against the enumerated login portal found via directory traversal. (108 words; Tools: nmap, gobuster, theHarvester; Methodology: Enumeration arrow Information Gathering arrow Credential Testing; Implementation: Dictionary attack preparation using reconnaissance data against identified web interfaces.),Olympus
Obfuscation Principles.user_opinions: Important for both offense and defense

Obscure.name: Obscure
Obscure.description: - **Terraform State File Discovery and Kubeconfig Extraction in Hybrid Infrastructure**: After initial nmap sweep identifies exposed Git repository endpoints or misconfigured S3 buckets (hybrid cloud exposure), employ tfsec or checkov against downloaded Terraform plans (.tf files) to map on-premises and cloud resource dependencies. Focus enumeration (gobuster) on CI/CD artifacts (Jenkins directories, .git remnants) for sensitive configuration files. Exploit overly permissive IAM roles or local Kubeconfig files cached during IaC deployment, providing direct access to container orchestration layers (Kubernetes) running within the private network segment. (115 words; Tools: nmap, gobuster, tfsec, checkov; Methodology: Reconnaissance arrow Static IaC Analysis arrow Access Escalation; Implementation: Static code auditing for hardcoded secrets followed by lateral movement leveraging harvested cluster credentials.),On-Premises IaC

Offensive Security Intro.name: Offensive Security Intro
Offensive Security Intro.description: - **Marine Cipher Decryption via Luffy's Gear Mechanics and Haki Enumeration**: Initial web port scan (nmap) targets a web service mimicking the Marine HQ portal. Directory brute-forcing (gobuster) with a custom wordlist derived from One Piece character names reveals an endpoint named `/bounty_list.php`. Exploitation hinges on identifying an SQL Injection vulnerability disguised as a request for a specific "Devil Fruit power level." The challenge mandates using theHarvester against known World Government domains to find email formats, which, when combined with specific Haki-related numeric sequences derived from Luffy's Gear progression (e.g., Gear Second = 2, Gear Third = 3), form the payload to leak the Poneglyph flag. (128 words; Tools: nmap, gobuster, theHarvester, sqlmap; Methodology: Reconnaissance arrow Enumeration arrow Injection Exploitation; Implementation: Input validation bypass using themed numerical/textual context to extract hidden database entries.),One Piece

Oh My WebServer.name: Oh My WebServer
Oh My WebServer.description: - **Opacity Image Layer Extraction via LSB Analysis and Metadata Carving**: Target HTTP service enumeration (nmap TCP 80/443) precedes deep file analysis. Reconnaissance identifies a seemingly innocuous .png asset related to the room's "opacity" theme. Initial inspection with binwalk reveals embedded compressed data. Subsequent steganography exploitation involves applying Stegsolve to cycle through Least Significant Bit (LSB) planes, specifically targeting the blue channel where hidden data is masked. Further extraction requires leveraging ExifTool on the image metadata to unmask a Base64 string concatenated across multiple Chroma subsampling offsets, which decodes directly to a user credential pair for the SSH service identified in the initial scan. (133 words; Tools: nmap, binwalk, Stegsolve, ExifTool; Methodology: Reconnaissance arrow Forensic Analysis arrow Data Carving/Decoding; Implementation: LSB plane shifting to reveal encoded payload, followed by metadata parsing for authentication credentials.),Opacity

Ollie.name: Ollie
Ollie.description: - **OpenVAS Authenticated Scan Integration with Asset Inventory**: Initial reconnaissance (nmap SYN scan) identifies open SMB ports. TheHarvester scrapes external emails, yielding potential service account credentials (user:pass). These credentials are used to configure an Authenticated Scan profile within the OpenVAS Greenbone Security Manager (GSM). The GSM then executes a deep, credentialed NVT check against identified Windows assets. Enhancement involves scripting the export of low/medium CVSS scores from the OpenVAS XML report, transforming the data into LDAP update statements, and bulk-applying patch status flags directly to an internal CMDB (Configuration Management Database) for remediation tracking, bypassing manual report parsing. (151 words; Tools: nmap, TheHarvester, OpenVAS GSM, XML parser/scripting (Python), LDAP client; Methodology: Reconnaissance arrow Credential Gathering arrow Authenticated Scanning arrow Automated Remediation Data Synchronization; Implementation: Credentialed scan configuration followed by report transformation for CMDB integration.),OpenVAS

Olympus.name: Olympus
Olympus.description: - **OpenVPN Certificate Authority (CA) Enumeration and Key Extraction**: Initial nmap UDP scan targeting the OpenVPN port (default 1194). Successful identification allows for gobuster or custom scripting against the configuration file directory if accessible via a mounted share or SMB vulnerability. The primary technique involves reverse-engineering the PKI structure. Using Easy-RSA tools (./pkitool or direct openssl commands), extract the server.crt, server.key, and ca.crt. Enhancement: Once the CA is secured, enumerate weak client configurations by searching configuration files for cipher BF-CBC or auth SHA1. Force re-keying intervals below 60 seconds on the server to degrade potential session hijacking chances, documented via a PowerShell script targeting the OpenVPN service configuration parameters. (163 words; Tools: nmap, gobuster, openssl, Easy-RSA scripts, PowerShell; Methodology: Reconnaissance arrow Port Identification arrow Key Extraction arrow Configuration Hardening; Implementation: Extract server keys, analyze cipher suite, deploy automated re-key enforcement.),OpenVPN

On-Premises IaC.name: On-Premises IaC
On-Premises IaC.description: - **System Hardening via CIS Benchmarks Implementation**: Initial nmap SYN scan (-sS) to map open ports; subsequent TCP wrapper review for unauthorized services. Enumeration phase involves running Lynis or OpenSCAP against the target OS to generate a compliance report detailing misconfigurations, specifically focusing on SUDO timeout settings and SSHd protocol 2 enforcement. Enhancement methodology: Implement least privilege model by auditing SUDOers file entries, removing NOPASSWD directives where granular command execution is not strictly required. Exploitation prevention involves deploying SELinux or AppArmor profiles tuned via auditd logs analysis, restricting unnecessary kernel module loading. Practical step: Disable unneeded kernel modules using modprobe -r after verification via lsmod. (175 words; Tools: nmap, Lynis, OpenSCAP, auditd, modprobe; Methodology: Reconnaissance arrow Compliance Scanning arrow Policy Enforcement arrow Access Control Refinement; Implementation: Audit SUDO, enforce SELinux, blacklist vulnerable kernel modules.),Operating System Security

One Piece.name: One Piece
One Piece.description: - **Oracle 9i Advanced Exploitation Vector Chain**: Initial nmap service detection reveals TNS listener on 1521. Enumeration proceeds with tnscmd or Odad scanner to fingerprint DB version and running schemas. Advanced technique involves leveraging UTL_HTTP or JAVA stored procedures post-initial SQLi (UNION-based or blind). Exploitation targets the DBA role, potentially utilizing ORA_HASH flaws or weak XDB credentials found via theHarvester searching for internal developer emails containing hardcoded passwords. Enhancement methodology: If direct shell upload fails, pivot to OS command execution via DBMS_SCHEDULER job creation, executing a reverse shell payload compiled for the underlying Linux/Windows target architecture. Practical implementation: Utilize sqlmap with custom payloads targeting DBMS_SCHEDULER functions; post-exploitation involves privilege escalation on the OS layer, potentially exploiting vulnerable Oracle CPU patches or insecure directory permissions for configuration files. (187 words; Tools: nmap, tnscmd, Odad, sqlmap, theHarvester; Methodology: Service Discovery arrow Version Fingerprinting arrow Stored Procedure Abuse arrow OS Command Execution; Implementation: TNS tuning, custom SQLi payloads, DBMS_SCHEDULER pivoting.),Oracle 9

Opacity.name: Opacity
Opacity.description: - **API3 Broken Object Level Authorization (BOLA) Exploitation Chain**: Initial reconnaissance focuses on identifying all exposed REST endpoints via static analysis of documentation (Swagger/OpenAPI specs often found via gobuster brute-forcing paths like `/api/v1/docs`). Enumeration confirms supported HTTP verbs and parameter structures. Exploitation technique involves systematically swapping authenticated user identifiers (e.g., changing `user_id=123` to `user_id=456` in path or body parameters) to bypass BOLA restrictions, accessing unauthorized resources or altering other users' data. Enhancement methodology: For API1 (Broken Authentication), target JWT validation weaknesses; use Burp Suite Intruder to test for missing or weak signature verification, attempting null or HS256 to none algorithm switching. Practical implementation: Craft payloads to test mass assignment vulnerabilities (API4), injecting extra fields into POST/PUT requests, leveraging missing property checks to elevate user privileges or change roles. Tools utilized: Burp Suite Pro (Sequencer, Intruder), curl, jq for JSON manipulation. (212 words; Tools: gobuster, Burp Suite, curl, jq; Methodology: Endpoint Discovery arrow IDOR Forcing arrow Token Tampering arrow Mass Assignment; Implementation: JWT alg:none injection, parameter fuzzing.),OWASP API Security Top 10

OpenCTI.name: OpenCTI
OpenCTI.description: - **Horizontal Privilege Escalation (BACL) via IDOR (API3 Overlap)**: Reconnaissance initiates with nmap service scanning (top ports) followed by gobuster using specialized wordlists targeting API resource paths (e.g., `/api/v2/users/*`, `/api/v2/documents/{id}`). Enumeration confirms the existence of unique resource identifiers (e.g., UUIDs, sequential integers) accessible via valid user session tokens obtained via theHarvester on exposed domains. Exploitation involves direct modification of the target resource ID within the URL path or request body (Burp Repeater) to sequentially access or modify records belonging to other authenticated users. Enhancement methodology: Systematically test for Vertical BACL by attempting to access administrative endpoints (e.g., `/admin/settings`) using standard low-privilege tokens; if denied, attempt token swapping with known admin tokens (if leaked) or token brute-forcing techniques focusing on token structure modification (e.g., changing `role:user` to `role:admin` in decoded JWT payload *before* re-signing if the server uses weak signing keys or accepts algorithm downgrade). Practical implementation: Use ffuf to fuzz resource ID fields with sequences (`1..100`) while monitoring HTTP status codes (200 indicates success/BACL bypass). Tools: nmap, gobuster, theHarvester, Burp Suite, ffuf. (224 words; Tools: nmap, gobuster, theHarvester, Burp Suite, ffuf; Methodology: Service Discovery arrow Resource ID Fuzzing arrow Vertical Endpoint Probing; Implementation: Status code analysis against sequenced ID requests.),OWASP Broken Access Control

OpenVAS.name: OpenVAS
OpenVAS.description: - **Injection Vulnerabilities (SQLi, NoSQLi) via Parameter Fuzzing (A03 Overlap)**: Reconnaissance involves initial nmap scans targeting common web server ports (80, 443, 8080) to identify the running application framework. Gobuster (using a OWASP-specific directory list) probes for hidden administrative interfaces or backup files (e.g., git directories, .env files). Enumeration focuses on identifying input vectors susceptible to injection, particularly search bars, login forms, and URL parameters containing database-interacting identifiers. Exploitation of SQLi is achieved by injecting standard time-based payloads (`' OR 1=SLEEP(5)--`) into relevant parameters using Burp Suite Intruder to confirm blind injection presence. Enhancement methodology: For NoSQLi (MongoDB context often found in modern apps), replace expected string inputs with \ne or \gt operators in the request body (tested via Postman or Burp Repeater) to bypass authentication or retrieve all records (db.collection.find({user:{\ne:null}})). Practical implementation: After identifying a vulnerable parameter, transition from basic payloads to using sqlmap for automated data exfiltration, ensuring proxy settings correctly route traffic through sqlmap to maintain the active session cookie identified during initial enumeration. Tools: nmap, gobuster, Burp Suite (Intruder, Repeater), sqlmap, Postman. (229 words; Tools: nmap, gobuster, Burp Suite, sqlmap, Postman; Methodology: Port Scanning arrow Directory Bruteforcing arrow Injection Payload Fuzzing arrow Automated Exfiltration; Implementation: Time-based SQLi confirmation followed by NoSQLi operator substitution.),OWASP Juice Shop

OpenVPN.name: OpenVPN
OpenVPN.description: - **Broken Access Control (IDOR/BOLA) Exploitation (A01 Focus)**: Reconnaissance commences with deep nmap scans (-sV, -p- to map all ports) followed by theHarvester targeting subdomains associated with the target IP range (using Shodan or DNSdumpster initial seeds). Enumeration involves using gobuster (using SecLists Discovery/Web-Content wordlists) against identified virtual hosts to locate hidden API endpoints (/api/v1/users, /admin). Exploitation targets parameter manipulation in GET or POST requests (tracked via Burp Proxy) where an object identifier (userID=123) is replaced with an adjacent or predictable ID (userID=124) to access unauthorized resources or functionality. Enhancement methodology: Vertical privilege escalation (standard user to admin) is tested by modifying JWT claims (using Burp JWT Editor) after initial base64 decoding and re-encoding (HS256 algorithm check). Practical implementation: Once an IDOR vector is confirmed, script the brute-force attempt using Burp Intruder against the parameter range, filtering HTTP responses for status code 200 or significant content length changes indicating successful unauthorized access. Tools: nmap, theHarvester, gobuster, Burp Suite (Proxy, Intruder, JWT Editor). (218 words; Tools: nmap, theHarvester, gobuster, Burp Suite; Methodology: Subdomain Discovery arrow API Endpoint Fuzzing arrow Parameter Manipulation arrow JWT Tampering; Implementation: ID enumeration via Intruder status code analysis.),OWASP Top 10

Operating System Security.name: Operating System Security
Operating System Security.description: - **Injection (SQLi/Command Injection) Exploitation (A03 Focus 2021)**: Reconnaissance employs nmap -sU (UDP scan) alongside standard TCP sweeps to map service exposure. Enumeration utilizes dirbuster (using a comprehensive directory list like Wolf SSL list) against identified web servers (port 8080/443), specifically targeting input fields or URL parameters prone to injection vectors. Exploitation phase involves using SQLmap (automatically detecting POST/GET parameters via -u flag or --forms-inline) to extract schema information (--dbs, --current-user) from backend databases, bypassing parameterized queries. Command Injection testing (via Burp Repeater) uses bash command chaining operators (;, ||, &&) appended to user input (e.g., ping 127.0.0.1; whoami) to confirm OS command execution. Enhancement methodology: Bypassing WAFs (Web Application Firewalls) requires payload encoding (URL encoding double encoding or hex encoding) or utilizing alternative SQL syntax (e.g., UNION SELECT NULL variants) not matched by signature-based detection. Practical implementation: Execute SQLmap with the --risk=3 --level=5 flags to aggressively test all injection types (time-based, boolean-based). Tools: nmap, dirbuster, SQLmap, Burp Suite (Repeater). (207 words; Tools: nmap, dirbuster, SQLmap, Burp Suite; Methodology: Service Mapping arrow Input Vector Identification arrow Automated DB Extraction arrow WAF Bypass Techniques; Implementation: Aggressive SQLmap scanning with advanced risk levels.),OWASP Top 10 - 2021

Oracle 9.name: Oracle 9
Oracle 9.description: - **Broken Access Control (IDOR/Privilege Escalation) via Internal API Endpoints (A01 Contextual Shift)**: Reconnaissance focuses on OpenStreetMap (OSM) data harvesting (Overpass API querying) to map infrastructure; theHarvester may be used to find subdomains hosting internal management interfaces. Enumeration involves gobuster with a custom wordlist specifically tuned for JSON/XML API routes (/api/v1/users, /admin/config) on non-standard ports identified by nmap -p-. Exploitation centers on manipulating user ID parameters or token scopes (JWT manipulation if present) to access other users' password manager data (e.g., changing user_id=1001 to user_id=1002 in a GET request). Enhancement methodology: If passwords are stored, test for weak hashing algorithms (MD5 or unsalted SHA1) identified during initial enumeration or data dump (via SQLi on a dependent service not the primary target). Practical implementation: Use Burp Intruder to brute-force sequential user IDs against a sensitive API endpoint while monitoring HTTP response codes (looking for 200 OK or differing lengths vs a known unauthorized ID). Tools: Overpass API, nmap, gobuster, theHarvester, Burp Intruder. (215 words; Tools: Overpass API, nmap, gobuster, theHarvester, Burp Intruder; Methodology: OSM Mapping arrow API Endpoint Discovery arrow Parameter Fuzzing arrow Hash Cracking; Implementation: Sequential ID brute-forcing using Intruder to discover unrestricted access to credential stores.),Overpass

OWASP API Security Top 10.name: OWASP API Security Top 10
OWASP API Security Top 10.description: - **Post-Exploitation Forensics on Compromised OSM Server (Log Tampering Detection)**: Reconnaissance shifts to identifying persistence mechanisms after initial web exploitation (likely via a vulnerable service running on the Overpass instance). Enumeration involves using nmap scans to map running processes (netstat or lsof commands executed post-shell) and locating OSM database directories (e.g., PostgreSQL data paths). IR methodology requires dumping critical system logs (auth.log, syslog, web server access logs) using tools like dc3dd or dd to create forensic images for offline analysis. Exploitation enhancement involves searching the dumped logs with grep or Volatility plugins to detect specific command execution or unusual Overpass API query patterns that preceded the incident. Practical implementation: Mount the disk image read-only, search for files modified after the initial compromise timestamp, and use theHarvester on internal network data harvested from the server to map data exfiltration targets. Tools: nmap, dc3dd/dd, Volatility Framework, grep, theHarvester. (227 words; Tools: nmap, dc3dd/dd, Volatility Framework, grep, theHarvester; Methodology: Process Listing arrow Disk Imaging arrow Log Analysis arrow Exfiltration Path Mapping; Implementation: Read-only forensic imaging followed by Volatility memory analysis and time-lining of log artifacts).,Overpass 2 - Hacked

OWASP Broken Access Control.name: OWASP Broken Access Control
OWASP Broken Access Control.description: - **Targeted Web Exploitation of Custom Hosting Panel**: Initial nmap scans reveal HTTP/S ports (80, 443, 8080) likely serving a custom hosting interface. Reconnaissance employs gobuster or dirbuster with OWASP Top 10 wordlists to identify administrative endpoints (e.g., /admin, /cpanel, /login). Enumeration focuses on identifying vulnerabilities specific to server-side scripting languages used in the hosting logic (PHP function exposure or improper input validation). Exploitation involves attempting Remote File Inclusion (RFI) or command injection (Shell Shock analogues) via URL parameters or POST data to achieve remote code execution (RCE). Enhancement methodology includes using theHarvester on the identified hosting domain to discover subdomains or associated emails, potentially revealing credentials for less protected services. Practical implementation: Use Burp Suite Intruder to fuzz all input fields with shell payloads (e.g., id=`whoami` or payload='nc -e /bin/bash LHOST LPORT' in a parameter). Tools: nmap, gobuster, dirbuster, Burp Suite, theHarvester. (230 words; Tools: nmap, gobuster, dirbuster, Burp Suite, theHarvester; Methodology: Port Scanning arrow Directory Bruteforcing arrow Input Fuzzing arrow RCE Payload Injection; Implementation: Systematic testing of all GET/POST inputs for command execution vulnerabilities).,Overpass 3 - Hosting

OWASP Juice Shop.name: OWASP Juice Shop
OWASP Juice Shop.description: - **Deep Network Forensics via PCAP Inspection**: Analysis commences with Wireshark to filter captured traffic (PCAP file) using display filters like `http or ftp or smb` to isolate relevant protocol layers. Reconnaissance phase involves identifying the source and destination IPs and ports using statistics menus (Endpoint List or Conversations). Enumeration focuses on following TCP streams to extract unencrypted credentials (e.g., Base64 decoded login data) or hidden files sent over FTP or SMB. Exploitation analog involves reconstructing data transferred using Wireshark's Export Objects functionality (HTTP) to recover stolen files or malicious code injected within protocol payloads. Enhancement methodology includes leveraging Tshark (command-line Wireshark) for automated extraction of all DNS queries to map out external C2 infrastructure not immediately obvious in the GUI. Practical implementation: Apply IO graph to detect unusual throughput spikes indicating exfiltration, then use `tshark -r capture.pcap -Y "ftp.request" -T fields -e ftp.request.command` to log all FTP commands. Tools: Wireshark, Tshark. (279 words; Tools: Wireshark, Tshark; Methodology: Protocol Filtering arrow Stream Reconstruction arrow Object Export arrow Automated Query Extraction; Implementation: Filtering by specific protocol and analyzing data within TCP sessions).,Packet Analysis

OWASP Top 10.name: OWASP Top 10
OWASP Top 10.description: - **Layer 2 Frame Structure Analysis via PCAP**: Focus on Ethernet II frames inspection in Wireshark to identify MAC addresses (Source and Destination) within the Data Link Layer (L2). Reconnaissance involves examining ARP requests and replies using the `arp` display filter to map IP-to-MAC resolutions on the local subnet. Enumeration requires understanding VLAN tagging if present (802.1Q header identification) to determine which logical network segment the traffic originated from or is destined for. Exploitation analog involves crafting spoofed frames using Scapy to test L2 security posture, e.g., sending gratuitous ARP replies for Man-in-the-Middle (MITM) attacks. Enhancement methodology incorporates using Tshark to programmatically extract all source MAC addresses from a large PCAP file via `tshark -r capture.pcap -T fields -e eth.src | sort | uniq` to build a host inventory. Practical implementation includes setting Wireshark column preferences to display Frame Length and Protocol type for quick identification of oversized (Jumbo Frame potential) or malformed L2 packets. Tools: Wireshark, Tshark, Scapy. (299 words; Tools: Wireshark, Tshark, Scapy; Methodology: Frame Field Isolation arrow Address Resolution Inspection arrow Protocol Header Identification arrow Packet Crafting; Implementation: Visualizing L2 headers and scripting MAC address extraction).,Packets & Frames

OWASP Top 10 - 2021.name: OWASP Top 10 - 2021
OWASP Top 10 - 2021.description: - **Web Application Enumeration via Directory Bruteforcing**: Initial reconnaissance using nmap (e.g., `nmap -sV -sC <target>`) to discover open ports and service versions on the PalsForLife server. Systematic enumeration of the web application involves directory bruteforcing with gobuster or dirbuster (e.g., `gobuster dir -u http://<target> -w common.txt -x php,html`) to locate hidden endpoints or administrative panels. Exploitation focuses on identifying vulnerabilities such as Local File Inclusion (LFI) or SQL Injection (SQLi) within application parameters suggested by the application theme. Practical steps include using Burp Suite to intercept and modify HTTP requests when testing for IDOR (Insecure Direct Object Reference) by incrementally changing user IDs in the URL or POST data to access other user profiles (the "Pals" data). Enhancement methodology involves leveraging theHarvester to gather external intelligence on the target domain to uncover subdomains and email addresses that might reveal user credentials or internal structure. Tools: nmap, gobuster, dirbuster, Burp Suite, theHarvester. (301 words; Tools: nmap, gobuster, dirbuster, Burp Suite, theHarvester; Methodology: Service Detection arrow Path Discovery arrow Parameter Fuzzing arrow Credential Harvesting; Implementation: Iterative HTTP request manipulation to bypass authorization logic).,PalsForLife

Overpass.name: Overpass
Overpass.description: - **Passive OSINT and Domain Discovery**: Initial reconnaissance focuses on passive data collection avoiding direct host interaction. TheHarvester is executed against the target domain (e.g., `theHarvester -d target.thm -b all -l 500`) to scrape publicly available data from search engines and PaaS providers for subdomains, email addresses, and hostnames. Shodan queries are performed passively using specific banner signatures or port signatures identified in prior OSINT stages to map the network footprint without generating direct traffic. Enhancement methodology involves leveraging DNS history tools like SecurityTrails or viewdns to retrieve historical IP address records and Zone Transfers if misconfigured (though Zone Transfer is active enumeration). Practical steps require aggregating discovered hostnames and running passive security checks against them using cortex or similar frameworks to identify low-hanging fruit before initiating active enumeration like nmap or gobuster. Tools: theHarvester, Shodan CLI/Web, SecurityTrails API interface, Cortex. (319 words; Tools: theHarvester, Shodan, SecurityTrails, Cortex; Methodology: Data Aggregation arrow Historical Record Analysis arrow Passive Footprinting; Implementation: Automated scraping via API calls to external databases).,Passive Reconnaissance

Overpass 2 - Hacked.name: Overpass 2 - Hacked
Overpass 2 - Hacked.description: - **Active Credential Testing and Weak Password Enumeration**: After initial service enumeration (e.g., nmap identifying SSH, FTP, or SMB ports), credential attacks commence. Hydra is the primary tool for brute-forcing identified services (e.g., `hydra -l userlist.txt -P passlist.txt ssh target.thm -t 4`) using custom or pre-compiled wordlists like rockyou.txt. Enhancement methodology involves implementing dictionary attacks specifically targeting common default credentials for specific vendor software identified during service fingerprinting (e.g., admin/admin for default web interfaces discovered via gobuster). For web login portals, Burp Suite Intruder is utilized to systematically test login forms against credential sets. Practical implementation requires rate-limiting tests to avoid account lockouts or firewall detection, often achieved by modifying Hydra's connection timing parameters. Tools: Hydra, Burp Suite Intruder, nmap (for service ID), rockyou.txt (wordlist). (324 words; Tools: Hydra, Burp Suite, nmap, rockyou.txt; Methodology: Service ID arrow Dictionary Attack arrow Credential Testing; Implementation: Service-specific wordlists and rate-limiting configuration within brute-force tooling).,Password Attacks

Overpass 3 - Hosting.name: Overpass 3 - Hosting
Overpass 3 - Hosting.description: - **Hash Acquisition and Offline Cracking via GPU Acceleration**: Post-exploitation hash dump retrieval (e.g., mimikatz for LSASS memory or shadow file access on Linux) is followed by hash identification (e.g., SHA-512, NTLMv2). John the Ripper (JTR) or Hashcat are employed for offline cracking. Hashcat is mandated for advanced performance utilizing GPU compute power (e.g., hashcat -m 1800 hashes.txt wordlist.txt --force --gpu-temp-disable). Enhancement involves hybrid attacks combining dictionary words with rule-based mutations (e.g., Hashcat rules like best64.rule) to circumvent simple append or prepend modifications. Practical implementation requires correct hash mode (-m flag) selection based on hashcat documentation and ensuring sufficient memory and VRAM for large datasets or complex masks. Tools: Hashcat, John the Ripper, mimikatz. (321 words; Tools: Hashcat, JTR, mimikatz; Methodology: Hash Acquisition arrow Hash Mode Selection arrow GPU-Accelerated Cracking; Implementation: Rule-based hybrid cracking with GPU optimization).,Password Cracking

Packet Analysis.name: Packet Analysis
Packet Analysis.description: - **Service Enumeration and Brute-Force Authentication Testing**: Initial reconnaissance using nmap identifies open ports and banner information (e.g., TCP/21 FTP, TCP/22 SSH, TCP/3389 RDP). Web enumeration via gobuster or dirbuster searches for login portals (e.g., /login.php, /admin). Exploitation involves dictionary attacks against identified services. Hydra is utilized for parallelized brute-forcing against various protocols (e.g., hydra -L users.txt -P pass.txt ssh ://target). Enhancement requires password spraying (using a small set of common passwords across many user accounts) to avoid account lockout mechanisms during enumeration. TheHarvester supplements recon by gathering potential usernames from OSINT sources. Practical implementation focuses on identifying weak default credentials or passwords reused from past breaches. Tools: nmap, gobuster, Hydra, theHarvester. (316 words; Tools: nmap, gobuster, Hydra, theHarvester; Methodology: Reconnaissance arrow Enumeration arrow Brute-Force Exploitation; Implementation: Protocol-specific credential testing with password spraying mitigation).,Passwords

Packets & Frames.name: Packets & Frames
Packets & Frames.description: - **Web Application Reconnaissance and Parameter Manipulation for Password Reset Exploitation**: Initial reconnaissance using nmap verifies HTTP/HTTPS service availability (TCP/80, TCP/443). Gobuster or dirbuster enumerate hidden directories and entry points like /forgotpassword or /reset. Exploitation targets the password reset workflow, often involving token enumeration (e.g., sequential ID in the reset URL or POST request) or insecure direct object reference (IDOR). Burp Suite is essential for intercepting, modifying, and replaying the password reset token generation or validation requests. Enhancement methodology includes checking if the reset token is sent via email only (leading to potential email header manipulation or session hijacking if the token is predictable). Practical steps focus on testing for vulnerabilities like no token validation or predictable random token generation after initial request. Tools: nmap, gobuster, Burp Suite. (301 words; Tools: nmap, gobuster, Burp Suite; Methodology: Reconnaissance arrow Enumeration arrow Token Manipulation/IDOR Exploitation; Implementation: Intercepting and modifying POST requests in the reset chain).,PaSsWoRd ReSeTtEr

PalsForLife.name: PalsForLife
PalsForLife.description: - **Endpoint Reconnaissance and Log Analysis for Indicators of Compromise (IoCs)**: Initial network enumeration using nmap identifies open ports (e.g., TCP/22, TCP/80, TCP/445) on the Paul Hunt target system. TheHarvester or OSINT techniques gather potential user identifiers or hostnames. Threat hunting methodology prioritizes log analysis (e.g., Sysmon, Windows Event Logs, web server access logs) for IoCs like suspicious process creation (Event ID 4688) or unusual network connections. Practical implementation involves querying logs (e.g., using PowerShell or Sysinternals Suite) to detect post-exploitation activity, such as persistence mechanisms or lateral movement attempts. Enhancement involves cross-referencing discovered IoCs against MITRE ATT&CK framework techniques to map the adversary's TTPs. Tools: nmap, theHarvester, Sysinternals Suite. (305 words; Tools: nmap, theHarvester, Sysinternals Suite; Methodology: Reconnaissance arrow IoC Discovery arrow Log Forensics and TTP Mapping; Implementation: Searching Windows Event Logs for anomalous process execution).,Paul Hunt

Passive Reconnaissance.name: Passive Reconnaissance
Passive Reconnaissance.description: - **Automated Asset Discovery and Directory Enumeration via Bookmark Verification**: Reconnaissance phase leverages bookmarks to prioritize targets. Initial host discovery is followed by automated web enumeration using gobuster (or dirbuster) with a comprehensive wordlist (e.g., SecLists/Discovery/Web Content/common.txt) to locate hidden directories or administrative panels on discovered HTTP services. The enhancement methodology integrates tool output (status codes 200, 301, 403) from gobuster into a centralized Markdown document for exploitation preparation. Practical implementation involves piping nmap scripting engine (NSE) results for version detection directly into the resource list to identify known vulnerabilities associated with specific software versions. Tools: gobuster, dirbuster, nmap (NSE), OWASP ZAP (for initial passive scan). (309 words; Tools: gobuster, dirbuster, nmap (NSE), OWASP ZAP; Methodology: Reconnaissance arrow Automated Enumeration arrow Vulnerability Mapping; Implementation: Executing gobuster against target ports and logging all 301/403 endpoints).,Pentest Bookmarks

Password Attacks.name: Password Attacks
Password Attacks.description: - **Foundational Information Gathering and Service Fingerprinting via Systematic Scanning**: Initial reconnaissance mandates comprehensive port scanning using nmap (SYN scan -sS or TCP Connect scan -sT) against target IPs to identify open ports and service versions (nmap -sV). This is followed by passive enumeration using theHarvester to scrape emails and subdomains from public sources (e.g., search engines, SSL certs). Active enumeration involves running gobuster on identified HTTP/S ports (ports 80/443) with a standard directory brute-forcing wordlist (e.g., CommonCrawl based) to discover web application endpoints. Enhancement methodology focuses on mapping nmap script output (e.g., http-enum scripts) directly to potential exploitation vectors (e.g., identifying outdated web server software for Metasploit module selection). Practical implementation requires strict adherence to the pentesting methodology phases before any attempted exploitation (e.g., no exploitation before full enumeration). Tools: nmap, gobuster, theHarvester. (307 words; Tools: nmap, gobuster, theHarvester; Methodology: Reconnaissance arrow Service Identification arrow Web Enumeration; Implementation: Sequential execution of nmap -sV followed by gobuster on open ports).,Pentesting Fundamentals

Password Cracking.name: Password Cracking
Password Cracking.description: - **Post-Exploitation Techniques for Maintaining Access and Detection Evasion**: Persistence implementation on Windows targets involves modifying Registry Run Keys (HKLM/Software/Microsoft/Windows/CurrentVersion/Run) or creating scheduled tasks (schtasks /create or using PowerShell cmdlets) to execute a payload (e.g., reverse shell listener stager). Linux persistence often requires modifying crontab entries (via crontab -e or placing scripts in /etc/cron.d/) or injecting into system startup scripts (e.g., rc.local). Detection methodology for Blue Teams requires monitoring system event logs (Windows Event ID 4688 for process creation, Registry key changes) and using Sysmon to track unusual process behavior or file write locations. Enhancement involves obfuscating payloads to bypass basic signature detection before establishing the persistence mechanism. Practical implementation steps include: 1. Upload staged binary. 2. Execute command to create the persistence entry. 3. Verify successful re-connection after reboot or task trigger. Tools: schtasks, Metasploit framework (for meterpreter payloads), Sysmon. (314 words; Tools: schtasks, Metasploit, Sysmon; Methodology: Persistence Installation vs. Log/Behavioral Monitoring; Implementation: Registry/Cron modification followed by validation).,Persistence

Passwords.name: Passwords
Passwords.description: - **Social Engineering via Email Phishing Attack Vector and Defensive Analysis**: Phishing implementation requires initial reconnaissance using theHarvester or OSINT techniques to gather employee email formats and domain details. Next, setup a look-alike domain and spoof sender headers (e.g., SPF/DKIM bypass or misconfiguration exploitation) to deliver the malicious payload (e.g., credential harvesting HTML page hosted via a basic web server setup). Blue Team detection focuses on analyzing email metadata (Received headers, IP reputation) and URL sandboxing using tools like URLScan or internal mail gateway logs. Enhancement involves spear-phishing with contextually aware attachments or links tailored from recon data. Practical steps include: 1. Register typosquatting domain. 2. Craft deceptive email content. 3. Monitor landing page access logs. Tools: theHarvester, SPF checkers, web server for hosting payload. (316 words; Tools: theHarvester, SPF checkers, web server; Methodology: OSINT Recon, Header Spoofing, Credential Harvesting; Implementation: Domain registration, content crafting, log monitoring).,Phishing

PaSsWoRd ReSeTtEr.name: PaSsWoRd ReSeTtEr
PaSsWoRd ReSeTtEr.description: - **Phishing Email Forensic Analysis Workflow for SOC Incident Response**: Initial triage involves extracting full headers from the MUA (Mail User Agent) to verify SPF, DKIM, and DMARC policy outcomes against sending domain. Payload analysis requires static inspection of embedded URLs using online scanners or local sandboxing (e.g., Cuckoo Sandbox) to detect redirection chains or credential capture scripts. Infrastructure mapping uses WHOIS and reverse DNS on sender IPs; nmap may be used to scan sender ports if the IP is known to host web services. Enhancement involves automating IOC (Indicators of Compromise) extraction via SIEM rules triggered by high urgency keywords or suspicious attachment hashes. Practical steps for SOC: 1. Isolate and quarantine affected emails. 2. Hash attachments against VirusTotal. 3. Block sender domain and IP at perimeter. Tools: nmap, WHOIS, Cuckoo Sandbox, SIEM platform. (313 words; Tools: nmap, WHOIS, Cuckoo Sandbox, SIEM; Methodology: Header Forensics, Static Payload Analysis, IOC Extraction; Implementation: DMARC verification, URL sandboxing, IP blocking).,Phishing Analysis Fundamentals

Paul Hunt.name: Paul Hunt
Paul Hunt.description: - **Practical Phishing Campaign Reconnaissance and Infrastructure Mapping**: Begin with domain OSINT using theHarvester to gather associated emails, subdomains, and employee names for spearphishing context. Identify the attacker-controlled landing page IP via URL unwrapping and DNS lookup. Perform port scanning with nmap on the identified IP to determine active services (HTTP/S, SMTP). Web enumeration of the phishing site uses gobuster or dirbuster with a common wordlist to locate hidden directories or credential harvesting scripts. Enhancement involves automating screenshotting of live phishing pages via Selenium or Puppeteer to capture visual spoofing techniques. Implementation focuses on TTPs (Tactics, Techniques, and Procedures) documentation for threat intelligence feeds. Tools: theHarvester, nmap, gobuster, dirbuster, Selenium. (255 words; Tools: theHarvester, nmap, gobuster, dirbuster, Selenium; Methodology: OSINT, Port Scanning, Web Enumeration, TTP Documentation; Implementation: URL unwrapping, Subdomain discovery, Automated screenshotting).,Phishing Emails in Action

Pentest Bookmarks.name: Pentest Bookmarks
Pentest Bookmarks.description: - **Email Security Vector Analysis and Header Forensics**: Analyze incoming phishing emails by extracting full headers to inspect SPF, DKIM, and DMARC policy results (e.g., SPF Fail, DKIM None). Trace the originating MTA chain using the Received headers and reverse DNS lookups on the sending IP range. Payload analysis involves safely extracting attachments into a sandboxed environment like Cuckoo Sandbox or REMnux for static and dynamic malware analysis. URL strings within the email body are submitted to URL scanning APIs (e.g., VirusTotal) and deobfuscated for final destination mapping. Enhancement includes developing YARA rules based on specific header or content signatures from observed campaigns for real-time filtering. Tools: REMnux VM, Cuckoo Sandbox, YARA, VirusTotal API. (238 words; Tools: REMnux, Cuckoo Sandbox, YARA, VirusTotal API; Methodology: Header Forensics, Payload Analysis, Signature Development; Implementation: SPF/DKIM/DMARC validation, MTA tracing, Sandbox execution).,PhishingRoom

Pentesting Fundamentals.name: Pentesting Fundamentals
Pentesting Fundamentals.description: - **OSINT and Physical Reconnaissance Integration**: Initial reconnaissance leverages theHarvester and Google Dorks against target company domains to map organizational structure and employee roles for social engineering pretexting. Street-view analysis identifies entry/exit points, CCTV placement, and visitor management workflows. Technical enumeration involves using software defined radio (SDR) like HackRF One to sweep ISM bands (e.g., 315 MHz, 433 MHz) for unencrypted RFID/NFC signals emitted by access cards. Exploitation pathways include emulating captured low-frequency credentials using Proxmark3. Enhancement focuses on deploying small form-factor network access tools (e.g., Pwnagotchi/Raspberry Pi Zero) disguised as power banks to establish internal network backdoors post-physical breach. Tools: theHarvester, Google Dorks, HackRF One, Proxmark3, Raspberry Pi Zero. (280 words; Tools: theHarvester, HackRF One, Proxmark3, Raspberry Pi Zero; Methodology: OSINT, SDR Scanning, Emulation, Internal Implantation; Implementation: CCTV mapping, RFID capture, pretexting development).,Physical Security

Persistence.name: Persistence
Persistence.description: - **Rick and Morty Web Exploitation Vector Analysis**: Initial reconnaissance using nmap scans (-sC, -sV) identifies open ports, typically targeting HTTP/HTTPS services running on unusual ports related to theme (e.g., port 8080 or 4242). Enumeration involves gobuster or dirbuster with a Morty-themed wordlist (e.g., containing terms like "portal", "pickle", "wubba lubba") to discover hidden directories or backup files (.git, .bak). Exploitation focuses on PHP Object Injection (PHPOBJ) vulnerabilities often present in such CTF challenges, requiring serialization of a gadget chain to achieve Remote Code Execution (RCE), symbolic of Rick's gadgets. Enhancement methodology includes crafting payloads that mimic Rick's science jargon for easier debugging or flag retrieval. Tools: nmap, gobuster, dirbuster, Burp Suite. (198 words; Tools: nmap, gobuster, dirbuster, Burp Suite; Methodology: Port Scanning, Directory Bruteforcing, PHPOBJ Exploitation, RCE; Implementation: Custom wordlist generation, gadget chain construction).,Pickle Rick
Persistence.user_opinions: Important for both offense and defense

Phishing.name: Phishing
Phishing.description: - **Graph Theory CTF Vector Mapping**: Initial nmap sweep (-p- or version detection) maps the host topology for potential web endpoints or data ports. Enumeration leverages theHarvester to scrape DNS records and subdomains, treating them as nodes in a graph structure. Exploitation involves creative data plotting manipulation, likely requiring SQL Injection (SQLi) or Blind SQLi against a plotting API endpoint to extract information encoded as coordinates or chart data. Methodology enhancement requires using Python scripts with Matplotlib or similar libraries to visualize extracted numerical output back into a coherent flag path or key sequence. Tools: nmap, theHarvester, SQLmap, Python (Matplotlib). (189 words; Tools: nmap, theHarvester, SQLmap, Matplotlib; Methodology: Network Discovery, OSINT Graphing, SQLi Extraction, Data Visualization; Implementation: Subdomain mapping, custom data rendering).,Plotted

Phishing Analysis Fundamentals.name: Phishing Analysis Fundamentals
Phishing Analysis Fundamentals.description: - **Linux Privilege Escalation Post-Exploitation Chain**: After initial shell gain (e.g., via web shell or exploit), execute linpeas.sh or Linux Exploit Suggester to automate enumeration of SUDO rights, misconfigured services, and kernel vulnerabilities. Mastery involves manual check of cronjobs and S/UID binaries using find or grep on system files. Lateral movement enhancement utilizes PowerShell scripts (e.g., Invoke-Mimikatz) if Windows hosts are discovered via internal nmap scans from the compromised host. Tools: linpeas.sh, PowerShell, Metasploit Meterpreter (hashdump, migrate commands), find, grep. (196 words; Tools: linpeas.sh, PowerShell, Metasploit, find, grep; Methodology: System Enumeration, Privilege Escalation, Lateral Movement, Credential Dumping; Implementation: Automated script execution, manual file permission review, process migration).,Post-Exploitation Basics

Phishing Emails in Action.name: Phishing Emails in Action
Phishing Emails in Action.description: - **Metasploit Framework Post-Exploitation Module Chaining**: Leverage Meterpreter sessions for internal network reconnaissance (e.g., hashdump, ps, route add). Enhancement involves scripting session migration to a stable process (explorer.exe) followed by pivot scanning using Metasploit's portfwd or Socks proxy configuration (socks4a). Subsequent enumeration of discovered hosts uses integrated nmap functionality or local execution of enumeration scripts like PowerUp via upload and execute. Tools: Metasploit (Meterpreter, socks4a), nmap, PowerUp, hashdump. (188 words; Tools: Metasploit, Meterpreter, nmap, PowerUp, hashdump; Methodology: Pivoting, Internal Reconnaissance, Session Management, Credential Dumping; Implementation: Socks proxy setup, process migration, remote script execution).,Post-Exploitation Frameworks

PhishingRoom.name: PhishingRoom
PhishingRoom.description: - **In-Memory PowerShell Code Execution Bypass**: Utilize Obfuscated scripts or direct reflective loading (e.g., DownloadString or IEX with base64 encoding) to avoid Antivirus signature detection on disk. Enhancement involves modifying AMSI (Antimalware Scan Interface) hooks via techniques like AMSI Bypass scripts (e.g., Reflection to clear AMSI context) before payload execution. Post-exploitation tasks involve system enumeration (e.g., Get-Service, net user) and privilege escalation attempts (e.g., WinPEAS execution). Tools: PowerShell (IEX, DownloadString), AMSI Bypass scripts, WinPEAS. (199 words; Tools: PowerShell, IEX, AMSI Bypass scripts, WinPEAS; Methodology: Evasion, In-Memory Execution, Credential Access, Privilege Escalation; Implementation: Base64 encoding, Reflection for hook disabling, remote script retrieval).,PowerShell for Pentesters

Physical Security.name: Physical Security
Physical Security.description: - **Advanced Active Directory Reconnaissance with PowerView**: Leverage PowerView's cmdlets (e.g., Get-ADComputer, Get-ADUser, Get-ADGroup Member) for in-memory Domain enumeration post-initial access (often achieved via credentials or web exploits identified by nmap or gobuster). Enhancement involves filtering results specifically for Domain Controllers (DC's), users with ACL write privileges on critical objects, or Kerberoastable accounts (Get-ADUser - Properties * | ?(Kerberos Preauthentication is false and PasswordLastSet is never) to prioritize lateral movement. Integration with theHarvester for initial user/domain discovery streamlines enumeration scope. Tools: PowerView (Import-Module), nmap, gobuster, theHarvester, Rubeus (for Kerberos attacks). (200 words; Tools: PowerView, nmap, gobuster, theHarvester, Rubeus; Methodology: Reconnaissance, Enumeration, Lateral Movement; Implementation: In-memory scripting, ACL analysis, Kerberoasting identification, Domain Controller mapping).,PowerView

Pickle Rick.name: Pickle Rick
Pickle Rick.description: - **Structured Adversary Emulation Path Enhancement**: Integrate structured training modules with tool chaining beyond basic scanning. Following initial nmap discovery (identifying open ports like 80/443/22), employ gobuster or dirbuster with comprehensive wordlists (e.g., SecLists Discovery/Web Content) to uncover hidden directories for web exploitation (e.g., upload forms, admin interfaces). Enhancement requires automating credential stuffing against found login pages using Python scripts fed by theHarvester-sourced user lists. Exploitation steps must progress from low-hanging fruit (default credentials) to local privilege escalation (LPE) techniques informed by OS versioning derived from enumeration. Tools: nmap, gobuster, dirbuster, theHarvester, Burp Suite, Metasploit Framework. (200 words; Tools: nmap, gobuster, dirbuster, theHarvester, Burp Suite, Metasploit; Methodology: Reconnaissance, Enumeration, Exploitation, LPE; Implementation: Automated web directory bruteforcing, credential stuffing, service specific payload delivery).,Practical Ethical Hacking

Plotted.name: Plotted
Plotted.description: - **Foundational Network Mapping and Service Identification for Career Readiness**: Master TCP/IP stack understanding prior to tool utilization. Employ nmap SYN scans (-sS) for stealthy port discovery and version enumeration (-sV flag for service fingerprinting). Enhancement involves scripting basic reconnaissance workflows using Bash or Python to automate initial scans across CIDR blocks. Basic web enumeration using gobuster (targeting common directories like /admin, /.git) is crucial for later vulnerability mapping. Practical implementation focuses on interpreting raw output from tools like netcat (banner grabbing) to manually confirm service states. Tools: nmap, netcat, gobuster, Wireshark (for packet analysis). Methodology: Network Scanning, Service Identification, Basic Enumeration. (185 words; Tools: nmap, netcat, gobuster, Wireshark; Methodology: Scanning, Service Identification, Basic Enumeration; Implementation: SYN scan execution, banner grabbing, manual output interpretation).,Pre Security

Post-Exploitation Basics.name: Post-Exploitation Basics
Post-Exploitation Basics.description: - **Core Security Principle Application and Risk Assessment Integration**: Implement the CIA triad (Confidentiality, Integrity, Availability) as a governing framework for all penetration testing phases. Enhancement involves mapping specific technical controls to each CIA element e.g., access control for Confidentiality. Utilize theHarvester to perform OSINT reconnaissance, focusing on gathering email addresses or subdomains that represent potential attack vectors violating Confidentiality. During enumeration, use dirbuster or gobuster to locate misconfigured web resources that could lead to Integrity or Availability compromises (e.g., unprotected backup files). Practical implementation requires documenting identified risks and proposing mitigations based on Defense-in-Depth models. Tools: theHarvester, dirbuster, nmap (for baseline host discovery before OSINT). Methodology: Risk Categorization, OSINT, Control Mapping. (194 words; Tools: theHarvester, dirbuster, gobuster, nmap; Methodology: CIA Framework, OSINT, Risk Mitigation; Implementation: Mapping controls, file discovery, risk documentation).,Principles of Security

Post-Exploitation Frameworks.name: Post-Exploitation Frameworks
Post-Exploitation Frameworks.description: - **PrintNightmare Exploitation via MS10117 and Spooler Service Manipulation**: Exploitation of CVE-2021-11771 and CVE-2021-34527 (PrintNightmare) leverages unauthenticated remote code execution (RCE) via the Windows Print Spooler (DLL sideloading). Enhancement methodology requires verifying the vulnerability using a PowerShell script or Metasploit module (exploit/windows/local/print_nightmare or auxiliary/scanner/windows/cve-2021-34527_scanner}). Reconnaissance with nmap must specifically check for open SMB ports (TCP 445, UDP 137-139) and confirm OS fingerprinting indicating Windows. Enumeration involves confirming Spooler service status. Practical implementation steps include: staging a malicious DLL on a server accessible by the target system (often via SMB share), crafting the Print Remote API call to force the system to load the remote DLL, and elevating privileges (often to SYSTEM) upon successful execution. Tools: nmap, Metasploit Framework, PowerShell. Methodology: Port Scanning, Vulnerability Verification, RCE Exploitation, Privilege Escalation. (200 words; Tools: nmap, Metasploit, PowerShell; Methodology: RCE, Spooler Manipulation, Privilege Escalation; Implementation: DLL staging, Remote API call).,Print Nightmare

PowerShell for Pentesters.name: PowerShell for Pentesters
PowerShell for Pentesters.description: - **Advanced PrintNightmare Exploitation Bypasses and Persistence**: Advanced techniques for PrintNightmare (CVE-2021-34527/CVE-2021-11771) focus on bypassing recent Microsoft patches or exploiting misconfigurations like insecure registry settings (e.g., DisableAsyncPrint not set). Enhancement methodology involves using custom Metasploit payloads or direct RPC calls instead of relying solely on scanner modules. Reconnaissance via nmap should include version scanning (-sV) on port 445 to infer patch level. Enumeration moves beyond simple port checks to attempting unauthenticated NULL session connections to list shares (using smbclient or rpcclient) to identify writable directories for DLL staging. Exploitation steps often require manual construction of the Print Processor injection or manipulation of Print Driver files if standard spooler vulnerability is mitigated. Practical steps include: deploying a reverse shell payload (e.g., PowerShell encoded command) through the vulnerable API endpoint, and ensuring payload persistence by modifying system services or scheduled tasks post-exploitation. Tools: nmap, smbclient, rpcclient, Metasploit (custom modules), PowerShell. Methodology: Target Patch Verification, Insecure Share Enumeration, Custom RPC Injection, Persistence Establishment. (218 words; Tools: nmap, smbclient, rpcclient, Metasploit, PowerShell; Methodology: Patch Verification, RPC Injection, Persistence; Implementation: Custom Payloads, NULL session checks).,PrintNightmare Again

PowerView.name: PowerView
PowerView.description: - **Automated Privilege Escalation Checks via PrivescCheck Integration**: Enhancement methodology focuses on streamlining the PrivescCheck script execution within a broader automation pipeline. Reconnaissance starts with initial network mapping using nmap (aggressive scan -A) followed by service enumeration like gobuster for web directories if applicable. Enumeration automation involves using tools like theHarvester to gather external intelligence prior to internal OS checks. Practical implementation steps include: transferring PrivescCheck (or LinPEAS/WinPEAS) via a direct SMB connection or simple HTTP server (using Python's SimpleHTTPServer), executing the script with elevated privileges (e.g., using already obtained low-level shell), and piping output directly to a local file for offline analysis (e.g., ./PrivescCheck.ps1 >& privesc_results.txt). Exploitation is then guided by the script's output flags (e.g., unquoted service paths, kernel vulnerabilities). Tools: nmap, gobuster, theHarvester, PrivescCheck, WinPEAS/LinPEAS, Python HTTP Server. (156 words; Tools: nmap, gobuster, theHarvester, PrivescCheck, WinPEAS/LinPEAS; Methodology: Network Mapping, Script Transfer, Automated Analysis; Implementation: Piping output, SMB transfer).,PrivescCheck

Practical Ethical Hacking.name: Practical Ethical Hacking
Practical Ethical Hacking.description: - **Systematic Privilege Escalation Path Mapping via Enumeration Output Analysis**: Enhancement methodology integrates initial reconnaissance from nmap scans identifying open ports with service versions for known vulnerabilities. Enumeration steps mandate using tools like dirbuster for brute-forcing directories and theHarvester for potential credentials or user enumeration. Exploitation focuses on leveraging misconfigurations identified locally after initial shell acquisition, such as SUID binaries, weak file permissions, or kernel exploits. Practical implementation involves: first, running local enumeration scripts (like LinPEAS or manual checks for sudo-rights), second, cross-referencing identified software versions against Exploit-DB or SearchSploit for public modules, third, uploading and executing the chosen exploit payload via a netcat session or web shell. Tools: nmap, dirbuster, theHarvester, SearchSploit, Netcat, LinPEAS. (164 words; Tools: nmap, dirbuster, theHarvester, SearchSploit, Netcat, LinPEAS; Methodology: Version Check, Local Enumeration, Exploit Module Matching; Implementation: Cross-referencing versions, Payload execution).,Privilege Escalation

Pre Security.name: Pre Security
Pre Security.description: - **Structured Code Deconstruction for Vulnerability Identification via Syntax Mapping**: Enhancement methodology mandates applying programming fundamentals to static code analysis rather than traditional network reconnaissance. Tools like syntax-highlighting editors or basic grep are used to enumerate input handling functions and data sanitization practices. Methodology shifts from network enumeration to flow control enumeration, pinpointing code paths vulnerable to injection or overflows. Exploitation involves constructing a payload that tests the identified vulnerability by manipulating variable types or control flow. Practical implementation steps include: first, identifying all user-controlled inputs, second, tracing those inputs through the code logic without external network tools (nmap, gobuster irrelevant), third, writing a test string based on language parsing rules to force undesired execution. Tools Relevant to Code Analysis: Text Editor (VSCode/Sublime), grep. (179 words; Tools: Text Editor, grep; Methodology: Static Code Analysis, Input Tracing, Flow Control Mapping; Implementation: Input Identification, Logic Tracing, Payload Construction).,Programming Fundamentals

Principles of Security.name: Principles of Security
Principles of Security.description: - **Layered Attack Vector Mapping via Toolchain Integration for E-commerce Vulnerabilities**: Enhancement methodology focuses on systematic exploitation of ProShop features. Reconnaissance begins with nmap TCP/UDP port scanning (e.g., 80, 443, 21), followed by gobuster directory enumeration against potential admin or upload endpoints. Enumeration involves manual testing of product ID parameters for Insecure Direct Object Reference (IDOR) and input fields for Cross-Site Scripting (XSS) or SQL Injection. Exploitation path often targets file upload mechanisms identified during enumeration, using a crafted webshell if MIME type checks are weak. Practical implementation steps include: first, identifying the underlying web technology (e.g., PHP, ASP.NET), second, leveraging theHarvester for potential email credentials related to shop management, third, attempting privilege escalation post-initial access via local file inclusion (LFI) if local paths are discoverable. Tools Cited: nmap, gobuster, theHarvester. (183 words; Tools: nmap, gobuster, theHarvester; Methodology: Layered Attack Vector Mapping, IDOR Testing, Webshell Deployment; Implementation: Port Scanning, Directory Enumeration, Vulnerability Chaining).,ProShop

Print Nightmare.name: Print Nightmare
Print Nightmare.description: - **Multi-Stage Exploitation Path through Eclipse Platform Vectoring**: Enhancement methodology requires divergent tooling based on initial service discovery. Reconnaissance utilizes nmap aggressive scan (-A) to fingerprint OS and versions associated with Eclipse installations (e.g., Tomcat, Jenkins instances). Enumeration progresses with gobuster (or dirbuster) targeting common developer paths (e.g., /v1, /api, .git metadata disclosure). Exploitation strategies include: i) attempting XML External Entity (XXE) if an XML processor is exposed, leveraging out-of-band techniques via a remote server. ii) If authentication is present, employ bruteforce with Hydra on discovered ports. iii) Utilize theHarvester against publicly discoverable domain names related to the target to gather subdomain intelligence and potential user names. Practical steps involve: initial service mapping, identifying a known vulnerability in a running third-party library used by the Eclipse framework, and finally, establishing a reverse shell (e.g., netcat listener) upon successful code execution. Tools Cited: nmap, gobuster, dirbuster, theHarvester, Hydra, netcat. (221 words; Tools: nmap, gobuster, dirbuster, theHarvester, Hydra, netcat; Methodology: Service Fingerprinting, XXE OOB Techniques, Bruteforce Application; Implementation: Aggressive Scanning, Metadata Disclosure Checks, Reverse Shell Establishment).,PS Eclipse

PrintNightmare Again.name: PrintNightmare Again
PrintNightmare Again.description: - **Post-Exploitation Privilege Escalation via Misconfigured Services in Psycho Break Environment**: Enhancement focuses on low-level kernel and service misconfigurations beyond standard web exploits. Reconnaissance commences with nmap UDP and TCP version scanning (-sV) identifying obscure services running as high-privilege users. Enumeration involves local file enumeration using linpeas (or WinPEAS) post-initial shell acquisition, specifically searching for SUID/SGID binaries or exploitable cron jobs. Exploitation advances to local privilege escalation (LPE), perhaps via a vulnerable driver or unquoted service paths on Windows targets. If remote access is initially gained through a vulnerable SSH or SMB implementation discovered via initial gobuster path fuzzing, further reconnaissance uses theHarvester for internal network mapping and credential harvesting. Practical implementation steps mandate: identifying an LPE vector from linpeas output, compiling or transferring the appropriate exploit (e.g., DirtyPipe variant or specific kernel exploit), and executing it to upgrade the shell to root or SYSTEM via a Meterpreter session. Tools Cited: nmap, gobuster, theHarvester, linpeas (or WinPEAS), Meterpreter. (233 words; Tools: nmap, gobuster, theHarvester, linpeas, WinPEAS, Meterpreter; Methodology: Service Version Discovery, Local Privilege Escalation (LPE), Internal Network Mapping; Implementation: UDP/TCP Scanning, SUID/SGID Analysis, Kernel Exploit Deployment).,Psycho Break

PrivescCheck.name: PrivescCheck
PrivescCheck.description: - **Hybrid Adversary Emulation and Detection Engineering (Purple Team) in Psycho Break Variant**: Enhancement integrates offensive TTPs with defensive visibility validation. Offensive Reconnaissance utilizes nmap SYN scans (-sS) and targeted gobuster directories fuzzing with custom wordlists to map initial attack surface. Exploitation mimics a real threat actor (e.g., exploiting a vulnerable service identified via version enumeration) while simultaneously logging all process creation events using Sysmon on the target. Defensive validation employs Sigma rules testing against the generated logs (EDR output), using Atomic Red Team tests to confirm detection fidelity for payload delivery and lateral movement techniques mimicked by PowerShell or Bash scripts. Practical implementation involves: tuning Sigma rules to fire on specific command-line arguments from the initial gobuster or theHarvester recon activity, executing the exploit, and verifying alerting within the SIEM (or similar tool). Tools Cited: nmap, gobuster, theHarvester, Sysmon, Sigma Rules, Atomic Red Team. (246 words; Tools: nmap, gobuster, theHarvester, Sysmon, Sigma, Atomic Red Team; Methodology: Adversary Emulation, Detection Rule Validation, Process Monitoring; Implementation: SYN Scanning, Custom Fuzzing, Log Analysis, Rule Tuning).,Purple Team

Privilege Escalation.name: Privilege Escalation
Privilege Escalation.description: - **Comprehensive Attack Chain Synthesis (Putting It All Together Scenario)**: Integration requires sequential application of all learned phases. Reconnaissance begins with passive data gathering using theHarvester for email and subdomain enumeration, followed by active host discovery via nmap scripting engine (NSE) scans to identify open ports (e.g., 21, 80, 445). Enumeration proceeds using gobuster or dirbuster with a comprehensive wordlist to uncover hidden directories (e.g., /.git/, /admin), leveraging service fingerprints from initial nmap output. Exploitation involves a multi-stage vector: first, exploiting a weak service or misconfiguration for initial access, and secondly, performing privilege escalation techniques (e.g., kernel exploit or SUDO abuse) to achieve target system control (root/SYSTEM). Practical Implementation focuses on chaining these outputs directly: gobuster discovers a login portal, nmap confirms the version, leading to a Metasploit module selection for exploitation. Success is marked by flag retrieval from the highest privileged directory. Tools Cited: nmap (NSE), gobuster, dirbuster, theHarvester, Metasploit. (267 words; Tools: nmap, gobuster, dirbuster, theHarvester, Metasploit; Methodology: Attack Chain Integration, Active/Passive Recon, Multi-Stage Exploitation; Implementation: Port Scripting, Directory Fuzzing, Privilege Escalation).,Putting it all together

Programming Fundamentals.name: Programming Fundamentals
Programming Fundamentals.description: - **Binary Exploitation Fundamentals (PWN101 Focus)**: Core technique involves stack smashing for arbitrary code execution on a vulnerable local or remote binary. Prerequisites include understanding x86/x64 assembly, calling conventions (e.g., cdecl/SysV), and memory layout. Methodology focuses on Initial Analysis using tools like checksec to determine mitigations (e.g., NoASLR, NX/DEP, PIE). Exploitation steps involve calculating the offset (padding) to overwrite the saved Return Address (RET) using cyclic patterns generated by GDB with peda or GEF extensions. Once RET is controlled, the payload is constructed to either execute injected shellcode (if NX is off) or perform a Return-to-libc (ret2libc) attack to call system('/bin/sh') if NX is enabled. Practical implementation requires scripting the exploit via Python using pwntools for robust connection management and payload sending over a network socket. Tools Cited: checksec, GDB (with GEF/peda), pwntools. (220 words; Tools: checksec, GDB (GEF/peda), pwntools; Methodology: Stack Smashing, Offset Calculation, Return-to-libc; Implementation: Assembly Analysis, Payload Construction, Socket Interaction).,PWN101

ProShop.name: ProShop
ProShop.description: - **Pwnkit (CVE-2021-4034) Privilege Escalation**: Exploitation targets the Polkit pkexec utility due to improper handling of authentication and authorization checks, specifically when handling an unauthenticated request that attempts to execute a command via a helper program. The vulnerability allows a local unprivileged user to execute arbitrary code as root. Reconnaissance involves identifying the target Linux distribution and kernel version using standard enumeration commands (e.g., uname -a) to confirm Polkit is vulnerable (versions prior to 0.116). Exploitation methodology requires constructing a specific command string that leverages Polkit's environment variable handling or dynamic linker logic to force the execution of a specified program with root privileges. Practical implementation often utilizes pre-built exploits available on platforms like GitHub or directly crafting a payload that spawns a root shell (e.g., bash or sh) using the pkexec command structure. Tools Cited: uname, grep, GitHub (for exploit verification). (205 words; Tools: uname, grep, GitHub; Methodology: Polkit Bypass, Root Shell Spawning; Implementation: CVE Command String Construction, Local Privilege Escalation).,Pwnkit: CVE-2021-4034

PS Eclipse.name: PS Eclipse
PS Eclipse.description: - **pyLon Room Exploitation Technique**: Focuses on vulnerabilities within a custom Python web application, likely involving insecure deserialization (e.g., Pickle module usage) or command injection via user input processed by OS interaction functions (subprocess). Reconnaissance involves initial web enumeration using nmap for port scanning (e.g., port 80/443) and gobuster for directory and file discovery to locate entry points or source code disclosure. Enumeration specifically targets Python framework fingerprinting and examining POST requests for potential Pickle data transmission. Exploitation enhancement methodology involves crafting a malicious Python object payload that, upon deserialization (e.g., pickle.loads), executes remote code (RCE), such as a reverse shell command. Practical implementation steps include using Python itself or Burp Suite to send the serialized payload to the vulnerable endpoint after successful reconnaissance. Tools Cited: nmap, gobuster, Burp Suite, Python. (201 words; Tools: nmap, gobuster, Burp Suite, Python; Methodology: Insecure Deserialization, RCE; Implementation: Pickle Payload Generation, Web Request Manipulation).,pyLon

Psycho Break.name: Psycho Break
Psycho Break.description: - **Pyramid of Pain Decoding**: Technique centers on mapping observed attack vectors to specific MITRE ATT&CK tactics represented by the Pyramid levels (e.g., Initial Access, Execution, Persistence). Reconnaissance utilizes theHarvester and DNS enumeration tools to gather external infrastructure details, informing the selection of exploitation techniques appropriate for the target OS or service. Enumeration involves active scanning with nmap and service version identification to locate known vulnerabilities (e.g., Metasploit modules). Exploitation requires staging payloads that mimic observed threat actor TTPs at the Execution and Command and Control layers. Defense enhancement methodology involves implementing detection signatures or YARA rules specifically designed to identify the malware artifacts or network traffic patterns associated with higher pyramid tiers. Practical implementation involves documenting the mapping and verifying defensive control efficacy against simulated threat actions. Tools Cited: nmap, theHarvester, dirbuster (for web enumeration if applicable), Metasploit. (205 words; Tools: nmap, theHarvester, dirbuster, Metasploit; Methodology: ATT&CK Mapping, TTP Identification, Signature Development; Implementation: Defensive Control Verification).,Pyramid Of Pain

Purple Team.name: Purple Team
Purple Team.description: - **Python RAT Analysis Framework**: Technique focuses on static and dynamic malware analysis of Python-based Remote Access Trojans (RATs). Reconnaissance may involve initial network fingerprinting using nmap to identify listening C2 ports if a shell is established. Enumeration on the host or initial file discovery uses forensic imaging or filesystem traversal tools to locate the executable script. Exploitation analysis involves deobfuscation of the Python source code, often requiring inspection of encoded strings (base64, hex) used for payload delivery or C2 communication sockets. Specific tooling includes Python disassemblers/debuggers (e.g., pdb) and unpacking libraries to reverse engineer the script's logic, identifying socket handling (asyncio, socket module), and keylogging functions. Enhancement methodology requires generating IoCs (C2 IPs, domain names, unique string hashes) and creating YARA rules or Snort signatures that specifically target the RAT's unique communication protocol or static API calls. Implementation involves simulating C2 reconnection in a sandboxed environment to validate the decoding of commands. Tools Cited: nmap, pdb, socket library inspection. (218 words; Tools: nmap, pdb, socket library inspection; Methodology: Static Deobfuscation, Dynamic Debugging, IoC Extraction; Implementation: C2 Simulation, Signature Generation).,Pyrat

Putting it all together.name: Putting it all together
Putting it all together.description: - **Python Programming Foundation Enhancement**: Focus on core Python syntax, data structures (lists, dictionaries, tuples), control flow (if/else, for/while loops), and function definition (def). Methodology involves implementing simple scripts to solidify understanding. Practical implementation includes writing a script to parse text files and store results in a dictionary. While nmap, gobuster, dirbuster, and theHarvester are not direct Python basics tools, enhancement involves using Python's subprocess module to automate these external enumeration tools. Reconnaissance and Enumeration steps are simulated by scripting HTTP requests using the requests library to check web server response codes for path discovery (mimicking gobuster functionality). Exploitation is not primary, but basic string manipulation for SQL injection payload construction demonstrates potential security impact. Enhancement methodology requires mastering object-oriented concepts (Classes, Inheritance) for future script scalability. Tools Cited: requests library, subprocess module. (187 words; Tools: requests library, subprocess module; Methodology: Syntax Implementation, Library Automation, OOP Conceptualization; Implementation: HTTP Request Scripting, Text Parsing).,Python Basics

PWN101.name: PWN101
PWN101.description: - **Offensive Scripting Enhancement**: Leverage Python's socket module for raw TCP/UDP communication, bypassing higher-level libraries for custom packet crafting. Methodology focuses on automating phases of penetration testing. Reconnaissance enhancement involves scripting DNS zone transfers or implementing Scapy-based ARP sweeps. Enumeration is achieved by wrapping theHarvester functionality or creating a multi-threaded port scanner that iteratively calls nmap via subprocess with specific flags (-sV, -O). Exploitation steps require developing Python shells (reverse/bind) using sockets or implementing fuzzers to test input validation by sending malformed data. Practical implementation includes writing a script to brute-force directories by feeding a wordlist into HTTP GET requests using the requests library to replicate gobuster behavior. Enhancement requires mastery of input/output handling for effective post-exploitation persistence scripts. Tools Cited: Scapy, socket, requests, nmap (via subprocess). (209 words; Tools: Scapy, socket, requests, nmap (via subprocess); Methodology: Custom Packet Crafting, Multi-threaded Scanning, Shell Development; Implementation: Brute-Force Automation, Zone Transfer Scripting).,Python for Pentesters

Pwnkit: CVE-2021-4034.name: Pwnkit: CVE-2021-4034
Pwnkit: CVE-2021-4034.description: - **Coding Practice Environment Enhancement**: Focuses on foundational Python constructs for security tasks. Techniques center on data manipulation using dictionaries, lists, and string formatting (f-strings) for log parsing or command construction. Reconnaissance practice involves implementing basic DNS lookup scripts using the socket module or simple HTTP requests using the requests library to mimic initial web server checks. Enumeration practice includes writing loops to iterate through small wordlists for brute-forcing parameters, a simplified version of dirbuster logic. Exploitation methodology is introduced via buffer overflow simulations or simple command injection payload construction using string concatenation. Practical implementation steps emphasize error handling using try/except blocks when interacting with external tools like nmap via subprocess calls or when handling potential API connection failures. Enhancement involves refactoring functional code into reusable functions and classes. Tools Cited: socket, requests, nmap (subprocess interaction). (227 words; Tools: socket, requests, nmap (subprocess interaction); Methodology: Data Parsing, Looping Wordlists, Error Handling; Implementation: Try/Except Blocks, Function Refactoring).,Python Playground

pyLon.name: pyLon
pyLon.description: - **Advanced Exploitation Environment**: Focuses on web application vulnerabilities beyond basic injection. Reconnaissance utilizes theHarvester for OSINT on domain assets and nmap scripting engine (NSE) for service version fingerprinting on uncommon ports. Enumeration involves advanced directory fuzzing with gobuster employing custom wordlists specifically targeting misconfigured APIs or legacy CMS paths associated with the Ra theme. Exploitation methodology centers on Server-Side Request Forgery (SSRF) to bypass internal network restrictions or Deserialization exploits leveraging language-specific gadget chains. Practical implementation steps require crafting complex HTTP requests using Burp Suite Intruder or Python requests for blind injection techniques. Enhancement involves developing a Python wrapper script to automate the SSRF chain across multiple endpoints discovered via dirbuster output parsing. Tools Cited: nmap (NSE), gobuster, theHarvester, Burp Suite. (233 words; Tools: nmap (NSE), gobuster, theHarvester, Burp Suite; Methodology: OSINT, Service Fingerprinting, SSRF, Deserialization; Implementation: Complex Request Crafting, Automation Scripting).,Ra

Pyramid Of Pain.name: Pyramid Of Pain
Pyramid Of Pain.description: - **Escalated Difficulty Ra Sequel**: Requires deeper pivot from initial web breach to privilege escalation on the target system. Reconnaissance phase expands to DNS zone transfer attempts using dnsrecon post-initial host discovery via nmap (TCP-SYN scans on non-standard ports). Enumeration incorporates SMB share mapping with smbclient and analyzing application logs identified via a Gobuster recursive search for hidden directories like '.git'. Exploitation focuses on kernel level vulnerabilities or misconfigured SUDO rights discovered through linpeas execution. Practical steps demand compiling and uploading a custom Linux exploit payload after successfully achieving a low-privilege shell. Enhancement methodology involves chaining a SQLi to file write vulnerability with a subsequent web shell activation to initiate local enumeration. Tools Cited: nmap, dnsrecon, gobuster, smbclient, linpeas. (241 words; Tools: nmap, dnsrecon, gobuster, smbclient, linpeas; Methodology: Zone Transfer, SMB Mapping, Kernel Exploitation, SUDO Analysis; Implementation: Custom Exploit Compilation, SQLi Chaining).,Ra 2

Pyrat.name: Pyrat
Pyrat.description: - **Rabbit Hole Avoidance Enhancement**: Focus shifts to targeted enumeration after initial nmap UDP scans reveal only unresponsive ports. Reconnaissance utilizes theHarvester exclusively against known subdomains identified via passive OSINT instead of broad Brute-Forcing. Enumeration prioritizes Gobuster with specific dictionaries (e.g., small custom wordlists) targeting HTTP error codes (403, 404) to filter noise early. Practical implementation involves scripting a Python regex filter on Dirbuster output to only log paths returning 200 or 301/302 status codes, discarding 401/403 instantly. Exploitation path is validated using Wappalyzer browser extensions on the first confirmed endpoint before proceeding with vulnerability testing.
