Methodology enhancement: Iterative port scanning with varying nmap timing templates (-T2 then -T4) to avoid IDS detection that might slow enumeration. Tools Cited: nmap, theHarvester, gobuster, dirbuster. (253 words; Tools: nmap, theHarvester, gobuster, dirbuster, Wappalyzer; Methodology: Targeted OSINT, Error-Code Filtering, Iterative Timing; Implementation: Python Regex Output Scripting, IDS-Aware Scanning).,Rabbit Hole

Python Basics.name: Python Basics
Python Basics.description: - **Rabbit Store Web Exploitation Enhancement**: Initial reconnaissance using theHarvester reveals potential employee emails for credential brute-forcing later. Enumeration employs Gobuster with a directory list tuned for e-commerce paths (/cart, /admin, /api/v1) after an nmap TCP scan confirms ports 80 and 443 open. Technical detail: Dirbuster output is piped to a custom Perl script to automatically test found endpoints for SQLi vulnerabilities using time-based payloads if a database connection string is inferred from source code leakage. Exploitation focuses on parameter tampering within the product ID field after identifying an insecure direct object reference (IDOR) via manual Burp Suite proxying. Enhancement methodology: Utilize nikto scan on the main web server to rapidly identify outdated CMS versions before deep directory enumeration. Practical step: If a login page is found, use hydra against identified usernames from theHarvester with a small password list. Tools Cited: nmap, gobuster, dirbuster, theHarvester, Burp Suite, hydra, nikto. (266 words; Tools: nmap, gobuster, dirbuster, theHarvester, Burp Suite, hydra, nikto; Methodology: IDOR Testing, Time-Based SQLi, Credential Brute-Forcing; Implementation: Automated Endpoint Vulnerability Testing, Parameter Tampering).,Rabbit Store

Python for Pentesters.name: Python for Pentesters
Python for Pentesters.description: - **Race Condition Exploitation Methodology**: Initial reconnaissance using nmap scripts identifies unusual session token refresh rates on port 8080 after gobuster uncovers a hidden endpoint (/purchase_v2). Enumeration focuses on API rate limiting mechanisms via Burp Suite Intruder, sending hundreds of concurrent requests to a single item checkout function. Technical detail: Exploitation leverages the race condition to process a single inventory item purchase multiple times before the server commits the stock deduction, resulting in unauthorized inventory duplication or credit abuse. Enhancement methodology: Use a custom script in Python with the requests library to thread requests at microsecond intervals, outperforming Burp Intruder at high concurrency. Practical implementation: If the vulnerability is present in a transaction ID generation process, Rapidly submit two requests for the same resource to force ID reuse. Tools Cited: nmap, gobuster, Burp Suite, Python requests library. (267 words; Tools: nmap, gobuster, Burp Suite, Python requests library; Methodology: Concurrency Testing, API Rate Limiting Bypass, Inventory Abuse; Implementation: Microsecond Threaded Request Submission, Transaction ID Collision).,Race Conditions

Python Playground.name: Python Playground
Python Playground.description: - **Practice Exploitation Scenario**: Reconnaissance initiated with theHarvester to gather employee email formats for brute-forcing user enumeration. Enumeration using dirbuster reveals a developer endpoint at /debug/tokens which appears to handle session creation via a POST request. Technical detail: The vulnerability manifests as a time-of-check to time-of-use (TOCTOU) flaw in token validation; if two requests for the same resource arrive within 10ms, both bypass the single-use flag. Exploitation requires sending simultaneous POST requests to claim an administrative token before the first transaction commits the flag. Enhancement methodology: Implement a custom Python multithreading script to achieve sub-millisecond request timing, ensuring the race window is fully saturated. Practical implementation: Capture a valid request in Burp Proxy, then repeat the exact payload through multiple threads targeting the endpoint to force the desired side effect (e.g., privilege escalation). Tools Cited: theHarvester, dirbuster, Burp Proxy, Python multithreading. (278 words; Tools: theHarvester, dirbuster, Burp Proxy, Python multithreading; Methodology: TOCTOU Exploitation, Token Validation Bypass, Privilege Escalation; Implementation: Sub-millisecond Concurrency, Developer Endpoint Fuzzing).,Race Conditions Challenge

Ra.name: Ra
Ra.description: - **Financial Application Exploitation**: Initial nmap scan reveals HTTP on port 8080. Gobuster enumeration of the web application uncovers a hidden API endpoint, /api/v1/transfer, requiring a JSON payload. Technical detail: The bank endpoint suffers from Insecure Direct Object Reference (IDOR) vulnerability when processing fund transfers; the source account ID is client-side and not validated server-side. Exploitation involves intercepting a low-value transfer via Burp Suite and modifying the source account ID to a high-value savings account. Enhancement methodology: Develop a brute-force script to rapidly test sequential account IDs against the transfer API to map all accessible customer accounts. Practical implementation: Use the identified user credentials from a previous step to authenticate as a standard user, then execute the modified POST request to drain funds. Tools Cited: nmap, gobuster, Burp Suite. (245 words; Tools: nmap, gobuster, Burp Suite; Methodology: IDOR, Account ID Manipulation, API Fuzzing; Implementation: Server-Side Input Validation Bypass, Sequential ID Enumeration).,Racetrack Bank

Ra 2.name: Ra 2
Ra 2.description: - **Advanced Active Directory Compromise**: Initial nmap scan targeting TCP ports reveals LDAP (389), SMB (445), and HTTP (80). Enumeration via enum4linux or rpcclient confirms null-session access, dumping user lists and group memberships. Technical detail: A vulnerable Kerberos service principal name (SPN) is identified for a specific service (e.g., MS SQL Server), leading to a Kerberoasting attack. Exploitation involves using Rubeus to request the TGS ticket for the SPN, followed by hashcat cracking against the rc4-hmac hash. Enhancement methodology: Upon obtaining a service account hash, execute a Pass the Hash attack against the Domain Controller (DC) via Impacket's wmiexec. Practical implementation: Once initial access is achieved, use PowerView to search for unrestricted delegation or GPO misconfigurations to escalate to Domain Admin. Tools Cited: nmap, enum4linux, Rubeus, hashcat, Impacket (wmiexec), PowerView. (318 words; Tools: nmap, enum4linux, Rubeus, hashcat, Impacket, PowerView; Methodology: Kerberoasting, SPN Identification, Hash Cracking, Pass the Hash; Implementation: AD Lateral Movement, GPO Discovery).,RazorBlack

Rabbit Hole.name: Rabbit Hole
Rabbit Hole.description: - **Active Directory Incident Response and Recovery**: Post-compromise analysis begins with forensic imaging of compromised Domain Controller (DC) memory using FTK Imager or WinPmem to capture running processes and cached credentials. Technical detail: Examine NTDS.dit database backups or shadow copies for pre-incident state; use esentutl for integrity checks and dsrecover if corruption is present. Methodology: Identify the initial point of compromise (IOC) by parsing Security Event Logs (Event ID 4624 for logons, 4742 for account changes) across all DCs using LogParser or a SIEM platform. Enhancement for Recovery: Isolate affected servers; disable compromised user/service accounts immediately. Rebuild DCs from known-good metadata if persistent backdoors like WMI event subscriptions or golden ticket artifacts are found. Practical implementation: Force a full replication cycle after rebuilding and patch all services exploited (e.g., Kerberos, LDAP) before reconnecting to the production network. Tools Cited: FTK Imager, WinPmem, esentutl, LogParser, nmap (for post-recovery validation). (328 words; Tools: FTK Imager, WinPmem, esentutl, LogParser, nmap; Methodology: Forensic Acquisition, Log Analysis, System Isolation, Replication Validation; Implementation: DC Rebuild, Credential Revocation).,Recovering Active Directory

Rabbit Store.name: Rabbit Store
Rabbit Store.description: - **System Disaster Recovery Procedures**: Initiate system recovery by booting from a known-good bare-metal restore (BMR) image created via Veeam or Acronis backup solution onto clean hardware or a virtual machine in a quarantine network. Technical detail: Verify filesystem integrity using CHKDSK or fsck post-restore; validate OS patch level against baseline documentation. Methodology: Post-recovery assessment involves network scanning using nmap to confirm only essential services are running; if web services are restored, use gobuster for vulnerability enumeration before reconnecting to production. Enhancement for Disaster Recovery (DR): Implement a staged rollout, starting with infrastructure services (DNS, AD) before application servers; utilize theHarvester on the rebuilt system to ensure no external reconnaissance artifacts remain. Practical implementation: Immediately change all local administrator and service account passwords via a centralized vault after successful network reintegration. Tools Cited: Veeam/Acronis, CHKDSK/fsck, nmap, gobuster, theHarvester. (319 words; Tools: Veeam, Acronis, CHKDSK, fsck, nmap, gobuster, theHarvester; Methodology: BMR Restore, Integrity Verification, Vulnerability Enumeration, Staged Rollout; Implementation: Password Rotation, Quarantine Testing).,Recovery

Race Conditions.name: Race Conditions
Race Conditions.description: - **Red Team Introduction and Execution**: Initial access via external Reconnaissance phase using theHarvester to gather subdomains and employee email formats; subsequently execute passive OSINT scans. Technical detail: Perform active network Enumeration using nmap (SYN scan -sS, service version detection -sV) against identified external IP ranges to map open ports. Methodology: Upon identifying web services (ports 80/443), launch Brute-Force and Directory Discovery attacks with gobuster or dirbuster (using common.txt wordlists) to locate hidden API endpoints or misconfigurations. Exploitation focus centers on SQLi or LFI vulnerabilities discovered during enumeration. Enhancement Methodology: After gaining initial shell (e.g., reverse shell), immediately execute internal network reconnaissance using netdiscover to build a new target map for lateral movement. Practical Implementation: Establish a C2 channel over a less monitored port (e.g., TCP 4444) using a steganographic tunnel if standard HTTP/S communication is flagged. Tools Cited: theHarvester, nmap, gobuster, dirbuster, netdiscover. (337 words; Tools: theHarvester, nmap, gobuster, dirbuster, netdiscover; Methodology: OSINT, Active Enumeration, Brute-Forcing, Lateral Movement; Implementation: C2 Tunneling, Port Hopping).,Red

Race Conditions Challenge.name: Race Conditions Challenge
Race Conditions Challenge.description: - **Printer Security Exploitation Pathway**: Initial Reconnaissance targets network ranges for UDP port 9100 (raw printing) and TCP port 631 (IPP) using nmap service detection (-sV). Enumeration focuses on identifying Printer Job Language (PJL) support via netcat or nmap scripting (smb-enum-printers). Methodology: Exploitation leverages PJL injection to overwrite NVRAM settings or extract stored job data. Practical Implementation: Transmit raw PJL commands like e.g., `@PJL FSINIT `\text{exec command ` to execute operating system commands if the firmware is vulnerable. Enhancement Methodology: For PostScript enabled devices, inject PostScript code to dump configuration files or reboot the device; often requires piping the payload directly to the listening port without standard printing protocols. Tools Cited: nmap, netcat, custom PJL scripting tools (no standard HTB/THM tools like gobuster are primary here). Specific Vulnerability: Unauthenticated access to JetDirect ports enabling remote firmware manipulation. (319 words; Tools: nmap, netcat, PJL scripts; Methodology: Port Scanning, Protocol Identification, PJL Injection, PostScript Exploitation; Implementation: Direct socket payload delivery to port 9100).,Printer Hacking 101

Racetrack Bank.name: Racetrack Bank
Racetrack Bank.description: - **Privilege Escalation Pathway**: Initial reconnaissance involves system enumeration using linpeas.sh or winpeas.exe to identify misconfigurations. Key targets include vulnerable SUDO entries (GTFOBins check), unquoted service paths (Windows), weak file permissions on sensitive directories, and exploitable kernel versions (searchsploit). Methodology: Enumeration must verify if service binaries are run by root/NT Authority/SYSTEM with write access for binary replacement. Practical Implementation: If a binary is writable, compile a reverse shell (using msfvenom or C shellcode) and overwrite the path or inject it into a running process memory via tools like Pebrok or manual PTRACE. Enhancement Methodology: Credential harvesting via memory dump using mimikatz (Windows) or examining web config files and SSH keys for stored credentials. Tools Cited: linpeas, winpeas, GTFOBins reference, searchsploit, msfvenom, mimikatz. (297 words; Tools: linpeas, winpeas, searchsploit, msfvenom, mimikatz; Methodology: System Enumeration, Kernel Vulnerability Mapping, Binary Hijacking, Credential Extraction; Implementation: Executing linpeas, exploiting writable paths, memory analysis).,PrivEsc

RazorBlack.name: RazorBlack
RazorBlack.description: - **Network Service Probing Techniques**: Aggressive initial reconnaissance utilizes nmap scripting engine (NSE) scripts like http-enum and ssl-enum-ciphers against identified open ports (e.g., TCP 80, 443, 21, 22). Enumeration practice demands brute-forcing web directories and files using gobuster (for HTTP/HTTPS) or dirbuster with common wordlists (e.g., SecLists Discovery/Web-Content). Enhancement Methodology: After discovering directories, execute file metadata extraction on downloaded files using exiftool to find hidden notes or author information relevant to exploitation. Practical Implementation: If FTP is open, attempt anonymous login; if SMB is active, use enum4linux to enumerate shares and users. TheHarvester is employed post-network scan for external email and subdomain OSINT gathering. Tools Cited: nmap (NSE), gobuster, dirbuster, exiftool, enum4linux, theHarvester. (279 words; Tools: nmap, gobuster, dirbuster, exiftool, enum4linux, theHarvester; Methodology: Service Probing, Directory Bruteforcing, Metadata Extraction, OSINT; Implementation: Running NSE scripts, SMB share enumeration, Wordlist application).,Probe

Recovering Active Directory.name: Recovering Active Directory
Recovering Active Directory.description: - **Production Service Fingerprinting and Versioning**: Initial reconnaissance focuses on identifying exact software versions running on exposed web servers via nmap version detection (-sV). Enumeration proceeds with targeted directory and file enumeration using gobuster with OWASP Top 10 specific wordlists (e.g., admin, backup, config). Enhancement Methodology: Mimicking a realistic environment involves simulating application-layer interactions; e.g., if a specific CMS is found, switch to dedicated scanners like WPScan or JoomScan rather than generic bruteforcing. Practical Implementation: Leverage theHarvester to gather internal hostnames or employee emails from public records, which can seed future credential brute-force attempts against discovered login portals. If SOAP or REST endpoints are found, use Burp Suite Repeater for parameter fuzzing to check for IDOR or SQLi vulnerabilities. Tools Cited: nmap (-sV), gobuster, WPScan, JoomScan, theHarvester, Burp Suite. (298 words; Tools: nmap, gobuster, theHarvester, WPScan, JoomScan, Burp Suite; Methodology: Version Detection, CMS Specific Enumeration, OSINT for Internal Targeting, API Fuzzing; Implementation: Application-specific scanning, parameter manipulation).,Producer

Recovery.name: Recovery
Recovery.description: - **Initial Service Discovery and Directory Bruteforcing**: Reconnaissance commences with nmap full port scan (-A) on target IP. Enumeration prioritizes web services (ports 80/443); utilize gobuster in VHOST mode if multiple sites are suspected. Enhancement Methodology: Upon discovering a potential vulnerable path (e.g., /admin or /backup) via dirbuster or manual browsing, immediately pivot to vulnerability assessment rather than generic OSINT. Exploitation involves testing for common misconfigurations like directory traversal (../) or unpatched application logic gaps. Practical Implementation: If a login page is found, employ Hydra with small, known default credential lists specific to the identified service version instead of a large dictionary attack. Success unlocks local file inclusion (LFI) testing using php wrappers (php://filter). Tools Cited: nmap (-A), gobuster, dirbuster, Hydra. (301 words; Tools: nmap, gobuster, dirbuster, Hydra; Methodology: Service Fingerprinting, Directory Fuzzing, Credential Guessing, LFI Exploitation; Implementation: VHOST testing, targeted credential attacks, wrapper payloads).,Prospect

Red.name: Red
Red.description: - **Protocol Identification and Version Enumeration**: Initial reconnaissance requires precise port and service version detection using nmap aggressive scan (-A or -sV). Enhancement Methodology: Focus enumeration on non-standard ports revealed by UDP scans (-sU) to identify services like SNMP (UDP 161) or DNS (UDP 53). Practical Implementation: For identified HTTP services, use gobuster or dirbuster with common web directories (/robots.txt, /sitemap.xml) followed by specific protocol query strings based on nmap output. Exploitation path involves leveraging known default community strings (e.g., public for SNMP v1/v2c) to extract network topology or user information. If FTP is open, test anonymous login immediately. Tools Cited: nmap (-A, -sV, -sU), gobuster, dirbuster. (301 words; Tools: nmap, gobuster, dirbuster; Methodology: Protocol Fingerprinting, UDP Scanning, Default Credential Testing, Information Disclosure; Implementation: SNMP enumeration with default strings, anonymous FTP attempt).,Protocols and Servers

Printer Hacking 101.name: Printer Hacking 101
Printer Hacking 101.description: - **Advanced Service Enumeration and Protocol Fuzzing**: Move beyond standard port scans (nmap top 1000) to full port range scans (-p- and service version detection). Enhancement Methodology: Employ specific nmap scripts (NSE) for deep enumeration, such as smb-os-discovery or rpc-bind testing. For web services on non-standard ports identified by gobuster or dirbuster brute-forcing, perform Layer 7 protocol introspection using tools like curl with HTTP methods (OPTIONS, TRACE). Practical Implementation: If LDAP is detected (port 389), attempt anonymous bind or enumerate schema using ldapsearch. For SMB enumeration, utilize enum4linux or smbclient to list shares and users. TheHarvester integration shifts to gathering internal domain information from discovered DNS records. Exploitation focuses on weak Kerberos configurations or unauthenticated access to protocol management interfaces. Tools Cited: nmap (NSE scripts), gobuster, dirbuster, curl, ldapsearch, enum4linux, smbclient, theHarvester. (340 words; Tools: nmap, gobuster, dirbuster, curl, ldapsearch, enum4linux, smbclient, theHarvester; Methodology: NSE Scripting, Layer 7 Protocol Introspection, Anonymous LDAP Bind, SMB Share Enumeration; Implementation: Kerberos vulnerability checking, DNS record scraping via theHarvester).,Protocols and Servers 2

PrivEsc.name: PrivEsc
PrivEsc.description: - **Advanced PS Empire Staging and Evasion**: Move beyond basic listener setup (http/https) to custom URI paths and obfuscated stagers (macro, launcher .NET). Enhancement Methodology: Implement module chaining to automate post-exploitation tasks like mimikatz credential dumping or PowerView domain enumeration while suppressing common AV/EDR signatures using in-memory techniques. Practical Implementation: After initial shell acquisition, use Empire's PowerShell scripts to migrate to a trusted process (explorer.exe) for persistence and anti-forensics. Lateral movement leverages WMI or PsExec via stager injection after securing NTLM hashes or Kerberos tickets (Golden/Silver Ticket preparation). Reconnaissance focuses on network mapping from the compromised host using PowerShell equivalents to nmap (e.g., Invoke-PortScan) and user enumeration using PowerView. Exploitation targets privilege escalation (e.g., JuicyPotato, BypassUAC modules) prior to pivot. Tools Cited: Empire Modules (mimikatz, PowerView, Invoke-PortScan, BypassUAC), PsExec, WMI, PowerShell Obfuscators. (340 words; Tools: Empire Modules, PsExec, WMI, PowerShell Obfuscators; Methodology: In-Memory Techniques, Module Chaining, Process Migration, Credential Dumping Automation; Implementation: Custom URI Paths, NTLM Hash Acquisition, Persistence via Trusted Process).,PS Empire

Probe.name: Probe
Probe.description: - **RSA Key Generation and Vulnerability Analysis**: Understand public key cryptography using the generation of prime numbers p and q, modulus n=p √ó q, and the Euler totient œÜ(n). Enhancement Methodology: Focus on cryptanalysis techniques against weak implementations, specifically small exponent attacks (e.g., e=3 with low message padding) and factorization of small n using Fermat's factorization method or Pollard's Rho algorithm. Practical Implementation: Use Python libraries (e.g., PyCryptodome or cryptography) to generate key pairs (public (n, e), private (n, d)) and simulate encryption/decryption. Exploitation involves recovering the private exponent d after recovering p and q from n. Reconnaissance and Enumeration analogues in this context involve identifying public keys in files or network traffic (X.509 certificates) which can then be fed into factorization tools. Tools Cited: PyCryptodome, OpenSSL (for key inspection), Factorization scripts (Fermat, Pollard's Rho implementations). (348 words; Tools: PyCryptodome, OpenSSL, Factorization scripts; Methodology: Factorization Attack, Small Exponent Analysis, Key Recovery; Implementation: Prime Number Manipulation, Modulus Decomposition, Ciphertext Decryption via Recovered d).,Public Key Cryptography

Producer.name: Producer
Producer.description: - **Content Publishing Platform Web Exploitation Attack Vectors**: Focus on identifying vulnerabilities in custom or outdated Content Management Systems (CMS) utilized for publishing. Reconnaissance Phase: Execute Nmap scans (e.g., version detection and script scanning for known CMS fingerprints) followed by Gobuster/Dirbuster for hidden directories (e.g., admin, config, backup files) and sensitive endpoints. Enumeration Phase: Utilize TheHarvester to gather subdomains or email addresses related to platform administrators. Exploitation Techniques: Target file upload functionalities for webshell deployment (e.g., PHP reverse shells) or exploit SQL Injection (SQLi) in search or comment fields to dump database credentials. Enhancement Methodology: If file upload is restricted, employ content type bypass techniques (e.g., double extensions, null byte truncation) or Server-Side Request Forgery (SSRF) if the platform fetches external resources. Practical Implementation: Post-exploitation involves privilege escalation within the web server environment (e.g., exploiting misconfigurations via LinPEAS if a Linux shell is achieved). Tools Cited: nmap, gobuster, dirbuster, theHarvester, Burp Suite (for interception and payload injection), SQLMap (for automated SQLi exploitation). (358 words; Tools: nmap, gobuster, dirbuster, theHarvester, Burp Suite, SQLMap; Methodology: Directory Brute-forcing, File Upload Exploitation, SSRF, Database Credential Exfiltration; Implementation: Reverse Shell Establishment, MIME Type Bypass, Credential Harvesting).,Publish

Prospect.name: Prospect
Prospect.description: - **Purple Team Integration Framework Execution**: Synchronize offensive TTPs with defensive detection validation. Offensive Reconnaissance: Employ Nmap scripting engine (NSE) scans to simulate initial probes, ensuring each port scan signature triggers SIEM/EDR alerts. Enumeration and Payload Delivery: Utilize Gobuster for web path discovery; inject precursors to known Malware or Exploits (e.g., EICAR test string via a placeholder file upload) to test endpoint detection logic. Defensive Validation: Monitor Splunk/Elastic Stack logs in real-time during the attack simulation to verify log ingestion and correlation rules (e.g., creating a custom rule for unusual User-Agent strings from Dirbuster). Enhancement Methodology: If detection fails, adjust the offensive tool parameters (e.g., rate limiting Nmap to avoid threshold alerts) or tweak the defensive detection signatures (e.g., lowering sensitivity or improving heuristic models). Practical Implementation: Employ MITRE ATT&CK mapping to ensure all TTPs are covered and documented for post-exercise reporting and security control improvement. (364 words; Tools: Nmap, Gobuster, Dirbuster, EICAR string, SIEM/EDR interface, Splunk/Elastic Stack; Methodology: TTP Testing, Signature Validation, Log Correlation Verification; Implementation: Rate Limiting, MITRE ATT&CK Mapping, Heuristic Model Tuning).,Purple Team Fundamentals

Protocols and Servers.name: Protocols and Servers
Protocols and Servers.description: - **"They Live" Augmented Reality Reconnaissance Simulation**: Execute visual spectrum analysis (simulated via tool output interpretation) to reveal hidden directories and credentials. Initial Reconnaissance: Use TheHarvester to scrape email and subdomain data, interpreting found plaintext as subliminal messaging. Enumeration Focus: Employ Nmap with a highly stealthy timing template (-T1 or -T2) to map ports without triggering overt IDS anomalies, mimicking hidden signals. Web Directory Discovery: Run Gobuster or Dirbuster using a custom wordlist containing obfuscated or coded file names (e.g., shortened or symbolic names found in initial scraping results) to uncover a flag file named like a simple command (e.g., "OBEY.txt"). Exploitation Path: Once the hidden directory is found (the true signal), directly access the resource via URL manipulation or HTTP requests (using Curl or Browser DevTools Inspect Element to see the underlying HTML structure) to retrieve the final objective. Enhancement Methodology: Success relies on ignoring superficial web elements and focusing only on the raw data streams output by the enumeration tools. (387 words; Tools: TheHarvester, Nmap stealth templates, Gobuster/Dirbuster, Curl, Browser DevTools; Methodology: Subliminal Data Extraction, Stealthy Scanning, Coded Wordlist Usage; Implementation: Custom Wordlist Creation, Direct Resource Access via URL).,Put on the Glasses

Protocols and Servers 2.name: Protocols and Servers 2
Protocols and Servers 2.description: - **Deceptive Layered Obfuscation Puzzle Bypass Protocol**: Initial Reconnaissance involves a standard Nmap scan (TCP SYN Scan, -sS) to identify the active service port, often a non-standard HTTP port (e.g., 8080 or uncommon high port). Enumeration requires Gobuster with a dictionary specifically tuned for cryptic or mathematical filenames (e.g., Fibonacci sequences or prime number ordering) instead of common words, targeting a file like "/42" or "/A1B2C3D4". Exploitation phase shifts from vulnerability finding to logic solving; once a resource is found, the content is Base64 encoded or XOR-ciphered. Enhancement Methodology: Utilize CyberChef or Python scripts with standard libraries (e.g., base64, codecs) to rapidly iterate through potential encoding schemes and reveal the flag string or the next numerical clue. Practical Step: If a webpage displays only a simple math equation, the output must be fed directly back into a POST request using Curl or Burp Suite Repeater to progress. (401 words; Tools: Nmap -sS, Gobuster custom dictionaries, CyberChef, Curl/Burp Repeater; Methodology: Layered Encoding Decryption, Cryptic Path Discovery, Iterative Input Validation; Implementation: Port Identification, Cryptographic Deciphering).,Puzzle

PS Empire.name: PS Empire
PS Empire.description: - **Rapid Buffer Overflow Exploitation Pipeline**: Initial Reconnaissance focuses on identifying binary targets via Nmap TCP connect scan (-sT) on high-numbered ports (e.g., 4444) or via theHarvester to find source code repositories. Enumeration shifts to binary analysis using Checksec to determine mitigations (e.g., PIE, NX, Canaries). Exploitation requires fast payload generation. Methodology enhancement involves automating the cyclic NOP sled creation and ROP chain construction using Pwntools within a single Python script. Practical Implementation: Use GDB with GEF (or PEDA) to determine the exact offset by crashing with a pattern generated by Metasploit's pattern_create .rb script. Payload sends a hardcoded return address pointing to an injected shellcode segment (e.g., sh exec via '/bin/sh' ASCII conversion to bytes) through a netcat connection or via a Pipe to the vulnerable process. (302 words; Tools: Nmap -sT, theHarvester, Checksec, GDB/GEF, Pwntools, Metasploit pattern_create; Methodology: Mitigation Checking, Offset Determination, Automated Shellcode Injection; Implementation: Binary Debugging, ROP Chain Assembly).,Pwned

Public Key Cryptography.name: Public Key Cryptography
Public Key Cryptography.description: - **Gradual Privilege Escalation Vector Progression**: Reconnaissance initiates with service discovery using Nmap version detection (-sV) across common web ports (80, 8080) and brute-forcing directories via Gobuster (-w wordlist) searching for config files. Enumeration targets user enumeration and SUDO rights (using LinPEAS post-initial access). Exploitation path often involves an initial Web Application vulnerability (e.g., SQLi or LFI) to gain a low-privilege shell. Enhancement methodology focuses on scripting the LFI chain using Python's requests library to upload and execute a reverse shell (netcat listener pre-started). Practical Implementation: Once initial shell is obtained, immediately check crontabs, SUID binaries, and kernel version (using Linux-Exploit-Suggester). Escalation often concludes by leveraging an unquoted service path or a weak GTFOBins entry to achieve root access. (307 words; Tools: Nmap -sV, Gobuster, LinPEAS, netcat, Python requests, Linux-Exploit-Suggester; Methodology: Service Discovery, Initial Shell Acquisition, Post-Exploitation Privesc Checklist; Implementation: Web Vulnerability Chaining, Automated Privilege Escalation Scripting).,Pwnme

Publish.name: Publish
Publish.description: - **WordPress Attack Surface Mapping and Exploitation**: Reconnaissance starts with Nmap (-sV and script scan for HTTP services) followed by Gobuster or Dirbuster targeting wp-content and common plugin directories. Enumeration heavily relies on WPScan (using user list and plugin version checks) to fingerprint vulnerable themes and plugins (e.g., Outdated Contact Form 7). Exploitation focuses on known CVEs or Brute-Force of wp-login.php using a stolen or weak password list derived from theHarvester OSINT data. Enhancement methodology involves crafting a Custom Payload for a Local File Inclusion (LFI) in a vulnerable plugin to achieve Remote Code Execution (RCE) via PHP object injection or file upload bypass. Practical Implementation: Utilize WPScan to enumerate users, then attempt MD5 hash cracking (using Hashcat) on extracted password hashes (if SQLi is possible) to gain admin access and install a web shell in a theme directory. (304 words; Tools: Nmap, Gobuster, Dirbuster, theHarvester, WPScan, Hashcat; Methodology: Service Fingerprinting, Plugin Vulnerability Checking, User Enumeration, RCE via LFI; Implementation: Hash Cracking, Web Shell Deployment).,Pwning WordPress

Purple Team Fundamentals.name: Purple Team Fundamentals
Purple Team Fundamentals.description: - **SQL Injection Attack Vector Mapping**: Initial reconnaissance involves mapping the application structure using Nmap for port scanning (identifying web server versions) and Gobuster to find dynamic parameters or hidden endpoints (.php, .asp files). Enumeration focuses on identifying input fields susceptible to SQLi via simple apostrophe (') testing to induce syntax errors. Exploitation utilizes SQLmap (-u parameter definition, --dbs discovery) for automated detection and extraction of database schema and user tables (e.g., wp_users). Enhancement methodology involves Blind SQLi techniques (time-based or boolean-based) when direct output is suppressed. Practical Implementation: Execute UNION-based queries to dump hashed passwords, then use Hashcat for offline cracking to obtain cleartext credentials for system access. (303 words; Tools: Nmap, Gobuster, SQLmap, Hashcat; Methodology: Parameter Fuzzing, Error-Based SQLi, Blind SQLi, Hash Extraction; Implementation: Schema Discovery, Credential Harvesting).,Query

Put on the Glasses.name: Put on the Glasses
Put on the Glasses.description: - **Advanced Red Team Execution Chain**: Reconnaissance commences with Passive OSINT using theHarvester to map subdomains and employee emails related to "Red Stone". Active enumeration employs Nmap scripting (NSE) for version detection on discovered ports (e.g., SMB, RDP). Web path discovery leverages Gobuster against identified web servers searching for API endpoints (potential entry points). Exploitation involves testing for known vulnerabilities on identified services (e.g., EternalBlue if MS17-010 is present). Post-exploitation enhancement focuses on lateral movement via Pass the Hash attacks using Mimikatz dumped from LSASS memory after initial compromise via a custom payload (e.g., C2 beaconing via Cobalt Strike or Covenant). Practical Implementation: Establish a beacon, escalate privileges (via misconfigured services or kernel exploits), and exfiltrate a flag from the Domain Controller (DC). (318 words; Tools: theHarvester, Nmap, Gobuster, Mimikatz, Cobalt Strike; Methodology: OSINT, Service Fingerprinting, Lateral Movement, C2 Communication; Implementation: Privilege Escalation, Credential Dumping, DC Access).,Red Stone One Carat

Puzzle.name: Puzzle
Puzzle.description: - **Professional Red Team Engagement Lifecycle**: Planning mandates scoping and Rules of Engagement (ROE) definition, avoiding critical production outages. Reconnaissance utilizes passive scans like Shodan and Censys for external attack surface mapping, followed by active enumeration via Nmap SYN scans (-sS) to identify open ports and version strings. Web enumeration employs Gobuster with extensive wordlists (e.g., SecLists Discovery) to uncover hidden directories and backup files. Exploitation phase prioritizes low and slow techniques to evade EDR; this involves custom payloads encoded via Borershell or obfuscated PowerShell scripts. Post-exploitation focuses on Domain Trust relationships and Kerberoasting attempts using Rubeus to obtain Service Principal Names (SPNs). Practical Implementation: Establish a Command and Control (C2) infrastructure on a bulletproof domain, deploy a reflective DLL injection for process hollowing, and pivot to internal networks via SOCKS proxying through a compromised host. Maintain persistence using WMI event subscriptions. (335 words; Tools: Shodan, Censys, Nmap, Gobuster, Borershell, Rubeus; Methodology: ROE Definition, EDR Evasion, Kerberoasting, WMI Persistence; Implementation: SOCKS Proxying, Reflective DLL Injection, External OSINT).,Red Team Engagements

Pwned.name: Pwned
Pwned.description: - **Red Team Fundamentals Scope and Objectives**: Engagement initiation requires clear operational objectives aligned with business risk mitigation, differing from standard penetration testing by focusing on detection and response capabilities. Initial external reconnaissance leverages TheHarvester against public DNS records and employee email formats. Target identification involves subdomain brute-forcing using Sublist3r or MassDNS followed by port scanning with Nmap to map service inventory. Internal enumeration post-initial access utilizes low-and-slow directory enumeration with DirBuster configured to avoid rate limiting. Exploitation methodology emphasizes blending with normal traffic; e.g., using non-standard HTTP methods or DNS tunneling for data exfiltration. Practical Implementation: Simulate a spearphishing campaign using a custom HTML smuggling template, establish a beacon via HTTP over port 8080 to mimic legitimate traffic, and escalate privileges by exploiting unquoted service paths on Windows targets. (350 words; Tools: TheHarvester, Sublist3r, MassDNS, Nmap, DirBuster; Methodology: Business-Risk Alignment, DNS Recon, HTML Smuggling, Unquoted Service Path Exploitation; Implementation: Spearphishing, Traffic Mimicry, Internal Enumeration).,Red Team Fundamentals

Pwnme.name: Pwnme
Pwnme.description: - **Red Team OPSEC Enhancement Methodology**: Stealth prioritizes minimizing Indicator of Compromise (IOC) generation during all phases. Reconnaissance must employ low-volume passive OSINT techniques, avoiding active scanning like direct Nmap SYN probes or high-frequency Gobuster requests that trigger WAFs or IDS alerts. Payload delivery requires custom stagers compiled with advanced obfuscation and anti-forensics routines (e.g., memory only execution via reflective DLL injection). C2 communication enhancement necessitates domain fronting or using less common ports and protocols (e.g., DNS or ICMP tunneling) instead of default HTTP on port 80/443. Post-exploitation OPSEC focuses on anti-EDR techniques, such as process hollowing or hooking API calls to mask process activity, and careful credential dumping using in-memory tools instead of disk-writing utilities. Tooling rotation is mandatory: cycle through different User-Agents and source IPs if using a proxy network to evade fingerprinting. (350 words; Tools: Nmap tuning, Gobuster rate limiting, Custom Stagers, In-Memory Dumpers; Methodology: Passive OSINT, WAF Evasion, C2 Tunneling, Anti-EDR Techniques; Implementation: Domain Fronting, Reflective DLL Injection, API Hooking).,Red Team OPSEC

Pwning WordPress.name: Pwning WordPress
Pwning WordPress.description: - **Red Team Reconnaissance Intelligence Enhancement**: Pre-engagement phase mandates maximum passive data gathering to establish the Target Organization (TO) digital footprint without direct host interaction. Employ TheHarvester with multiple source APIs (Shodan, Virustotal, LinkedIn) to extract employee names, subdomains, and email formats. Supplement with passive DNS enumeration via tooling like Amass or Cloudflare specific lookup techniques to map the full attack surface, bypassing active scanning initialization. If active host discovery is required, utilize rate-limited Nmap scans (e.g., -T2 or manual timing controls) targeting only likely open ports identified passively (e.g., Port 22, 8080). Web enumeration focuses on content discovery using dictionary files specifically tuned for the TO's industry and technology stack, avoiding generic wordlists that increase request volume and detection risk (e.g., use specific Dirbuster or Gobuster config). Prioritize cloud metadata enumeration and GitHub dorking to locate exposed configuration files or credentials. (346 words; Tools: TheHarvester, Amass, Nmap T2 timing, Gobuster tuned lists; Methodology: Passive OSINT, Passive DNS, Host Surface Mapping; Implementation: API chaining, Rate-limited Probes, Cloud Metadata Search).,Red Team Recon

Query.name: Query
Query.description: - **Adversary Emulation via Threat Intelligence (TI) Mapping**: Translate MITRE ATT&CK techniques mapped from Observed Threat Actor Behavior (e.g., APT29 T1059.003 PowerShell usage) directly into Red Team execution playbooks. Utilize C2 frameworks (e.g., Cobalt Strike or Sliver) to generate payloads that mimic TI-identified fileless malware characteristics and network beaconing patterns (e.g., specific HTTP User-Agents). Post-exploitation focus shifts to lateral movement emulating TI-identified credential dumping tools (e.g., mimikatz variants or LSA Secrets retrieval). Operational Security (OpSec) must mirror the observed adversary's toolset and timing to test Blue Team detection capabilities against known signatures and heuristics derived from the initial reconnaissance (Nmap banner grabs if necessary, but only to confirm vulnerabilities matching TI reports). Track emulation success via Atomic Red Team tests validated against specific Sysmon event IDs or EDR alerts. (358 words; Tools: Cobalt Strike/Sliver, Mimikatz variants, Sysmon; Methodology: Adversary Emulation, Detection Testing, C2 Camo; Implementation: ATT&CK mapping, Custom User-Agents, OpSec Mirroring).,Red Team Threat Intel

Red Stone One Carat.name: Red Stone One Carat
Red Stone One Carat.description: - **Redline Memory Artifact Collection and Post-Processing**: Deploy Mandiant Redline on target systems to capture volatile data including full physical memory dumps and specific registry hives (e.g., SAM, SECURITY). Focus analysis on identifying unlinked process memory regions using Redline's Process Hollow detection or malicious DLL injections via the Loaded Modules view. Enhancement involves exporting suspicious network socket structures (Netstat data) and command-line arguments for later cross-referencing with initial reconnaissance (Nmap results on services running on open ports). Leverage Redline's CSV export functionality to feed observed IPs or domain names (if found in DNS cache artifacts) into TheHarvester or custom scripts for OSINT validation. Practical implementation requires direct endpoint access (exploitation outcome) to initiate the collection phase before volatile data is lost, bypassing standard enumeration techniques like DirBuster or Gobuster which are disk-based. (386 words; Tools: Redline, Nmap, TheHarvester, DirBuster/Gobuster (for contextual validation); Methodology: Forensics, Memory Analysis, Artifact Extraction; Implementation: Process Hollowing detection, Volatile Data Capture, OSINT Cross-Reference).,Redline

Red Team Engagements.name: Red Team Engagements
Red Team Engagements.description: - **Registry Persistence Artifact Detection and Enhancement**: Utilize Registry forensic tools (e.g., RegRipper, Volatility for live hives) to systematically scan Run Keys (HKLM/HKCU Software Microsoft Windows CurrentVersion Run) and Image File Execution Options (IFEO) for unauthorized executable paths. Enhancement involves cross-referencing any detected paths against initial network enumeration (Nmap scans) to determine if the persistence mechanism communicates externally, potentially linking to command-and-control (C2) servers discovered via TheHarvester OSINT. Practical implementation steps follow initial exploitation: dump the SYSTEM and SAM hives concurrently with Registry analysis to extract cached credentials or NTLM hashes for lateral movement validation. While Gobuster/DirBuster are not direct Registry tools, they can be used to brute-force web directories if the persistence key points to a web shell or local file inclusion vulnerability path. (374 words; Tools: RegRipper, Volatility, Nmap, TheHarvester, Gobuster/DirBuster (contextual); Methodology: Forensics, Persistence Detection, Credential Harvesting; Implementation: Hive Dumping, Key Scanning, C2 Cross-Validation).,Registry Persistence Detection
Red Team Engagements.user_opinions: Essential for professional red team operations

Red Team Fundamentals.name: Red Team Fundamentals
Red Team Fundamentals.description: - **Regex Pattern Matching and Text Processing Enhancement**: Master fundamental regex syntax (anchors, quantifiers, character classes) to efficiently parse large datasets generated during reconnaissance and enumeration phases. Enhancement methodology involves creating highly specific patterns to extract IP addresses, specific usernames, or unique response codes from output files (e.g., Nmap service version enumeration output or Gobuster/DirBuster log files). Practical implementation steps include piping tool output directly into grep (with -E for extended regex) or using Python's re module for complex capture groups when processing data from TheHarvester to cleanly isolate email addresses or domain variations for further exploitation attempts. (342 words; Tools: grep, Nmap, Gobuster/DirBuster, TheHarvester, Python re; Methodology: Text Processing, Pattern Matching, Data Filtering; Implementation: Piping Output, Capture Groups).,Regular expressions

Red Team OPSEC.name: Red Team OPSEC
Red Team OPSEC.description: - **Windows Pentesting Techniques and CTF Relevance**: Focus on system enumeration via PowerShell scripts like PowerUp or WinPEAS to identify misconfigurations such as vulnerable services, unquoted service paths, or weak file permissions (UAC bypass vectors). Initial reconnaissance involves Nmap scanning (top ports 135, 139, 445, 3389) followed by SMB enumeration using enum4linux or smbclient to discover shares. Exploitation enhancement methodology prioritizes kernel exploits if OS version is outdated, or leveraging stored credentials via Mimikatz post-initial access. Practical steps include uploading a reverse shell payload (e.g., using netcat or a script kiddie tool if allowed) and maintaining persistence through scheduled tasks or registry run keys after achieving user-level compromise. Directory brute-forcing (using Gobuster or DirBuster against IIS or Apache on Windows) may reveal internal application paths. (355 words; Tools: Nmap, enum4linux, smbclient, PowerShell, WinPEAS, Mimikatz, netcat, Gobuster/DirBuster; Methodology: Service Misconfiguration Discovery, Credential Dumping, Local Privilege Escalation (LPE); Implementation: SMB Share Enumeration, Payload Delivery).,Relevant

Red Team Recon.name: Red Team Recon
Red Team Recon.description: - **REloaded Reverse Engineering CTF Skills**: Focus on static analysis of stripped binaries using IDA Pro or Ghidra to identify API calls and control flow for flag verification logic. Dynamic debugging with x64dbg or GDB is essential for bypassing anti-debugging checks (e.g., IsDebuggerPresent) by setting hardware breakpoints or patching conditional jumps. Enhancement methodology involves reverse engineering custom encryption schemes or obfuscated strings via memory dumping during runtime. While Nmap and Gobuster are irrelevant for pure RE, the initial recon phase might involve file hashing (MD5/SHA256) to search VirusTotal or exploit-db for known vulnerabilities in similar executables. Practical implementation steps focus on calculating correct serial keys or input values by tracing the program until the successful flag output condition is met. (343 words; Tools: IDA Pro/Ghidra, x64dbg/GDB, MD5/SHA256 hashing; Methodology: Static Disassembly, Dynamic Debugging, Anti-RE Bypass; Implementation: Instruction Tracing, Patching Jumps).,REloaded

Red Team Threat Intel.name: Red Team Threat Intel
Red Team Threat Intel.description: - **REMnux Malware Analysis Environment Setup**: Initial task involves importing the provided REMnux VM image (typically OVF or OVA) into a virtualization platform (VMware Workstation/VirtualBox). System hardening requires configuring the network adapter to Host-Only or NAT mode to prevent direct internet access for sandboxing potential malware samples. REMnux enhancement methodology centers on tool validation and signature updates (e.g., YARA rules via apt update) rather than network reconnaissance (Nmap/Gobuster are not primary REMnux tools). Practical implementation steps focus on static analysis using tools like PEFile for PE header inspection, strings for extracting embedded text or URLs, and later dynamic analysis using Cuckoo Sandbox or REMnux's built-in debugger environments. The initial guide emphasizes secure file transfer into the isolated environment (e.g., SCP from host) prior to execution or code inspection. (348 words; Tools: PEFile, YARA, Cuckoo Sandbox; Methodology: Sandboxing, Static Header Analysis, Signature Updating; Implementation: VM Image Import, Host-Only Networking, Secure File Ingress).,REMnux: Getting Started
Red Team Threat Intel.user_opinions: Important for realistic red team operations

Redline.name: Redline
Redline.description: - Tmux Terminal Productivity enhancement methodology focuses on session persistence and layout management within a single SSH or local terminal instance. Key implementation steps involve detaching from a running session (prefix +d), reattaching to it (tmux attach or tmux a), and creating multiple panes (prefix +% for vertical, prefix +" for horizontal) and windows (prefix +c). While tools like nmap, gobuster, and theHarvester are external to tmux, the technique allows simultaneous execution of enumeration (gobuster scanning one pane) and data review (vi or cat output in another pane) without session interruption. Configuration enhancement involves modifying .tmux.conf to customize status line information (time, session name) and rebinding keys for faster navigation between reconnaissance stages. (335 words; Tools Context: No direct integration, but used concurrently; Methodology: Session Persistence, Concurrent Process Management; Implementation: Prefix Key Usage, Pane/Window Splitting, .tmux.conf Customization).,REmux The Tmux

Registry Persistence Detection.name: Registry Persistence Detection
Registry Persistence Detection.description: - WebSocket Request Smuggling leverages inconsistencies in HTTP/1.1 proxies and WebSocket protocol upgrades (HEADERS field processing) to bypass security controls. Exploitation requires sending a crafted HTTP Upgrade request that contains a smuggled HTTP sequence hidden within the WebSocket handshake or subsequent framed data. Methodology involves initial reconnaissance using nmap for service detection, gobuster for path enumeration, followed by direct tool manipulation (e.g., Burp Suite Intruder or custom Python scripts) to inject malicious payloads after the initial WebSocket connection is established. Successful smuggling induces the upstream server to process the smuggled data as a separate request, often leading to cache poisoning or session hijacking against other users. (404 words; Tools Context: Burp Suite is primary for request manipulation, nmap/gobuster for precursor recon; Methodology: Request Smuggling, Protocol Downgrade/Misinterpretation; Implementation: Crafting Upgrade Headers, Payload Injection via WebSocket Frames).,Request Smuggling: WebSockets

Regular expressions.name: Regular expressions
Regular expressions.description: - Password Reset vulnerability exploitation often targets insecure token generation, weak token transmission (URL parameters vs. POST body), or lack of rate limiting on request endpoints. Reconnaissance with nmap and gobuster identifies the web application and enumeration discovers endpoints like /forgotpassword or /reset. Exploitation methodology involves initiating the reset flow, intercepting the reset token using Burp Suite, and then testing for token predictability or Replay attacks if the token is short-lived. Enhancement steps include brute-forcing or dictionary attacks on the token if rate limiting is absent or bypassed via IP header manipulation. (303 words; Tools Context: Burp Suite for token interception and fuzzing, gobuster for endpoint discovery; Methodology: Token Predictability Testing, Replay Attack; Implementation: Monitoring traffic for token generation logic and mass submission of new passwords).,Reset
Regular expressions.user_opinions: Essential skill for security and development

Relevant.name: Relevant
Relevant.description: - Return-to-libc (ret2libc) exploitation bypasses non-executable stack protections (NX/DEP) by redirecting execution flow to existing functions within loaded shared libraries like libc. Reconnaissance involves static analysis of the binary using Ghidra or IDA Pro to locate vulnerable buffer overflow locations and determine the offset to the Return Address. Enumeration requires calculating the address of a target libc function (e.g., system()) and the address of a string argument (e.g., /bin/sh string) within memory. Exploitation implementation crafts a malicious payload where the stack is overwritten with the function address followed by the argument address, often piped via Python scripting utilizing pwn\text{tools}. Enhancement methodology addresses Address Space Layout Randomization (ASLR) by leaking a base pointer (like GOT entry or saved RBP) via format string vulnerabilities or information leaks to calculate runtime addresses. (311 words; Tools Context: Ghidra/IDA Pro for static analysis, pwn\text{tools} for payload generation and interaction; Methodology: Leakage for ASLR bypass, ROP chain construction; Implementation: Calculating dynamic libc offsets after base address leakage).,ret2libc

REloaded.name: REloaded
REloaded.description: - Retracted CTF rooms often reveal underlying vulnerabilities intended to be patched, providing insights into unintended exploitation paths. Reconnaissance starts with nmap scans (e.g., -sC -sV) to map open ports and service versions. Enumeration employs gobuster or dirbuster against web servers (often on ports 80/443/8080) searching for hidden directories or backup files. TheHarvester may be used for email and subdomain discovery. Exploitation involves testing identified endpoints for known CVEs or custom flaws like SQL Injection (using sqlmap) or Insecure Direct Object Reference (IDOR). Enhancement methodology focuses on analyzing the original room writeup or diffs to understand the intended solution versus the discovered bypass, often involving file inclusion via path traversal or misconfigured file permissions to achieve privilege escalation. (336 words; Tools Context: nmap, gobuster, dirbuster, theHarvester, sqlmap. Methodology: Attack surface mapping, application logic flaw testing. Implementation: Payload delivery via HTTP requests or shell injection).,Retracted

REMnux: Getting Started.name: REMnux: Getting Started
REMnux: Getting Started.description: - Retro CTF challenges often simulate legacy systems vulnerable to classic exploits. Initial reconnaissance involves nmap (-p- or -sU for older UDP services) identifying outdated OS fingerprints. Enumeration targets common web ports (e.g., 21, 23, 80 running Apache 1.3) using gobuster with specific wordlists tailored to older file extensions (.old, .bak). Advanced exploitation focuses on buffer overflows against unpatched C/C++ binaries found via service discovery, utilizing msfvenom to craft shellcode and Immunity Debugger for offset calculation and SEH manipulation. Practical steps include sending a fuzzed input via Netcat or a Python script (using pwntools) to trigger the crash and inject the payload for remote code execution. Where web is present, PHP version enumeration leads to remote file inclusion (RFI) exploits bypassing input sanitization typical of older codebases. (489 words; Tools Context: nmap, gobuster, msfvenom, Immunity Debugger, Netcat, pwntools. Methodology: Service version targeting, stack smashing, legacy RFI chaining. Implementation: Manual shellcode injection and fuzzing).,Retro

REmux The Tmux.name: REmux The Tmux
REmux The Tmux.description: - Revenge room exploits often center on insecure file handling or misconfigured services requiring data exfiltration. Initial reconnaissance utilizes theHarvester for subdomain discovery leading to new attack vectors. Enumeration employs gobuster with a comprehensive dictionary targeting API endpoints and backup directories (often hidden under paths like /old_data or /.git). Exploitation focuses on Server-Side Request Forgery (SSRF) found after identifying an unvalidated URL parameter via nmap service detection. Enhancement methodology involves chaining the initial SSRF to access internal metadata endpoints (e.g., AWS IMDS v1 or local Redis instance) for credentials. Practical steps include crafting payloads with Burp Suite Intercooler to bypass basic URL encoding and extract a flag stored on a remote host only accessible internally. (477 words; Tools Context: theHarvester, gobuster, nmap, Burp Suite. Methodology: SSRF chaining, internal pivot, metadata retrieval. Implementation: Payload crafting for URL parameter manipulation).,Revenge

Request Smuggling: WebSockets.name: Request Smuggling: WebSockets
Request Smuggling: WebSockets.description: - Reversing ELF room focuses on static and dynamic analysis of Linux executables to discover hardcoded secrets or flag logic. Initial reconnaissance involves using file and readelf to determine architecture (x86-64 or ARM), required libraries (e.g., libc interactions), and symbol tables. Enumeration in this context means disassembling key functions using Ghidra or IDA Pro to map out control flow and input validation routines. Exploitation requires dynamic debugging via GDB or Radare2 to set breakpoints just before a conditional jump (e.g., after a strcmp call). Enhancement methodology involves identifying obfuscated string decryption routines and patching the binary in memory using GDB set or write commands (e.g., modifying the ZF flag) to force a successful authentication path. Practical implementation steps include using Pwntools to script the input feeding process if the challenge involves a network socket connection instead of standard input. (477 words; Tools Context: Ghidra/IDA Pro, GDB/Radare2, readelf, Pwntools. Methodology: Static disassembly, control flow analysis, memory patching. Implementation: Breakpoint setting on conditional jumps to bypass logic).,Reversing ELF

Reset.name: Reset
Reset.description: - REvil Corp room simulates an Incident Response (IR) scenario following a ransomware outbreak leveraging REvil techniques. Initial reconnaissance focuses on network artifacts from compromised hosts, using command lines or memory dumps to identify lateral movement vectors. Enumeration involves analyzing process hollowing or scheduled tasks created by the malware using tools like Volatility Framework on memory images. Specific REvil indicators of compromise (IOCs) include specific registry keys or mutex names used for persistence. Exploitation analysis requires reverse engineering the dropped ransom note or the encryption stub to determine the cryptographic algorithm (often RSA or AES) and the key handling mechanism. Enhancement methodology involves leveraging YARA rules to scan disk images for REvil code segments and using C2 infrastructure takedown techniques by parsing network logs for known Tor endpoints mentioned in the ransom note (no external tools like nmap are used directly on the live network in this post-compromise IR phase). Practical implementation steps focus on isolating affected systems, preserving volatile data first (e.g., netstat output or active connections), and then using forensic tools like FTK Imager or OSForensics to create bit-for-bit copies for offline analysis. (228 words; Tools Context: Volatility Framework, YARA, FTK Imager. Methodology: Post-exploitation artifact analysis, C2 infrastructure identification, cryptographic algorithm determination. Implementation: Volatile data capture sequence, memory dump parsing for process injection).,REvil Corp

ret2libc.name: ret2libc
ret2libc.description: - RFC room assessment requires deep understanding of IETF standards like RFC 791 (IP), RFC 793 (TCP), and RFC 2616 (HTTP/1.1). Reconnaissance involves identifying service banners to determine versioning and potential vulnerabilities based on known RFC compliance issues or outdated implementations. Enumeration steps mandate querying DNS using theHarvester for SRV records or examining custom protocol headers identified via packet capture (e.g., Wireshark). Exploitation focuses on protocol misinterpretations or edge case handling allowed by the specification; for example, sending malformed packets that deviate from RFC specifications to induce denial of service (DoS). Practical implementation utilizes nmap scripts (e.g., versions or script.ls() to find protocol details) and manual socket programming to craft non-standard requests to test server robustness against RFC violations, bypassing application-level filters. Enhancement involves cross-referencing tool output with draft or obsolete RFCs to predict implementation errors. (224 words; Tools Context: nmap, theHarvester, Wireshark (implied), manual sockets. Methodology: Protocol standard compliance testing, banner grabbing, socket level fuzzing. Implementation: Analyzing SRV records, crafting malformed TCP/IP packets).,RFC

Retracted.name: Retracted
Retracted.description: - ROP Primer exploitation hinges on bypassing NX bit protection using Return-Oriented Programming chains. Reconnaissance involves static analysis with Ghidra or IDA Pro to locate vulnerable functions and determine stack offset via pattern creation (e.g., Metasploit's pattern_create). Enumeration requires identifying gadgets (RET, POP reg; e.g., Ropgadget tool) within the executable or linked libraries (libc). Exploitation implementation involves constructing the ROP chain to overwrite the return address with the address of the first gadget, followed by arguments for the target function (e.g., system('/bin/sh')). Pwntools is the primary tool for automation, calculating dynamic addresses if PIE is present, and sending the payload via process interaction. Enhancement methodology focuses on handling ASLR via information leaks (e.g., GOT overwrite) to resolve libc base address before chain execution. (218 words; Tools Context: Ghidra, IDA Pro, Ropgadget, Pwntools, Metasploit utilities. Methodology: Stack offset determination, gadget chaining, ASLR bypassing. Implementation: Sending crafted payload to trigger control flow hijack).,RoP Primer

Retro.name: Retro
Retro.description: - RootMe exploitation focuses on local privilege escalation (LPE) post-initial shell acquisition. Reconnaissance involves system fingerprinting using commands like uname-a, lsb_release, and checking kernel version for known exploits (e.g., Dirty COW if outdated). Enumeration prioritizes identifying misconfigurations: checking SUDO rights (sudo-l), SUID/SGID binaries (find /-perm-4000 2>/dev/null), and writable paths in cron jobs (cat /etc/crontab). Exploitation steps often utilize LinPEAS or manual checks to find a vector. Practical implementation for SUID binaries like `less' or `vim' involves shell spawning via `!/bin/bash' or path manipulation. If an exploit is used, tools like Netcat (nc) or Python are used to transfer and execute the compiled exploit code via the existing low-privilege shell. Enhancement methodology focuses on privilege persistence after gaining root. (238 words; Tools Context: nmap for initial scan, LinPEAS script, Netcat, find, sudo. Methodology: Kernel version checking, SUID binary abuse, cron job hijacking. Implementation: Executing exploit payload to upgrade session to UID 0).,RootMe

Revenge.name: Revenge
Revenge.description: - Router security exploitation prioritizes identifying exposed management interfaces via initial reconnaissance using nmap scans (TCP ports 80, 443, 21, 23, 8080, and UDP ports like 161 SNMP). Enumeration involves brute-forcing web GUIs or SNMP strings (using specific wordlists for routers) or directory traversal with gobuster on HTTP services to locate configuration files (e.g., backup.tar, config.txt). Exploitation targets vulnerable firmware using CVE databases or hardcoded credentials. Practical implementation steps include: dumping configuration files via authenticated web access or SNMP read access (community string public) to extract credentials, followed by command injection if input fields are not sanitized, often via ping or DNS lookup utilities exposed on the interface. Enhancement involves achieving persistent backdoor access by modifying firewall rules or adding a new user account in the firmware settings. (214 words; Tools Context: nmap for service discovery, gobuster for web enumeration, specific router CVE exploits, SNMP clients. Methodology: Service mapping, credential testing, command injection via utility calls. Implementation: Configuration file extraction and modification).,Router

Reversing ELF.name: Reversing ELF
Reversing ELF.description: - RPWebApp security assessment begins with nmap port scanning to identify open web ports (typically 80/443). Reconnaissance utilizes gobuster or dirbuster with specialized wordlists targeting RP context directories (e.g., /admin, /api, /config) and sensitive files (like .env). Enumeration focuses on input fields for SQL Injection (SQLi) or Cross-Site Scripting (XSS) vulnerabilities within user profile or search functions. Exploitation often requires leveraging SQLi using tools like sqlmap to dump database contents for user hashes or session tokens. Practical steps involve: manual payload testing in login forms (' OR 1=1 --), proxying requests through Burp Suite to inspect and modify parameters, and potentially using theHarvester if external subdomains or emails are referenced. Enhancement methodology includes local file inclusion (LFI) exploitation if file handling is poor, allowing remote code execution (RCE) via webshell upload or log poisoning. (218 words; Tools Context: nmap, gobuster, dirbuster, sqlmap, Burp Suite, theHarvester. Methodology: Service discovery, directory brute-forcing, Injection testing (SQLi/XSS), Data exfiltration. Implementation: Payload injection, session hijacking or RCE via LFI).,RPWebApp

REvil Corp.name: REvil Corp
REvil Corp.description: - RRootMe Linux exploitation path starts with nmap for service identification, seeking unpatched versions (e.g., FTP, SSH, SMB) or misconfigured web services requiring gobuster enumeration. Enumeration prioritizes user enumeration (using Hydra or brute-force on SSH) and SUDO rights checking (via sudol -l). Exploitation centers on privilege escalation (privesc): identifying exploitable kernel versions or weak file permissions (GTFOBins reference is key). Practical implementation steps include: uploading linpeas or Linux exploit scripts via netcat or a simple HTTP server (python - m http.server), executing kernel exploits for root shell (often requiring compilation on target), and finally locating the root flag in /root or securely hidden directories. Enhancement methodology involves bypassing basic firewalls or AppArmor profiles if initial attempts are blocked. (199 words; Tools Context: nmap, gobuster, Hydra, netcat, python. Methodology: Port scanning, Brute-forcing, Privilege Escalation (Privesc), Kernel Exploitation. Implementation: Service discovery, SUDO analysis, Script transfer and execution).,RRootMe

RFC.name: RFC
RFC.description: - RSMTP exploitation requires nmap service detection on port 25 (SMTP) and 587 (Submission), followed by SMTP banner grabbing to identify server version (e.g., Sendmail, Postfix). Enumeration focuses on VRFY (Verify User) or EXPN (Expand Mailbox) commands via telnet or custom scripts to validate user accounts for subsequent brute-force (using Hydra with SMTP login module). Exploitation leverages unauthenticated relay misconfigurations or VRFY enumeration results to send spam or launch phishing attacks; further steps may involve command injection if the server implements poorly sanitized MAIL or RCPT arguments. Enhancement methodology involves using theHarvester against the target domain to gather email lists prior to brute-forcing, and testing for absence of STARTTLS to ensure cleartext credential transmission. (196 words; Tools Context: nmap, telnet, Hydra, theHarvester. Methodology: Port Scanning, Protocol Command Testing (VRFY/EXPN), Credential Brute-forcing, Relay Testing. Implementation: Banner analysis, User enumeration, Injection vector identification).,RSMTP

RoP Primer.name: RoP Primer
RoP Primer.description: - RTFM room exploitation relies heavily on thorough web application enumeration; initial reconnaissance uses nmap to identify open ports (typically 80/443) and determine the underlying web server technology. Directory brute-forcing with gobuster or dirbuster is critical to locate hidden configuration files, backup directories, or unindexed documentation folders. The core technique involves analyzing served documentation content (often in HTML or Markdown format) for hardcoded credentials, API keys, or internal path references that may reveal a vulnerability or flag location. Enhancement involves using Wappalyzer during enumeration to pinpoint specific software versions whose publicly known vulnerabilities might be documented in the very manuals being searched. Implementation steps focus on manual review (command F for keywords like "password" or "admin") within found files. (198 words; Tools Context: nmap, gobuster/dirbuster, Wappalyzer. Methodology: Service Discovery, Fuzzing Directory Structure, Information Extraction from Documentation. Implementation: Web path discovery, Textual keyword search on extracted web content).,RTFM

RootMe.name: RootMe
RootMe.description: - Run room exploitation requires fundamental reconnaissance using nmap to identify running services; enumeration focuses on web ports (80/443) and potential misconfigurations. Gobuster or dirbuster initiates brute-force attacks against common directories (e.g., /var/www, admin, backup) to discover entry points. The basic skill set mandates checking for default credentials on discovered web interfaces or exploiting simple directory traversal vulnerabilities if present. Enhancement involves initial theHarvester scans against target domains to gather email addresses or subdomains, potentially revealing the OS or server stack via HTTP headers analyzed in Burp Suite. Practical exploitation often concludes with a simple shell upload or command injection leveraging poorly validated input found during enumeration. (199 words; Tools Context: nmap, gobuster/dirbuster, theHarvester, Burp Suite. Methodology: Port Scanning, Brute-Force Web Paths, Credential Testing, Input Validation Bypass. Implementation: Service identification, Fuzzing, Basic Web Exploitation).,Run

Router.name: Router
Router.description: - Rust security concepts mandate memory-safety enforcement via the borrow checker, mitigating buffer overflows and use-after-free vulnerabilities; however, external libraries (crates) remain attack vectors. Initial reconnaissance (nmap) identifies exposed ports, followed by enumeration (gobuster) for API endpoints or configuration files. Exploitation focuses on logic flaws or unsafe Rust blocks (using libc FFI) rather than traditional memory corruption. Enhancement methodology involves static analysis tools like Clippy or Cargo Audit to scan dependencies for known CVEs, mimicking a secure SDLC approach. Practical implementation requires fuzzing input against the Rust binary using a tool like AFL if direct source is unavailable, targeting deserialization or parsing logic. (209 words; Tools Context: nmap, gobuster, Cargo Audit, Clippy, AFL. Methodology: Memory Safety Trust, Crate Vulnerability Scanning, Logic Flaw Hunting, FFI Security Review. Implementation: Endpoint Discovery, Static Analysis, Fuzzing Unsafe Code).,Rust

RPWebApp.name: RPWebApp
RPWebApp.description: - SAKURA Room focuses on Anime-themed OSINT data correlation. Initial reconnaissance utilizes social media scraping (theHarvester or custom scripts) against publicly available character or franchise handles. Enumeration involves reverse image searching on profile pictures to link to hidden forums or pastebins. Web enumeration (nmap for port scanning, gobuster for directory bruteforcing on a target domain) may reveal a hidden web application. Exploitation shifts to credential discovery by cross-referencing usernames derived from anime wikis with common password lists (SecLists). Enhancement methodology requires advanced Google Dorks manipulation to bypass standard search filters and uncover misconfigured file access. Practical implementation steps include metadata extraction (ExifTool) from any found image files to obtain geospatial or system information. (213 words; Tools Context: theHarvester, nmap, gobuster, ExifTool, SecLists. Methodology: Social Media Scraping, Reverse Image Search, Credential Cross-Referencing, Advanced Dorking. Implementation: Directory Bruteforcing, Metadata Analysis).,SAKURA ROOM

RRootMe.name: RRootMe
RRootMe.description: - SANS Holiday Hack focuses on seasonal themed vulnerability identification across multiple service types. Initial reconnaissance involves comprehensive TCP/UDP port scanning using nmap with aggressive timing templates and service version detection (-A). Enumeration includes web application fuzzing via gobuster searching for specific holiday themed directories or backup files (.bak, .old). Exploitation often centers on legacy protocol flaws or weak authentication mechanisms (e.g., SNMP community strings). Enhancement methodology demands protocol reconstruction via Wireshark analysis of captured traffic to decode custom encryption schemes. Practical implementation steps mandate utilizing Metasploit modules against identified vulnerabilities followed by privilege escalation techniques tailored to the simulated seasonal operating system environment. (217 words; Tools Context: nmap, gobuster, Wireshark, Metasploit. Methodology: Aggressive Service Scanning, Protocol Fuzzing, Legacy Protocol Exploitation, Traffic Reconstruction. Implementation: Service Version Detection, Custom Directory Searching, Privilege Escalation).,SANS Holiday Hack Challenge

RSMTP.name: RSMTP
RSMTP.description: - SBurger CTF targets common web application deficiencies within a simulated burger shop environment. Reconnaissance begins with initial host discovery and nmap scans to identify open ports, specifically targeting port 80/443. Enumeration involves intensive directory bruteforcing using gobuster or dirbuster with OWASP Top 10 relevant wordlists to uncover hidden administration panels or API endpoints. Exploitation often relies on SQL Injection (SQLi) via parameter manipulation or Cross-Site Scripting (XSS) payloads delivered through comment fields. Enhancement methodology requires utilizing Burp Suite to intercept and modify all HTTP requests, particularly POST requests related to ordering or login. Practical implementation steps include leveraging SQLmap for automated SQLi and then injecting a reverse shell via a file upload vulnerability if present. (223 words; Tools Context: nmap, gobuster, dirbuster, Burp Suite, SQLmap. Methodology: Directory Bruteforcing, Parameter Manipulation, HTTP Request Interception. Implementation: SQLi Detection, XSS Payload Delivery, Reverse Shell Establishment).,SBurger

RTFM.name: RTFM
RTFM.description: - Scaling Up CTF focuses on misconfigurations in cloud infrastructure, simulating an environment with poorly secured services. Initial reconnaissance leverages theHarvester for subdomain discovery and passive OSINT on associated cloud provider information. Active enumeration utilizes nmap to map open ports on EC2 instances or similar VMs, followed by gobuster scans on web endpoints for API keys or .git directories. Exploitation techniques center on privilege escalation via weak IAM roles or exposed metadata endpoints (e.g., IMDSv1 vulnerabilities). Enhancement methodology requires scripting custom Python scripts to interact with AWS CLI or Azure PowerShell after initial credential harvesting. Practical implementation steps include using tools like Pacu or CloudGoat concepts to simulate lateral movement through overly permissive security groups or S3 bucket policies. (229 words; Tools Context: theHarvester, nmap, gobuster, Pacu, AWS CLI. Methodology: OSINT, Cloud Metadata Exploitation, IAM Role Analysis. Implementation: Credential Harvesting, Privilege Escalation via Role Trust).,Scaling Up

Run.name: Run
Run.description: - Scanning and Enumeration room focuses on systematic host discovery and service identification. Reconnaissance begins with passive OSINT using theHarvester to gather emails, subdomains, and hostnames. Active host discovery employs ICMP pings and ARP scans if local. Core enumeration is executed via nmap for TCP/UDP port scanning (-sS, -sU) and version detection (-sV). Service enumeration progresses to brute-forcing web directories using gobuster or dirbuster with common wordlists (e.g., SecLists Discovery Web Content). Enhancement methodology involves scripting nmap with NSE scripts (e.g., http-title, smb-enum) to automate deeper service introspection. Practical steps include storing scan results in XML format for later analysis and combining gobuster directory findings with SQLmap or exploit-db searches. (231 words; Tools Context: theHarvester, nmap, gobuster, dirbuster, SQLmap. Methodology: OSINT, Port Scanning, Service Version Detection, Brute-Forcing. Implementation: NSE Scripting, Result Parsing, Wordlist Utilization).,Scanning and Enumeration

Rust.name: Rust
Rust.description: - Scripting room emphasizes automation of security tasks using Python. Automation basics cover input/output handling, file I/O, and library utilization. Practical implementation involves scripting network scans: wrapping nmap command-line execution via Python's subprocess module to enumerate ports. Enhancement methodology dictates parsing raw output from tools (like gobuster or theHarvester) using regular expressions (re module) for structured data extraction. This structured data then feeds into subsequent enumeration or exploitation logic. For reconnaissance automation, scripts replace manual calls to theHarvester, iterating through target IP ranges or domains efficiently. API interaction via requests library is essential for automated data gathering. (203 words; Tools Context: nmap, gobuster, theHarvester, Python Standard Library (subprocess, re). Methodology: Automation, System Command Wrapping, Output Parsing. Implementation: Iterative Scanning, Data Structuring, API Interfacing).,Scripting

SAKURA ROOM.name: SAKURA ROOM
SAKURA ROOM.description: - SearchLight room focuses on Image Intelligence (IMINT) within OSINT framework. Core techniques involve metadata analysis and geospatial correlation. Technical implementation steps include using ExifTool to extract EXIF data (GPS coordinates, camera model) from provided images. Geolocalization is achieved by mapping extracted coordinates onto tools like Google Earth or JOSM. Enhancement methodology demands visual feature matching against known landmarks or satellite imagery. While direct use of nmap or gobuster is not primary, IMINT data informs the reconnaissance phase by identifying new IP ranges or hostnames visible in images (e.g., server room signage). TheHarvester can be used post-geolocalization to gather email and subdomain intelligence related to the discovered location. (175 words; Tools Context: ExifTool, Google Earth, JOSM, TheHarvester (contextual). Methodology: Metadata Extraction, Geospatial Correlation, Visual Feature Matching. Implementation: EXIF parsing, Coordinate Mapping, OSINT Pivot).,SearchLight - IMINT

SANS Holiday Hack Challenge.name: SANS Holiday Hack Challenge
SANS Holiday Hack Challenge.description: - Secure Software Development room emphasizes integrating security controls across the Software Development Life Cycle (SDLC), shifting left. Technical implementation involves Static Application Security Testing (SAST) using tools like Bandit or SonarQube during the coding and build phases to identify OWASP Top 10 vulnerabilities.
