Dynamic Application Security Testing (DAST) occurs post-deployment or staging, where tools analogous to web app scanners (e.g., Burp Suite Intruder for enumeration or fuzzing) simulate exploitation attempts. Reconnaissance in this context pertains to threat modeling during requirements gathering. Enhancement methodology requires implementing secure defaults, input validation at all boundaries, and utilizing parameterized queries to prevent SQLi. The concept moves beyond traditional network scanners (nmap) toward code auditing. (180 words; Tools Context: Bandit, SonarQube, Burp Suite Intruder (analogous). Methodology: SAST, DAST, Threat Modeling. Implementation: Code Review, Input Validation, Parameterized Queries).,Secure Software Development

SBurger.name: SBurger
SBurger.description: - SecureSolaireYou room is a Dark Souls themed CTF requiring exploitation of misconfigured web services. Initial reconnaissance utilizes nmap for identifying open ports and service versions, often targeting HTTP/HTTPS. Enumeration proceeds with directory brute-forcing using gobuster or dirbuster to uncover hidden directories or administrative interfaces (e.g., /.git, /.svn). Exploitation focuses on web vulnerabilities like Insecure Direct Object Reference (IDOR) or command injection related to theme-specific inputs. Enhancement methodology involves post-exploitation privilege escalation leveraging weak file permissions or kernel exploits found via local enumeration after initial shell gain. (147 words; Tools: nmap, gobuster, dirbuster. Methodologies: Reconnaissance, Enumeration, Exploitation, Privilege Escalation. Implementation: Port Scanning, Directory Brute-forcing, IDOR testing).,SecureSolaireYou

Scaling Up.name: Scaling Up
Scaling Up.description: - Security Awareness room focuses on human factors in cybersecurity, often simulating phishing or social engineering attacks. Technical reconnaissance may involve using theHarvester to gather employee email formats or subdomain information for crafting spear-phishing payloads. While nmap or gobuster are less central, the exploitation phase revolves around user interaction, such as clicking a malicious link or submitting credentials to a simulated login portal. Enhancement methodology involves analyzing user input data via backend logging to quantify susceptibility rates. (119 words; Tools: theHarvester, Implied Phishing Frameworks. Methodologies: Social Engineering, Data Collection, User Behavioral Analysis. Implementation: Email Harvesting, Simulated Credential Theft).,Security Awareness

Scanning and Enumeration.name: Scanning and Enumeration
Scanning and Enumeration.description: - Security Engineer Intro room introduces foundational defensive and offensive security concepts, often requiring basic network scans. Reconnaissance utilizes nmap for identifying live hosts and open ports (e.g., TCP SYN scan). Enumeration may involve using gobuster or dirbuster to brute-force common web directories (e.g., /admin, /.git). Exploitation is usually abstracted, focusing on understanding vulnerability classification rather than active exploitation. Enhancement methodology focuses on documenting system architecture diagrams and initial threat modeling. (119 words; Tools: nmap, gobuster, dirbuster. Methodologies: Port Scanning, Web Directory Brute-Forcing, Asset Discovery. Implementation: Service Version Detection, Web Path Enumeration).,Security Engineer Intro

Scripting.name: Scripting
Scripting.description: - Security Operations room focuses on Security Information and Event Management (SIEM) log analysis and incident response workflows. Initial threat intelligence gathering often mimics reconnaissance, potentially using theHarvester for OSINT on domains, though primary tasks involve alert validation. Enumeration translates to log data drilling down from high-level alerts (e.g., brute-force attempts identified via WAF logs). Exploitation is simulated through identifying indicators of compromise (IOCs). Enhancement methodology involves tuning SIEM correlation rules to reduce false positives and developing runbooks for Tier 1 analyst triage. (119 words; Tools: SIEM interface (Splunk/ELK equivalent), theHarvester. Methodologies: Incident Triage, Log Forensics, IOC Matching. Implementation: Querying firewall and authentication logs, Generating alert response documentation).,Security Operations

SearchLight - IMINT.name: SearchLight - IMINT
SearchLight - IMINT.description: - Security Principles room reinforces CIA triad (Confidentiality, Integrity, Availability) and Defense-in-Depth (DiD). Techniques involve analyzing vulnerability scanning reports (e.g., output from simulated nmap scans showing open ports), mapping to Least Privilege enforcement. Enumeration contextually applies to identifying misconfigurations that violate Integrity controls (e.g., unrestricted file upload paths identified via gobuster or dirbuster). Enhancement methodology focuses on prioritizing patch management based on severity scores (CVSS) to strengthen DiD. Practical implementation involves documenting access control matrices and implementing strong password policies. (122 words; Tools: nmap, gobuster, dirbuster. Methodologies: Vulnerability Assessment, Access Control Mapping, Patch Management. Implementation: Analyzing scan results, Mapping findings to CIA principles).,Security Principles

Secure Software Development.name: Secure Software Development
Secure Software Development.description: - Seekr room focuses on SQL Injection (SQLi) via unvalidated search parameters. Reconnaissance utilizes nmap for service discovery and gobuster to identify hidden endpoints (e.g., directories or APIs). Exploitation involves crafting time-based or error-based SQLi payloads to extract database schema (UNION SELECT or blind techniques). Enhancement methodology mandates parameterized queries (prepared statements) to neutralize SQLi vulnerabilities. Practical steps include input validation at the application layer and principle of least privilege for database service accounts. theHarvester may be used in initial recon for subdomain enumeration. (135 words; Tools: nmap, gobuster, theHarvester. Methodologies: Reconnaissance, Enumeration, SQLi Exploitation. Implementation: Parameterized queries, Input validation).,Seekr

SecureSolaireYou.name: SecureSolaireYou
SecureSolaireYou.description: - SEH Overflow room targets vulnerable Windows applications using stack overflows to hijack control flow via Structured Exception Handlers. Reconnaissance involves identifying target service versioning using nmap or service banner grabbing. Exploitation requires calculating offset to overwrite the SEH record with the address of the shellcode. Methodology utilizes Python scripts with pwntools or similar for payload generation, often injecting a reverse shell or incognito shellcode. Enhancement methodology focuses on implementing Non-Executable stack (NX/DEP) and Address Space Layout Randomization (ASLR) mitigations to prevent exploitation. dirbuster/gobuster are less relevant for this binary level exploit. (135 words; Tools: nmap, pwntools (implied Python scripting). Methodologies: Reconnaissance, Stack Overflow, Control Flow Hijacking. Implementation: Offset calculation, Shellcode injection, Mitigation analysis).,SEH Overflow

Security Awareness.name: Security Awareness
Security Awareness.description: - SSTI room exploitation targets dynamic template rendering vulnerabilities (Jinja2, Twig, Velocity). Reconnaissance involves identifying template engine via error-based payloads (e.g., Jinja2 {{7*7\}} or similar math evaluations). Enumeration uses gobuster/dirbuster for discovering hidden endpoints. Exploitation focuses on achieving Remote Code Execution (RCE) by accessing underlying system APIs through the template context objects (e.g., subprocess or os modules). Advanced steps include bypassing input sanitization using template-specific polymorphism and obfuscation techniques to execute shell commands and establish a reverse shell. theHarvester may be used for initial domain enumeration. (138 words; Tools: gobuster, dirbuster, theHarvester. Methodologies: Reconnaissance, Template Engine Fingerprinting, RCE via Context Manipulation. Implementation: Payload crafting, Bypassing filters).,Server-Side Template Injection

Security Engineer Intro.name: Security Engineer Intro
Security Engineer Intro.description: - Serverless room exploitation focuses on AWS Lambda or Azure Functions misconfigurations. Reconnaissance involves identifying exposed API Gateways and function endpoints, potentially using nmap for port scanning or direct URL enumeration. Enumeration targets IAM roles and attached policies for overly permissive permissions (e.g., wildcard access to S3 or DynamoDB). Exploitation leverages improper input validation within the function handler to inject commands or access environment variables containing secrets. Enhancement methodology involves lateral movement from a compromised function to other cloud resources via assumed roles. (137 words; Tools: nmap for initial network discovery on related infrastructure. Methodologies: Cloud Role Enumeration, Injection into Function Handler. Implementation: IAM privilege escalation via function context).,Serverless

Security Operations.name: Security Operations
Security Operations.description: - Services room guide focuses on identifying and understanding common network services running on targets. Reconnaissance starts with nmap aggressive scans (-sA) or version detection (-sV) to map open ports and service banners. Enumeration progresses by tailoring tool usage to specific ports; e.g., using gobuster or dirbuster on port 80/443 for web directory brute-forcing, or connecting directly to FTP/SMB services for anonymous access. Exploitation involves testing banner information against public exploits or default credentials. Enhancement methodology involves leveraging theHarvester post-enumeration to gather external context about the target domain related to misconfigured services. (140 words; Tools: nmap, gobuster, dirbuster, theHarvester. Methodologies: Port Scanning, Service Fingerprinting, Directory Brute-forcing. Implementation: Protocol-specific interaction based on nmap output).,Services

Security Principles.name: Security Principles
Security Principles.description: - Shell Commands room focuses on essential Linux CLI mastery for system interaction and initial exploitation phases. Fundamentals include file navigation (cd, ls, pwd), file manipulation (cp, mv, rm, cat, less), and permission management (chmod, chown). Enumeration involves using commands like ps aux to identify running processes, netstat -tuln for listening sockets, and find with appropriate flags to locate sensitive files (e.g., find / -name "config.php"). Exploitation often relies on redirection and piping (command | grep, command >> file) to extract data or inject payloads. Enhancement methodology integrates these commands with network tools; e.g., using bash to transfer a payload downloaded via wget or curl after an initial nmap scan reveals an open shell. (157 words; Tools: nmap, wget, curl utilized via shell. Methodologies: File System Traversal, Process Inspection, Data Exfiltration. Implementation: Chaining standard utilities with pipes and redirections).,Shell Commands

Seekr.name: Seekr
Seekr.description: - Shell Scripting room focuses on automating repetitive tasks using Bash, incorporating variables, loops (for, while), conditional statements (if/elif/else), and function definitions. Automation basics center on scripting sequences of commands for efficiency. Practical implementation involves creating reconnaissance scripts that automatically execute nmap port scans and pipe output to grep or awk for parsing results. Enhancement methodology extends to building custom enumeration workflows; e.g., a script iterates through a list of IPs, running gobuster or dirbuster against each host and saving unique directory findings to separate log files. Exploitation automation can include scripts to mass-check for specific vulnerabilities identified during initial theHarvester OSINT gathering. (171 words; Tools: nmap, gobuster, dirbuster, theHarvester, grep, awk. Methodologies: Automated Reconnaissance, Systematic Enumeration, Bulk Vulnerability Checking. Implementation: Looping external tool execution with dynamic parameter substitution).,Shell Scripting

SEH Overflow.name: SEH Overflow
SEH Overflow.description: - Shodan.io room focuses on leveraging the IoT search engine for advanced OSINT and network reconnaissance. Technique involves crafting specific Shodan queries using filters like `country:', `port:', `org:', and `product:' to identify exposed infrastructure. Practical implementation uses the Shodan CLI or API to programmatically extract IP ranges and banner information. Enhancement methodology integrates Shodan output into subsequent enumeration steps; e.g., exporting Shodan-discovered IPs and feeding them as input lists for automated nmap scans or gobuster/dirbuster attacks. This superset of reconnaissance can precede more targeted exploitation by pinpointing specific service versions exposed to the internet, reducing time spent on passive OSINT tools like theHarvester. (168 words; Tools: Shodan CLI/API, nmap, gobuster, dirbuster, theHarvester (for comparison). Methodologies: OSINT via Internet Scanning, Active Reconnaissance Targeting, Data Pipeline Integration. Implementation: Filter crafting, API data piping).,Shodan.io

Server-Side Template Injection.name: Server-Side Template Injection
Server-Side Template Injection.description: - Simple CTF room utilizes foundational exploitation techniques requiring initial network reconnaissance. Methodology starts with nmap full port scan (`-sC -sV' or Agressive scan `-A' on identified host IPs to fingerprint services. Enumeration involves directory bruteforcing using gobuster or dirbuster on web ports (e.g., 80, 443, 8080) with common wordlists. Enhancement involves manual review of web server banners and source code to locate vulnerabilities like insecure file uploads or misconfigurations. Exploitation often culminates in simple command injection or local file inclusion (LFI) to obtain a reverse shell or read flag files. TheHarvester is used only if external email or subdomain OSINT is necessary to find the target machine. (157 words; Tools: nmap, gobuster, dirbuster, theHarvester (secondary). Methodologies: Port Scanning, Web Enumeration, Command Injection Exploitation. Implementation: Banner grabbing, Bruteforce attacks, Reverse shell listener setup).,Simple CTF

Serverless.name: Serverless
Serverless.description: - Skynet room focuses on AI themed vulnerabilities, starting with nmap Service Version detection (`-sV') to identify obsolete protocols. Enumeration targets non-standard ports often associated with proprietary API endpoints, using gobuster with custom wordlists containing Skynet keywords (e.g., 'target' 'judgment' 'T-800'). Enhancement involves exploiting an XML External Entity (XXE) vulnerability on a simulated AI interface to extract internal configuration files. Exploitation path requires LFI or path traversal via a GET parameter to read the local flag or obtain initial user credentials. TheHarvester may be used to scour for compromised internal domain names related to 'Cyberdyne' Systems if external recon is required. (165 words; Tools: nmap, gobuster, theHarvester (optional), Manual HTTP requests via Burp Suite necessary for XXE payload delivery. Methodologies: Service Fingerprinting, Custom Bruteforcing, XXE Exploitation, Path Traversal. Implementation: Payload injection into XML document structure).,Skynet

Services.name: Services
Services.description: - SmagGrotto room entails web application enumeration targeting a SMB share or web portal hidden within the grotto. Initial recon utilizes nmap scripting engine (NSE) for SMB enumeration (`smb-enum-shares') after identifying port 445 open. Gobuster or dirb with common directory names like 'cave' 'secrets' 'logbook' reveals a vulnerable upload mechanism. Exploitation focuses on shell upload via a misconfigured PHP script, requiring bypass of file extension filters using null byte injection or double extension techniques. Successful upload of a reverse shell payload to be triggered by subsequent web access grants a low-privileged shell. Privilege escalation may involve searching for insecure SUDO entries or kernel exploits relevant to the target OS. (167 words; Tools: nmap, gobuster/dirb, Burp Suite for request manipulation. Methodologies: Port Scanning, SMB Enumeration, Web Directory Bruteforcing, Shell Upload Exploitation, Post-Exploitation Prep. Implementation: HTTP POST request with multipart/form-data containing the webshell).,SmagGrotto

Shell Commands.name: Shell Commands
Shell Commands.description: - SmagGrotto network forensics requires PCAP analysis after initial compromise or network traffic capture. Wireshark filters isolate SMB traffic (tcp.port == 445) and HTTP requests revealing directory enumeration attempts using common wordlists like those used with gobuster. Specific technique involves decrypting SMB session traffic if credentials are captured incleartext during the exploitation phase. Replay captured HTTP POST requests containing webshell payloads using Tcpreplay against a local honeypot to replicate the vulnerability trigger. Forensic enhancement includes extracting embedded base64 encoded commands from HTTP POST bodies that represent system command execution. (173 words; Tools: Wireshark, Tshark, Tcpreplay, CyberChef. Methodologies: Packet Capture Filtering, Protocol Reconstruction, Payload Extraction, Command Reconstruction. Implementation: Applying display filters for unencrypted credentials or application layer data transfer).,Smag Grotto

Shell Scripting.name: Shell Scripting
Shell Scripting.description: - SMTP misconfiguration exploitation begins with nmap script scanning (nmap -sV -p 25 --script=smtp-commands,smtp-open-proxy) to identify extended command support like VRFY, EXPN, or Relay restrictions. Enumeration proceeds using theHarvester with -d targetdomain -b smtp to gather valid email addresses. Exploitation involves brute-forcing user lists via SMTP AUTH using Metasploit's auxiliary/scanner/smtp/smtp_login module or custom scripts with telnet for manual AUTH PLUTO attempts. Post-exploitation enhancement focuses on confirming open relay by crafting a valid MAIL FROM and RCPT TO sequence to send email to an external address without authentication. (183 words; Tools: nmap, theHarvester, telnet, Metasploit. Methodologies: Service Fingerprinting, User Enumeration, Authentication Bypassing, Relay Testing. Implementation: Scripted bruteforce via Metasploit or manual VRFY testing over port 25).,SMTP Misconfigurations

Shodan.io.name: Shodan.io
Shodan.io.description: - Snort IDS configuration analysis requires initial network reconnaissance using nmap to map target ports and service versions, informing the creation of custom detection rules. Rule exploitation involves crafting signatures using alert action targeting specific payloads or TCP/UDP flags observed during attack simulation (e.g., web shell indicators like POST requests with suspicious parameters). Methodology enhancement involves testing rule efficacy by injecting the attack signature via a traffic replay tool like tcpreplay or manual packet generation to verify Snort logs (/var/log/snort/alert) correctly fire the defined signature. (186 words; Tools: nmap, tcpreplay, Snort CLI. Methodologies: Network Mapping, Signature Development, Traffic Injection, Log Verification. Implementation: Developing a rule with signature content and testing detection against synthetic malicious traffic).,Snort

Simple CTF.name: Simple CTF
Simple CTF.description: - Live attack detection in Snort mandates continuous monitoring of live packet streams after initial enumeration using gobuster to uncover hidden directories. Enhancement involves writing specific threshold rules (threshold: type limit ...) to counter rapid successive requests indicative of brute-forcing or port scanning that might bypass simple signature matches. Implementation requires setting Snort to HOME_NET variables accurately to differentiate internal vs. external traffic, then analyzing alert output against evidence of exploitation attempts from scanning tools. (194 words; Tools: gobuster, Snort CLI. Methodologies: Directory Enumeration, Threshold Tuning, Real-time Monitoring, Network Security Contextualization. Implementation: Tuning Snort HOME_NET and developing rate-limiting detection rules to identify automated reconnaissance activity).,Snort Challenge - Live Attacks

Skynet.name: Skynet
Skynet.description: - Snort IDS fundamentals rely on signature-based detection using rule options like content and pcre to match known malicious payloads generated during reconnaissance phase often initiated by nmap sweeps. Enhancement involves transitioning from simple content matching to stateful protocol analysis (sid: X, msg: ...", flow: established, ...) to accurately track multi-step enumeration sequences simulated by tools like dirbuster. Practical implementation requires correctly defining the network variables (HOME_NET, EXTERNAL_NET) within snort.conf before activating the detection engine to capture TCP handshakes and HTTP requests. (213 words; Tools: nmap, dirbuster, Snort CLI. Methodologies: Signature Tuning, Protocol Analysis, Configuration Management. Implementation: Developing baseline detection rules using content and flow keywords to identify unauthorized scanning activity).,Snort Challenge - The Basics

SmagGrotto.name: SmagGrotto
SmagGrotto.description: - SOC analysis techniques mandate continuous security monitoring using SIEM platforms to parse logs generated by IDS like Snort and endpoint security agents. Enhancement involves developing custom detection rules within the SIEM to correlate low-level events (e.g., nmap port scans, gobuster directory attempts) into high-fidelity incidents. Practical implementation focuses on querying event data using SPL (Search Processing Language) or similar query languages to trace exploitation vectors identified from web server access logs following an enumeration phase. (218 words; Tools: SIEM platform (e.g., Splunk, ELK), nmap, gobuster. Methodologies: Log Aggregation, Event Correlation, Incident Triage. Implementation: Tuning SIEM alerts for lateral movement indicators derived from initial reconnaissance data).,SOC Analysis

Smag Grotto.name: Smag Grotto
Smag Grotto.description: - SOC automation leverages SOAR platforms to orchestrate playbooks for handling known threat patterns identified during initial reconnaissance phases like theHarvester data collection. Enhancement involves scripting automated data enrichment workflows triggered by suspicious network activity (e.g., mass nmap scans or dirbuster brute-forcing attempts). Practical implementation focuses on API integration to automatically quarantine hosts flagged during enumeration and initiate sandboxing of potential exploitation payloads without manual analyst intervention. (228 words; Tools: SOAR platform (e.g., Phantom, Cortex XSOAR), theHarvester, nmap, dirbuster. Methodologies: Orchestration, Playbook Development, Automated Response. Implementation: Building API calls to firewalls and EDR systems based on scan data thresholds).,SOC Automation

SMTP Misconfigurations.name: SMTP Misconfigurations
SMTP Misconfigurations.description: - SOC fundamentals require mastery of detection and triage workflows mapping to the attack lifecycle (reconnaissance, enumeration, exploitation). Technical implementation involves configuring SIEM rules to ingest logs indicating host discovery via nmap or vulnerability scanning attempts like gobuster dirbuster web enumeration. Enhancement methodology centers on developing runbooks to automatically correlate outbound data leak indicators with initial theHarvester-style OSINT activity for prioritized incident handling. (225 words; Tools: SIEM (e.g., Splunk, ELK), nmap, gobuster, dirbuster, theHarvester. Methodologies: Log Analysis, Alert Triage, Runbook Development. Implementation: Creating correlation searches and defining severity levels for enumeration successes).,SOC Fundamentals

Snort.name: Snort
Snort.description: - Level 1 SOC training mandates alert validation against predefined IOCs derived from initial reconnaissance outputs (e.g., IPs flagged by nmap scans or domains harvested by theHarvester). Practical implementation involves using the SIEM to investigate web server access logs for suspicious path traversals indicated by failed gobuster or dirbuster attempts prior to actual exploitation. Enhancement methodology focuses on escalation procedures when initial triage confirms active enumeration tools interacting with internal assets. (244 words; Tools: SIEM platform, nmap, gobuster, dirbuster, theHarvester. Methodologies: Alert Validation, Log Triage, Incident Escalation. Implementation: Cross-referencing external recon data with internal traffic logs).,SOC Level 1

Snort Challenge - Live Attacks.name: Snort Challenge - Live Attacks
Snort Challenge - Live Attacks.description: - SOC Workbooks require custom lookup table integration to enrich raw SIEM events with context derived from external reconnaissance phases (e.g., mapping nmap open ports or web directories found via gobuster). Practical implementation involves writing queries that join firewall logs against a pre-populated Threat Intelligence lookup populated from initial theHarvester output to score enumeration activity. Enhancement methodology focuses on automating this enrichment to reduce false positives during initial triage of potential exploitation indicators detected by behavioral analytics within the workbook environment. (279 words; Tools: SIEM Query Language, nmap, gobuster, theHarvester. Methodologies: Data Enrichment, Threat Intelligence Integration, Behavioral Analytics. Implementation: Developing SIEM lookups to correlate external scans with internal alerts).,SOC Workbooks and Lookups

Snort Challenge - The Basics.name: Snort Challenge - The Basics
Snort Challenge - The Basics.description: - Solar CTF challenge requires initial nmap scan identifying non-standard ports subsequent to initial reconnaissance using theHarvester for domain enumeration. Enumeration involves dirbuster or gobuster brute-forcing web directories to locate SolarWinds or similar platform configuration files. Exploitation methodology focuses on SQL injection or path traversal against the exposed web application endpoint validated by the initial port scan, leading to command execution and flag retrieval. Practical implementation steps mandate output from enumeration tools be parsed to prioritize payload delivery vectors. (290 words; Tools: nmap, theHarvester, dirbuster, gobuster. Methodologies: Reconnaissance, Enumeration (Web Directory Bruteforcing), Exploitation (SQLi, Path Traversal). Implementation: Correlating service discovery with vulnerability discovery).,Solar

SOC Analysis.name: SOC Analysis
SOC Analysis.description: - Source code security analysis requires initial nmap scan for discovering versioning information followed by theHarvester to gather developer email addresses and potential repository URLs. Enumeration utilizes gobuster for discovering .git directories or backup files which are then subjected to static code review using grep or a dedicated SAST tool to identify hardcoded credentials or insecure API key usage. Exploitation techniques involve developing proof-of-concepts based on identified vulnerabilities like insecure deserialization or command injection found via code digging. Enhancement methodology prioritizes deep dive into the web application logic revealed by dirbuster directory listing to find underlying scripts. (310 words; Tools: nmap, theHarvester, gobuster, dirbuster, grep. Methodologies: Reconnaissance, Enumeration (Directory Listing), Code Review (SAST Principles), Exploitation (Deserialization, Command Injection). Implementation: Linking network discovery to source artifact retrieval).,Source

SOC Automation.name: SOC Automation
SOC Automation.description: - Comprehensive source code security demands integration of secure development lifecycle (SDLC) practices. Reconnaissance begins with nmap scans targeting version disclosure on running services. Enumeration shifts to using gobuster or dirbuster for discovering hidden directories and configuration files, often leading to sensitive code snippets. TheHarvester may reveal internal repository references. Static analysis of retrieved code must check for OWASP Top 10 flaws like SQL Injection and XSS patterns. Exploitation validation involves crafting payloads to confirm vulnerability severity. Enhancement methodology mandates implementing input validation and output encoding at the development stage, enforcing principle of least privilege within application logic. (308 words; Tools: nmap, gobuster, dirbuster, theHarvester. Methodologies: Reconnaissance, Enumeration, Code Analysis (Static), Exploitation Validation. Implementation: SDLC integration, Input Validation, Output Encoding).,Source Code Security

SOC Fundamentals.name: SOC Fundamentals
SOC Fundamentals.description: - Intermediate Splunk techniques in SIEM operations focus on advanced data correlation and threat hunting beyond basic searches. Initial reconnaissance might employ nmap to map Splunk component ports (e.g., 8000, 8089). Enumeration involves using gobuster against web interfaces to find misconfigurations or hidden REST endpoints for data input. Technical exploitation simulations involve crafting SPL (Search Processing Language) queries utilizing the join, transaction, and predict commands to link disparate security events across indexes. Practical implementation steps include developing custom correlation searches for lateral movement detection using base searches and scheduled alerts. Enhancement methodology prioritizes TTP (Tactics, Techniques, and Procedures) mapping to MITRE ATT&CK framework within Splunk dashboards for proactive defense. TheHarvester may assist in identifying external IPs to monitor in network logs. (308 words; Tools: nmap, gobuster, theHarvester. Methodologies: Reconnaissance, Enumeration, SPL Querying, Threat Hunting. Implementation: Custom Correlation Searches, ATT&CK Mapping).,Splunk 2

SOC Level 1.name: SOC Level 1
SOC Level 1.description: - Advanced Splunk techniques for SIEM involve complex machine learning toolkit (MLTK) integrations for anomaly detection on high-volume data streams. Reconnaissance extends to identifying all potential data sources ingested via Deployment Server configurations. Enumeration focuses on identifying privilege escalation vectors within Splunk user roles and capabilities using internal logs (splunkd.log). Exploitation simulation requires writing SPL that leverages subsearches and statistical functions (like rare and anomalydetection) to uncover low-and-slow attacks. Practical implementation involves deploying custom Python scripts as lookup files or modular inputs to enrich security events. Enhancement methodology mandates performance tuning of index and search head clustering to maintain real-time visibility. While nmap or gobuster are external scanners, their output must be efficiently indexed for Splunk analysis. (312 words; Tools: MLTK integration, internal logs. Methodologies: Anomaly Detection, Statistical Analysis, Cluster Tuning. Implementation: Modular Inputs, Custom Lookups).,Splunk 3

SOC Workbooks and Lookups.name: SOC Workbooks and Lookups
SOC Workbooks and Lookups.description: - Splunk SIEM introduction centers on ingesting firewall logs (e.g., Cisco ASA or pfSense) via Universal Forwarders using TCP port 9997. Basic reconnaissance involves using nmap to identify open ports and subsequently configuring inputs.conf stanzas to monitor these services. Enumeration translates to initial data parsing using the PIPE (|) character with commands like stats, count, and timechart on sourcetype=firewall. Exploitation practice is simulated by searching for failed login attempts or excessive denied connections via SPL. Enhancement methodology at this stage focuses on defining initial alerts on high-volume events using the Alert Builder. Practical steps include verifying data integrity via the Data Summary page. Tools like theHarvester can generate external context data to be manually uploaded as lookups. (303 words; Tools: Universal Forwarders, nmap, theHarvester. Methodologies: Data Ingestion, Parsing. Implementation: inputs.conf configuration, SPL basic commands, Alert Creation).,Splunk: Basics

Solar.name: Solar
Solar.description: - Splunk Dashboards employ Visualization API (JS based) to render search results from underlying SPL queries. Reports are scheduled exports of these searches. Enhancement methodology involves utilizing multiple inputs within a single dashboard panel using the input tag for dynamic filtering. Reconnaissance output from nmap scans (e.g., XML format) must be ingested and indexed before visualization. Enumeration on the dashboard is achieved by applying drilldown actions to visual elements, linking low-level event data to higher-level KPIs. Exploitation context is visualized via choropleth maps if IP geolocation lookups are applied to traffic logs. Practical implementation steps include defining Time Range Pickers and Dropdown inputs, binding them to the base search string using the token mechanism (e.g., ‚Üíken\). Reports are generated via Settings arrow Searches, and scheduled to email PDF or CSV attachments. Tools like gobuster or dirbuster outputs can inform web access monitoring dashboards. (316 words; Tools: nmap, gobuster, dirbuster. Methodologies: Data Visualization, Scheduled Reporting. Implementation: Input token binding, Drilldown configuration, PDF export scheduling).,Splunk: Dashboards and Reports

Source.name: Source
Source.description: - Advanced SPL data manipulation leverages subsearches via the `join`, `append`, and `map` commands to enrich primary event streams. Enhancement methodology focuses on statistical processing using `eventstats` and `streamstats` to calculate running totals and outlier detection without losing individual event context. Reconnaissance data from theHarvester must be normalized using `rex` or `spath` to extract email or host fields before joining to proxy logs. Enumeration results from gobuster directory listings are processed with `lookup` to flag unauthorized access attempts in web server logs. Practical implementation involves using the `transaction` command to group related events (e.g., login success followed by data export) over a defined time window. Exploitation indicators, such as high volume of failed SSH attempts, are condensed using `stats` count by src_ip and then piped to `where` clause to filter thresholds. Leverage the `dedup` command after complex joins to maintain search performance. nmap port scan data is often enriched using CIDR lookups to attribute scans to internal or external subnets. (277 words; Tools: theHarvester, gobuster, nmap. Methodologies: Statistical Aggregation, Data Enrichment. Implementation: Subsearch chaining, `transaction` windowing, `eventstats` application).,Splunk: Data Manipulation

Source Code Security.name: Source Code Security
Source Code Security.description: - Deep dive into Splunk Processing Language (SPL) mastery focuses on optimizing search pipeline stages, specifically utilizing high-cardinality fields early in the search to reduce intermediate result sets. Enhancement methodology demands premature field extraction via `eval` or `spath` before expensive commands like `stats` or `timechart`. Reconnaissance indicators, such as DNS records parsed from theHarvester output, are indexed via automatic or manual lookups for rapid correlation. Enumeration activities, specifically web directory fuzzing logs generated by gobuster or dirbuster, are filtered using `where status‚â†200' to isolate potential vulnerabilities. Practical implementation involves leveraging the `inputlookup` command to pre-stage known-good hashes or IP blacklists for real-time comparison against nmap scan records. Exploitation detection is refined by using `streamstats` count over a sliding window to identify abnormal event frequency patterns that suggest a successful injection. Advanced statistical modeling employs `map` to apply a complex statistical function to each subsearch result. (279 words; Tools: theHarvester, gobuster, dirbuster, nmap. Methodologies: Pipeline Optimization, Anomaly Frequency Detection. Implementation: Premature Extraction, Lookup Pre-staging, `streamstats` windowing).,Splunk: Exploring SPL

Splunk 2.name: Splunk 2
Splunk 2.description: - Setting up Splunk SOC lab mandates deploying Universal Forwarders (UF) on simulated endpoints to ingest diverse data sources like Windows Event Logs (XML/EVTX) and Linux syslog. SIEM deployment focuses on configuring data inputs via `inputs.conf` and setting appropriate sourcetypes for efficient indexing. Reconnaissance log sources include simulated nmap scan results parsed via `csv` input or direct syslog piping. Enumeration detection requires developing correlation searches that flag repeated failed login attempts mimicking Brute-force via gobuster or dirbuster traffic patterns in web server access logs. Enhancement methodology involves creating lookup tables of known malicious IPs from theHarvester output and joining them to network flow data using the `join` command. Practical implementation steps include writing Splunk Alert Actions to trigger hypothetical isolation scripts upon exploitation indicators detected in process creation events. Tuning data models and accelerated searches enhances SOC dashboard performance. (270 words; Tools: nmap, gobuster, dirbuster, theHarvester. Methodologies: Log Ingestion Optimization, Correlation Rule Development. Implementation: UF Deployment, Lookup Joining, Alert Action Scripting).,Splunk: Setting up a SOC Lab

Splunk 3.name: Splunk 3
Splunk 3.description: - Spring security vulnerability assessment targets misconfigurations in Spring Security filter chains, specifically CSRF token handling or improper method-level security (@PreAuthorize omission). Reconnaissance involves spidering endpoints using Burp Suite or a custom script to map all HTTP methods (GET, POST, PUT, DELETE). Enumeration focuses on identifying exposed endpoints potentially vulnerable to Insecure Direct Object Reference (IDOR) by fuzzing URL path parameters with sequential IDs. Exploitation techniques include attempting Remote Code Execution (RCE) via Spring Expression Language (SpEL) injection if user-supplied input is evaluated unsafely in annotations. Enhancement methodology involves implementing strict CORS policies and utilizing Spring Boot Actuator security settings to restrict access to management endpoints. Practical steps require configuring WebSecurityConfigurerAdapter or SecurityFilterChain Bean to enforce RBAC on all REST controllers and validating input using Bean Validation. (280 words; Tools: Burp Suite, Custom Scripts (replacing nmap for API recon). Methodologies: Endpoint Mapping, Input Fuzzing, Security Configuration Hardening. Implementation: CORS Policy Enforcement, Actuator Restriction, SpEL Sanitization).,Spring

Splunk: Basics.name: Splunk: Basics
Splunk: Basics.description: - Spring4Shell (CVE-2022-22965) exploits improper binding in Spring MVC data binding when using Spring Framework versions 5.3.0-5.3.17 or 5.2.0-5.2.19. Reconnaissance involves using nmap to scan for standard ports (8080, 8443) and identifying the target application server (e.g., Tomcat). Enumeration requires locating the application context path, often achieved via gobuster or dirbuster to find exposed endpoints or application directories. Exploitation targets the specific setter methods within Spring Class WebDataBinder via a malicious HTTP request containing a JSON payload that overwrites a protected property, such as a log4j configuration or a web server attribute to achieve RCE through context manipulation. Practical steps involve crafting a payload to set the request attribute leading to command execution, often by modifying the classloader or request dispatcher. Enhancement methodology mandates immediate patching to Spring Framework versions greater than 5.3.18 or 5.2.20, and disabling Spring MVC if not strictly required to mitigate the vulnerability vector. (310 words; Tools: nmap, gobuster, dirbuster, Custom HTTP Client for Payloads. Methodologies: Port Scanning, Endpoint Discovery, Context Property Manipulation. Implementation: RCE Payload Delivery, Version Downgrade Prevention).,Spring4Shell: CVE-2022-22965

Splunk: Dashboards and Reports.name: Splunk: Dashboards and Reports
Splunk: Dashboards and Reports.description: - SQHell room focuses on advanced SQL Injection (SQLi), often involving blind or time-based techniques when standard error-based methods fail. Reconnaissance begins with nmap for service discovery (ports 80/443), followed by gobuster or dirbuster for web directory and parameter enumeration. Enumeration specifically tests input fields for vulnerability using common SQLi payloads (e.g., AND 1=1, apostrophe test). Exploitation moves to Blind SQLi, requiring Boolean logic or time-delays (SLEEP()) to exfiltrate data character by character if direct output is suppressed. Practical implementation utilizes tools like sqlmap to automate the discovery and dumping of database schema, tables, and eventually the flag. Enhancement methodology involves bypassing WAFs using encoding or obfuscation of SQL keywords (e.g., using comments or hex encoding) if the target environment employs defenses. (304 words; Tools: nmap, gobuster, dirbuster, sqlmap, Custom HTTP Client. Methodologies: Service Discovery, Parameter Fuzzing, Blind Time-Based Exfiltration. Implementation: Schema Dumping, WAF Bypass Techniques).,SQHell

Splunk: Data Manipulation.name: Splunk: Data Manipulation
Splunk: Data Manipulation.description: - SQL Fundamentals room covers basic relational database concepts and initial SQLi testing. Reconnaissance involves nmap scan for running web services (often HTTP on 80) and gobuster for identifying dynamic pages likely querying a backend. Enumeration focuses on identifying vulnerable input fields and testing for error-based SQLi using single quotes (') to force database errors. Database basics include understanding SELECT, FROM, WHERE, and UNION clauses. Exploitation implementation starts with determining column count using ORDER BY or UNION SELECT NULL statements. Practical steps then move to extracting schema information (e.g., information_schema.tables) via UNION attacks. Enhancement involves manual or semi-automated payload construction before transitioning to sqlmap for speed. theHarvester is optional for external recon but less critical than direct web application testing. (305 words; Tools: nmap, gobuster, sqlmap (optional), browser dev tools. Methodologies: Error-Based Detection, Schema Discovery, UNION Attack Construction. Implementation: Column Counting, Data Extraction via UNION).,SQL Fundamentals

Splunk: Exploring SPL.name: Splunk: Exploring SPL
Splunk: Exploring SPL.description: - SQL Injection room focuses on advanced exploitation beyond basic UNION attacks, emphasizing Blind SQLi and Out-of-Band techniques. Reconnaissance employs nmap for service discovery and gobuster or dirbuster to map hidden directories potentially exposing APIs or admin panels. Enumeration involves systematic testing for time-based Blind SQLi using SLEEP() or benchmark functions to confirm vulnerability without direct output. Web security essentials covered include input sanitization failure analysis. Exploitation implementation shifts to character-by-character data extraction via Boolean logic or DNS/HTTP exfiltration for Out-of-Band attacks. Practical steps require mastering ASCII and substring logic within payloads. Enhancement methodology prioritizes automating Blind SQLi data retrieval using sqlmap or custom Python scripts to decode time delays or Boolean responses. theHarvester remains peripheral, but direct application layer fuzzing is key. (305 words; Tools: nmap, gobuster/dirbuster, sqlmap, Python. Methodologies: Blind SQLi Character Extraction, Out-of-Band Techniques, Input Fuzzing. Implementation: SLEEP() testing, ASCII Conversion, Data Exfiltration).,SQL Injection

Splunk: Setting up a SOC Lab.name: Splunk: Setting up a SOC Lab
Splunk: Setting up a SOC Lab.description: - SQL Injection Lab emphasizes hands-on exploitation of classic vulnerabilities in integer and string parameter fields. Reconnaissance involves nmap scans to identify the web server and ports, followed by gobuster utilization for path enumeration of potential login endpoints. Enumeration focuses on character testing with single quotes (') to force SQL errors, confirming vulnerability. Exploitation techniques include simple UNION SELECT attacks to dump schema metadata like table names and column counts. Practical implementation requires manually constructing payloads to bypass basic input filtering on user and password fields. Enhancement methodology involves transitioning from manual payload crafting to sqlmap automation for rapid database schema discovery and data retrieval. theHarvester is not directly applicable to the injected endpoint but useful for initial OSINT. (301 words; Tools: nmap, gobuster, sqlmap. Methodologies: Error-Based SQLi, UNION Injection, Schema Dumping. Implementation: Quote Testing, Payload Construction, Column Counting).,SQL Injection Lab

Spring.name: Spring
Spring.description: - SQLMap room focuses on automated SQL injection exploitation using the sqlmap framework. Initial reconnaissance utilizes nmap to discover running web services and directory enumeration employs gobuster or dirbuster to locate injection points not immediately obvious. Enumeration steps involve sqlmap's parameter discovery (-p option) and database fingerprinting (--fingerprint). Exploitation path centers on direct command execution or data dumping (--dbs, --tables, --columns, --dump). Practical implementation requires specifying the target URL (-u), testing various injection types (--technique BMTU), and managing session cookies (--cookie). Enhancement methodology incorporates leveraging out-of-band techniques (OOB) and utilizing custom tamper scripts to evade Web Application Firewalls (WAFs). theHarvester remains peripheral, useful only for preliminary host identification. (303 words; Tools: sqlmap, nmap, gobuster, dirbuster. Methodologies: Automated SQLi, Fingerprinting, WAF Bypass. Implementation: URL Targeting, Technique Selection, Data Extraction).,SQLMAP

Spring4Shell: CVE-2022-22965.name: Spring4Shell: CVE-2022-22965
Spring4Shell: CVE-2022-22965.description: - SQLMap Basics room introduces automated SQL injection via the command line. Reconnaissance focuses on identifying vulnerable GET parameters (-u flag with URL). Enumeration starts with retrieving database names (--dbs) and user privileges (--current-user). Exploitation path prioritizes in-band techniques like UNION and Error-based SQLi implicitly by default. Practical implementation steps involve testing a single URL for all injection types (--all-test-ids) and then drilling down to dumping specific table content (UNION SELECT structuring). Enhancement methodology begins with verbosely logging output (--v level) to debug payloads. External tools like nmap or gobuster are used preemptively to locate the web application endpoint before SQLMap engagement. theHarvester provides domain context, though not directly interacting with SQLMap automation. (290 words; Tools: sqlmap, nmap, gobuster. Methodologies: In-Band Exploitation, Parameter Discovery, Data Retrieval. Implementation: Direct URL Targeting, Verbose Debugging).,SQLMap: The Basics

SQHell.name: SQHell
SQHell.description: - Squid Game room theme maps challenges to show events requiring systematic enumeration. Reconnaissance involves port scanning via nmap (-sC -sV) to identify active services on target host. Enumeration progresses to directory and file bruteforcing using gobuster or dirbuster with common wordlists to uncover hidden web paths relevant to the challenge narrative. Exploitation steps are tiered, often starting with credential guessing or simple local file inclusion (LFI). Practical implementation requires mapping discovered endpoints to specific game stages (e.g., Red Light, Green Light). Enhancement methodology involves leveraging OSINT via theHarvester if the room introduces external domain targets for information gathering. Privilege escalation techniques follow initial shell acquisition, utilizing linpeas scripts or manual search for misconfigured SUID binaries. (260 words; Tools: nmap, gobuster, dirbuster, theHarvester. Methodologies: Service Discovery, Bruteforcing, OSINT, Privilege Escalation. Implementation: Port Scanning, Directory Fuzzing, Credential Testing).,Squid Game

SQL Fundamentals.name: SQL Fundamentals
SQL Fundamentals.description: - Road themed CTF focuses on linear progression simulating a journey through network segments. Initial reconnaissance mandates comprehensive nmap sweeps (-p-, -A) to map the network landscape and identify gateways. Enumeration targets web ports (80, 443) using gobuster with a specific wordlist tailored to the road theme (e.g., stop, sign, route). Basic exploitation often involves path traversal vulnerabilities or unauthenticated service access discovered via service fingerprinting. Enhancement methodology integrates low-hanging fruit exploitation to gain the first low-privileged shell. Practical implementation steps include piping nmap XML output into scripting for automated vulnerability checks. Lateral movement across simulated road milestones requires re-running the entire cycle on new subnets. (259 words; Tools: nmap, gobuster. Methodologies: Network Mapping, Service Fingerprinting, Path Traversal Exploitation. Implementation: Full Port Scanning, Directory Bruteforcing, Shell Acquisition).,Road

SQL Injection.name: SQL Injection
SQL Injection.description: - Rogue Access Point scenario demands initial wireless reconnaissance using Aircrack-ng suite (airodump-ng) to capture handshakes and identify SSIDs/BSSIDs. Tool enhancement involves using Kismet for passive network mapping to discover hidden SSIDs. Enumeration shifts to host discovery on the compromised network via arp-scan or nmap ICMP sweeps. Exploitation targets weak WPA2-PSK by cracking captured handshakes offline using Hashcat with a large dictionary file. Post-exploitation involves using gobuster against internal web services revealed after client isolation is bypassed. Practical implementation requires monitormode interface setup and deauthentication attacks to force clients to reconnect to the rogue AP. TheHarvester may be used on internal IPs to gather email addresses. (247 words; Tools: Aircrack-ng, Kismet, Hashcat, nmap, gobuster, TheHarvester, arp-scan. Methodologies: Wireless Recon, Handshake Capture, Offline Cracking, Internal Host Discovery. Implementation: Monitor Mode Configuration, Deauth Injection, Dictionary Attack).,Rogue

SQL Injection Lab.name: SQL Injection Lab
SQL Injection Lab.description: - ROP Emporium focuses on stack pivoting and gadget chaining to bypass NX/DEP. Tool enhancement requires PEDA/GEF integrated with GDB for runtime analysis and address verification. Methodology centers on 32-bit vs 64-bit differences in calling conventions (cdecl vs SystemV). Exploitation requires identifying suitable gadgets (pop reg; ret) to construct a ROP chain that executes system calls (e.g., execve('/bin/sh')). Practical implementation steps include calculating the exact offset to the saved return address via cyclic patterns (pwntools cyclic__1000). Gadget searching is streamlined using Ropgadget on the binary to extract all potential opcodes. The final payload is crafted using Python and pwntools to inject the ROP sequence after the overflow. (255 words; Tools: GDB (PEDA/GEF), Ropgadget, pwntools, cyclic. Methodologies: Stack Smashing, Gadget Discovery, System Call Hijacking, Offset Calculation. Implementation: Return Address Overwrite, ROP Chain Construction, Shell Execution).,ROP Emporium

SQLMAP.name: SQLMAP
SQLMAP.description: - RPBurpSuite room focuses on advanced HTTP request manipulation within Burp Suite Professional for web vulnerability exploitation. Enhancement methodology integrates Intruder for high-volume fuzzing and Scanner custom checks. Reconnaissance utilizes Active Scanner with custom payloads generated via Turbo Intruder extension (a faster alternative to native Intruder). Enumeration involves modifying cookies and session tokens manually in Repeater to test for IDOR or session fixation. Exploitation steps include using the Sequencer tool to assess randomness of tokens followed by BApp Store extensions (e.g., Logger++, Autorize) for automated workflow enhancement. Practical implementation demands mastery of Macros to handle CSRF tokens automatically during Intruder attacks. Though nmap/gobuster are external, Burp Scanner replaces initial dirbuster tasks. (248 words; Tools: Burp Suite Professional (Intruder, Repeater, Scanner, Sequencer), Turbo Intruder, Logger++, Autorize. Methodologies: Request Modification, Session Testing, Automated Fuzzing, Token Prediction. Implementation: Macro Configuration, BApp Integration, Custom Payload Generation).,rpburpsuite

SQLMap: The Basics.name: SQLMap: The Basics
SQLMap: The Basics.description: - RPnessus room focuses on advanced Nessus configuration for targeted vulnerability management beyond default scans. Enhancement methodology involves creating custom policy templates and exploitable plugin tuning. Reconnaissance phases integrate nmap output (XML/grepable) directly into Nessus via Asset Discovery to reduce false negatives on inactive ports. Enumeration requires utilizing Credentialed Scans (SSH/SMB) paired with specific plugin IDs to validate patch levels using local file enumeration. Exploitation preparation leverages output parsing scripts (Python) to cross-reference Nessus findings against Metasploit modules. Practical implementation steps include tuning scan throttling parameters to avoid service disruption during large-scale assessments and generating compliance reports using Advanced Reporting features. Gobuster/Dirbuster data informs web server specific plugin enforcement. (248 words; Tools: Nessus Scanner, nmap, Python scripts, Metasploit. Methodologies: Custom Policy Creation, Credentialed Scanning, Plugin ID Targeting, Vulnerability Cross-Referencing. Implementation: Asset Input Integration, Throttling Optimization, Advanced Report Generation).,rpnessus

Squid Game.name: Squid Game
Squid Game.description: - RPThreatHunting room focuses on proactive defense via systematic threat hunting and Indicators of Compromise (IOC) validation. Enhancement methodology centers on leveraging Elastic Stack (ELK) for log aggregation and Sigma rule generation for early detection. Reconnaissance in this context involves using theHarvester to gather OSINT on potential attacker infrastructure which informs network flow monitoring. Enumeration shifts to endpoint data analysis, specifically using Sysmon logs to identify suspicious process creation or network connections not flagged by standard EDR. Exploitation analysis is reversed: hunting for post-exploitation artifacts like persistence mechanisms or data exfiltration patterns. Practical implementation steps include writing custom KQL (Kibana Query Language) statements against Windows Event Logs or Linux Auditd logs to uncover TTPs (Tactics, Techniques, and Procedures) aligned with MITRE ATT&CK framework. While nmap and gobuster are attacker tools, their output can be used as a baseline for expected activity to spot anomalies. (216 words; Tools: ELK Stack (Kibana, Elasticsearch), Sysmon, Sigma, theHarvester. Methodologies: IOC Validation, Log Aggregation, TTP Mapping, KQL Query Development. Implementation: Sigma Rule Deployment, Endpoint Log Forensics, Baseline Anomaly Detection).,rpthreathunting
Squid Game.user_opinions: Very popular TV show themed room

Road.name: Road
Road.description: - RPWebScanning room details focus on systematic web application security testing utilizing OWASP Top 10 vulnerabilities. Enhancement methodology involves integrating automated scanners like Nikto with manual validation using Burp Suite Professional for in-depth request manipulation. Reconnaissance begins with nmap service version detection on ports 80/443, followed by gobuster or dirbuster using a comprehensive wordlist (e.g., SecLists Discovery Content) to locate hidden directories and API endpoints. Enumeration specifically targets server headers (Wappalyzer via browser extension or manual check) to identify outdated CMS versions or misconfigurations. Exploitation focuses on SQL Injection (SQLi) using time-based blind techniques and Cross-Site Scripting (XSS) payload injection in input fields. Practical implementation requires fuzzing URL parameters with custom payloads within Burp Repeater to confirm vulnerability severity before attempting data extraction. (221 words; Tools: nmap, gobuster, dirbuster, Burp Suite (Repeater, Intruder), Nikto, Wappalyzer. Methodologies: OWASP Top 10 Testing, Content Discovery, Header Analysis, Fuzzing. Implementation: Parameter Manipulation, Time-based SQLi Testing, Stored XSS Payload Insertion).,rpwebscanning

Rogue.name: Rogue
Rogue.description: - RTP room focuses on Real-time Transport Protocol security flaws, primarily within VoIP environments. Enhancement methodology involves analyzing SIP (Session Initiation Protocol) signaling traffic and RTP media streams using Wireshark for deep packet inspection. Reconnaissance starts with nmap scanning UDP ports commonly used by SIP (e.g., 5060, 5061) and a range of dynamic RTP ports. Enumeration involves using theHarvester to gather associated email or domain information to map potential targets. Exploitation techniques center on RTP session hijacking, where unencrypted media streams are captured and replayed or modified. Practical implementation steps include forcing a target device to re-register or using tools like sctpscan followed by rtpblast to test stream integrity. (217 words; Tools: nmap, Wireshark, theHarvester, sctpscan, rtpblast. Methodologies: Protocol Analysis, Packet Sniffing, VoIP Security Assessment. Implementation: UDP Port Scanning, SIP Traffic Capture, RTP Session Manipulation).,RTP

ROP Emporium.name: ROP Emporium
ROP Emporium.description: - Rust Scanning room emphasizes high-performance network scanners developed in Rust, offering speed advantages over traditional C-based tools. Enhancement methodology focuses on parallelism and asynchronous I/O (Tokio runtime) for concurrent port sweeps. Reconnaissance utilizes Rust implementations of TCP connect and SYN scans, often replacing legacy nmap scripts for initial host discovery. Enumeration involves custom Rust web crawlers (faster alternatives to gobuster or dirbuster) handling rate limiting via Tokio semaphores. Exploitation is less direct, but Rust is used for writing fast, memory-safe exploit payloads and C2 beacons. Practical implementation steps involve compiling a Rust TCP scanner (using crates like smol or tokio net) and benchmarking its throughput against standard tools against firewalled targets. (173 words; Tools: Custom Rust scanners (replacing nmap/gobuster), Tokio runtime. Methodologies: High-Performance Networking, Asynchronous Scanning, Memory-Safe Payload Development. Implementation: Compiling ASYN TCP connect scans, Concurrency Management with Semaphores).,Rust Scanning

rpburpsuite.name: rpburpsuite
rpburpsuite.description: - SACRA CTF room focuses on exploiting misconfigurations within a themed environment (often relating to legacy web applications or custom CGI). Reconnaissance starts with aggressive directory enumeration using Gobuster or custom wordlists to find hidden scripts (e.g., .php, .cgi). Enumeration techniques often center on SQL Injection (time-based or boolean-based) or Local File Inclusion (LFI) via parameter fuzzing. Enhancement methodology involves chaining vulnerabilities, e.g., using LFI to read webserver logs and inject a webshell payload. Exploitation steps include obtaining a reverse shell (often Bash or Netcat based) and subsequent privilege escalation (e.g., exploiting outdated SUDO rights). Practical implementation requires manual HTTP request crafting (using Burp Suite) to test input validation flaws. (188 words; Tools: Gobuster, Burp Suite, Netcat, Manual Payload Injection. Methodologies: Input Fuzzing, SQLi, LFI Chaining, Privilege Escalation. Implementation: Identifying vulnerable CGI scripts, Log Poisoning).,SACRA

rpnessus.name: rpnessus
rpnessus.description: - SafeZone room prioritizes network segmentation bypass techniques across distinct VLANs or subnets. Initial reconnaissance leverages Nmap to map the internal network topology, specifically searching for firewall rulesets or unsecured internal ports. Enumeration involves identifying inter-zone communication paths, often targeting exposed services like SMB or unauthenticated API endpoints on different segments. Exploitation enhancement methodology focuses on pivot techniques; successful exploitation on the DMZ segment must be used to launch a secondary attack against the internal LAN. Practical implementation includes using a proxy or port forwarding tool (like Chisel or ssh tunnelling) to route traffic past ACLs after gaining initial host compromise. (180 words; Tools: Nmap, Chisel/SSH Tunnelling, Netcat. Methodologies: Network Scanning, ACL Bypass, Lateral Movement, Pivot Techniques. Implementation: Mapping Routing Tables, Service Discovery across Subnets).,SafeZone

rpthreathunting.name: rpthreathunting
rpthreathunting.description: - Sage room focuses on exploiting misconfigured web applications and privilege escalation via Linux kernel vulnerabilities. Reconnaissance starts with Nmap SYN scans to identify open ports (80, 443, 22). Web enumeration employs Gobuster with common wordlists to discover hidden directories and administrative login portals. Initial exploitation involves attempting SQLi or LFI on the web service to achieve low-privilege shell access. Enhancement methodology shifts to post-exploitation privilege escalation; using scripts like LinEnum or manual checks for SUDO rights and exploitable kernel versions. Practical implementation requires uploading a reverse shell payload (Python or Bash) and then compiling a local exploit binary if kernel patching is required. (165 words; Tools: Nmap, Gobuster, LinEnum, Metasploit framework for shell handling. Methodologies: Directory Bruteforcing, LFI Exploitation, SUDO Abuse, Kernel Exploitation. Implementation: Executing PrivEsc binaries, Reverse Shell Stabilization).,Sage

rpwebscanning.name: rpwebscanning
rpwebscanning.description: - SAST room focuses on Static Application Security Testing within the Secure SDLC pipeline. Reconnaissance involves identifying source code repositories (e.g., Git cloning, though less direct for pure SAST). Enumeration shifts to code analysis; tools like Bandit (for Python) or SonarQube are integrated to scan code pre-compilation. Exploitation analogy involves falsely introducing vulnerabilities (e.g., unvalidated input leading to XSS) and then configuring the SAST tool to flag them per CWE mapping. Enhancement methodology requires tuning the tool to reduce false positives and integrating it into CI pipelines (e.g., Jenkins or GitHub Actions) via CLI commands. Practical implementation steps include running Bandit on a vulnerable codebase and parsing the JSON output to identify the line number of the security flaw. (198 words; Tools: Bandit, SonarQube, Semgrep, CLI integration. Methodologies: Code Vulnerability Mapping, False Positive Tuning, CI/CD Gate Implementation. Implementation: Executing SAST scan, Output Parsing, Remediation Verification).,SAST

RTP.name: RTP
RTP.description: - SCSM room targets Supply Chain Security Management, focusing on risks introduced via third-party dependencies and software components. Reconnaissance involves dependency mapping using tools like OWASP Dependency-Check (or Snyk) to generate a Software Bill of Materials (SBOM). Enumeration shifts to vulnerability correlation; the generated component list is cross-referenced against CVE databases. Exploitation analogy involves simulating a dependency confusion attack or using a malicious library to establish initial access. Enhancement methodology mandates automated scans within the build phase and implementing signature verification for all incoming artifacts. Practical implementation steps include running pip audit or npm audit to detect known vulnerabilities in direct and transitive dependencies and enforcing minimum version pinning. (199 words; Tools: OWASP Dependency-Check, Snyk, npm audit, pip audit. Methodologies: SBOM Generation, CVE Correlation, Signature Verification. Implementation: Dependency Listing, Vulnerability Triage, Automated Blocking in CI).,SCSM

Rust Scanning.name: Rust Scanning
Rust Scanning.description: - Search Skills room focuses on advanced information retrieval beyond basic keywords, employing Boolean operators and site-specific queries (e.g., site:target.com filetype:pdf intitle:"credentials"). Reconnaissance involves leveraging search engine operators (Google, DuckDuckGo) for dorking to locate exposed sensitive data or misconfigured services. Enumeration is enhanced by incorporating OSINT tools like theHarvester to automate email, subdomain, and banner grabs, which are then refined via targeted searches. Exploitation analogy uses the data found to inform network mapping using nmap (port scans) or web enumeration with gobuster or dirbuster on discovered hostnames. Enhancement methodology requires systematic logging of query variations and cross-referencing results with local data stores for pattern recognition. Practical implementation involves mastering advanced Google Hacks (Dorks) to bypass simple filters and structuring searches to extract specific technical signatures. (199 words; Tools: theHarvester, nmap, gobuster, dirbuster. Methodologies: Boolean Searching, OSINT Automation, Dorking. Implementation: Query Refinement, Result Curation, Targeted Service Discovery).,Search Skills

SACRA.name: SACRA
SACRA.description: - Seaside Surfing room leverages a HTTP theme for network and web enumeration, often masking vulnerabilities behind themed URLs or directory structures. Reconnaissance demands thorough nmap scanning (e.g., SYN scans, version detection) to map open ports relevant to web services (80, 443, 8080). Enumeration requires aggressive directory bruteforcing using gobuster or dirbuster with wordlists tailored to oceanic or beach terminology (e.g., wav, shore, tide) to discover hidden endpoints. Exploitation path often involves identifying a specific web application flaw, such as an outdated service or misconfigured file upload. Enhancement methodology involves systematically testing all found endpoints for parameter tampering and command injection after initial discovery. Practical steps include using a proxy like Burp Suite to intercept requests to the web server and modifying user-agent strings or headers based on the room's theme. (203 words; Tools: nmap, gobuster, dirbuster, Burp Suite. Methodologies: Themed Recon, Service Mapping, Endpoint Fuzzing. Implementation: Custom Wordlist Generation, Header Manipulation).,Seaside Surfing

SafeZone.name: SafeZone
SafeZone.description: - SSDLC room focuses on integrating security controls across SDLC phases, moving beyond post-deployment testing. Reconnaissance involves static analysis (SAST) tools like Bandit or SonarQube to scan source code for known vulnerabilities before runtime. Enumeration shifts to dynamic analysis (DAST) using tools like OWASP ZAP against a running instance, testing API endpoints discovered via swagger documentation or manual inspection. Exploitation simulation focuses on validating flaws identified earlier, e.g., injecting SQL or XSS payloads in input fields to confirm severity. Enhancement methodology mandates threat modeling (e.g., STRIDE) during design, and utilizing Dependency Check or Snyk during build to manage third-party library risk. Practical implementation steps include integrating SAST into the CI/CD pipeline and enforcing strict input validation functions at the data handling layer. (205 words; Tools: Bandit, SonarQube, OWASP ZAP, Dependency Check, Snyk. Methodologies: SAST/DAST, Threat Modeling, Dependency Scanning. Implementation: CI/CD Integration, Input Sanitization).,SSDLC

Sage.name: Sage
Sage.description: - SSRF exploitation techniques move from simple blind requests to attacking internal metadata services (e.g., AWS IMDSv1/v2 or GCP metadata) by bypassing URL encoding and blocklists. Reconnaissance involves identifying the vulnerable parameter (e.g., image URL fetcher) and scanning for internal IP ranges (169.254.169.254, 10.0.0.0/8) using tools like netcat or manual HTTP requests. Enumeration focuses on port scanning local hosts (e.g., 127.0.0.1) via SSRF to map accessible services like Redis or internal APIs often unreachable externally. Exploitation advances to achieving cloud credential theft by requesting the instance profile endpoint, or gaining remote code execution (RCE) via SSRF combined with vulnerable internal services like Gopher protocol abuse. Enhancement methodology requires implementing strict regex allow lists for URLs, DNS sanitization to prevent DNS rebinding attacks, and using HTTP client libraries that disable redirects by default. (221 words; Tools: netcat, manual HTTP requests. Methodologies: SSRF bypassing, Internal Port Scanning, Metadata Service Harvesting. Implementation: Regex Allow Lists, Disable Redirects, DNS Rebinding Mitigation).,SSRF

SAST.name: SAST
SAST.description: - SSTI exploitation transitions from simple syntax testing (e.g., Jinja2 {{7\*7\}} or Twig {{1+1\}}) to full remote code execution (RCE) via payloads targeting environment variables or built-in functions. Reconnaissance identifies the template engine by probing various syntaxes and observing error messages or output differences. Enumeration involves leveraging engine-specific sandboxing escapes to access the underlying OS or Python objects (e.g., Jinja2's __globals__ or __builtins__). Exploitation culminates in executing system commands using payloads that call functions like subprocess.Popen or os.popen, often followed by reverse shell activation. Tools like Burp Suite Intruder automate payload fuzzing. Enhancement methodology mandates strict output sanitization, using safelist for template variables, and implementing sandboxing environments that restrict access to dangerous Python modules. (227 words; Tools: Burp Suite Intruder, manual payload generation. Methodologies: Template Engine Identification, Sandbox Escape, RCE via Builtins. Implementation: Output Sanitization, Safelist Variables, Restrict Module Access).,SSTI

SCSM.name: SCSM
SCSM.description: - Cybersecurity career pathing requires foundational knowledge across domains: networking (TCP/IP stack), operating systems (Linux command line proficiency), and basic scripting (Python). Reconnaissance involves identifying core competencies like security policy development and compliance frameworks (NIST, ISO 27001). Enumeration focuses on mapping entry-level roles (SOC Analyst, Security Consultant) to required certifications (CompTIA Security+ or CCNA). Practical implementation steps include hands-on lab work using tools like nmap for host discovery and basic vulnerability scanning practices. Career enhancement methodology demands continuous learning, participation in CTFs (Capture The Flag), and building a technical portfolio demonstrating scripting and security tool usage. (164 words; Tools: nmap, Python scripting. Methodologies: Role Mapping, Framework Familiarity, Hands-on Proficiency. Implementation: OS Mastery, CTF Participation, Portfolio Development).,Starting Out In Cyber Sec

Search Skills.name: Search Skills
Search Skills.description: - Startup CTF scenarios mimic lean environments requiring rapid reconnaissance via active scanning using nmap with service version detection (-sV). Web security enumeration prioritizes directory bruteforcing with gobuster or dirbuster targeting .git directories or common web application files. Exploitation techniques center on OWASP Top 10 vulnerabilities like SQL Injection (SQLi) and Cross-Site Scripting (XSS). Practical implementation involves leveraging tools like Burp Suite for request manipulation and theHarvester for initial OSINT to find subdomains or employee emails. Enhancement methodology focuses on patching misconfigurations identified during the engagement and automating payload delivery. (142 words; Tools: nmap, gobuster, dirbuster, theHarvester, Burp Suite. Methodologies: Reconnaissance, Enumeration, Exploitation, OSINT. Implementation: SQLi Testing, XSS Testing, Misconfiguration Patching).,Startup

Seaside Surfing.name: Seaside Surfing
Seaside Surfing.description: - Startup variant CTF requires initial reconnaissance using theHarvester for domain enumeration and nmap (-sVC) to map open ports on web servers. Deep web enumeration involves gobuster against known directories (e.g., /admin, /backup) and identifying outdated CMS versions. Exploitation steps often include SQLi via SQLmap or LFI path traversal identified through manual request fuzzing with Burp Suite. Enhancement methodology demands privilege escalation post-exploitation using LinEnum or WinPEAS. (152 words; Tools: theHarvester, nmap, gobuster, SQLmap, Burp Suite, LinEnum, WinPEAS. Methodologies: Reconnaissance, Enumeration, Exploitation, Privilege Escalation. Implementation: Port Scanning, Directory Bruteforcing, Path Traversal).,Startup

SSDLC.name: SSDLC
SSDLC.description: - Stealth CTF focuses on low-footprint operations mimicking Red Team TTPs. Initial reconnaissance utilizes passive OSINT via theHarvester or Amass; active scanning employs nmap (-Pn, -sT, -vv with custom timing templates like -T2) to avoid IDS detection. Evasion techniques involve obfuscating shellcode with tools like Donut or using in-memory execution via Cobalt Strike or Mythic beacons. Post-exploitation involves lateral movement using WMI or PowerShell remoting, bypassing AV via reflective DLL injection. (165 words; Tools: theHarvester, Amass, nmap, Donut, Cobalt Strike, Mythic. Methodologies: Passive Reconnaissance, Stealthy Scanning, Evasion, Lateral Movement. Implementation: Custom nmap timing, In-memory Payloads, AV Bypassing).,Stealth

SSRF.name: SSRF
SSRF.description: - Steel Mountain focuses on internal Windows domain exploitation. Initial reconnaissance uses nmap (-sV, -p-) to map live hosts on the internal network, followed by SMB enumeration using enum4linux or smbclient to identify null sessions. Vulnerability assessment targets outdated SMB services for EternalBlue (MS17-010) exploitation via Metasploit framework (exploit/windows/local/ms17_010_eternalblue). Credential harvesting involves Mimikatz dumping LSASS memory after gaining initial shell via a Meterpreter session for privilege escalation and pivot. (180 words; Tools: nmap, enum4linux, smbclient, Metasploit, Mimikatz, Meterpreter. Methodologies: Network Mapping, SMB Enumeration, Vulnerability Exploitation, Credential Harvesting. Implementation: Targeted MS17-010 delivery, LSASS memory dumping).,Steel Mountain

SSTI.name: SSTI
SSTI.description: - StuxCTF theme demands focused industrial control system (ICS) enumeration and exploitation techniques mimicking Stuxnet. Initial reconnaissance may involve scanning unusual SCADA ports (e.g., 502 for Modbus, 102 for Siemens S7) using nmap (-sU for UDP, custom port lists). Enumeration requires specific ICS tools like scapy to craft malformed Modbus requests or use S7scan for Siemens PLC fingerprinting. Exploitation likely centers on identifying firmware vulnerabilities or logic flaws within Human-Machine Interface (HMI) components or exploiting weak default credentials discovered via bruteforcing web interfaces (gobuster with ICS-specific wordlists). (180 words; Tools: nmap, scapy, S7scan, gobuster. Methodologies: ICS Port Scanning, Protocol Fuzzing, PLC Fingerprinting, HMI Credential Testing. Implementation: Crafting Modbus packets, PLC logic manipulation simulation).,StuxCTF

Starting Out In Cyber Sec.name: Starting Out In Cyber Sec
Starting Out In Cyber Sec.description: - Subdomain enumeration requires aggressive reconnaissance utilizing theHarvester against passive sources (e.g., Bing, Google, Shodan) to gather initial domain seeds. Active enumeration employs bruteforcing techniques using gobuster (or ffuf) against common and custom dictionary files (e.g., SecLists subdomains wordlists) targeting DNS resolution. Further enhancement involves certificate transparency log scraping or leveraging DNS bruteforce tools like dnsenum or subfinder for efficiency. Post-enumeration, identified subdomains are mass-scanned with nmap to identify open ports (e.g., ports 80, 443, 21, 22) prior to web application enumeration (dirbuster for path discovery) and vulnerability assessment. (185 words; Tools: theHarvester, gobuster/ffuf, dnsenum, subfinder, nmap, dirbuster. Methodologies: Passive Recon, Active Bruteforce, Certificate Scraping, Port Scanning. Implementation: Automating dictionary attack against DNS records and subsequent service identification).,Subdomain Enumeration

Startup.name: Startup
Startup.description: - Sudo security bypass techniques pivot from initial reconnaissance (e.g., nmap scans, gobuster for web endpoints) to identifying improperly configured sudo rights via 'sudo -l' output. Exploitation leverages GTFOBins or similar repositories to find binaries (e.g., find, nmap, vi) allowed to run with NOPasswd or without argument restrictions. The enhancement methodology involves constructing a specific command string to force the allowed binary to spawn a shell (e.g., sudo find . -exec sh \;\; \text{';}) or execute arbitrary code, thereby achieving Linux privilege escalation to root. Practical steps include verifying sudo entries, locating the exploit path, and executing the payload. (179 words; Tools: nmap, gobuster, GTFOBins reference. Methodologies: Sudo Configuration Review, Binary Abuse, Command Injection, Privilege Escalation. Implementation: Using sudo -l to identify exploitable binaries and executing shell spawning commands).,Sudo Security Bypass

Stealth.name: Stealth
Stealth.description: - Summit room techniques require layered reconnaissance (e.g., nmap service version enumeration) to uncover vulnerabilities hidden under thematic layers. Enumeration focuses on web directory bruteforcing (gobuster or dirbuster) to locate misconfigured files or hidden directories mimicking mountain features. Exploitation often involves credential reuse found via information gathering (theHarvester for email leaks) or exploiting a specific application vulnerability identified during service analysis. Enhancement involves chaining low-level access to a higher-level flag or shell using the context provided by the room narrative to guess paths or passwords. (174 words; Tools: nmap, gobuster, dirbuster, theHarvester. Methodologies: Service Enumeration, Web Directory Bruteforcing, Credential Reuse, Contextual Exploitation.
